<answer>



Well if it's yummy who the hell cares if it's falling apart on the way in lol.



You have plenty of time to experiment so I would start making 1/2 or 1/4 batches and try adding more egg, more liquid and more flour. One of those 3 options should work, hard to tell since you didn't mention it being overly dry or moist, i'd start with the egg first since thats the number 1 binding ingredient in most recipies.

<answer>



Depending on how nice your butcher is or what they normally have available you can sometimes find turkey breasts. If not then ground turkey is readily available in most stores. I would make a traditional thanksgiving meal just mini sized, you can put turkey breast on top of some stuffing in a casserole dish and bake it, make some mashed potatoes and yams or squash. Or you could make a turkey pot pie or sheppards pie, somthing hearty and homey feeling that you can make in smaller ammounts.



</answer>

<answer>



Hey Brown_ey, no it's not, your wrong there, if you go to the more larger grocery stores. Check out the meat and poultry section. Here in Montreal we can get quarter and half turkeys. So if you want turkey have a look around.



For a meal idea i would open with a Prosciutto and Melon, a slice or two of the Italian Parma Prosciutto wrapped around the center of a quarter cantaloupe.



If you can't get the turkey, do a duck, really there is not to much on a young duck, and the sauce you can do with the pan juices, bit of chicken stock and the squeeze of a orange is fantastic.



Besides your standard veggies, you could do a tossed salad with a nice vinaigrette. Desert you have the traditional thanksgiving stuff, or you could be inspirational and use your imagination there.



You need more specifics contact me here at Yahoo Answers and I will fill you in on the details, however you sound like someone that does not get lost around a kitchen.



Chris

<question>



How to roast chicken in a microwave?



it is my first time to use a microwave oven.want to know how to roast whole chicken in it... what to use as ingredient, which pan to use, what to avoid to use. the store told us not to use wax paper or foil... pls help!!!



</question>



<answer from>



A W
Member since: 17 November 2006
Total points: 694 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



aren't you supposed to cook a chicken in a conventional or fan forced oven? not a microwave oven



</answer>



<answer from>



Well Hello ♥
Member since: 28 February 2008
Total points: 4026 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



you cannot use any sort of metal in the microwave , it will spark and ignite



you cant roast a chicken in the microwave , it will cokk ye, but come out white and soggy.  use a fan forced oven for best results



</answer>



<answer from>



Sarah
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 1407 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



do not EVER put a whole uncracked egg in the microwave.  it will explode.  also, cauliflower will spark up, as will carrots.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sugar Pie
Member since: 18 March 2006
Total points: 70482 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



No foil or any metal in the m/w!!!



You cannot roast in the m/w; only "cook."  Your chicken will not end up browned and caramelized.  You need a regular oven for that.



Perfect Roast Chicken



1 (5 to 6 pound) roasting chicken



Kosher salt



Freshly ground black pepper



1 large bunch fresh thyme, plus 20 sprigs



1 lemon, halved



1 head garlic, cut in half crosswise



2 tablespoons (1/4 stick) butter, melted



1 large yellow onion, thickly sliced



4 carrots cut into 2-inch chunks



1 bulb of fennel, tops removed, and cut into wedges (optional)
Olive oil



Preheat the oven to 425 degrees F.



Remove the chicken giblets. Rinse the chicken inside and out. Remove any excess fat and leftover pin feathers and pat the outside dry. Liberally salt and pepper the inside of the chicken. Stuff the cavity with the bunch of thyme, both halves of lemon, and all the garlic. Brush the outside of the chicken with the butter and sprinkle again with salt and pepper. Tie the legs together with kitchen string and tuck the wing tips under the body of the chicken. Place the onions, carrots, and fennel in a roasting pan. Toss with salt, pepper, 20 sprigs of thyme, and olive oil. Spread around the bottom of the roasting pan and place the chicken on top.



Roast the chicken for 1 1/2 hours, or until the juices run clear when you cut between a leg and thigh. Remove the chicken and vegetables to a platter and cover with aluminum foil for about 20 minutes. Slice the chicken onto a platter and serve it with the vegetables.



--Ina Garten



</answer>

<question>



When baking cakes, they tend to rise in the middle and then crack along the top.?



Does anyone know why this is and how can I stop it?!  I have to slice the top of the cake off to make it level - it don't look attractive!!  Thanks in advance.



</question>



<answer from>



L T
Member since: 31 December 2005
Total points: 870 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be uneven heating, try a slightly lower temp.



Or just very gently turn the cake upside down before you frost it



</answer>



<answer from>



wiltin' daisies
Member since: 21 January 2008
Total points: 10101 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Too much moisture, too much heat too soon, and don't open the oven to "check" on the cake before it's done.



Source(s):



Trial and error.



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 7158 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Put a pan of water in the bottom of the oven while your baking the cake. It will keep the cake from cracking. I'm not sure if it will help with the rising. Most professional cake decorators cut the top of the cake off since there's not really any way around it.



</answer>

<answer>



You are putting too many wet ingredients into your cake. You need to put more flower. Also it sounds like your oven might be a little too high.



</answer>



<answer from>



nanof2su...
Member since: 13 December 2007
Total points: 1731 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The oven is set too high, the cake mix hardens on top to fast and the the inside is like a volcano still trying to expand and so it cracks the surface, lower the heat slightly especially if you have a fan assisted oven.



</answer>

<answer>



When spreading batter in the pan, spread it thicker on the sides, and thinner in the middle.  It should even out some.  Cake mixes are bad about doming like this; yo may try a scratch cake, too.

<answer>



Simpliest chocolate brownie



Quantity Ingredients



225g (8oz)  soft margarine



100g (3.5oz) walnut pieces



110g (4oz)  plain chocolate



170g (6oz) plain flour



400g (14oz)  caster sugar



4 eggs



2.5ml  salt



10ml vanilla essence



2.5ml baking powder



100g (3.5oz) chocolate chip



Method
1. melt the margarine and chocolate together.
2. remove heat add sugar mix well
3. add the vannilla eggs and chocolate chips
4. sift the baking powder with flour and salt
5. fold the flour into the chocolate mixture
6. pour into lightly greased 23cm square or circle pan
7 .bake at 160c for fifty minutes
8. remove from oven and leave to cool for 12 hours



Personally I prefer using brown chocolate, for a strong chocolatey taste just add more chocolate



I know 15 brownie recipes :)



</answer>

Sugar Pie

Cooking & Recipes

<answer>



This recipe has more chocolate than flour!



Outrageous Brownies



1 pound unsalted butter



1 pound plus 12 ounces semisweet chocolate chips, divided



6 ounces unsweetened chocolate



6 extra-large eggs



3 tablespoons instant coffee powder



2 tablespoons real vanilla extract



2 1/4 cups sugar



1 1/4 cups all-purpose flour, divided (1 cup for batter and 1/4 cup in the chips and nuts)



1 tablespoon baking powder



1 teaspoon kosher salt



3 cups diced walnut pieces



Preheat oven to 350º F. Grease and flour a 13x18x 1½” sheet pan.



Melt together the butter, 1 pound chocolate chips, and unsweetened chocolate on top of a double boiler. Cool slightly. Stir together the eggs, instant coffee, vanilla and sugar. Stir in the warm chocolate mixture and cool to room temperature.



Stir together 1 cup of the flour, baking powder and salt. Add to cooled chocolate mixture. Toss the walnuts and 12 ounces of chocolate chips with 1/4 cup flour to coat. Then add to the chocolate batter. Pour into prepared pan.



Bake for about 30 minutes, or until tester just comes out clean. Halfway through the baking, rap the pan against the oven shelf to allow air to escape from between the pan and the brownie dough. Do not over-bake! Cool thoroughly, refrigerate well and cut into squares.



--Ina Garten



</answer>

<question>



NEeD A EASY SPONE CAKE RECIPE!?



well i need a sponge cake recipe thats:
. easy
. non ingredient consuming
. if dont take too much ingriedients i would like it with a wettish texture



NOTE:i dont mind if you dont have all the preferabilities above i just want a easy tasty sponge cake recipe and explain it precisely plz



thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Miss Expert
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 1203 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have some easy recipes for you.



Sponge Cake One



Ingredients
500g sugar
120g flour
10 egg yolks
10 egg whites (beaten)
1 teaspoon lemon extract
3 teaspoons baking powder (optional)



Action
a. Stir egg yolks and sugar till perfectly light.
b. Beat egg whites lightly with the flour.
c. Add lemon extract, and baking powder into the flour.
d. Bake in preheated 180°C oven for about 15 minutes.



Sponge Cake Two



Ingredients
800g sugar
12 eggs
340g flour



Action
a. Set a deep bowl in a pan of iced water.
b. Place the eggs and sugar together in the bowl.
c. Beat the mixture rapidly for 30 minutes.
d. Lightly stir in the flour .
e. Bake in preheated 200°C oven for 5 minutes, and
another 15 minutes on 180°C oven.



Note: This batter can also be used for lady-fingers and jelly rolls.



Sponge Cake Three



Ingredients
1 teaspoon granulated sugar
240g flour
1/4 teaspoon salt
60g butter
3 eggs
1 teaspoon baking powder
Some coconut flakes and jam



Action
a. Whisk the eggs to a cream in a large mixing bowl.
b. Whisk butter, sugar and salt with the eggs for 5 minutes.
c. Stir in the flour and baking powder gradually.
d. Grease 2 cake tins, put in each a thin layer of the mixture
and bake for 15 minutes in a preheated 180°C oven.
e. When the cakes are nicely set, remove from the tins,
place them on a sieve to cool.
f. Spread the jam and press together the cakes.
g. Scatter the coconut over the top.
h. Cut up into fingers and diamond shapes.



Try them?



Source(s):



http://www.allcookmakeeasy.com/strawberr...



</answer>



<asker's comment>

<answer from>



Rebecca
Member since: 21 May 2008
Total points: 208 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



ngredients (serves 6)



* 1/3 cup (50g) cornflour



* 1/3 cup (50g) plain flour



* 1/3 cup (50g) self-raising flour



* 4 x 60g eggs, at room temperature



* 2/3 cup (150g) caster sugar



Method



1. Grease 2 x deep, 20cm round cake tins (or different tins, as directed in individual recipes) and line bases with baking paper. Sift flours and 1/4 tsp salt together three times to aerate.



2. Preheat oven to 180C. Using an electric mixer, beat eggs and sugar in a large bowl on medium-high speed for 6 minutes, or until mixture is thick, pale and tripled in volume.



3. Gradually sift flour mixture over egg mixture while simultaneously folding in with a large metal spoon until just combined. Divide mixture between prepared tins. To level batter, gently spin tins on kitchen counter. Bake for 20 minutes (or as directed in individual recipes), or until cakes have shrunk away from the sides slightly and spring back when gently touched.



4. Turn out on to baking paper-lined wire racks. Carefully peel away baking paper, then leave to cool.



</answer>



<answer from>



melissa
Member since: 11 August 2007
Total points: 5540 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



2 eggs



1 cup flour



1 teaspoon baking powder



1 cup sugar



1/2 cup milk



2 tablespoons of butter



1) allow eggs to stand at room temperature for 30 min's. grease a 9X9X2 pan



2) stir together flour and baking powder



3) beat eggs until thick slowly add sugar beating on medium speed until mixture is light and fluffy
4) add flour mixture beat on low until combined.



5) heat butter and milk until the butter melts. add to batter and beat until combined.
6) bake 350* for 20-25 mins.



</answer>

Bratt

</answer from>



<answer>



Make a deviled egg. Just put the egg in a pot of cold water and put in some salt and put on high until it comes to a boil. When it starts boiling turn it down just a little so that it is still boiling but not bouncing around in the pot. Let it boil for 5 or 6 minutes then remove from heat. Run cold water in the pot and let the egg cool to the point where you can pick it up. Peel the egg cut it in half and remove the yolk to another container. Put a teaspoon of mayonnaise in the yolk and some salt and pepper and, whatever other seasoning you might like and mix it well. Put the mixture back into the halved egg and enjoy!



</answer>



<answer from>



Hari
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 5906 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Egg,fine cut green Chili & onion mix it ,put salt to taste & cook it on fry pan with little oil.Some people add tomato also



</answer>

<question from>



Angel

<question>



How do you make a raspberry coulis?



I know you use caster sugar but just don't know how long to boil the raspberries for etc??!!!!



</question>



<answer from>



guitar virgin
Member since: 27 April 2008
Total points: 3654 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't have to cook the rasberries at all.  Just mix them with the sugar and push them through a fine sieve.



Some recipes do require you to cook the rasberries and the time of cooking varies from recipe to recipe from between a few minutes and fifteen minutes.  If you choose to cook them allow the consistency (thickness) of the coulis to be your guide as to how long to cook them for.



Source(s):



Over thirty years a chef, head chef and chef patissier.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hari
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 5906 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients
2 1/2 cups fresh raspberries



1/4 cup sugar



1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice, or to taste



1 pint chocolate sorbet



Fresh raspberries, for garnish



Directions
Puree raspberries with sugar and lemon juice in a blender or food processor. Pour mixture through a fine sieve into a bowl, pressing on solids.



Scoop sorbet into individual serving bowls and top with coulis. Garnish with a few fresh raspberries.



Coulis keeps 3 days, covered and chilled.



</answer>



<answer from>



caroline ♥
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 32591 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Glasgow



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients:



300g fresh (or frozen) raspberries
juice of 1 lime (or lemon)
1 tbsp icing sugar (plus extra to taste, if desired) Method:



Add the raspberries and the lime juice to a saucepan and slowly heat. Sprinkle the sugar on top and stir to dissolve. Bring the mixture to a simmer, mashing the fruit with the back of a spoon.



Take off the heat and pour into a sieve. Push the fruit through, collecting the liquid. Discard the pulp then taste then taste the liquid and adjust the sugar, if needed. Remember, however, that a coulis should be tart, to contrast with the generally sweet confection it's served with.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sugar Pie
Member since: 18 March 2006
Total points: 70490 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



RASPBERRY SAUCE
2 quarts raspberries - fresh or frozen, thawed
1 cup sugar (or more to taste)
3 Tablespoons corn starch



Place the raspberries and sugar into a large saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring often, until the mixture boils. Place the cornstarch into a small bowl. Slowly stir juice from the raspberry/sugar mixture into the cornstarch until a smooth consistency is achieved. Slowly pour the cornstarch mix into the raspberry mixture stirring constantly. Keep stirring until the mixture thickens slightly. Remove from heat. Serve warm or cold.  Coulis may be strained thru a sieve if seedless sauce is desired.



</answer>



<answer from>



Gemma F
Member since: 30 April 2008
Total points: 16039 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



All a coulis consists of is the juice from the fruit, sweetened as necessary, so for raspberry coulis you take a load of ripe raspberries, whizz them in a blender then strain through a fine sieve. Add icing sugar to the juice - and you may wish to add a drop of lemon juice to it although I can't think why! You chuck the pulp and seeds left in the strainer in the bin.
Why people make such a fuss - to the extent of making a major production number out of it - beats me ! ! !



</answer>

<question>



Please.  Why do so many recipes use bell peppers?  I am allergic to them.?



</question>



<answer from>



musicimp...
Member since: 12 December 2005
Total points: 15176 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I imagine the reason is that they are relatively cheap, nutritious, and available all year. They have a mild flavor that most people can appreciate for adding a slight kick to the food.



If you dont like them, you can always just leave them out. Substitute another kind of pepper. I can't think of any recipe that absolutely depends on them, except stuffed peppers. Even with that you could use a tomato.



</answer>

<question>



Is the soft baked pretzel a pastry?

<answer from>



Been There~Done That!
Member since: 23 May 2006
Total points: 108202 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Family



</answer from>



<answer>



A pretzel is a bread pastry of German origin, that has the shape of a three looped knot or twisted braid. Pretzels are either soft or hard. Hard pretzels have evolved into a variety of shapes from knotted loops to straight "pretzel sticks" (called "Salzstangen" in German, Ropi in Hungarian).



</answer>

<question from>



I &lt;33 Him
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 74 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why are certain foods served in the South?



please answer this with a type of food and why it is served in the South?



</question>



<answer from>



jomo1228...
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 592 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Traditionally Southern food came about mostly out of necessity. Some of the best foods were made from the cheapest ingredients. Mainly slaves and the poor ate these foods such as fried chicken, hoe cakes, scrapple, chittlin's, collard/turnip/mustard greens, etc. Sugar was a commodity and was usually replaced with molasses or not used at all ( which is why biscuits in the south aren't sweet like they are up north) With the onset of the Great Depression the culinary creativity in the South only intensified. From my own family history, recipes like Tomato Soup Cake and Supper on a Loaf, both recipes that use a smorgasbord of ingredients and are easily adaptable to whats on hand. In short, the true beauty of Southern cooking comes not from the ingredients but from the amazing flavor that our ancestors were able to put into the meager supply that they had. Flavors so good in fact that many thrive to this day.



Source(s):



I was born and raised in the South by Southerners
I have a couple recipes on my blog : getonthegravytrain.blogspot.com



</answer>



<asker's comment>



This explains and I asked this for a report for school and I posted the whole thing on the report to answer that question that I asked and you answered. I hope I pass this thing because that answer takes up half of my report thanks veryy mmuch for this specific answer.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



ariel_ok...
Member since: 12 September 2006
Total points: 8058 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Certain dishes are popular in certain regions based on the availability of items.  Therefore, those items were used to come up with dishes that are now commonly associated with those regions.



</answer>

<answer>



I think the most important thing with a chilli is to give the chilli powder time to soak into the dish.
I always add the powder to the meat/onions/kidney beans etc and cook very gently for at least 20 mins. This is what makes the difference between a chilli burning your lips as soon as its tasted or getting the slower nicer heat a minute or two after its first tasted.Its always best made a day in advance too as this allows all the flavours to blend into one another.
I usually use sieved or chopped tomatos, gravy granules and ketchup for my sauce.



Source(s):



Chef of 20 years



</answer>



<answer from>



caroline ♥
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 32621 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Glasgow



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients
500g (1Lb) Lean Minced Beef
250g (8oz) Skinned tomatoes
225g (8oz) Haricot or Red Kidney beans (soaked overnight)
50g (2oz) of Butter
2 Teaspoons Olive or Corn oil
2 Medium onions
2 Cloves of garlic
1 Medium sized green pepper
1 Level teaspoon Chilli powder
¼ Level teaspoon of salt
1 Level tablespoon of flour
4 Tablespoons fresh single cream
150ml (¼ pint) of Water



Method
(1) Drain the beans. Cook in boiling salted water until almost tender. Strain and keep on one side.



(2) Chop the onions and garlic finely. Fry gently in butter plus the oil, until golden (oil stops butter from burning). Add the meat and fry for a further 5 minutes (or until brown), breaking it up with a fork and turning it over all the time.



(3) Chop the skinned tomatoes and green pepper. Then add to the pan with kidney beans, chilli powder, salt and half the quantity of water. Cover and cook over a very low heat, for between 45 minutes to an hour (or until beans are soft), stirring occasionally.



(4) Combine the flour with the rest of the water and pour into the pan. Cook and stir until the mixture thickens.



(5) Remove from the heat and stir in the cream.



</answer>

Total points: 4079 (Level 4)

<answer>



2 cups all-purpose flour, stirred or sifted before measuring
2 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 egg, slightly beaten
1 1/2 cups milk



2 tablespoons melted butter



</answer>



<answer from>



leiishab...
Member since: 07 September 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes you can eat them the day after.  =]



here is the link..



http://www.taste.com.au/recipes/16348/tr...



& here is the recipe..



Preparation Time 15 - 45 minutes



Cooking Time 50 minutes



Makes 10



Ingredients



300g (2 cups) self-raising flour



Pinch of salt



500ml (2 cups) milk



2 eggs



60g butter, melted



Melted butter, extra, to grease



2 x 250g punnets strawberries,



washed, hulled, halved, to serve



Maple syrup, to serve



Maple syrup butter



120g butter, at room temperature



1 tbs maple syrup
Method
Sift the flour and salt into a large bowl. Make a well in the centre. Whisk together the milk and eggs in a large jug. Add the milk mixture to the flour mixture, whisking constantly until a smooth batter forms. Stir in the butter. Cover with plastic wrap and place in the fridge for 30 minutes to rest.



Meanwhile, to make the maple syrup butter, use an electric beater to beat the butter in a medium bowl until pale and creamy. Add the maple syrup and beat until well combined.



Heat a large non-stick frying pan over medium heat. Brush with the extra melted butter to lightly grease. Pour 80ml (1/3 cup) of the batter into the pan to form a 15cm-diameter pancake. Cook for 2-3 minutes or until bubbles appear on the surface and the pancake is golden underneath. Turn and cook for a further 1-2 minutes or until golden. Transfer to a plate and cover with a clean tea towel to keep warm. Repeat, in 9 more batches, with melted butter and remaining batter, reheating pan between batches, to make 10 pancakes.



Place pancakes on serving plates. Top with the maple syrup butter and strawberries. Drizzle over maple syrup to serve.



have fun.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sugar Pie
Member since: 18 March 2006
Total points: 70490 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



A nonstick griddle works best.  Ladle a small amount of batter onto griddle, stopping before it's the size you want the pancake as it will spread.  A godo tip is to try to keep the circle of batter not much bigger than your spatula.  Med. heat.  You will see bubbles rise to the top as it cooks.  When edges look sort of dry and many bubbles are popped, slip spatula under pancake and quickly flip.  (This may take a little practice, so don't give up.  If you sort of flip it off-center, you can wait a moment, then flip again to cook exposed batter.)  Cook a minute or so on other side, then remove to plate.  Top a stack fo 3-4 pancakes w/ soft butter and maple syrup.



As far as reheating the next day, allow pancakes to cool on wire rack.  When room temp, slip into zipper bag and freeze.  They can then be reheated in a toaster oven (best) or microwave (okay).



The Best Buttermilk Pancakes



1 cup Buttermilk**
1 egg, room temp
3 Tbsp butter, melted
¾ cup all purpose flour
½ tsp salt
1 tsp baking soda



Put the buttermilk, egg and melted butter in a mixing bowl. Stir briskly until the mixture is smooth and blended.
Stir the flour, salt and baking soda together in a small bowl. Stir into the buttermilk mixture only until the dry ingredients are moistened - leave the smaller lumps.
Heat a skillet or griddle to medium hot. Grease lightly and spoon out a 3 TBLS of batter per pancake. Cook until a few bubbles form on top and break. Flip the pancake over and cook until golden brown..not too long.



These are the best pancakes and nothing else will compare after having these!!! Enjoy.



Makes about 6-8 pancakes.



**To make your own buttermilk, add 2 tsp of lemon juice or vinegar to a scant cup of milk, stir, and let sit at room temp for 15-30 min.  Stir again before adding to recipe.



</answer>



<answer from>



gay s
Member since: 09 September 2007
Total points: 346 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have an easy recipe for pancakes.Beat one egg til fluffy then add 1 cup all purpose or whole wheat flour,3/4 cup milk,1 tablespoon sugar,2 tablespoons vegetable oil,3 teaspoons baking powder and 1/4 teaspoon salt.Stir all ingredients together ,batter will be lumpy but that's ok.Heat griddle to 375 degrees,you may have to grease your griddle,pour about 1/4 cup of batter onto griddle and wait til bubbles form and cake looks dry then flip over and cook til golden brown,put butter on top while still warm and maple syrup and you can put these in a zip-lock bag and reheat in microwave the next day.Enjoy!



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>

<answer from>



Juz
Member since: 15 January 2007
Total points: 211 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Put toffee on a bonfire.



</answer>



<answer from>



Pam L
Member since: 20 September 2007
Total points: 3495 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



try this:



Bonfire Toffee



A nice recipe for the kids.



Ingredients:



60g Margarine



180g White Sugar



155g Golden Syrup



70g Black Treacle



20mls Vinegar



Method:



Put the margarine and the white sugar in a saucepan and heat gently, stirring all of the time. When all of the margarine has melted, add the golden syrup and black treacle. Continue to stir until the sugar has dissolved. Boil slowly, over a low heat, stirring occasionally.



You need to boil off enough water for the mixture to solidify when cooled to room temperature but you also need to keep the temperature of the mixture low enough during cooking to prevent burning. The test involves getting a sample of mixture on a teaspoon and dropping it into cold water - either in a cup or a saucer.



When the test yields a soft but not liquid result, add the vinegar carefully. The water and most of the acetic acid in the vinegar will boil off but some will stay in the toffee and modify the flavour - most importantly, the malt will stay in the final toffee.



Lightly grease a toffee tray with margarine.



Keep on boiling slowly and testing every few minutes (things speed up towards the end) until you get a stiff result - you will get a feel for how fast you can boil toffee without burning it. Carefully pour into a greased toffee tray and let cool. When cold, break up with a toffee hammer or the handle of a heavy knife or spoon.



Variations:



Add some peppermint oil or orange oil near the end to alter the flavour slightly.



Add some nuts (sliced roast almonds or brazils).



Storage:



Break up and store in an airtight tin - bonfire toffee is deliquescent so, unless you want to end up with a sugar solution, make sure that it is airtight.



Serving suggestions:



Eat straight from the tin whilst watching the bonfire



or this:
BONFIRE TOFFEE



INGREDIENTS



1 lb sugar, preferably Demerara



1/3 pint water



1 ozs butter
2 level tablespoons black treacle
1 teaspoon malt vinegar



METHOD



Put all the ingredients into a strong saucepan and stir over a steady
heat until the sugar has dissolved.



Bring to the boil and cook slowly.



To test for consistency stage drop about half a teaspoon of the mixture
into a cup of cold water, if it sets hard then it is done, if still soft
and chewy cook for a little longer and test again.



Pour into oiled or buttered tin and either allow to set as a slab or
mark in squared as toffee becomes partially set.
Break when completely set.



</answer>



<answer from>



caroline ♥
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 32621 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Glasgow



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients
300g / 12oz Demerarar sugar
100g / 4oz butter
2 level tablespoons of golden syrup
1 level tablespoon of black treacle
4 tablespoons of water



Method
(1) Put all the ingredients into a pan.



(1) Heat slowly, stirring until the butter melts and the sugar dissolves.



(1) Bring to the boil. Cover the pan, and boil gently for 2 minutes.



(1) Uncover the pan, and continue to boil for 10 to 15 minutes, stirring occasionally.



(1) Test by dropping a little of the mixture into a cup of cold water. It should seperate into brittle threads.



(1) Pour into a buttered 15cm / 6in square tin, and leave to set.



(1) Turn out on a board, and break up with a small hammer.



Makes about 500g / 1LB of Toffee.



</answer>



<answer from>



shortie
Member since: 02 July 2006
Total points: 927 (Level 2)

<question>



Looking for an Alfredo baked chicken breast recipe?



I am making fettuccine alfredo for my husbands birthday this Friday. It will be the first time I have ever cooked for his family (8 people!) I have made this before but I want to do something different. I am wondering if anyone has a good recipe for baking the chicken breast to have along with the noodles rather than putting it in with the noodles. My husband does not like tomato sauce so I'm looking for a recipe with a cheese cream sauce.



Thank you :)



</question>



<answer from>



Happy Cooker
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 20586 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's one for you.



CHICKEN ALFREDO



2 lbs boneless chicken breasts
4 tablespoons oil
1/4 cup butter
1/2 cup Parmesan cheese, grated
3/4 cup heavy cream
salt and pepper, to taste
1 lb fettucine



Heat oil in a 10 inch skillet. Cut chicken breast into strips. Add salt and pepper. Fry on medium heat until cooked through.



Sauce:



Melt butter in saucepan; add cream and cheese. cook over low heat, stirring constantly. Do not boil.
Cook fettucine in 3 quarts boiling water. Mix chicken and Alfredo sauce together. Drain noodles. Put sauce and chicken over noodles.



6 servings



</answer>



<answer from>



Been There~Done That!
Member since: 23 May 2006
Total points: 108213 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Family



</answer from>



<answer>



Alfredo Chicken Bake



Try a new twist on Chicken and Dumplings! Chicken breast, Swiss cheese, peas and Alfredo sauce raise the bar for a creamy filling married with dumplings.



1	package (9 oz) frozen diced cooked chicken breast, thawed (about 2 cups)
1/2	cup Green Giant® Valley Fresh Steamers™ frozen sweet peas
1/2	cup shredded Swiss cheese (2 oz)
3/4	cup Alfredo pasta sauce
2	tablespoons slivered almonds
1	cup Original Bisquick® mix
1/3	cup milk



1.	Heat oven to 425°F. In 1 1/2-quart saucepan, mix chicken, peas, cheese, Alfredo sauce and almonds. Heat to boiling over medium-high heat. Pour into ungreased 1 1/2-quart casserole.
2.	In small bowl, stir Bisquick mix and milk until soft dough forms. Drop dough by about 12 spoonfuls onto chicken mixture.
3.	Bake uncovered 20 to 25 minutes or until golden brown.
High Altitude (3500-6500 ft): In step 1, stir 1/4 cup water into chicken mixture. In step 3, bake 25 to 30 minutes.



Chicken Alfredo Recipe



- 2 chicken breasts (boneless and skinless)



- 750gr. of fettuccine (fettuccine)



- 1/2 cup red pepper



- 1 clove garlic (minced)



- 1/2 cup of grated Parmesan cheese



- 8 ounces of cream cheese



- 6 tablespoons of butter



- 1/2 cup of milk
- 1 sweet onion (chopped)



- Salt and pepper



1. Bring a large pot of water to a boil.
2. Cook your pasta and drain well.
3. Cut the chicken breasts in strips.
4. Melt the cream cheese and butter in a skillet (low heat).
5. Stir until smooth. Add the milk, onions, garlic and Parmesan cheese.
6. Cook the sauce for 2-3 minutes, stirring constantly. Add salt and pepper.
7. Add the chicken strips and mushrooms to the sauce.
8. Cook until the chicken is ready.
9. Serve on the fettuccine.
Enjoy!



Conclusion
This might not be the healthiest recipe but it's by far one of the most popular. It tastes great and it's pretty easy to make. Why not cheat, once in a while ;)



</answer>

<answer>



This is my favorite no bake cookie recipe!



3/4 cup peanut butter
1 cup sugar
1 cup cocoa powder
1/4 cup water
1 tsp. vanilla flavoring
6 cups quick cooking oats



combine sugar, cocoa and water in a sauce pan over low heat, bring to a rolling boil and reduce heat again. Add peanut butter and combine. Add oats and vanilla flavoring. Drop onto wax paper in small balls. Makes about 4 dozen.



</answer>



<answer from>



lt;3 LiZzY &lt;3
Member since: 05 January 2008
Total points: 477 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Peanut Butter Crispies



1 (11-ounce) package or 1 2/3 cups NESTLÉ® TOLL HOUSE® Butterscotch Flavored Morsels
1/4 cup peanut butter



3 cups corn flakes



1/2 cup raisins, (optional)



Microwave morsels and peanut butter in medium, microwave-safe bowl on MEDIUM-HIGH (70%) power for 1 minute; stir. Microwave at additional 10 to 20 second intervals, stirring until smooth. Stir in corn flakes and raisins.



Drop by rounded tablespoon onto waxed paper-lined baking sheet. Chill for 20 minutes or until set. Store in airtight container.



Makes 2 dozen.



Source(s):



http://www.cooksrecipes.com/cookie/peanu...



</answer>

<answer>



Applesauce Recipe



Preparation time: 45 minutes. The sugar amounts are just guidelines, depending your taste, and on the sweetness of your apples, use less or more. If you use less sugar, you'll likely want to use less lemon juice. The lemon juice brightens the flavor of the apples and balances the sweetness.
Ingredients



* 3 to 4 lbs of peeled, cored, and quartered apples. (Make sure you use a good cooking apple like Golden Delicious, Granny Smith, Fuji, Jonathan, Mcintosh, or Gravenstein.)



* 4 strips of lemon peel - use a vegetable peeler to strip 4 lengths



* Juice of one lemon, about 3-4 Tbsp



* 3 inches of cinnamon stick



* 1/4 cup of dark brown sugar



* up to 1/4 cup of white sugar



* 1 cup of water



* 1/2 teaspoon of salt



Method



1 Put all ingredients into a large pot. Cover. Bring to boil. Lower heat and simmer for 20-30 minutes.



2 Remove from heat. Remove cinnamon sticks and lemon peels. Mash with potato masher.



Ready to serve, either hot or refrigerated. Delicious with vanilla ice cream or vanilla yogurt.



Freezes easily, lasts up to one year in a cold freezer.



Source(s):



http://www.elise.com/recipes/archives/00...



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweet_Di
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 3751 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - United States



</answer from>



<answer>



Prep Time: 15 minutes
Cook Time: 20 minutes
Ingredients:
1 quart Apples (peeled and sliced)
1 cup Water
1/2 cup Sugar
1 tsp. Lemon Juice
Cinnamon (optional)
Preparation:
Put all the ingredients in a sauce pan and cook until tender, about 20 minutes. Mash the mixture using a potato masher or an electric mixer until it is smooth. Put the applesauce in an airtight container and place in the refrigerator to cool. Once cool, top with a little cinnamon if you like, and enjoy a bowl of fresh applesauce!



</answer>

<question>



I WOULD LIKE TO TRY OUT A RECEIPE AND ONE OF THE MEASUREMENT IS 20cl CAN ANYONE TELL ME HOW MUCH THIS IS. TA ?



</question>



<answer from>



Ray J
Member since: 12 March 2008
Total points: 7996 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



cl is centiliter.  1 Centiliter = 0.04228 cups.  20 centiliters is .8456 cups or just under a cup. ~7 fluid ounces or 7/8 of a cup.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cherry N
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it's 200ml, or 7.03901304 Imperial fluid ounces.



Just use google for such conversions!



Source(s):



Google

Been There~Done That!

<answer>



Make some Taco Boats.



Get some WonTon Wraps from your local grocery store. They usually hang in the produce isle near the Tofu. They come 60 to a package.



I can make about 48-50 of these with two pounds of ground beef.



Brown your ground beef ( 1-2 pounds) with chopped sweet onion (large or small). Drain and add the dry Ranch Dressing mix (1 pkg. for 1 lb. 2 for 2 lbs.). Stir in well.



While your meat is cooking take the Wonton Wraps and place them individually in a muffin tin to bake and form a small bowl. Transfer them to a cookie sheet after you finish baking them.



Spoon in your meat mixture to each bowl and add grated cheddar cheese to the top. Place them back in the oven to melt the cheese slightly.



Toppings can range from sour cream, guacamole, shredded lettuce, chopped tomatoes, corn, chopped green onions and salsa of course.



They are fun to make and more fun to eat. And believe me they will disappear so don't think you can make to many!



</answer>

<question>



Pancakes and what is grease?



i made pancakes the other day. i didnt know what grease was so i put butter and my pancakes didnt turn out well just the first one was ok. please tell me what is grease. thank you.



</question>



<answer from>



Yasmeeee...
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 385 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



grease is oil or butter, personally i think pancakes taste nicer when they're cooked with butter.



if you were supposed to put the grease into the mix then maybe you didn't mix the mixture enough inbetween pancake making meaning that the mixture separated after the first pancake.



if you're referring to when you cook them in the pan you are supposed to add a little more grease each time you make a new pancake to ensure the pancakes don't stick to the bottom of the pan.



</answer>



<answer from>



ben's mama
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 647 (Level 2)

<answer>

<question>



What's a good chicken soup recipe?



I have a cold *sniff cough* and i want a nice chicken soup recipe.



BUT i don't have any chicken stock cubes in the house, just veg ones. I have a chicken breast and thigh in the freezer, whats the best to use?



And i don't want pasta or rice with it, just veggies. Sorry to be so fussy lol, but can anyone suggest a nice recipe to meet that??



Oh, and best answer goes to whoever can tell me how to defrost the chicken quickly but safely!! xxx



</question>

arsene knows best

<answer>



chicken and hot water



</answer>



<answer from>



tao2288
Member since: 15 April 2008
Total points: 301 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a diet chicken soup recipe, its only 106 calories per serving!



Serves 6
Ready in 3 hours 10 minutes
Ingredients



* 1 organic free-range chicken



* 1 medium parsnip



* 2 carrots



* 1 leek



* 1 onion



* 2 sticks of celery



* 2 bay leaves



* 1 bunch of flat leaf parsley



* Salt and pepper



* About 4 litres of water



1. Firstly, prep the vegetables. Cut the parsnip into quarters, top and tail the carrots and cut in half.



2. Cut the leek, celery and onion into big pieces and put into your biggest saucepan. Then add the chicken.



3. Finally, cover in water and add the bay leaves, plus half of the parsley - stalks and all.



4. Slowly bring the pan to boil and then turn right down. Leave just below a simmer for three hours.



5. Drain all the stock into another saucepan. Slice the carrots and add to the stock, and finally add some chopped chicken back in.



6. I usually add one breast back into the soup and make the rest into Thai chicken salad or use for sandwiches.



7. Then add a handful of chopped parsley and check the seasoning. Et voila!



Source(s):



http://www.channel4.com/food/recipes/hea...



</answer>



<answer from>



sportych...
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 585 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



see the recipe and then see how to defrost quickly
1 tablespoon vegetable oil
3 tablespoons chopped green onions
2 teaspoons ground ginger
2 cloves garlic, finely minced
5 cups chicken broth
1 cup snow peas, sliced in 1-inch lengths
1 cup canned sliced bamboo shoots, drained and rinsed
1/2 cup sliced water chestnuts, drained
2 cups diced cooked chicken
2 tablespoons chopped fresh cilantro or parsley
1 tablespoon white wine vinegar
2 teaspoons sesame oil
salt, to taste
ground cayenne pepper, to taste
In a large soup pot, heat the oil over medium-low heat. Add the green onions and garlic; sauté for 1 minute. Add ginger and the chicken stock and bring the mixture to a boil.
Stir in the snow peas, bamboo shoots, and water chestnuts; simmer for 5 minutes, or until snow peas are tender.



Stir in the chicken, cilantro or parsley, vinegar, sesame oil, salt, and cayenne pepper. Simmer until thoroughly heated. Serve hot.



Serves 6.
Put the chicken in a bowl, set in the sink and let COLD water run over it. The water does not have to be turned on full blast, just a steady stream. Hot water on raw meat will cause bacteria to grow and cause a person to get sick. Do not risk it. I work in food service we are not allowed to have raw meat defrost in hot water due to this fact. Chicken breasts take about 20 minutes to defrost using this method.



</answer>

<question>



Cheese and Wine parties...what should I know?

What kind of cheese should I get? Wine Etc..

<answer from>



Doodles

<answer>



the main thing is to have a good variety of each.
go to a local cheese shop and do some tastings if possible.
you want to have different types of cheese and different varieties of wine as well.
seek out someone that has some experience and do some reading on the internet other than this forum and you will be fine.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lindsay  Jane
Member since: 08 January 2007
Total points: 12997 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Make sure you have a good selection of cheeses, i.e. cheddar,Brie,cheshire,Edam,stilton and lancashire or red leicester.
You could also serve it with a fruit bowl Selection ,mixed crackers and french stick.Sweet pickle would also go well and olives. As for wine a good selection would be , medium sweet, white wine , medium dry white wine and red wine .You could also have an asti spumanti and a jug of orange juice for those that drink less .



</answer>

<question>



Does anyone have a recipe for?



Peanut butter balls



</question>



<answer from>



Russ
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 2189 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Blob a few scoops of peanut butter on some anchovies, chopped liver, and raw chicken livers, then roll to size and enjoy. LOL



</answer>



<answer from>



Tori G
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



1/2 cup Sugar
1/2 cup White Karo
1 cup Peanut Butter
2 cups of Corn Flakes
Wax paper



Bring Sugar and Karo to a boil for 2 minutes or so
Remove from heat and add peanut butter and corn flakes
Stir until everything is mixed together suffiecently
Spoon drop onto wax paper as small or as large as desired
Let cool for 2 hours (otherwise burnt tounges will be plentiful)
Enjoy!



</answer>



<answer from>



msmagoo
Member since: 11 April 2007
Total points: 1764 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I cup peanut butter I like the crunchy kind.
one box of confectionery sugar. mix well. Wash hands and use to mix this up into balls the size you want. Take a tooth pick insert in the ball.



You should have melted cho. chips in a double boiler. Dip let cool. Eat and enjoy. Happy eating



</answer>



<answer from>



shortie
Member since: 02 July 2006
Total points: 929 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Peanut butter balls



1 cup peanut butter
1 cup honey
2 cups powdered milk
1 cup confectioners' sugar
1 cup melted chocolate
1 1/2 cups crushed sweetened corn cereal



Mix peanut butter, honey, and milk together to form very thick mixture. Roll out into small balls about the size of a walnut. Roll in confectioners' sugar. Dip in melted chocolate. Roll in crushed cereal. Place on waxed paper and refrigerate until set.



OR



Peanut Butter Balls
12 ounces peanut butter (smooth or crunchy)
1 cup butter (real)
1 box confectioners' sugar
1 teaspoon vanilla
1 package chocolate chips or Chocolate brick (for dipping balls)



1. Mix peanut butter, butter, sugar and vanilla. Roll into balls and place on cookie sheet, place in freezer for an hour. Melt chocolate in a double boiler. Dip balls into mixture. Cool.



</answer>

<answer>

fry it up with someoil and a stock cube

<answer from>



agnes r

<answer>



buy dolmao lasagna kit from the supermarket it contains the pasta sheets and the 2 sauces needed plus you need to buy 1/2lb minced beef brown the mince add the dolmao tomato sauce then get a oven proof dish and layer starting with the mince then pasta then white sauce then pasta and so on cook in a medium oven for about 45 min and hey presto



</answer>



<answer from>



MK_bratt...
Member since: 03 May 2006
Total points: 5607 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Table-For-Two Lasagna



Ingredients:



1 cup Ricotta cheese
1 egg, lightly beaten
1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese
2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley
6 lasagna noodles, cooked, drained
1 jar (14 oz. size) spaghetti sauce
1 cup shredded Mozzarella cheese



Directions:
Preheat oven to 350F. Spray 9x5-inch loaf pan with cooking spray. Mix together ricotta, egg, Parmesan cheese and parsley.



Trim noodles to fit loaf pan; reserve trimmings. Place 2 of the noodles in bottom of prepared pan; cover with layers of 1/4 each of the spaghetti sauce and ricotta mixture and 1/4 cup of the mozzarella cheese.



Repeat all layers 2 more times. Top with layers of the reserved noodle trimmings, remaining sauce, ricotta mixture and mozzarella cheese.



Bake 30 minutes. Let stand 5 minutes before cutting into slices to serve.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michael P
Member since: 06 May 2007
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Seems odd that Kraft Foods has an advertisement for a simple lasagna recipe on the side of the webpage.



Source(s):



http://www.kraftfoods.com/kf/Pages/home....



</answer>



<answer from>



Spin
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 1345 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



How about lasagna roll-ups?



Take your cooked lasagna noodle and spread the ricotta cheese mixture onto it, then roll it up.



Place the rolls (flat side down) into a baking dish that has a layer of tomato sauce in the bottom.  Cover with more tomato sauce and sprinkle mozarella & parmasean cheese on top and bake until bubbly.



350 degree oven for about 30 minutes



Ricotta cheese mixture:
1 tub ricotta
1 egg
handful of parmasean cheese
parsley and basil



</answer>



<answer from>



carly s
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 1531 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lasagna is a good choice - it's really easy to make.
It can be a bit tricky making it for two however I manage it. I have a normal sized casserole dish rectangular in shape and I just make it in half of the dish. If you have a dish the right size then will be alot easier.



I use tesco or Asda's own Lasagna sheets and Ragu red and white sauce.
You'll need about 400-500grams of minced beef.



-Brown off mince in frying pan (once brown drain off oil & fat)
-Stir in red sauce and bring to a simmer
-Once cooked, put a 3cm layer of mince in (half of the casserole dish) or if you have the right size dish a 3cm layer in the whole dish.
-Cover with uncooked lasagna sheets
-Spoon on a layer of white sauce straight from jar
-Repeat the last 3 steps *mince



*lasagna sheets



*white sauce
-Grate some cheese over the top and sprinkle with some pepper



-Put in middle of oven for 20-30 mins at 180deg



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



if you coat the meat in regular plain flour before you fry it,it make it nice and brown, and thickens up the liquid you add to is.



</answer>



<answer from>



old know all
Member since: 13 April 2006
Total points: 55176 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you just want to thicken the stock, cornflour is less likely to go lumpy.  A better technique is to coat the raw meat in plain flour then fry it for a minute before stewing it.  The cooked flour will absorb the blood and thicken the stock.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



WHAT IS YOUR RECIPE FOR A UPSIDE DOWN GERMAN CHOCALATE CAKE?



</question>



<answer from>



Tori G
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This delicious cake, made with a cake mix, makes its own topping.



Cook Time: 45 minutes
Ingredients:
1 cup flaked sweetened coconut
1 cup chopped pecans
1 package (18.25 ounces) German chocolate cake mix
eggs, water, and oil as directed on package
8 ounces cream cheese, room temperature
1/2 cup butter or margarine, room temperature
1 pound confectioners' sugar, about 3 3/4 cups, unsifted
Preparation:
Grease and flour a 9x13x2-inch baking pan. Heat oven to 350°.
Sprinkle coconut and pecans evenly over the bottom of the prepared pan. Prepare cake mix with the appropriate measurements of water, oil, and eggs, following the package directions. Pour the cake batter over the coconut and pecans. Beat together the cream cheese, butter and confectioners' sugar; drop by spoonfuls over the top of cake batter. Bake for about 45 to 50 minutes. A toothpick should come out clean when inserted into the center of the cake portion.



Cool the cake in the pan on a rack. To serve, cut into individual serving-size pieces and, using a spatula or cake server, remove from the pan and turn upside-down on dessert plates.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lost In Space
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 898 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Didn't you see the election results last night?



</answer>



<answer from>



safdenny
Member since: 05 September 2007
Total points: 4432 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I use this one:



1 cup flaked sweetened coconut
1 cup chopped pecans
1 package (18.25 ounces) German chocolate cake mix
eggs, water, and oil as directed on package
8 ounces cream cheese, room temperature
1/2 cup butter or margarine, room temperature
1 pound confectioners' sugar, about 3 3/4 cups, unsifted



Preparation:
Grease and flour a 9x13x2-inch baking pan. Heat oven to 350°.
Sprinkle coconut and pecans evenly over the bottom of the prepared pan. Prepare cake mix with the appropriate measurements of water, oil, and eggs, following the package directions. Pour the cake batter over the coconut and pecans. Beat together the cream cheese, butter and confectioners' sugar; drop by spoonfuls over the top of cake batter. Bake for about 45 to 50 minutes. A toothpick should come out clean when inserted into the center of the cake portion.



Cool the cake in the pan on a rack. To serve, cut into individual serving-size pieces and, using a spatula or cake server, remove from the pan and turn upside-down on dessert plates.



Hope this helps



</answer>

<answer from>



Leo
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 13289 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Upside Down German Chocolate Cake



1. Spread a greased 9 X 13 pan with 1 cup of coconut and 2 cups chopped pecans



2. Prepare a German chocolate cake mix according to directions and pour over nuts and coconut.



3. Mix:
1 cup melted butter
1 pound powdered sugar
8 ounces cream cheese
Pour over cake batter and swirl with a knife



Bake at 350 degrees for 1 hour.



Or if you are watching your weight



1  Sprays cooking spray



2 tbsp Light butter



3/4 cup Water



2/3 cup Unpacked brown sugar



3/4 cup Packaged shredded coconut



1/2 cup Chopped pecans



5 Large egg white(s)



1 cup Buttermilk



1/2 cup Fat-free sour cream



1/3 cup Unsweetened applesauce



18 1/2 oz German chocolate cake mix, 1 package
Preparation



Preheat oven to 350ºF. Coat a 9- x 13-inch nonstick baking pan with cooking spray.



In a small saucepan over low heat, melt butter with water. Stir in brown sugar until smooth; pour evenly into baking pan. Sprinkle coconut and pecans evenly over melted sugar mixture.



In a large bowl, using an electric mixer set on high speed, beat egg whites for 30 seconds. Beat in buttermilk, sour cream and applesauce. Add cake mix and beat on low speed until moistened, about 30 seconds. Beat for an additional 2 minutes; pour into pan.



Bake for 40 minutes. Cool in pan on a rack. Cut into 16 pieces and serve.



</answer>

<question from>



momofone
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 839 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Recipes for corn chowder using frozen corn and milk?



I do not have either canned or cream style corn, only frozen from our garden. I also don't have evaporated milk but do have 1 1/2 % or whole milk. Would love a great tasty recipe, thanks!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's a favorite of mine. It's so easy to make:



Texas Corn Chowder



INGREDIENTS



1/4 cup chopped onion



1 tablespoon butter or margarine



1 tablespoon all-purpose flour (I use 4 Tablespoons to make it thicker)
1 cup diced peeled potato



1 cup water



1 cube chicken bouillon



1 cup fresh or frozen corn



1 teaspoon finely chopped jalapeno or green chilies



2 cups milk



1/4 teaspoon garlic salt



1/8 teaspoon pepper



1 dash paprika



DIRECTIONS
In a medium saucepan, saute onion in butter until tender. Stir in flour. Add the potato, water and bouillon; bring to a boil. Reduce heat; cover and simmer for 7-10 minutes or until potato is tender. Add corn, jalapeno, milk and seasonings. Cover and simmer for 15 minutes.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Texas-Corn-...



</answer>









<original file>16415.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk106547.txt</current file name>




<category>



Food & Drink



Cooking & Recipes



</category>



<question from>



Payola$
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 2072 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What's the secret to making crispy bacon?



It seems that no matter how long I fry it, it stays soft.  I like the really crispy, almost-burnt style, but that just doesn't happen.



?



Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Paula M
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 997 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This works every time!



1. Start with a cold pan or baking sheet. This is of paramount importance. If you are using a frying pan, make sure it is as cold as possible, put your bacon on it, and only then put it on the stove element. If using the oven, start with a cold baking sheet, put your bacon on it, and put it in the oven. Adding the bacon directly to a hot surface will almost instantly coagulate the fat on the bottom surface, which practically locks in the fat. That might be good for roasts, but not for bacon.



2. Use lower temperatures. The increases the time that the fat on the surface will take to coagulate, thus allowing more fat to drain off.



3. Drain the fat frequently. You do not want the bacon swimming in its own fat. If using a frying pan, use a spatula to hold the bacon in place while you pour the fat into a heat resistant container. (Make sure not to get any fat on the outside of the pan, as it could catch fire on the element). If using the oven, put your bacon on one of those trays that allows the fat to drain off, and put that on a baking sheet to catch the fat.



4. Cook smaller amounts at a time. This applies mostly to the frying pan method, as you will need to drain more frequently if you put more bacon in the pan. If you are cooking a lot of bacon, use the oven. If you are doing multiple batches in a frying pan, remember to rinse the pan with cold water between batches, so all bacon starts on a cold surface.



Source(s):



http://absolutely.scrump-tio.us/how-to-m...



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris Guzman, BPBH host
Member since: 15 June 2006
Total points: 1615 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



When frying bacon, it wants to stay soft because it's sitting in all that liquid fat.  Bacon needs a couple of minutes resting on paper towels to get "crispy". . .which, in my opinion (like yours) is the only way to eat it.



My preferred method to cooking bacon is wrapped in several paper towels and placed in the microwave (one minute per slice).  Let it sit for a minute, then give it another minute of cooking time.  Do a couple of trial runs to get it just the way you like it, but the paper towel wicks away the fatty moisture, leaving only the crispy, crunchy perfection of nearly-burnt pork candy (bacon).



</answer>



<answer from>



jken2322...
Member since: 20 October 2008
Total points: 1549 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bake it in the oven.  Lay a single layer of bacon on a baking plan.  Set your oven to 375.  Watch the bacon because it will burn quickly.  You will get crispy bacon that is perfectly flat and straight.  Do not drain the fat while it's baking.  That's the key to cooking the bacon evenly.  I do this when I'm making bacon for cobb salad.  It's needs to be crisp!



</answer>



<answer from>



zzzzzzzz...
Member since: 20 April 2006
Total points: 1013 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's very easy...drain it on paper towls.



I put mine on a plate with a paper towel and in the microwave for 2 minutes.  Crispy every time.



</answer>

<answer>



pork tenderloin medalions with a orzo stuffed pepper and a mango pure



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweet_Di
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 3769 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - United States



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients
4 rib eye steaks (1/2 in)



1/4 teaspoon pepper



1/4 teaspoon salt



4 tablespoons butter (divided)



3 teaspoons green onions, chopped



1 teaspoon prepared mustard



1 teaspoon lemon juice



1 1/2 teaspoons Worcestershire sauce



1 teaspoon parsley



1 teaspoon fresh chives, minced



Directions
1Sprinkle steaks with salt and pepper.



2Heat 2 T butter in skillet,stir in onions and mustard.



3Add steaks.



4Cook for 3 minutes on each side.



5Remove to serving platter and keep warm.



6To skillet, add lemon juice, worcestershire sauce, and remaining 2 T butter.



7Cook for 2 minutes.



8Add parsley and chives.



9Pour over steaks.



Cheesy Mash Potatoes Recipe
Ingredients:
6 to 8 potatoes
1/4 to 1/2 c. milk
1/2 to 1 stick butter
1 egg
1/2 c. Parmesan cheese
4 oz. Mozzarella cheese
Salt to taste
Pepper to taste
Parsley flakes to taste



</answer>

sassinya
Member since: 19 February 2006
Total points: 17576 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try this:
Recipe Title:Old Bay Shrimp Pot



____________________________



INGREDIENTS:



1lb Large Tiger or white Shrimp deveined with shells on
Old Bay seasoning start with 1/3 cup add more if needed
4 sm frozen corn halves (half the size of full ear)
1 stick unsalted butter
1 bag small red potatoes
1 tblsp Parsley (Fresh or dried)



DIRECTIONS:
Leave frozen corn in sink to thaw.
Cook potatoes until fork slides nicely through



Cook corn to desired temp/texture.
Place Potatoes & Corn in big bowl sprinkle with parsley and shake some old bay on corn and cover w/foil
Rinse shrimp in colander.
Put steamer in stock pot w/water just below
Turn burner on high to med-high (stove varies)
Place butter in sauce pan with 1/3 old bay med/low
Steam shrimp constantly checking and moving
Around shrimp for each one to get pink.
Shake Old bay seasoning throughout as you move it around.Place shrimp on potatoes and corn and then butter mixture.  Shake small amount old bay again then more parsley flakes.EAT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Livey ♥
Member since: 10 February 2008
Total points: 501 (Level 2)

<answer>



Korean Beef Dish



Combine beef, sliced in thin strips with:



Accent
Garlic
Ginger
Soy sauce
Onion
Carrots
Green onion
Sesame oil
Rice wine
Sugar
Hot pepper (optional)



The ingredients are according to personal taste, combined and sauteed. Serve over steamed rice.



Fried Rice
INGREDIENTS



1/3 cup chopped onion



1/4 cup butter or margarine



4 cups cooked rice



3 tablespoons teriyaki sauce



2 tablespoons minced fresh parsley



1 teaspoon garlic powder



1/8 teaspoon pepper



1 egg, lightly beaten



DIRECTIONS
In a skillet, saute onion in butter until tender.



Stir in the rice, teriyaki sauce, parsley, garlic powder and pepper. Cook over medium-low heat for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add the egg; cook and stir until egg is completely set, about 3 minutes.



</answer>



<answer from>



Spin
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 1353 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's what I would prepare - my guy love it:



- Strip loin steak seasoned with S&P, bbq'd to medium rare (5 minutes per side per inch)



- Skewer of shrimp - bbq'd



- Loaded baked potato (with butter, grated cheese, chives, bacon bits and sour cream)



- Grilled tomato (slice a roma tomato in half, scoop out the goop/seeds.  In the cavity put 1 basil leaf, and some parmasean or feta cheese).



Grill for 2 or 3 minutes.



</answer>

<question>



BBQ Oven Cooked Pork Ribs?



I need a good receipt for moist oven cooked bar-b-q pork ribs swimming in sauce.



</question>



<answer from>



Bogie
Member since: 20 July 2006
Total points: 39342 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



just season your ribs with salt, pepper, and garlic powder. put them in a baking dish ( if you need to cut them it is ok). cover with one cup of sauce mixed with one cup of water. Cover dish with foil and bake at 350 degrees for one hour. Remove ribs and turn on your broiler. broil till ribs get some color, turn repeat. turn ribs and brush with bbq sauce, repeat on other side.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweet_Di
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 3775 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - United States



</answer from>



<answer>



1 lg. oven cooking bag
1/4 c. flour
1 1/2 c. your favorite BBQ sauce
1/2 sm. chopped onion
1/2 sm. chopped green pepper
3 1/2 lb. pork spare ribs (trim excess fat)



Preheat oven to 325 degrees. Shake flour in bag. Place in 9x13 inch pan. Add BBQ sauce, onion and green pepper to bag. Squeeze bag to blend. Cut ribs in serving pieces and place in bag. Close bag with tie provided and cut slits in top of bag. Bake 1 1/2 hours



</answer>



<answer from>



Renie
Member since: 11 June 2008
Total points: 5412 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go to foodnetwork.com and search Emeril Lagasse's rib recipes.  There are many to choose from.  Don't be discouraged by his recipes because he uses a lot of ingredients.  You will not be disappointed.  He has a great talent in blending multiple flavors which enhance one another resulting in awesome tasting food.  If the recipe calls for finishing off the ribs (baby back pork ribs are the best cut and worth the extra $) just use your broiler.  If you are pressed for time, you can always make the sauce a day ahead (which makes it taste better anyway).  You will not be disappointed!  Yum!



</answer>



<answer from>



luke m
Member since: 27 August 2006
Total points: 5491 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



many of us think that boiling the meat first will tenderize it,what you want to do is steam the ribs in a pan throughout the primary cook time ,covered and with diluted sauce reducing then creates a carmalized glaze ready for the grill or broiler ,then turning and basting several times to keep moist you build a niece crunchy crust  in the same pan (drained of fat ) place ribs and pour sauce as u like  heat till bubbly and enjoy



forget the towels just wash the hands

<question from>



Suednim
Member since: 13 June 2006
Total points: 1797 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Looking for a recipe for "butter caramels"  that is tried and true from an experienced candy maker.?



I have searched the net, and have found a few, none of which is "the one"  calling all candy makers who may have "it", you would make my husband very happy :-)



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients



* 5 cups sugar



* 1 cup water



* 6 tablespoons butter



* 1 cup cream, warmed if possible



Directions



Place sugar in a clean dry saucepan. Pour the water around the wall of the pan to avoid any splashing of sugar crystals onto the sides of the pan. Bring to a boil and continue cooking on high until amber colored. Turn heat off and with a wooden spoon, stir in the butter and then the cream. Pour into an 8 by 8-inch pan that has been lined with foil and well-buttered and let the caramel cool and set until firm. Once firm, cut into squares. Wrap in decorative clear plastic. Store at room temperature.



</answer>

Cooking & Recipes



</category>



<question from>



death-ea...
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 77 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why do milk gets spoilt even though it is boiled before?



boiling of milk kills the bacteria present in it and prevents it from spoiling.but why do we have to boil it again after few hours of storing(without using fridge) to prevent it from spoiling?if bacteria again enters the milk from where does it come as it was killed when we boiled it for the first time?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Bacteria are microorganisms and they are there everywhere in air, water, soil etc etc. When we boil the milk all the bacteria are killed. Then we keep the milk at room temperature. The milk cools down and then the surface of the milk which is in contact with the air permits the atmospheric bacteria to enter in the milk. The milk is an ideal environment for the luxurious and fast growth of the bacteria.  To stop this growth the milk needs to be boiled again if one wants to store the milk without refrigerator. If it is kept at cold temperature then the bacterial growth slows down and the milk remains good for more time.



</answer>

hot rod

</answer from>



<answer>



How much fat and cholesterol do u want in it?



maximum amount?  use butter n cream and full fat cheese



reduced amount?  use soy margarine, and non fat dry milk n filtered water with non fat cheese



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweet_Di
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 3775 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - United States



</answer from>



<answer>



1/2 cup real butter
1 pint (2 cups / 16 fl. oz.) heavy whipping cream
1 tsp. garlic powder
salt and pepper - to taste
1 dash cayenne pepper
2/3 cup fresh grated Parmesan OR Romano cheese
1 lb. box fettuccine noodles - prepared as directed
chopped fresh parsley - for garnish, optional



-In a 2-quart saucepan over medium-low heat, melt butter; add cream, garlic powder, and salt and peppers; simmer for 20-30 minutes, stirring constantly, until thick.
-Remove sauce from heat and stir in cheese. Do not heat sauce after cheese has been added.
-Serve sauce over hot fettuccine noodles and sprinkle with parsley, if desired.



Notes: Though you can’t rush this sauce, if it seems to be taking too long to thicken, stir in up to 1/4 cup cream cheese. Make sure your Parmesan or Romano is grated and not shredded; it won't melt properly if shredded. Do not use Kraft® Grated Parmesan in the canister



</answer>



<answer from>



david h
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 278 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's how I do it:
1-2 slices of bacon
1 stick butter
1 cup heavy cream
1 cup finely shredded parmesan



Minced fresh garlic  (I like a lot, so i put about 5-7 cloves-you can vary yours to accommodate your tastes.)
Cracked black pepper (to taste)



Fry bacon until crisp, and set aside.  To the bacon grease add butter and saute garlic.  Add cream.  Add cheese.  Add pepper.  Once it is thick, creamy and gooey add your other meats or veggies- you can chop up the bacon and add if you like.  Add noodles and toss.



I would have the broccoli already cooked, so you are just adding to coat.  Shrimp cooks so quickly that it can be added raw.  Wait till the shrimp is about 95% done before adding noodles.



Source(s):



This sounds good...I might make some tonite!



</answer>

<question>



What are some good recipes for cookies?



</question>



<answer from>



joiedevi...
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 729 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mexican Wedding Cookies are wonderful and a nice departure from traditional chocolate chip cookies. They're light and buttery but not overly sweet.



http://www.joyofbaking.com/Mexican%20Wed...



Source(s):



http://www.joyofbaking.com/Mexican%20Wed...



</answer>



<answer from>



saratha m
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 1200 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



* 1 stick unsalted butter, melted



* 1 cup dark brown sugar



* 1/4 cup molasses



* 1 large egg



* 2 1/4 cup all purpose flour



* 1 teaspoon baking powder



* 1 teaspoon baking soda



* 2 teaspoons ground ginger



* 3/4 tsp + 1/4 tsp cloves, ground



* 1/2 teaspoon salt



* White granulated sugar



Method



Place butter in a mixing bowl with brown sugar and molasses. Cream with hand mixer or stand mixer with paddle attachment. Add remaining ingredients, making sure everything is well incorporated. Take dough and make two logs about 2 inches in diameter after placing on wax paper. Roll tightly, secure at ends and place in refrigerator overnight. Next day take out, remove wax paper and slice into cookies, about 1/8 inch slices. Dip in granulated sugar and place on a cookie sheet. Bake cookies in a preheated 375 degree oven for 8-10 minutes. Take out and let cool on a rack or piece of foil. Store in air tight container for up to two weeks.



</answer>



<answer from>



sweetien...
Member since: 10 November 2006
Total points: 9920 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Oatmeal Raisin cookies, my favorite:



1/2 pound (2 sticks) margarine or butter, softened



1 cup firmly packed brown sugar



1/2 cup granulated sugar



2 eggs



1 teaspoon vanilla



1-1/2 cups all-purpose flour



1 teaspoon baking soda



1 teaspoon ground cinnamon



1/2 teaspoon salt (optional)



3 cups Quaker® Oats (quick or old fashioned, uncooked)



1 cup raisins



Preparation Steps
Heat oven to 350°F. In large bowl, beat margarine and sugars until creamy. Add eggs and vanilla; beat well. Add combined flour, baking soda, cinnamon and salt; mix well. Add oats and raisins; mix well.



Drop dough by rounded tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.



Bake 10 to 12 minutes or until light golden brown. Cool 1 minute on cookie sheets; remove to wire rack. Cool completely. Store tightly covered.



VARIATIONS: Stir in 1 cup chopped nuts. Substitute 1 cup semisweet chocolate chips or candy-coated chocolate pieces for raisins; omit cinnamon.Substitute 1 cup diced dried mixed fruit.



Source(s):



http://quakeroatmeal.com/qo_quakerKitche...



</answer>

<question>



Chefs' theories and opinions about recipes being published?



i am in culinary arts in college and one of the questions is how has writing recipes in published books help the culinary industry. i need to collect different chefs' opinions so feel free to answer. thanks.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Having access to all the different cooking styles and recipes is a great help- it has made cooking things I will never have access to possible. I can't imagine I will ever make it to China, Russia, or Germany- but my life is richer having tried the food from these nations.



</answer>

<question from>
