<question>



need a recipe for pumpkin dip?



i went to a party and this girl i dont know made this pumpkin dip it was soo good. all i know is that it had a can of pumpkin and cool whip in it does anyone know this recipe or a good one like it??



</question>



<answer from>



saratha m
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 1200 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



1 (8 ounce) package cream cheese, softened
2 cups confectioners' sugar
1 (15 ounce) can solid pack pumpkin
1 tablespoon ground cinnamon
1 tablespoon pumpkin pie spice
1 teaspoon frozen orange juice concentrate
Turn this recipe into a puzzle! [click]



Directions:



In a medium bowl, blend cream cheese and confectioners' sugar. In another medium bowl, mix solid pack pumpkin, ground cinnamon, pumpkin pie spice and frozen orange juice concentrate. Thoroughly mix in the cream cheese blend. Chill in the refrigerator until serving.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jana B
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 600 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



PUMPKIN DIP



8 oz. Cool Whip
23 oz. pumpkin pie mix in a can
4 oz. vanilla instant pudding



Mix all ingredients. Serve dipped or spread on spiced wafers



jp



</answer>



<answer from>



MASTER L
Member since: 29 October 2007
Total points: 586 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This one sounds like it might be what you had, it sounds great and has great reviews



Pumpkin Fluff Dip



Ready In: 5 Minutes
Yields: 32 servings



"This is a very creamy and yummy vanilla pumpkin dip that is served with graham crackers. I like the cinnamon graham crackers best, but you can decide for yourself."
INGREDIENTS:
1 (16 ounce) container frozen



whipped topping, thawed
1 (5 ounce) package instant



vanilla pudding mix 1 (15 ounce) can solid pack



pumpkin
1 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice



DIRECTIONS:
1. In a large bowl, mix together instant vanilla pudding mix, pumpkin and pumpkin pie spice. Fold in the thawed frozen whipped topping. Chill in the refrigerator until serving.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Pumpkin-Flu...



</answer>

<question from>



I am trying
Member since: 07 October 2006
Total points: 3506 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Can you give me a VERY EASY Sugar Cookie recipe?



give me a super EASY sugar cookie recipe please.



</question>



<answer from>



Madness
Member since: 29 September 2006
Total points: 1221 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



1 cup soft unsalted butter



1 2/3 cup granulated sugar



2 large eggs



1 tbsp. vanilla extract



3 1/2 cup all-purpose flour



3/4 tsp. salt



2 1/2 tsp. baking powder



Instructions:
Cream together the butter and sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs and the vanilla. Mix together the flour, salt, and baking powder. Fold the flour into the butter mixture.



Roll the dough into balls and place on a cookie sheet lined with a baking mat.



Dip the bottom of a drinking glass in sugar and press the cookie balls to a quarter-inch thick. Bake at 400 degrees F (200 C) for 8-10 minutes.



Makes approximately 4 to 4 1/2 dozen (2 1/2-3-inch) cookies.



Source(s):



http://www.dianasdesserts.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



botygy
Member since: 26 December 2007
Total points: 7778 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cream together 1 C butter and 2 C sugar.  Mix in 2 beaten eggs.  Sift in 4 1/2 C flour, 1 t soda and a pinch of salt and combine.  Stir in 1 t vanilla.  Turn out onto board and shape into 2 rolls about 2" in diameter.  Wrap in waxed paper and refrigerate for at least a day.  Then slice and bake.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jana B
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 600 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



SO-EASY SUGAR COOKIES



3/4 c. sugar
1/3 c. shortening (I use butter flavor Crisco)
1/3 c. oil
1 tbsp. milk
1 tsp. almond extract (I use vanilla)
1 egg
1 1/2 c. flour
1 1/2 tsp. baking powder
1/4 tsp. salt
1 tbsp. sugar



Heat oven to 375 degrees. In bowl combine sugar, shortening, oil, milk, almond extract and egg; mix well. Stir in flour, baking powder and salt. Spread evenly in ungreased 15x10 inch jelly roll pan. Sprinkle with 1 tbsp. sugar. Bake at 375 degrees for 10-12 minutes or until light golden brown. Cool and cut into squares.
(I omit the 1 tbsp. sugar. Bake as directed. Cool and then frost with powdered sugar icing.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Parrothe...
Member since: 03 June 2008
Total points: 1692 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes! My favorite is to go to the grocery, back by the eggs and whatnot, Pillsbury makes a premade dough!!  That is my favorite EASY recipe!!



</answer>

TwinyN!

<answer>



CAKE MIX COOKIES
(I make these at Christmastime for gift giving)



White Cake Mix
2 Tablespoons water
2 eggs
1/2 cup cooking oil
1 teaspoon almond extract
1/2 cup chopped nuts
powdered sugar



Mix all ingredients, except powdered sugar.



Drop batter (about a teaspoon per cookie) into a bowl of powdered sugar.



Roll in sugar until it is an approximate shape of a ball.



Place ion a lightly greased cookie sheet.



Bake at 350 degrees about 18 minutes, until lightly browned.



Cool on wire racks. Makes about 4 dozen cookies.



(Use any flavoring or cake mix you desire.)



Use regular sugar instead of the powdered sugar.



Source(s):



personal recipe file....enjoy...Pat in Indiana



</answer>

<question>



What do you like to accompany lobster with?



Any side dishes that you recommend when eating lobster?

<answer from>



saratha m
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 1200 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Lobster Mousse



lobsters fresh 	4
water 	2 1/2 cups
small onion chopped 	1
white pepper 	1/2 teaspoon
envelopes gelatin unflavored 	2 envelopes
green pepper chopped 	1/4 cup
tarragon 	1/2 teaspoon
mayonnaise 	1/2 cup
lemon juice 	1/4 cup
hot pepper sauce 	1/2 teaspoon
Heavy Cream Whipped 	1/2 cup



Steam the lobsters and pick out the meat. Begin this recipe in the morning so the mousse has time to set. Place the water in a large skillet; sprinkle the gelatin over the water. Cook over low heat until the gelatin is dissolved. Add onion, white pepper and tarragon. Heat to boiling and then reduce heat to low; cover and simmer for 5 minutes. Remove lobster from liquid. Strain liquid into a 4 cup measure. Add mixture and refrigerate until thickened. Puree thickened mixture with mayonnaise, lemon juice and hot pepper sauce. Add green pepper. Fold in whipped cream. Pour into 5 cup mold and refrigerate until set. To serve, unmold on lettuce and garnish.



Serves 8 as an appetizer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Janine
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 434 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<question from>



PB&J
Member since: 16 July 2007
Total points: 15983 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



What, in your opinion, is the best way to prepare salmon fillets?



Everytime I bake salmon,  it turns out dry.  I obviously bake it to long.



</question>



<answer from>



tinktink...
Member since: 29 April 2006
Total points: 2985 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



With my special ranch sauce!!  Turns out great every time!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweet_Di
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 3795 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - United States



</answer from>



<answer>



2 cloves garlic, minced



6 tablespoons light olive oil



1 teaspoon dried basil



1 teaspoon salt



1 teaspoon ground black pepper



1 tablespoon lemon juice



1 tablespoon fresh parsley, chopped



2 (6 ounce) fillets salmon



DIRECTIONS
In a medium glass bowl, prepare marinade by mixing garlic, light olive oil, basil, salt, pepper, lemon juice and parsley. Place salmon fillets in a medium glass baking dish, and cover with the marinade. Marinate in the refrigerator about 1 hour, turning occasionally.



Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).



Place fillets in aluminum foil, cover with marinade, and seal. Place sealed salmon in the glass dish, and bake 35 to 45 minutes, until easily flaked with a fork.



</answer>



<answer from>



JenBunny
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 749 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



on the grill with lemon pepper and some olive oil to add moisture



</answer>



<answer from>



inverse_...
Member since: 31 July 2006
Total points: 16447 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cancer



</answer from>



<answer>



If you bake, try keeping it in a pouch to keep moisture in.



I personally love to microwave any fish. Place in glass dish, cover with cling wrap, season as preferred, and nuke. Slender filets are done in about 6-7 minutes. Salmon, usually cut thicker, takes longer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sew What?
Member since: 26 July 2007
Total points: 9321 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I love salmon.  I want it simple, no fancy stuff.



My favorite way to prepare fillets is to saute them in butter and olive oil, seasoned with a little salt and pepper. Just before I pull them out of the pan I drizzle with lemon juice.  Depending on the thickness of your fillets, this will take from 3 to 7 minutes total cooking time.  If you cook it until it's firm to the touch--it's overcooked.



I sometimes serve  a sour cream dressing on the side, but that's to appease my husband who thinks you have to have something to punch up the salmon.  I'm happy with it's lovely delicate flavor.



</answer>



<answer from>



Coley
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 2250 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I like fresh Salmon fillets on the grill.  I use tinfoil to place it on & butter (not margarine)  then I use mesquite seasoning.  Very yummy.  My kids prefer salmon to other fish when I make it this way.  It really doesn't take long to cook.  The biggest mistake people make when cooking fish is to over cook it.



</answer>



<answer from>



firstlad...
Member since: 21 February 2007
Total points: 932 (Level 2)

</answer>

- Floridian~``

<answer>



Pan fry or grill with a touch of salt, pepper and olive oil.  Do not overcook.

<question from>

<question>



How long does a whole chicken take to cook in a roaster with the cover on?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



If you cook it at 350 F then it is 20 minutes per pound - usually about an hour for a average chicken.  Use a meat thermometer to be safe.  It should reach an internal temperature of 170 F.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Burgundy or Shiraz for cooking?



I've got a choice of two wines I could cook with: a Burgundy (Pinot Noir type) or Shiraz (Cabernet Merlot type I think).  Which would be the better one for cooking with? (not interested in drinking this, only cooking with it!).  I am thinking of using it to marinade for a casserole, maybe beef, or in Italian meat sauce/ragout and/or woud welcome any other recipe ideas that are good for cooking using either of these red wines!



</question>



<answer from>



Rawley M
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 1821 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, a Pinot Noir wine is lighter than a Merlot, So ask yourself do you want a more intense flavour or not?



</answer>



<answer from>



goofy fish!
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 1312 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



When cooking with wine, choose a wine thats not very good, especially if you are not going to drink it. When you cook it, the alcohol is cooked out and wheather its a good or bad wine, its going to taste almost the same when you have the finished product. I recommend to drink your burgundy or shiraz and use a different wine for your food. If you want to drink wine and cook with it, then go with a good burgundy. If not, dont waste good wine only to cook it away! Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jimmy d.



- Floridian~``
Member since: 21 July 2007
Total points: 50163 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Either would be fine...the final product will not be much different.



</answer>



<answer from>



wine-o
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 832 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



firstly if it's shiraz it's shiraz, not cab/merlot,
the burgundy is a must if cooking bourginon, otherwise any decent wine will suffice.



please ignore above comments about using cr*% wine for cooking, you wouldn't drink it, then you should't cook with it!



</answer>

<question from>



reegs73
Member since: 22 August 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Anyone have a good Mince Pie Recipe?



I was thinking of attempting mince pies this Xmas...anyone have a good pastry recipe?



</question>



<answer from>



Huge
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 10674 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients
140g/5oz cold butter, diced
225g/8oz plain flour
50g/2oz ground almonds
50g/2oz golden caster sugar
1 orange, zest only
pinch of salt
1 egg yolk
1-2 tsp cold water
280g/10oz the very best quality mincemeat
1 egg, beaten
icing sugar for dusting



Method
1. Preheat oven to 200C/400F/Gas 6.
2. Rub the butter into the flour and add the almonds, caster sugar, orange rind and salt until the mixture is a bit crumbly.



3. Combine mixture with the egg yolk and 1-2 teaspoons of water until it forms soft dough, then put it into a plastic bag and chill for 20 - 30 minutes.



4. Roll out the pastry to a thickness of 2-3mm(0.1in) and cut out about 18 rounds measuring 7.5cm(3in) with a pastry cutter.
5. Place in lightly greased patty tins and spoon the mincemeat evenly into the pies.
6. Re-roll the leftover pastry and cut out round lids, stars or other festive shapes to fit on top of the mincemeat.
7. Lightly brush the pastry tops with the beaten egg and bake in the oven for 12 - 15 minutes until golden.
8. Remove from oven and leave for a few minutes before removing from tins and cooling on a wire rack.



9. Dust with icing sugar.



Source(s):



Saturday kitchen



</answer>



<answer from>



Xiomy
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 15653 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



MINCE MEAT PIE



1 lb. mince meat
2 c. diced apple
2 tbsp. lemon juice
1/2 tsp. grated lemon rind



Heat ingredients thoroughly. Turn into pan lined with pie crust. Add top crust and seal. Bake 30-35 minutes at 425 degrees.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sweet_Di
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 3795 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - United States



</answer from>



<answer>



2 pounds granny smith apples or other tart apples



2 pounds apples mcintosh



2 medium oranges



2 medium lemons



2 1/2 cups golden raisins



1 2/3 cups currants



1/2 cup candied orange peel diced



1 1/4 cups brown sugar, light



2/3 cup dark rum or brandy



1/4 cup vinegar



8 tablespoons butter



1 teaspoon nutmeg freshly grated



1 teaspoon cinnamon ground



1/2 teaspoon cloves ground



1/2 teaspoon ginger ground



1 x sour cream dough 2 crust pie



1 each egg well beaten with, 1pinch salt



2 teaspoons sugar for finishing the top of the pies optional



Directions
Two 9inch Pyrex pie pans To make the filling, peel, halve and core the apples.



Grate them coarsely by hand or in the food processor.



Place the grated apples in a large nonreactive saucepan.



Grate the zest of both the oranges and lemons, then squeeze both fruits and strain the juice and add it with the zest into the pan.



Stir in the remaining ingredients. Bring to a simmer over low heat, stirring occasionally.



Continue cooking for about 45 minutes longer, stirring often this scorches easily until the mixture is reduced to a thick, jamlike consistency.



Let cool. Set racks at the middle and lowest levels of the oven and preheat to 400 degrees.



Divide the double batch of dough into quarters. Roll one quarter out to form a bottom crust and arrange in pan.



Repeat with the second piece.



</answer>



<answer from>



Happy Cooker
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 20626 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Do you mean mincemeat pies (sweet) or minced beef (hamburger)?  We never know if questions come from the UK or America and it makes a big difference in the answer here in Canada.



</answer>

brads

<question from>



Nicole K
Member since: 27 September 2006
Total points: 448 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Peeking Ravioli- What's Inside?



They are my favorite chinese food but i don't know whats in the middle and am a little scared to fine out...any ideas?



Also, what is that sauce that tastes like soy sauce but a bit different?



</question>



<answer from>



smdiner
Member since: 29 September 2006
Total points: 20068 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Peking Ravioli is another name for the Chinese dumplings known as potstickers.  Pan-fried on the bottom and steamed on top, the dumplings are called potstickers because they tend to stick to the bottom of the pan.



The term Peking Ravioli was coined by well-known chef and restaurateur Joyce Chen coined in the 1950's.  Her restaurant was located in a largely Italian neighborhood, and she wanted a name that would help customers understand what the dumplings were like.  Today, many Chinese restaurants in Boston still use the term Peking Ravioli instead of potstickers.



Most popular Peking Ravioli



Ingredients:
1 package gyoza or wonton wrappers
Filling:
1 egg, lightly beaten
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 cup ground pork (not lean)
4 ounces shrimp meat, finely chopped
6 shelled and deveined prawns, finely chopped
5 water chestnuts, fresh or canned, finely chopped
4 tablespoons shredded carrot
1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro leaves
2 tablespoons minced green/spring onion
1 tablespoon minced ginger
1 tablespoon soy sauce
1 teaspoon sesame oil
Freshly ground black or white pepper, to taste



Preparation:
Lightly beat the egg with the salt. Place the pork in a bowl, add the shrimp, prawns, water chestnuts, carrot, cilantro, green onion, ginger, egg, soy sauce, sesame oil and pepper.



Place a small bowl of water on the work area. Lay out one of the gyoza wrappers in front of you.  Dip your finger in the water and moisten the edges of the wrapper.



Place a heaping teaspoon of filling in the middle of the wrapper.



Fold the gyoza wrapper over the filling and pinch the edges to seal it shut. (You may want to use a cornstarch/water mixture to make this easier).



Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a large skillet or wok.When oil is ready, carefully add the dumplings and cook on high heat until golden brown (about 1 minute).



Without turning the dumplings over, add 1/2 cup of water and cover.  Cook for about 1 minute to cook the raw filling and then uncover and continue cooking until most of the liquid is absobred.



Serve the potstickers with the burnt side on top, with potsticker dipping sauce or soy sauce mixed with minced ginger for dipping.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you!



</asker's comment>

<question>



I need an extremely spicy salsa recipe.?



Nothing mild, hotter than hell preferably, please nothing where it would cost more than $15 dollars to make it-10 points.



</question>



<answer from>



Cister
Member since: 10 November 2006
Total points: 61987 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This is an extremely hot salsa recipe ….use with Caution!!



I'm telling you it doesn't get any hotter than this. If heat is what you want then you are going to love this "Damn Good'n Hot Salsa".



Please don't serve it to your "chile tenderfoot" friends 'cause you might make them an enemy… remember revenge is swift.
Good'n Hot Salsa



8 Habanero Chiles, roasted, peeled, stems and seeds removed, finely diced



3 Roma tomatoes, finely diced



1/4 cup chopped fresh cilantro



1/4 cup minced white onion



1/4 cup lime juice



Combine all the ingredients and let sit for 30 minutes at room temperature to allow the flavors to ripen…."yeah right" just get hotter you mean.



Yep!



Heat Scale: "Damn Hot"



Sure try this "Hot Salsa" Recipe with Jalapenos…sure to please and not near as toasty as the "Damn Good'n Hot Salsa. Hey you can simply start with only one of those Scotch Bonnet beauties still will get some heat…get out the tongue warming blanket.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks, time to burn my stomach out ;)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



jody
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 278 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Any salsa recipe can be made hotter or milder depending on the chiles you use and whether you add the pepper seeds or not.  If you want HOT, use habanero, complete with seeds but be warned that it will be quite hot - not just a little spicy.  You may want to start with just a bit of habanero and some jalapeno, give the flavors a chance to blend and then try it.  You can always add more pepper and seeds if you need more heat.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jen
Member since: 17 October 2007
Total points: 10498 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



SPICY SALSA DIP



1 red onion
1 green chilli
1 red chilli
6 fresh vine tomatoes
1 red pepper
1 lime
fresh coriander



Chop all ingredients finely. Can be chopped briefly in a blender. Squeeze in the juice of lime and add fresh coriander to taste.
Serve with corn chips



OR



SPICY FRESH SALSA



1 lg. can crushed tomatoes
1 lg. can whole tomatoes (cut into bite-size pieces)
3 cloves garlic, diced or crushed
5 or 6 fresh or canned jalapeno peppers, diced
2 fresh yellow or mild peppers, diced
1 fresh green pepper, diced
2 tbsp. vinegar
1 1/2 tsp. basil
5 or 6 green onions, diced
1 med. sweet onion, diced
2 or 3 stalks celery, diced
Olive oil
Onion powder to taste
Garlic powder to taste



Saute green onions, garlic, and a few pieces of celery in olive oil for about 5 minutes. Set aside. In a large bowl mix all ingredients except for vinegar, onion powder and garlic powder. Add saute ingredients to mixture and simply add vinegar and powders to taste. Refrigerate



OR



HOT AND SPICY SALSA



4-5 tomatoes
1 med. onion
1 Lawry Salsa pkg. (usually found by env. of gravy mix)
2-3 tbsp. pickled jalapenos
3-4 tbsp. Ragu sauce
Tabasco to taste
Red pepper flakes to taste



Chop tomatoes, chunky. Add package of Salsa mix. Chop onion and jalapenos and add to mixture. Add tomato sauce, more or less depending on how juicy tomatoes are. 3-4 or MORE shakes of Tabasco and 1 teaspoon red pepper flakes. Mix well and chill.



JM



</answer>

<question>



Does anyone know a recipe for potato cakes/ farls that uses Potato Flour (am gluten/wheat free). Thank you.?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



http://images.search.yahoo.com/images/vi...
I know how to make potato cakes but it doesn't use flour at all! Only leftover cold mashed potatoes eggs, onions n salt/pepper...You can also do this with left over cream style corn, mackerel or salmon. Yummy! It's the way I've always done them, my grandma showed me how when I was a lil girl..
Make mashed potatoes, now they have to be cold, left over from the day before preferably. It's important that they are thick. Anyway add 2 or 3 eggs depending on how many potatoes you have. Saute some onion and drain oil, stir the cooked onions in there. Salt n pepper. Mix very well, if they are not sticking together then add more egg... Take a big spoon and sorta form a patty, put it in a hot skillet. Only enough oil to film the bottom, fry till firm and brown, flip and brown... You may add a lil oil per batch...



</answer>

<answer from>



goofy fish!
Member since: 11 September 2007
Total points: 1312 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



All you can do is add more liquid! Some people say that if you add a piece of bread or a potato, that they help absorb the salt but all they really do, is absorb liquid. Try adding beef or chicken stock (watch the salt content in that) to add flavor and not dilute it too much. Good luck!



</answer>

<question>



I want to make something sweet that isn't so expensive.Any ideas?



I have a craving for something sweet.Something like a desert or tart.I don't have a lot of money so it needs to be simple.



</question>



<answer from>



disappro...
Member since: 27 April 2008
Total points: 5160 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



try this no-bake cheesecake, it's the easiest thing i've ever made and i always get raves! just mix together 2 8-oz packages cream cheese (softened), 1 14-oz can sweetened condensed milk, 1/4 cup lemon juice, and 1 tsp vanilla. blend til smooth & pour into prepared graham cracker or oreo crust. (i like to make mini cheesecakes - instead of the crust, just line some muffin tins with paper cupcake liners & drop an oreo into each one.) cover & let set in the fridge or freezer & voila! cheap to make, but looks fancy & tastes awesome.



some other ideas are chocolate-dipped fruit, rice krispie treats, baked apples, worms & dirt, s'mores...don't be afraid to get creative! :-)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I loved it.Thanks



</asker's comment>

ejane_25
Member since: 11 May 2007
Total points: 161 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



try chilled chocolate pretzel its great,easy and not expensive
Ingredients
2 cups milk chocolate chips
1 teaspoon cayenne
2 tablespoons vegetable shortening
36 pretzels



In a microwave-safe bowl, combine the chocolate, cayenne and vegetable shortening. Microwave on 50 percent power for 1 minute, then remove and stir. Continue this process in 10-second increments until mixture is smooth and blended. Dip the pretzels in the chocolate one at a time, making certain to coat both sides. Place coated pretzels on wax paper, then chill in the refrigerator until hard.



Source(s):



http://www.recipesarefree.com/chile-choc...



</answer>



<answer from>



Mabes
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 2516 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I make these squares all the time and everyone loves them!



1 cup of peanut butter
1/2 cup of butter/margarine
1 cup chocolate chips



melt it together on the stove over low heat. stir a lot to make sure the bottom doesn't burn. when its melted and creamy looking, add a tablespoon of vanila. when it's blended in, pour into a pan and put in the fridge for an hour or so. cut into squares and savour!! :)



------------



or another idea is to cut up a couple apples into thin slices. lay flat in a pan/cookie sheet. rub a thin layer of butter/margarine on top, and then sprinkle with cinnamon and brown sugar. bake in the oven for about 10-15 minutes until soft and hot. tastes like apple pie but without a crust of course. awesome in a bowl with ice cream on top!!!



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



How do I make mashed potatoes?



I was staying in the states for a year and my host mother made me mashed potatoes!  It was so delicious and I tried to make my self at home, but I couldn't.
Please help me!



</question>



<answer from>



Happy Cooker
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 20634 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Boil 2-3 potatoes in salted water until cooked.  Drain.  Add a pat of butter and a little milk and mash them with a potato masher. Use a fork if you don't have one.



</answer>



<answer from>



Frank P
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Boil potatoes
Add salt and pepper, milk and butter
Mash them with a fork



Source(s):



Mashed Potato Marketing Board



</answer>

thknuvu
Member since: 29 April 2008

<answer>

<answer from>



Sandhaya
Member since: 25 October 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



PEEL POTATOES,CUBE & BOIL IN SALTED WATER.
DRAIN WATER.



HEAT MILK & BUTTER TOGETHER IN A MUG IN THE MICROWAVE.



ADD TO THE POTATOES & MASH WELL FOR A SOFT & FLUFFY MASH!



</answer>



<answer from>



neopolitan angel♥♥
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 661 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



tools
Stove



Potato Peeler



Sharp Knife



Potato Masher, Ricer, or Electric Mixer



Saucepan or Pot



Colander



Large Bowl or Mixing Bowl



ingredients
Potatoes (4-6 medium-sized potatoes; more if the potatoes are small)



Butter (2-4 tbsp.)



Milk or Cream (1 cup, warm; milk is more common, but cream will make them, well, creamier)



Salt



Pepper



steps



Wash the potatoes by scrubbing rigorously. You can use a potato scrubber or your hands, but don't use soap. Running water will do just fine.



Remove the eyes of the potatoes with the tip of your potato peeler.



Peel the potatoes next.



If you're using red potatoes, you'll want to leave those skins on for some added texture and flavor.



Cut out bad spots that you find after peeling. They are easy to see because of their dark color.



Cut the potatoes in half lengthwise. Cut into quarters if desired.



Place in a saucepan or pot and cover with water. Add salt to the water, bring to a gentle boil and simmer for about 20-25 minutes. It's better to overcook than to undercook.



When potatoes are soft and a knife or fork can pierce through the center easily, drain the potatoes in a colander
step 2
Using a masher, potato ricer, or fork, begin a preliminary gentle mashing of the potatoes. You can also use an electric mixer if desired.



Add some butter and begin adding milk or cream in small amounts. Start with about 1/3 or 1/2 of the milk/cream, and slowly add more as necessary. Continue mashing until you've reached the desired fluffiness, smoothness and consistency.



Be careful not to overdo it with the mashing, as this will make them gummy and not fluffy.



</answer>



<answer from>



grannybr...
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 791 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



peel and chop potatoes, boil in salted water until they fall off a fork easily. drain add half a stick of butter and start mashing with a potato masher or fork or hand mixer, add milk to get the smoothness you want salt and pepper to taste. or you can put cooked potatoes through a ricer and then add butter, milk, salt and pepper to taste. good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



peel 4 med size potatoes, and cut into small pieces, boil them until they are tender when poked with a fork or knife.  Drain the water, and rinse a little to keep the mashed potatoes from becoming gummy.  Add 2-4 tablespoons of butter or margarine (butter tastes better) and about 1/4 to 1/3 cup of milk, salt and pepper to your taste, and mash them until all the lumps of potato are gone.  Enjoy!!



</answer>

Joanne N

</answer from>



<answer>



Well this recipe makes a lot but you can cut it down for less servings. When I make this for family gatherings people want to lick the bowl.



5 pounds of White potatoes
1 stick butter
8 ounce sour cream
1/2 cup Parmesan cheese
8 oz package chive and onion cream cheese.
1 teaspoon salt



Peel potatoes and chop/dice in 1 inch cubes
Place potatoes in a large pot and cover with water and add 1 teaspoon salt.
Boil Under tender.
Drain all the water and add the rest of the ingredients and Mash.
At this point you can serve them OR I put them in a baking dish and bake them on 350 until just lightly brown on top.



Source(s):



Family recipe



</answer>



<answer from>



Holl...
Member since: 17 August 2006
Total points: 431 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Peel and cut the potatoes in half.



2. Put the potatoes in a pot of water.
3. Put the pot on the stove on medium.
4. Wait till the potatoes become tender or water is boiling. (About 15 minutes)
5. Drain the potatoes and put them in a bowl.



6. Mash the potatoes and mash in some butter and milk. (Make sure the potatoes are really mashed or they will be lumpy)
To make garlic mashed potatoes, you can season with garlic salt of put fresh garlic in the boiling water of the potatoes.



</answer>



<answer from>



Janvie ♥
Member since: 21 August 2007
Total points: 9318 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



*****Garlic Mashed potatoes with butter, and Parmesan cheese, along with low fat milk and seasonings.



7 cups peeled and cubed baking potatoes



6 cloves garlic, peeled



1/2 cup low-fat milk



1/4 cup Parmesan cheese, grated



2 tablespoons butter



1/2 teaspoon salt



1/8 teaspoon pepper
Place potatoes and garlic in a saucepan. Cover with water; bring to a boil. Reduce heat. Simmer 20 minutes; drain. Place drained potatoes and garlic in a mixing bowl. Add remaining ingredients; beat with mixer until smooth.
*****Cheddar Cheese Mashed Potatoes
4 large baking potatoes, about 2 pounds, peeled and cut into 1-inch pieces



1 cup heated milk



2 tablespoons butter, room temperature



4 ounces shredded process American cheese



4 ounces shredded sharp Cheddar cheese



1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper



1/4 teaspoon salt



1/4 teaspoon paprika



pinch ground red pepper
Cook potatoes in boiling water until tender, about 15 minutes. Drain well.Put potatoes back in saucepan; stir over low heat until dry, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat. Mash, adding about 1/2 cup milk and the 2 tablespoons butter. Add grated cheese and seasonings. Beat with a spoon, adding remaining milk until desired consistency is reached.
******Creamy Mashed Potatoes



3 pound baking (russet) potatoes



3/4 stick unsalted butter, cut into bits and softened



1 to 1, cups heavy cream or half-and-half, heated until hot
Bring a large pot of water to a boil (enough to cover potatoes by 1 inch) and add salt to taste. Peel potatoes and quarter. Add potatoes to water, then return to a boil. Gently boil potatoes until tender, 15 to 20 minutes, and drain in a colander. Force potatoes, while still warm, through ricer into a large bowl. Add butter and stir with a wooden spoon, letting butter melt completely. Add 1 cup cream and incorporate by gently stirring with wooden spoon, adding more cream to thin to desired consistency.



******Wasabi Mashed Potatoes



3 pounds russet potatoes, peeled, cut into 2-inch pieces



3/4 cup whole milk



1 tablespoon wasabi powder



1/4 cup butter
Place potatoes in large pot of cold salted water. Boil until tender, about 20 minutes. Drain. Return to pot; mash.Combine 3/4 cup milk and 1 tablespoon wasabi powder in small bowl. Stir to dissolve powder. Add milk mixture and butter to potatoes. Using electric mixer, beat potatoes until fluffy and smooth. Season potatoes to taste with salt and pepper. (Can be prepared 2 hours ahead. Cover and keep at room temperature. Rewarm mashed potatoes over low heat, stirring frequently.)



*****Sour Cream Mashed Potatoes



3 pounds boiling potatoes, peeled



Kosher salt



1 1/2 cups milk



6 tablespoons unsalted butter



1/2 cup sour cream



1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
Cut the potatoes into 1-inch cubes and place them in a large pot. Cover the potatoes with cold water and add enough salt so the water tastes quite salty. Bring to a boil, then lower the heat and simmer, uncovered, for about 10 to 12 minutes, until the potatoes fall apart easily when pierced with a fork.Meanwhile, heat the milk and butter in a small saucepan, making sure it doesn't boil. Set aside until the potatoes are done.
As soon as the potatoes are tender, drain them in a colander. Place a food mill fitted with a small disc/blade over a glass bowl. Process the potatoes through the food mill, turning the handle back and forth to force the potatoes through the disc. As soon as the potatoes are mashed, slowly whisk in enough of the hot milk/butter mixture to make the potatoes very creamy. Add 2 teaspoons of salt and the sour cream and pepper and whisk to combine. Taste for seasoning and serve hot.



ENJOY :-)



</answer>

<question from>



R......
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 83 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Explain how the yeast cause the cause the dough to rise.?



please help



</question>



<answer from>



Becky T
Member since: 20 August 2008
Total points: 208 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The yeast is like a fungi that grows best under hot, moist conditions, such as that of dough in the oven.
The yeast grows and so does the bread it's inside
Hope that helps :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Happy Cooker
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 20634 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Baker's yeast is the common name for the strains of yeast commonly used as a leavening agent in baking bread and related products, where it converts the fermentable sugars present in the dough into carbon dioxide and ethanol. The use of potatoes, water from potato boiling, eggs, or sugar in a bread dough accelerates the growth of yeasts. Salt and fats such as butter slow down yeast growth. The majority of the yeast used in baking is Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the same species commonly used in alcoholic fermentation. Additionally, Saccharomyces exiguus (also known as S. minor) is a wild yeast found on plants, fruits, and grains that is occasionally used for baking; it is not, however, generally used in a pure form, but comes from being propagated in a sourdough starter.



</answer>



<answer from>



STEVE S
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 3203 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeast is a fungus that feeds on sugar. In dough, the yeast grows and multiplies using the sugar as food. The by-products of the yeast's metabolic process are alcohol and carbon dioxide gas. The alcohol evaporates when the bread is baked, the yeast is killed by the heat and the carbon dioxide is trapped as bubbles in the dough and causes the dough to expand like a sponge.



</answer>



<answer from>



jack g
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



yeast is a living thing, like all living things it needs food  (sugar) warmth and moisture in the form of warm liquid eg milk. Not too hot though as this will kill it



Adding these things to yeast before you add it to the mixture and then letting the bread "prove" so the yeast grows and gives off gases this makes the bread rise



Source(s):



ex baker



</answer>

<question>



How do I make breaded chicken?



</question>



<answer from>



Billie R
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 1228 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The correct culinary taught three step process is flour, egg, bread crumbs



I mix seasoning with my flour- depends on what I am breading- in what seasoning I will use



Milk and egg mix is great



Bread crumbs- seasoned or Panko is the way- but you could use corn meal



You should have 1 plate with plain product- 3 dipping vessels, and one tray for finished product-



You can take any or all of these and use them-



</answer>



<answer from>



Sai
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 774 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



coat the chicken lightly with flour, then dip it in a beaten egg, and then coat it with breadcrumbs. fry it in oil or bake it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rob C
Member since: 09 October 2006
Total points: 199 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



use boneless skinless chicken breasts. thin cut is best or cut them yourself after defrosting. scramble an egg. dip each piece in the egg then roll in breadcrumbs. place in a frying pan with heated oil at just above medium. only turn once. remove when browned on both sides (approx 5 minutes on each side). put on metal grate (not on paper towel) to let excess oil drain. it is great served with a honey mustard sauce. good luck.



Source(s):



personal experience



</answer>



<answer from>



mrwinky4...
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 380 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Get 3 large bowls. In 1 put the an egg/milk mixture (3 or 4 eggs with jut enough milk to thin the eggs). In the second you put a flour mixture and any spices that you want that is not already in the bread crumbs. I like to put seasoning salt in it. In the third bowl you put the bread crumbs. I use Pregresso Italian Bread crumbs as they have a very nice flavor that does not over power the chicken.
I would dip the chicken in the flower then the the eggs then the bread crumbs. Some people will dip the chicken in the egg/milk and then the flour then the egg/milk then the bread crumbs. I think it is called double dipped. put the finished chicken on a tray or plate.



If you fry them do not over load the pan. They will not cook evenly. I like to use an electric frying pan it will keep a more constant heat the a burner from a stove.



If you bake them make sure to use an oven rack (that is sprayed with something like "Pam") in the tray you cook the in. That will cut down on the soggy breading.
Have fun and experiment, cooking can be very enjoyable and a good stress reliever.



</answer>

<answer from>



toastett...
Member since: 29 June 2006
Total points: 16461 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



yep, this one is tried and true...it can't be bad if it has butter in it!



Banana Bread Recipe
Print Options



Ingredients



* 3 or 4 ripe bananas, smashed



* 1/3 cup melted butter



* 1 cup sugar (can easily reduce to 3/4 cup)



* 1 egg, beaten



* 1 teaspoon vanilla



* 1 teaspoon baking soda



* Pinch of salt



* 1 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour



Method



No need for a mixer for this recipe. Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). With a wooden spoon, mix butter into the mashed bananas in a large mixing bowl. Mix in the sugar, egg, and vanilla. Sprinkle the baking soda and salt over the mixture and mix in. Add the flour last, mix. Pour mixture into a buttered 4x8 inch loaf pan. Bake for 1 hour. Cool on a rack. Remove from pan and slice to serve.



</answer>



<answer from>



austuden...
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer>



this is a great recipe, you should double it for a remarkable taste and something fun to talk about. [of course, the alcohol cooks out of the dish]
BEER CHILI



1 tbsp. butter
1 lb. ground beef
3/4 c. onion (chopped)
1 (No. 303) can tomatoes
1 (6 oz.) can tomato paste
1 tsp. salt
1/4 tsp. pepper
1 1/2 tsp. chili powder
1/2 tsp. paprika
1 can beer
1 (No. 303) can kidney beans



Melt butter in heavy fry pan or Dutch oven. Add meat and onion. Cook until lightly browned, stirring frequently. Add remaining ingredients except kidney beans. Stir and cover. Simmer one hour, stirring occasionally. Add kidney beans. Simmer 20 minutes. Stir frequently. Serves 6.



</answer>

<answer>



Thai Salad



2 packages Ramen noodles – crushed – do not use seasoning packet
½ cup sunflower seeds
½ cup slivered almonds
½ cup (I stick) butter/margarine
Sauté all above until golden, set aside to cool



Chop 1 head Napa cabbage
Chop 1 bunch green onions



Dressing: Mix together:
1 cup oil
1 cup sugar
½ cup white vinegar
2 tablespoons soy sauce
1 teaspoon garlic powder



Combine all ingredients just before serving



</answer>



<answer from>



cin2win
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 25050 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



2 (10 ounce) cans chunk chicken, drained



2 (8 ounce) packages cream cheese, softened



1 cup Ranch dressing



3/4 cup pepper sauce, such as Franks® Red Hot®



1 1/2 cups shredded Cheddar cheese



1 bunch celery, cleaned and cut into 4 inch pieces



crackers or tortillas



DIRECTIONS
Heat chicken and hot sauce in a skillet over medium heat, until heated through. Stir in cream cheese and ranch dressing. Cook, stirring until well blended and warm. Mix in half of the shredded cheese, and transfer the mixture to a slow cooker. Sprinkle the remaining cheese over the top, cover, and cook on Low setting until hot and bubbly. Serve with celery sticks and crackers.

white wine vinegar has a a  ore subtle taste as it is has a lower acidity than white vinegar, white vinegar is just as malt vinegar excepth for the color. so the answer is no they are not the same



note to andrew m
all vinegar is not mage from wine, some are made from cider, some from fuit, some from plain old barley and water, thenthey are all distilled, and left to react to obtain ethanol, which is what gives it the taste

<answer>



ALL AMERICAN LASAGNA



2 tbsp. cooking oil
3/4 c. chopped onion
2 cloves garlic
3/4 lbs. ground beef
3 1/2 c. tomatoes
1 (6 oz.) can tomato paste
2 tsp. salt
2 tsp. oregano
1/4 tsp. black pepper
12 oz. lasagna noodles or other broad noodles
1 c. sm. curd cottage cheese
2 c. coarsely shredded cheddar cheese
3/4 c. coarsely shredded cheddar cheese
3/4 c. grated Parmesan cheese



Heat oil in large heavy saucepan. Add onion and garlic and cook until tender. Add ground beef and cook until meat is brown. Mash tomatoes. Add to ground meat mixture. Stir in tomato paste, salt, oregano and black pepper. Simmer about 2 hours, or until sauce is thick.
Cook lasagna noodles in boiling salted water until tender, about 15 minutes. Rinse lasagna with cool water until noodles are cool enough to handle; drain. Lightly grease a 9"x13" pan. Arrange 1/3 of the noodles in pan; cover with 1/3 of meat sauce, cottage cheese, cheddar cheese and Parmesan cheese. Repeat layers twice. Bake in moderate oven, 340 degrees, for 40 minutes. Serve at once. This food freezes well.



Serves 8.



VEGETABLE LASAGNA



portobello mushrooms
zucchini
yellow squash
onion
spinach
garlic
olive oil
tomato sauce
lasagna noodles
ricotta cheese
shredded mozzerella



Fry mushrooms, onion,garlic, zucchini and squash in olive oil.
Mix 1/2 cup of mozzarella with ricotta cheese. Layer accordingly, adding spinach (don't cook spinach first becasue it will add moisture).



Bake 350 for 30 min to an hour.

<answer>



This one is really yummy and uses corn tortillas instead of lasagna noodles.



Black Bean Lasagna



INGREDIENTS (Nutrition)
1 tablespoon vegetable oil



2 onions, chopped



4 cloves garlic, chopped



1/2 green bell pepper, diced



1/2 red bell pepper, diced



1 (14.5 ounce) can chopped tomatoes



1 cup salsa



2 (15 ounce) cans black beans, drained and rinsed



salt and black pepper to taste



2 avocados - peeled, pitted, and mashed



1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice



12 (6 inch) corn tortillas, quartered



2 cups shredded Cheddar cheese



DIRECTIONS
Preheat oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Lightly grease a 9x13-inch baking dish.



Warm oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Stir in onions, 3 cloves of chopped garlic, and green and red bell peppers. Cook until the onions are soft and translucent. Stir in tomatoes with juice, salsa, and black beans. Season with salt and pepper. Bring to a simmer, and cook about 3 minutes.



In a bowl, mash the avocados with 1 clove chopped garlic and lemon juice.



Place a layer of tortillas on the bottom of the baking dish. Spread 1/3 of the tomato and bean mixture on top. Spread 1/2 of guacamole on top, then sprinkle with 1/3 of cheese. Lay out another layer of tortillas. Top with half of the remaining tomato and bean mixture. Then spread remaining guacamole on top. Sprinkle with half the cheese. Repeat with remaining ingredients.



Bake in preheated oven for 35 minutes, or until sauce is bubbly.



Simply Traditional Lasagna



1 pound ground beef



1 pound bulk Italian sausage



1/2 cup warm water



1 cup sliced black olives



1 pinch basil



2 teaspoons garlic powder



1 tablespoon dried oregano



1 1/2 teaspoons dried sage



2 teaspoons ground black pepper



2 tablespoons minced garlic



1 tablespoon dried onion flakes



2 (14 ounce) jars marinara sauce



1 (16 ounce) package lasagna noodles



8 ounces ricotta cheese



1 pound mozzarella cheese, shredded



DIRECTIONS
Brown the ground beef and Italian sausage in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Drain excess grease. Stir in the water and black olives, and season with basil, garlic powder, oregano, sage, pepper, minced garlic, and onion flakes. Simmer for about 15 minutes, stirring frequently. Stir in the marinara sauce, and remove from the heat.



Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).



Place a layer of the meat and sauce in the bottom of a 9x13 inch baking dish. Cover with a layer of dry noodles. Spread a thin layer of ricotta cheese over the noodles, and sprinkle with a little mozzarella cheese. Cover with another layer of sauce, and repeat layering ending with the meat and sauce on top. Reserve about 1/2 cup of mozzarella cheese for later.



Bake for 45 minutes in the preheated oven, but check after 30 minutes depending on how thick the lasagna is. Lasagna is cooked when you can easily stick a knife into it. Sprinkle the reserved cheese over the top, and return to the oven for about 10 minutes for a nice melted cheese topping.



This one is my absolute favorite and can made without the sausage to make it veggie or with to make it meat! :-)



Sausage Spinach Alfredo Lasagna



INGREDIENTS (Nutrition)
1 pound spicy pork sausage



1 (10 ounce) package frozen chopped spinach, thawed and drained



1 (16 ounce) jar Alfredo sauce



1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper



2 cups shredded Cheddar cheese



1 (15 ounce) container ricotta cheese



1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese



1 egg, lightly beaten



3/4 (16 ounce) package no-boil lasagna noodles



1 cup shredded mozzarella cheese



DIRECTIONS
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).



In a skillet over medium heat, cook the sausage until evenly brown. Drain, and mix in the spinach and Alfredo sauce. Season with pepper. Continue cooking until spinach and sauce are heated through.



In a bowl, mix the Cheddar cheese, ricotta cheese, Parmesan cheese, and egg.



In a 9x13 inch baking dish, layer 1/3 of the sausage mixture, 1/3 of the noodles, and 1/3 of the cheese mixture. Repeat layers twice, and top with mozzarella cheese.



Cover, and bake 45 minutes in the preheated oven. Let stand 15 minutes before serving.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Black-Bean-... http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Simply-Trad... http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Sausage-Spi...



</answer>

<question>



Does anyone have any good recipes for jerky?

<answer from>



Jana B

<answer>



BEEF JERKY



4 pounds lean beef, sliced into 1/4" strips
1/2 tsp hickory or mesquite smoke flavoring
1/4 cup soy or teriyaki sauce
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce
1 tsp garlic powder
1 tsp onion powder
1 tsp cracked black pepper
pinch of cayenne pepper
2 tablespoons molasses or brown sugar (optional)
1/2 cup barbecue sauce or ketchup



Choose lean beef only, as fat goes rancid when making jerky. Remove all fat from meat.
Beef top round, flank steak and rump work well. To make jerky that isn't hard to chew, slice across the grain no more than 1/4" thick and don't overdry it. If you freeze meat for a short time, not until it is frozen solid, but just until ice crystals form and meat can still be pierced easily with the point of a knife, then it will be easier to slice thinly. You can also use an electric slicer (Rival or Chef's Choice make home type slicers if you'll be making a lot of jerky).



Combine ingredients and marinate meat in a ziploc bag in the refrigerator for 12-24 hours, stirring occasionally. Be sure marinade gets between the slices and covers the meat.



Drain liquid and place in smoker, oven, or food dehydrator at 160-180°F. Turn when dripping stops. They are ready when jerky is dry enough to easily break off a portion, but still has enough resilience to crack when bent, but not break (4-8 hours). It should not be tough and leathery.



It's important to store jerky away from humidity. Let cool completely before packaging. Seal up in Food Saver bags, canning jars or use Press-N-Seal or aluminum foil to keep away air and humidity. If you won't be using right away, store in the refrigerator to preserve freshness longer, but jerky can be kept without refrigeration.



Note: Sodium Nitrate (curing salt) can be used to enhance preservative qualities, but is not required. If used, add 3/4 teaspoon to the above recipe or follow directions on package.



jb



</answer>



<answer from>



Been There~Done That!
Member since: 23 May 2006
Total points: 108261 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Family



</answer from>



<answer>



Alton Brown's is the best and the best method.



*  1 1/2 to 2 pounds flank steak



* 2/3 cup Worcestershire sauce



* 2/3 cup soy sauce



* 1 tablespoon honey



* 2 teaspoons freshly ground black pepper



* 2 teaspoons onion powder



* 1 teaspoon liquid smoke



* 1 teaspoon red pepper flakes



* Special Equipment: 1 box fan, 4 paper air-conditioning filters, and 2 bungee cords.



Trim the flank steak of any excess fat, place in a zip-top bag, and place it in the freezer for 1 to 2 hours in order to firm up.



Remove the steak from the freezer and thinly slice the meat with the grain, into long strips.



Place the strips of meat along with all of the remaining ingredients into a large, 1-gallon plastic zip-top bag and move around to evenly distribute all of the ingredients. Place the bag into the refrigerator for 3 to 6 hours.



Remove the meat from the brine and pat dry. Evenly distribute the strips of meat onto 3 of the air filters, laying them in the grooves and then stacking the filters on top of one another. Top these with 1 empty filter. Next, lay the box fan on its side and lay the filters on top of it. Strap the filters to the fan with 2 bungee cords. Stand the fan upright, plug in and set to medium. Allow the meat dry for 8 to 12 hours. If using a commercial dehydrator, follow the manufacturer's directions.



Once dry, store in a cool dry place, in an airtight container for 2 to 3 months.



</answer>

<answer>

Flour
Salt and pepper
Oil
1 pkg. Lipton's dry soup mix
1 can cream of mushroom soup
1 can sliced mushrooms
Cooked rice or noodles



Shake pounded  meat in bag of flour, salt and pepper to coat meat well. Brown in hot oil in skillet with lid. Add onion soup mix and enough water to cover meat. Simmer until meat is tender and liquid is reduced considerably. Add cream of mushroom soup and mushrooms, stirring to blend. Serve over hot cooked rice or noodles.

<answer>



GOOD VENISON STEW



Serves 4-6 people
2 lbs cubed (1") venison
4 large potatoes peeled and cubed
4 - 5 large carrots, cut into 1" pieces
2 large onions cut into med size pieces
2 Tablespoons salt
1/2 Tablespoon pepper
3 whole bay leaves
3 beef bouillon cubes
pinch of sage
pinch of garlic



Place all veggies in large stock pot add 1 Tablespoon salt, 1/2 Tablespoon pepper, pinch of sage and garlic cover with water. Bring to a boil then reduce heat to simmer.
Now in another large sauce pan or stock pot cover venison with water and add 1 Tablespoon salt.



Bring up to a boil, then reduce heat.



Turn down to simmer for another 10 min.



Drain venison and rinse briefly then combine it with the veggies. Add 3 beef bouillon cubes, and 3 bay leaves.



Bring to a simmer, adding a little water as needed.



This stew is best cooked for several hours or even all day so start it early in the day.



jb



</answer>

<answer>



I had this several times while on vacation in Germany/Austria. It's delicious! If you can't find Speck you can use bacon, proscuitto or pancetta. Also, you can use vegetable oil in place of the lard. Just add a tablespoon at a time, as you need it, for browning etc.



Venison Goulash: Gulgas di CaprioloRecipe copyright 2001, Mario Batali. All rights reserved



Show: Molto MarioEpisode: A Casa A Cormons
Cook Time2 hr 0 min
Level
Intermediate
Yield
4 servings



Ingredients
4 pounds venison shoulder



1 carrot, cut into 1/2-inch dice



2 ribs celery, cut into 1/2-inch dice



2 Spanish onions, cut into 1/2-inch dice



1 sprig fresh rosemary



1 sprig fresh thyme



6 sage leaves



6 cloves garlic



6 peppercorns



6 juniper berries



1 bottle dry red wine



1/4 cup lard



3 tablespoons all-purpose flour



4 ounces speck, cut into 1/4-inch dice



1 1/2 teaspoons cinnamon



4 cloves



1 cup sour cream



2 tablspoons roughly chopped flat-leaf parsley



Grated Montasio, for garnish



Directions
Trim the venison of any connective tissue, and cut it into 2 by 1-inch cubes. In a 6-quart pot, combine the carrot, celery, onions, rosemary, thyme, sage, garlic, peppercorns, juniper berries, and red wine and bring to a boil. Remove from the heat, allow the marinade to cool, and submerge the venison pieces. Cover and refrigerate overnight.



Remove the meat from the marinade and pat dry with towels, reserving marinade. In a heavy-bottomed Dutch oven, heat the lard until smoking. Season the venison with salt and pepper and place 4 to 5 pieces at a time in the pan. Sear until deep golden brown all over, then remove to a plate. Repeat the process until all the meat is done. Add the flour and speck to the pan and bring to boil. Add the cinnamon, cloves, remaining marinade and meat, including juices exuded onto the plate, and bring to a boil. Lower the heat to a simmer and cook slowly for 1 1/4 hours, or until the meat is very tender. Remove from the heat, stir in the sour cream, sprinkle with parsley, check for seasoning, and serve immediately.



Source(s):



food network



</answer>

<question>



What is a basic pie crust I can make right now?



</question>



<answer from>



cin2win
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 25050 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon salt
1 teaspoon sugar
2 sticks butter, unsalted, cut into 1 tbsp. pieces., very cold
1/4 to 1/2 cup water, cold



Put the flour, salt and sugar into a food processor and pulse once or twice. Add the butter and process until the mixture looks grainy. Then slowly, while pulsing, add the water until you can form the dough by pressing it between your fingers.
Decant the loose dough onto a piece of plastic wrap. Using the wrap, fold the loose dough towards the middle and press with the back of your hands to form dough. Split into two pieces and wrap each and chill for at least 4 hours before using. Dough can be made ahead for up to one week



</answer>



<answer from>



Paula M
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 1033 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



All Butter Crust for Sweet and Savory Pies (Pâte Brisée)



2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, plus extra for rolling



1 cup (2 sticks) unsalted butter, very-cold, cut into 1/2 inch cubes



1 teaspoon salt



1 teaspoon sugar



4 to 6 Tbsp ice water



Method
Cut the sticks of butter into 1/2-inch cubes and place in the freezer for 15 minutes to an hour (the longer the better) so that they become thoroughly chilled.



Combine flour, salt, and sugar in a food processor; pulse to mix. Add butter and pulse 6 to 8 times, until mixture resembles coarse meal, with pea size pieces of butter. Add ice water 1 Tbsp at a time, pulsing until mixture just begins to clump together. If you pinch some of the crumbly dough and it holds together, it's ready. If the dough doesn't hold together, add a little more water and pulse again.



Remove dough from machine and place in a mound on a clean surface. Gently shape into 2 discs. Knead the dough just enough to form the discs, do not over-knead. You should be able to see little bits of butter in the dough. These small chunks of butter are what will allow the resulting crust to be flaky. Sprinkle a little flour around the discs. Wrap each disc in plastic wrap and refrigerate at least 1 hour, and up to 2 days.



Remove one crust disk from the refrigerator. Let sit at room temperature for 5-10 minutes in order to soften just enough to make rolling out a bit easier. Roll out with a rolling pin on a lightly floured surface to a 12-inch circle; about 1/8 of an inch thick. As you roll out the dough, check if the dough is sticking to the surface below. If necessary, add a few sprinkles of flour under the dough to keep the dough from sticking. Carefully place onto a 9-inch pie plate. Gently press the pie dough down so that it lines the bottom and sides of the pie plate. Use a pair of kitchen scissors to trim the dough to within 1/2 inch of the edge of the pie dish.



Add filling to the pie.



Roll out second disk of dough, as before. Gently place onto the top of the filling in the pie. Pinch top and bottom of dough rounds firmly together. Trim excess dough with kitchen shears, leaving a 3/4 inch overhang. Fold the edge of the top piece of dough over and under the edge of the bottom piece of dough, pressing together. Flute edges using thumb and forefinger or press with a fork. Score the top of the pie with four 2-inch long cuts, so that steam from the cooking pie can escape.



http://www.elise.com/recipes/archives/00...



</answer>

<question from>



warpedhy...
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 854 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Why is it not recommended to put warm/hot food int the frigerator?



Is there a reason why it's frowned upon to put food that just came out of the oven/off the stove into the fridge while still warm?



</question>



<answer from>



John B
Member since: 24 March 2008
Total points: 1222 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Food temperatures are considered critical between 40-140 degrees F.
If they remain in this temperature zone for more then 4 hours it is considered dangerous because bacteria grows exponentially in this zone.  If you put something in the fridge hot there is a very good chance it will stay in this critical zone for that amount of time.  When below 40 it greatly slows growth, freezing even more so.  But does not kill bacteria, causing eventual spoilage.  Heating foods above 140 kills bacteria.  That's why many recipes say to cook to at least 160, just to be extra safe.
Peace



</answer>



<asker's comment>

<answer from>



RAZNA
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 5781 (Level 5)



Contributing In:

Anthropology



</answer from>



<answer>



The reason is that the heat in the food brings the ambient temperature of the refrigerator down.  Depending on how hot the food is, that may actually make other things more likely to spoil  Say you put a dish of hot soup next to a carton of milk.  It may bring down the temperature of the milk enough that bacteria begins to grow in the milk.  Then the milk might spoil by the next day, even though the soup will be fine.  So, it's better to leave the soup out for an hour or so, until it has come down to room temperature.  Then put it in the fridge.  That way it won't ruin anything that's cold in the fridge.



Source(s):



Little old lady who learned this the hard way (which means I've ruined other food many times before I figured out what I was doing wrong!)



</answer>



<answer from>



Soda
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 11614 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because the temperature of that warm/hot food starts to warm nearby food items in the refrigerator. It can spoil items that contain proteins (eggs, dairy, etc) and cause those items to grow bacteria that normally wouldn't in a cold refrigerator. Plus, those hot foods, which would probably be wrapped in plastic or foil have a greater chance of developing bacteria since the core will end up taking much, much longer to cool down.



</answer>



<answer from>



jlkladyb...
Member since: 28 July 2006
Total points: 171 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's best to let food cool off quite a bit before putting it in the fridge, if it is very big (such as a casserole,) because the heat from the food can raise the temperature of the entire refrigerator, possibly bringing others foods to an unsafe temperature.



Source(s):



Various cooking publications



</answer>



<answer from>



suellenh
Member since: 02 January 2008
Total points: 13026 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes.  It warms up the interior of the fridge and causes it to run excessively in order to cool down again, increasing electrical usage.  The recommended course of action is to allow the food to almost totally cool, then place in the fridge.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sugar Pie
Member since: 18 March 2006
Total points: 70500 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



The hot food can warm up the interior of the fridge, brining other foods into an unsafe temperature range.



The hot food can also take longer than anticipated to cool off, keeping it in an unsafe temp range.



Unsafe = 45ºF-140ºF



</answer>



<answer from>



cowgirl_...

<question>



Rice????????????????



what kind of rice do u need to make boiled or fried rice?( i got some plain rice boiled it but then when it was cooked there was a little lump on them which was really horrible so what kind of rice do i need)



also do you just boil it to make boiled rice?
next question is how do you make egg fried rice and what ingredient do i need?
last question-is boiled rice and fried rice fattening? about how many calories are in?



</question>



<additional details>



also could you give me some vegetarian meals i know i need vetables but i dont like them so is ther any recipies wher you cant really taste them?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sweet_Di
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 3809 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - United States



</answer from>



<answer>



1 cup water



1/2 teaspoon salt



2 tablespoons soy sauce



1 cup uncooked instant rice



1 teaspoon vegetable oil



1/2 onion, finely chopped



1/2 cup green beans



1 egg, lightly beaten



1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper



DIRECTIONS
In a saucepan bring water, salt and soy sauce to a boil. Add rice and stir. Remove from heat, cover and let stand 5 minutes.



Heat oil in a medium skillet or wok over medium heat. Saute onions and green beans for 2 to 3 minutes. Pour in egg and fry for 2 minutes, scrambling egg while it cooks.



Stir in the cooked rice, mix well and sprinkle with pepper



</answer>



<answer from>



busybake...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 3268 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



I use long grain white rice. Cook as usual and then chill. Fluff with a fork or chopsticks before using in the recipe.



* Exported from MasterCook *



Choo Choo Fried Rice



Recipe By



:
Serving Size  : 0



Preparation Time :0:00
Categories



:



Amount  Measure



Ingredient -- Preparation Method
--------  ------------  --------------------------------



4



cups  cooked rice -- cold



2



large  eggs



1/2



teaspoon  dry sherry



1/4



cup  corn oil -- OR canola OR peanut oil



2



tablespoons  onion -- minced



1 1/2



teaspoons  salt



1/2



cup  cooked ham -- diced



1/2



cup  frozen snow peas -- thawed



Place the rice in a mixing bowl and use your fingers to separate the grains until they are loose. Set aside. Lightly beat the eggs and sherry together with a fork or chopsticks. Set aside.



Heat the oil in a wok or stir-fry pan over high heat. When the oil is hot, stir in the onions and the eggs. Scramble until the eggs re dry and break into small pieces.



Add the rice, salt, ham, and peas and stir constantly until the ingredients are well blended and heated through, about 8 to 10 minutes. Serves 3 to 5.



Note: I have used thawed frozen peas in a pinch. They don't taste quite as good as the snow peas but they will work.



From: Helen Chen



- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -



Per Serving (excluding unknown items): 1723 Calories; 74g Fat (39.2% calories from fat); 45g Protein; 212g Carbohydrate; 3g Dietary Fiber; 462mg Cholesterol; 4242mg Sodium.  Exchanges: 13 1/2 Grain(Starch); 3 1/2 Lean Meat; 1/2 Vegetable; 12 Fat.



Nutr. Assoc. : 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0



</answer>



<answer from>



Sai
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 783 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes, you boil it, using exactly double the amount of water as rice. white rice takes about 15-20 mins, as does jasmine or basmati. brown rice takes about 40. and you don't boil it hard, you simmer it as gently as possible, just hot enough to bubble. to make fried rice you do the above, then fry it hard in a pan with plenty of oil. if you're adding veggies get them frying first. season with soy, red pepper, sesame oil, five-spice powder, garlic, ginger, whatever you like. plain rice has like 160 calories per serving. the oil adds about another 60-80 depending how much.



</answer>



<answer from>



ann_hehe
Member since: 13 March 2007
Total points: 1601 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the trick is when you boil the rice, put less water. That way, it'll keep the rice dry and perfect to have it fried on pan.



The typical yellowish color of fried rice comes from eggs. So you just have to fry the rice with mixed eggs and add anything you that you prefer (shrimps, peas.. etc)



</answer>



<answer from>



Kris L
Member since: 22 December 2006
Total points: 55304 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



To make 'boiled' long grain white rice, use twice as much water as you use dry rice.  Put both into the water at the same time, apply heat.  When the water is boiling, turn it down to simmer, cover, and cook for twenty minutes.  Take the lid off and if there is still visible water, let it continue to cook until you can't see any.
To make fried rice you need a wok or slope sided fry pan.  Put one tablespoon of good oil (use canola or plain olive oil) into the pan and heat to 'high' then add the rice and stir like crazy.  Have a well beaten egg to which you have added an 'egg worth' of water and cooked and sliced before (fry it in as little oil as possible).  Add the egg right before taking it off the heat.
Since you don't like vegetables, try making what I fondly call 'mess' ... go to the grocery store and buy a small amount of every vegetable you hate.  Take them home and chop them into small cubes.  Put a tiny bit of oil into a slope sided pan and heat.  Add a mixture of the vegetables you hate.  Add a bit of soy sauce at the end.  Serve beside the fried rice.  Believe it or not, when you taste the 'mess' you'll find that you do like vegetables, especially mixed and cooked properly.



White rice is far more fattening than brown rice.  You can make brown rice (follow the directions on the package) and fry it or eat it 'plain' with a bit of butter and salt and pepper or soy sauce.  Also try eating the vegetables raw ... you can eat virtually every vegetable raw, but cut them up and arrange them to make a 'pleasant looking' plate, and have some 'dip' for them.  Use non-fat sour cream to make the dip so you don't get too fat.



I don't know how many calories are in plain cooked rice or fried rice, but I do know there are fewer calories if you use brown rice instead of white rice.  You should also include some beans ... red kidney beans, black beans, even pinto beans ... if you want a 'complete protein.'  Also get some edamame (soy beans) or some tofu (I use 'firm') for more protein.  Don't eat much bread or rolls except 'whole grain' or 'multi-grain.'



There are three types of rice.  Long grain white (jasmine or basmati taste best, with a 'flowery' aftertaste that is quite pleasant.  Short grain rice (the 'sticky' rice used to make sushi and sashimi).  Brown rice ... it's the whole rice kernel, not the 'white' inner part used to make white rice, so there is more fiber to it and fewer calories.



I hope this helped ... and do try the 'mess.'  I had a friend who had three sons who HATED vegetables.  I got a list of all the veg they wouldn't eat, took that to the store and made 'mess' with some stewing beef added.  All three sons ate every bit and asked for seconds and thirds.  They asked for the recipe for their mom.  I smiled and handed them the 'list of stuff we hate' and said 'That's what you ate for supper tonight.'  They were very surprised, and went to the store with their mom to be sure she got the 'wrong now right' vegetables the next time she shopped.



</answer>



<answer from>



paterish...
Member since: 18 November 2006
Total points: 281 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



2 eggs, beaten
4T oyster sauce
2T soy sauce
2 cloves garlic, chopped
4T oil
4T frozen peas
1 spring onion, sliced
2T shredded carrot
2½ cups of cooked, chilled rice (chilled rice doesn't clump)



cook and shred egg with a little oil,add garlic and rice and the rest of the oil, stir and cook a little, then add thawed peas, spring onion and carrot, cook a little longer, then add oyster sauce,soy sauce and salt and pepper to taste
This is a traditional asian breakfast...



Source(s):



http://www.videojug.com/film/how-to-make...



</answer>
