<question from>



Twlight....
Member since: 22 July 2007
Total points: 3594 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</question from>



<question>



When baking, why are egg shells so hard to get out...?



When cracking an egg, and you accidentally drop a small piece of egg shell into the mixture - Why is it so hard to get the small piece out?



Also - any tips or tricks to keep it from happening?
What about tips and tricks to get the shell out?



</question>



<additional details>



I'm asking because my 4 y-o son likes to bake with me, and eggs are a pain!



</additional details>



<answer from>



G
Member since: 06 December 2006
Total points: 13431 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Probably because it's a viscous liquid and a thin sharp solid.



To keep it from happening, crack your eggs on a flat surface, not on the edge of a bowl or other sharp corner. This will keep the shell from splitting into the egg. Rotate the egg after tapping it on the counter to get an even split around the egg. When opening the egg, don't shove your fingers into it. Just pull apart the edges.



To get the shell pieces out, I've heard that using half of the shell itself makes it easy to retrieve. I've never really had much luck with this. You can always use a strainer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Christian Woman Laughing
Member since: 17 May 2007
Total points: 428 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It has something to do with the oils in your hands and the egg white but I don't know how to explain that part.



When you do drop some shell into your bowl, use the egg shell a the scoop to get it out.



Also for this reason, you should use a separate bowl to break the eggs into.



</answer>



<answer from>



janet a
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 3702 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I always crack eggs into a separate bowl  - one time I added the 3rd egg to a cake mix only to discover the egg was bloody -- yuck!  I had to throw everything away.  So, I have always cracked eggs individually into a separate bowl.  If you do get a little piece of shell in the egg, use the shell you have left to scoop out the shell in the bowl.  I don't know why this works, but it is like a magnet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ten Walker
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 435 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



first of all, if you're getting a lot of shell in your eggs, crack them more gently.  You're only trying to CRACK the egg... NOT smash it.  I have a cook in my kitchen who does this all the time. Whack! half way through the egg on the edge of the bowl.  All you have to do it TAP it as you turn it a little until you can pull it open.  Practice.



Now.. until you get the hang of cracking the egg... use one of the larger pieces of eggshell to scoop out the bits.  it's about the only thing that does it first try.  Weird, I know.  It's hard to pick the shells out because the whites are slippery and the use of a piece of shell can pierce the slick whites.



</answer>

<question>



Making lamb tonight, have mint sauce in the fridge to use up how should i use the mint sauce with the lamb?



</question>



<answer from>



C.M. C
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 2365 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Dizzy106, basically you have been steered on the right path, depending on how many people your serving, I allow half a table spoon per person, plus a half. in a small glass measuring jug I give it a little burst in the microwave just to remove the fridge chill.



If it's the one in the bottle, give it a shake so you stir up the mint leaves that have settled to the bottom.



Serve in a gravy boat with a serving spoon, or you can add mint sauce at the table over the meat, don't over sauce the meat or you will loose the flavor of the lamb.



Enjoy



Chris

<question from>



charmeds...
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What can I make for dinner when all I have is chicken breast ?



I am a struggling college student , My roomates are always making dinner for me , and I want to make something for them . I am willing to buy extra things as long as it wont cost me alot to buy . I also have ground beef though but I dont have a lot of supplies .. any help will be greatly appricieated



</question>



<additional details>



I was thinking about also making lemon pepper chicken .. i dont know though , I making for other people



</additional details>



<answer from>



zetagirl
Member since: 06 December 2006
Total points: 355 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Go simple....Pound the chicken between wax paper.  If you don't have a specialized tool, use something around the house like a wine bottle or can of veggies.  Hit it until it its about 1/2 inch thick.  Spray a pan with cooking spray or put a little olive oil in it.  Heat the pan over medium heat.  Meanwhile put a little salt and pepper on the meat (or lemon pepper seasoning if you like).  Put meat in the pan.  Brown until the pink disappears on the edges and remains in the center. Flip and cook about 2 more minutes.  You can top it with bbq sauce or even leave it plain.  Serve with salad and baked potato.



You could also get some potatoes, cut them up in 1 inch chunks, put in a ziploc bag with salt, pepper, and garlic powder.  Bake them on 350 for 20 minutes.



Hope you enjoy!



Source(s):



my kitchen!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



this is perfect not too complicated and super cheap thank you !!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Himeko
Member since: 05 August 2007
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can try making Orange Chicken!



Orange Chicken (serves 2)



1 tablespoon butter



2 skinless boneless chicken breast halves (~175g each)



1 tablespoon all-purpose flour



1/2 cup orange juice



1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice, or more to taste



Salt and pepper to taste



In a large heavy skillet, melt 1/2 tablespoon of butter over medium-high heat. Add the chicken breasts in a single layer. Cook till golden on one side, 1 to 2 minutes; turn and cook till golden on the other, about 3 minutes total time.



Reduce the heat to low and cook till the chicken is done, 6 to 8 minutes, depending upon how thick the breasts are. Do not overcook.



While the chicken is cooking, in a medium saucepan, melt remaining butter over medium heat. Add the flour and cook, stirring constantly, until well blended.



Gradually stir in the orange juice and cook, stirring constantly, until thickened, about 2 -3 minutes. Add the lemon juice and stir until combined. Season well with salt and pepper.



Arrange the chicken breasts on a platter and pour the orange sauce over them. Serve with roast potatoes or fresh salad greens.



If not, you can always make some spaghetti by buying store-bought pasta sauce and just dice the chicken breast up and add fry it with the ground beef in chopped onion and garlic before adding in the pasta sauce. Serve with cooked pasta.



Source(s):



http://foodismylife.wordpress.com/2008/0...



</answer>



<answer from>



cali_can...
Member since: 25 May 2006
Total points: 537 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cheesy Chicken & Rice Casserole
Nutrition Information
From: Campbell's Kitchen
Prep: 15 minutes
Bake: 50 minutes
Stand: 10 minutes
Serves: 4



Ingredients:



1 can (10 3/4 ounces) Campbell's® Condensed Cream of Chicken Soup (Regular or 98% Fat Free)
1 1/3 cups water
3/4 cup uncooked regular long-grain white rice
1/2 tsp. onion powder
1/4 tsp. ground black pepper
2 cups frozen mixed vegetables
4 skinless, boneless chicken breasts halves
1/2 cup shredded Cheddar cheese



Directions:



Heat the oven to 375°F.  Stir the soup, water, rice, onion powder, black pepper and vegetables in a 2-quart shallow baking dish.



Top with the chicken. Season the chicken as desired. Cover the baking dish.



Bake for 50 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through and the rice is tender. Top with the cheese. Let the casserole stand for 10 minutes. Stir the rice before serving.



Tip:



To try it Alfredo, substitute broccoli flowerets for the vegetables and substitute 1/4 cup grated Parmesan for the Cheddar cheese. Add 2 tablespoons Parmesan cheese with the soup. Sprinkle the chicken with the remaining Parmesan cheese.



Trim It Down:



Use Campbell's® 98% Fat Free Cream of Chicken Soup instead of regular soup and use low fat cheese instead of regular cheese.



Mexican:



In place of onion powder and pepper use 1 teaspoon chili powder. Substitute Mexican cheese blend for Cheddar.



Italian:



In place of onion powder and pepper use 1 teaspoon Italian seasoning, crushed. Substitute 1/3 cup shredded Parmesan for Cheddar.



** This is not only SUPER easy to make, the ingredients are CHEAP!



My mom used to make it for me all the time, it's delicious! You're making a whole meal in one dish...easy clean up, quick, good, and cheap! :D



Source(s):



campbellkitchen.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Donna
Member since: 01 July 2007
Total points: 9000 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is a recipe on the Minute Rice box for chicken and rice.



Basically you cook the chicken in some canola oil about 10 minutes or until tender.
Then add 2 Tbsp. of the oil into a stewer or skillet. Add in 1- 10 ounce can of cream of mushroom soup, 1 cup of uncooked Minute Rice and bring to a boil on medium high. Then add the chicken pieces (about 2 pounds cut up) then cover and reduce heat to medium-low and cook about 10 minutes. Stir it frequently.



Then you can cook some green beans for a side dish.



</answer>

<answer>



chicken in lemon butter sauce. it's very simple...



slice chicken in bite sizes (like chicken nuggets). dip chicken in egg (slightly beaten) & dredge with flour/cornstarch. fry in a pan over medium heat (you don't have to deep fry although deep frying would be good) until golden. set aside.



for the sauce, saute about a tablespoon of minced garlic on 1 or 1 1/2 tbsp of unsalted butter. once butter turns gold (not brown you don't want your garlic burnt), squeeze in juice from half a lemon (large one). add a tsp of surgar. salt & pepper to taste.



you can either mix in the fried chicken pieces into the sauce or just put the sauce on the chicken slices.



</answer>

<answer>



Cook the chicken breasts in a skillet with a little oil about 4 minutes per side on medium heat. Add one chopped onion, cook briefly and add 1 cup of chicken broth. Meanwhile, cook some spaghetti following directions on the box. Drain the pasta and serve the chicken and sauce over the pasta.  Add some bagged salad and Italian bread and there’s a meal.

<question>



Chocolate Truffle recipe?



So, this summer I spent my time working in a kitchen at a bible camp, and we made these amazing truffles for the tea-parties we held every week. And I remember they started with a cake mix, baked in a loaf pan, then, when it cooled, we crumbled it, and mixed it with some other ingredients over heat, but I don't remember what they were, I think they were like cocoa powder, powdered sugar, and butter, but I'm not quite sure, Then they were covered in melted chocolate on teh outside. Anyone have a recipe like this? Please help me! I'm making them for a New mother and her family!



</question>



<answer from>



maie
Member since: 06 April 2008
Total points: 193 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



crushed graham crackers
crushed peanuts
cocoa powder
butter (softened)
condensed milk (it's the thick sticky one) - if this is not available, then you'll need white/powdered sugar and a some more butter to hold everything together.



all you have to do is mix a certain proportion of everything until everything holds together. and yup you may coat them with melted chocolate or confectioners sugar or simply serve it cooled.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks for the recipe! My kitchen friend from the sumer gave me the actual one, it's really simple.



</asker's comment>

<question>



Is there such a thing... marsala alfredo sauce recipe?



I want to make this sauce for a chicken penne but can't find a recipe. HELP!



</question>



<answer from>



Keekster...
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 307 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Creamy Marsala Alfredo Sauce
Source: Nestlefoodservices



Serves: 64 (2 oz.) servings



Stouffer's® Marsala Wine Sauce with Portobello Mushrooms (hot, 2 qt.



Stouffer's® Alfredo Sauce (64 oz. Pouch), prepared, hot, 2 qt.



In a 2 gallon sauce pot over medium high heat, add Marsala Sauce.



Add hot prepared Alfredo Sauce and blend thoroughly.
Keep warm until needed.



Toss with prepared hot pasta, grilled chicken, pork or veal medallions. Toss with grilled large diced vegetables for a great twist on Primavera.



Source(s):



http://www.recipelink.com/msgid/1418734



</answer>



<answer from>



Ten Walker
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 465 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is really easy.



Ingredients
1/2 cup sweet butter



2 garlic cloves, minced



2 cups heavy cream



1/4 teaspoon white pepper



1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese



3/4 cup mozzarella cheese



1/2 Marsala



Directions
1Melt butter in medium saucepan over medium/low heat.



2Add the garlic, cream, white pepper and bring mixture to a simmer.



3Stir often.



4Add the Parmesan cheese and simmer sauce for 8-10 minutes or until sauce has thickened and is smooth.



5When sauce has thickened add the Mozzarella cheese and stir until smooth. STIR FREQUENTLY.



6 Add the Marsala and stir until smooth.



7 Serve as you please over pasta



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



janet a
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 3771 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I bake a 20-pound turkey at 325 degrees for about 4-5 hours.  Longer if you have stuffing in the turkey.  I usually check by sticking a fork in the thigh -- juices should run clear, not any blood.  And if you wiggle the turkey leg, it should feel as though you could easily pull it off.  I never go by minutes per pound -- it varies so much and it depends on the turkey -- large thighs, small breast, etc.  Also, if it starts to brown too much before it is done, just cover the breast area with aluminum foil.



Boy, now I am starving for turkey!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



galixcys...

<answer>



I actually put my turkey in around 9pm the night before on low like 200 swamped in fluids, I use a ton of chicken or turkey broth along with a bit of cajun spices and I bake it through the night.  When I get up in the morning I add more broth.  About an hour before we eat I take the lid off the turkey and turn up the heat, so that we have a nice crunchy skin.  I have REALLY moist turkey by noon that day.  However, at that point we have to almost ladle it out instead of carving it we really like the moistness of our turkey instead of how pretty it looks.

<question from>



Autumn Leaves
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 3819 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Egg Yolks In An Angel Food Cake?



I have  six egg yolks left over from the last time I made an angel food cake(they're in the freezer).  How would it taste if I add them to a box of  angel food cake mix?  Or any other boxed mix?  Just yolks, no whites. And how long would  it take to thaw out egg yolks?



</question>



<answer from>



Ms.Suz E.HomeBAKER♥
Member since: 06 September 2006
Total points: 4347 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



To safely thaw out egg yolks, they should be thawed in the fridge. Plan to place them in the fridge a day (not more, not less) ahead before you use them in baking. If they are left in the fridge longer, the yolks will become thick and lumpy, and difficult to blend with other ingredients.
Hopefully, prior to freezing, you have whisked the egg yolks together, and added sugar or salt to protect them from becoming a thick, dense, unusuable mass once they are thawed.



I am not sure what would happen if you add egg yolks (instead of egg whites) Angel food cake batter, but I bet you'd end up with something similar to Classic Yellow cake- but with a lighter texture. You might need to incorporate some leavener like baking powder and/or baking soda to the cake batter to compensate for the volume that the egg whites contribute to light and airy textured cake.



Source(s):



Years of baking



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Rick W
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 1557 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Egg yolks have fat in them.  IF you put them in anglefood cake they will destroy the cake and the froth will not stay in place.



Angel Food Cake



Recipe courtesy Alton Brown



Show: Good EatsEpisode: Let them Eat Foam (Angel Food Cake)



* RECIPE



* COMMENTS & REVIEWS(97)



*



Cook Time



35 min



*



Level



Intermediate



*



Yield



10 to 12 servings



Close
Times:



Prep



20 min
Inactive Prep



--
Cook



35 min
Total:



55 min

* Get Card



* Save Recipe

Adding Recipe

Success



This recipe was added to your Folder_Name folder.



Do not show this message again
Close
x
Add To My Recipe Box



Please sign in to add this recipe to your Recipe Box.



Sign In or Create your Recipe Box
Ingredients



* 1 3/4 cups sugar



* 1/4 teaspoon salt



* 1 cup cake flour, sifted



* 12 egg whites (the closer to room temperature the better)



* 1/3 cup warm water



* 1 teaspoon orange extract, or extract of your choice



* 1 1/2 teaspoons cream of tartar



Directions



Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.



In a food processor spin sugar about 2 minutes until it is superfine. Sift half of the sugar with the salt the cake flour, setting the remaining sugar aside.



In a large bowl, use a balloon whisk to thoroughly combine egg whites, water, orange extract, and cream of tartar. After 2 minutes, switch to a hand mixer. Slowly sift the reserved sugar, beating continuously at medium speed. Once you have achieved medium peaks, sift enough of the flour mixture in to dust the top of the foam. Using a spatula fold in gently. Continue until all of the flour mixture is incorporated.



Carefully spoon mixture into an ungreased tube pan. Bake for 35 minutes before checking for doneness with a wooden skewer. (When inserted halfway between the inner and outer wall, the skewer should come out dry).



Cool upside down on cooling rack for at least an hour before removing from pan.



Cook's Note: Since they're easier to separate use the freshest eggs you can get.
http://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/alton...



Ricotta and Chocolate-Hazelnut Calzones



Recipe courtesy Giada De Laurentiis



Show: Everyday ItalianEpisode: I Love Chocolate



* RECIPE



* COMMENTS & REVIEWS(25)



*



Cook Time



10 min



*



Level

*



Yield



6 servings

Add To My Recipe Box



Please sign in to add this recipe to your Recipe Box.



Sign In or Create your Recipe Box
Ingredients



* 3/4 cup whole milk ricotta cheese



* 1/4 cup mascarpone cheese



* 1 large egg yolk



* 2 tablespoons powdered sugar, plus more for dusting



* 8 ounces frozen strawberries, thawed



* 2 tablespoons sugar



* 2/3 cup chocolate-hazelnut spread (recommended: Nutella), at room temperature



* 3 tablespoons whipping cream, at room temperature



* 6 (2-ounce) pieces homemade or purchased pizza dough, cold



* 1 large egg, beaten to blend



Directions



Blend the ricotta, mascarpone, egg yolk, and powdered sugar in a food processor until smooth and creamy. Transfer the ricotta mixture to a small bowl, then cover and refrigerate for 30 minutes.



Meanwhile, blend the strawberries and 1 tablespoon of sugar in a clean food processor until smooth. Transfer the strawberry sauce to a small bowl and set aside.



Whisk the chocolate-hazelnut spread and cream in a medium bowl to blend.



Position the oven rack in the center of the oven and preheat to 450 degrees F.



Line a heavy large baking sheet with parchment paper. Roll out each piece of pizza dough into a 7-inch-diameter round. Spoon the ricotta mixture atop the center of the lower half of each pizza dough. Spoon the chocolate-hazelnut mixture atop the cheese mixture. Brush the lower edges of the dough with egg wash. Fold the plain dough halves over the filling, forming half circles. Pinch the edges of dough firmly together to seal. Using a pastry wheel, trim the edges. Transfer the calzones to the prepared baking sheet, spacing evenly.



Brush the tops of the calzones with more egg wash. Bake until the calzones puff and become golden brown, about 10 minutes. T

<answer>



Angel Food cakes do NOT have egg yolks in them.  Then you'd have either a Chiffon or Sponge cake, and the baking directions are different.  Just put them in with other eggs and make scrambled eggs, or an omelet ... make custard or pudding ... make an egg bread and add extra yolks......



</answer>

Don't try to use this in Angel Food Cake however, it won't work!  Any other cake mix should be fine or cookies!



</answer>

<question from>



Isis
Member since: 16 April 2006
Total points: 12523 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



What is the approximate cooking time for beef in a pressure cooker?



</question>



<answer from>



deepak v
Member since: 15 July 2006
Total points: 325 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



for 1 kg beef, on high plame for 15 minutes, low flame for 30 minutes



Source(s):



i am a chef



</answer>



<answer from>



granny.r...
Member since: 23 November 2007
Total points: 13378 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



Cooking time is in relation to
1) Cut of beef...(sHIN WILL COOK FOR LONGER THAN RUMP)
2) Size of beef (weight)....



Do not fret...If you find that the meat is not tender enough after cooking it for a while, you can always close the cooker and cook it some more



</answer>



<answer from>



healing wings
Member since: 05 February 2007
Total points: 4685 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



A 4 lb. beef pot roast should cook 35 minutes after pressure is achieved, and then allowed to cool down on it's own, another 20 or so minutes.  A rolled rib of beef would go 8-10 minutes per lb. for rare meat, 10-12 minutes per lb. for medium meat, and 12-15 minutes per lb. for well done meat.  Allow to cool on own, not with cold water. Corned beef (4 lbs.) requires longer cooking.  Place it on a meat rack and cook 40-50 minutes after pressure is achieved.  Cool on own. 2 lbs. of short ribs....25 minutes.  Whereas swiss steak, 2 lbs, cut in one inch pieces, 15 minutes.  Hamburger patties, 5 minutes.  Meat balls, 15 minutes.  Cool all on own.  2 lb. meat loaf, 15 minutes after pressure achieved.  Have fun!  I love my pressure cooker for great, quick flavorful meals.  Oh, just to add, most of the meats require between 2 tablespoons to 1/4 cup water, except the corned beef....2 cups of water.



</answer>

<question from>



live.you...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 434 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Chocolate brownies?



?



i need to cook for my family tonight and i was going to make chococate brownies for dessert... is there any kinda sauce that is easy to make that would go with brownies? like strawberry sauce or something?



</question>



<answer from>



weirdfis...
Member since: 25 January 2008
Total points: 4537 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't like strawberry sauce with brownies, but raspberry sauce with brownies is amazing. Just take some sugar and some frozen raspberries and cook it down on the stovetop until it's hot and bubbly and syrupy. Keep stirring and don't have the heat up past medium or it could burn.



Another possibility is caramel sauce: sugar with a little bit of water (just enough to wet it really) cooked until it turns golden brown, add butter and cream when you take it off the stove.



Or beat butter, powdered sugar, and cocoa together for an easy chocolate frosting.



Or you could just melt some marshmallows on top. Sprinkle them on right before the brownies are done, return them to the oven (top rack this time), switch to the broiler and wait for them to turn melty and golden.



</answer>



<answer from>



glamorou...
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 1848 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



How about a scoop of vanilla ice-cream on top, then drizzle it with caramel??



</answer>

<question>



Pot Roast question...?



i have a 1.5 lbs. round roast.. i want to slow cook it in my slow cooker with the regular potatoes, carrots, and onion and a cup of water.  do i cook it for 6 hours... the recipe that i was following was calling for a 3 to 3.5 lbs roast.. is it all the same, or should i cook it for 6 instead.. due to the size of the roast... thanks!



</question>



<additional details>



ALSO... i like juice with my pot roast.. is a cup of water enough.. i added lipton onion soup with it.. but should i add more water if i want the juice?... this is my first time to cook pot roast.



ALSO.. AGAIN... lol.. do i put the meat in the water or on top of the veggies.. some say put the veggies in then the meat on top.. that just sounds like it would dry it out...



</additional details>



<answer from>



PATRICIA T
Member since: 04 November 2008

<answer>

<answer from>



Still for Clinton!

<answer>



You shouldn't have to cook it for that long if it's only 1.5 lbs. I would try maybe 4 hours.



And I would add the cup of water and if you see it's starting to get dry, add some more. I hate cooking pot roast in the slow cooker because of all the juice that's left over but that's just my prefrence.

<answer from>



just an average fatty
Member since: 28 November 2007

</answer from>



<answer>



If you are going to leave it all day while you are at work leave it on low and if it sits 6 to 8 hours on low it will be fine



I usually put all my stuff in the pot then dump the seasoning and water on top. The water will cook out of the veggies and meat too so a cup of water should be good! Dont worry about it the slow cooker does all the work

<answer from>



Watcher1...
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 4477 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Put the veggies in the bottom of the crock pot, then place the roast on top. Pour your liquid over the roast then sprinkle the soup mix on top. Cook it on low about 3 hours or on high 2



Source(s):



The crock pot is my friend



</answer>



<answer from>



stumble1...
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 879 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



is this your first time using a slow cooker?  if it is cook something else first.  Seriously, dont ruin a pot roast in a slow cooker that isnt slow.  I found out the hard way that my slow cooker will bring water to a rolling boil on the low setting.  Not good for long slow cooking but good for large orders of soup.  Put two or three cups of water in your cooker and check out the temps at 15 minute intervals.



In my properly working other slow cooker I do pot roasts with a can of cream of mushroom soup and toss in chumked potatoes 1/2 hour before serving.  Meat, taters n gravy all in one.



</answer>



<answer from>



glamorou...
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 1848 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Place the roast in the crockpot, the veggies around it evenly, and then personally, I like to mix the lipton onion soup mix in a measuring cup FIRST with one cup of warm water.  This will ensure the onion and seasonings are evenly distributed and you don't have just a plunk of seasoning on the top of your roast.  Pour the liquid over the top of everything, then leave on low for 6 to 7 hours.  ALSO...I always set a plexi-glass cutting board under my crockpot...just so it doesn't get TOO hot and burn my countertop.



Good luck and YUM!!  Sounds like the perfect meal!!



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



CoronaQu...
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 571 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tonight is Wednesday night and we usually have "catch-as-catch-can"  meals. I try and do quick meals since it's just myself and my older son. We love healthy wraps with a bowl of pears on the side. Here are a few recipes for wraps:



Asian Chicken Salad Wrap



3 1/2 cups cooked, shredded chicken
4 green onions, chopped
2 cups bean sprouts, rinsed, drained
1 large carrot, grated
1/2 cup chopped cilantro
1/4 cup each: chopped basil, chopped dry-roasted peanuts
3/4 cup mayonnaise
3 tablespoons bottled sweet and sour sauce
Juice of 1 lime
6 each: 12-inch flour tortillas, Boston lettuce leaves



Combine chicken, onions, sprouts, carrot, cilantro, basil and peanuts in medium bowl; set aside. Mix together mayonnaise, sweet and sour sauce and lime juice in small bowl. Pour dressing over chicken mixture; toss to combine.
Heat tortillas, turning every few seconds, in skillet over medium heat until hot. Or, microwave between sheets of paper toweling until hot, about 20 seconds. Place lettuce leaf in center of tortilla; top with chicken salad. Fold over 2 sides; roll up.



Here are a couple more: 2 Quick Picnic Wraps
http://buzz.prevention.com/community/car...



These are especially good healthy choices for the holidays when we get busy with meal planning. The kids can make these for themselves.



Enjoy!
óÓò .·:*Çö®öñåQüéëñ*:·. óÓò



Source(s):



Prevention Buzz Blog
http://buzz.prevention.com/community/cat...



</answer>

<question>



What should I make for a bake sale?



My company is doing a bake sale for United Way and I don't know what to bring.  The signup sheet is full of cookies, cupcakes and brownies.  Anything suggestions for something else?



</question>



<answer from>



Helsinki...
Member since: 15 December 2006
Total points: 576 (Level 2)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



13 weeks with #1
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 259 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cookies, cupcakes and brownies are smart because they're individual eats. My favorite cookie is peanut butter blossoms, the no bake kind.



All you do is mix peanut butter chips and sweetened condensed milk and microwave and stir until smooth. Refrigerate over night. Then in the morning, scoop out bits, roll into balls, roll through white granulated sugar. Then push a Hershey Kiss into the center of the peanut butter ball. They're really good and pretty easy



</answer>

<answer from>



granny.r...
Member since: 23 November 2007
Total points: 13388 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



This is simple, yet unusual;



Bread Fritters;
Go to the bakery section of the store where you normally buy bread.
Ask the baker for an "unbaked" loaf of bread.
He must put exactly the same amount of dough he would have used to bake a bread with in to a plastic bag for you, and it would cost no more than a loaf of bread.



Take that home and in a pot warm some cooking oil to about half the depth of the pot. (Smaller pots take less oil than bigger ones do)...
The oil temperature should be medium hot. (About half the heat that the stove plate will go)



Now cut from the unbaked dough a slice about the size of your palm, and with a little water on your fingers (to prevent the dough from sticking to your hand), stretch out the dough in all directions until it is about the size of your whole hand including the fingers. That brings the cutting of dough to about twice the size it was when you cut it....



Now with care, drop the stretched out dough in to the hot oil.
It would rise almost instantly.
Fry it in the oil until it is golden brown all over, taking care to turn it over occasionally.
It would be puffy and crisp when done.



With a large ladle or sieve, scoop out the bread fritter and place on an absorbent kitchen towel to rid it of most of the oil still on it.
Repeat this process until all the dough is done.



These bread fritters are extremely filling, and can be cut open and filled with almost anything from grated cheese to minced meat to cold processed meat, syrup or jam.
Try it, you will probably have some left over for two or three days, which you can take to work if you like....
Bread fritters can be frozen and warmed up again if you have made too much, but the dough cannot, so rather make the whole lot and freeze what is left over for another day. If you decide to freeze them, do so without a filling. Fillings should always be made fresh.



</answer>



<answer from>



Strawbel...
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer>



MY BEST, MOST DELICIOUS, EASY RECIPE (TO IMPRESS):



Penni Gorgonzola:



Get a couple fillets of chicken breasts, chop & cook them over the stove in a little olive oil.



THEN stir in a little packet of alfredo sauce, some milk (per directions)



THEN MOST IMPORTANTLY: Buy a little package of CRUMBLED BLUE CHEESE (or gorgonzola) & toss it into the alfredo (melts beautifully).



Serve over penne pasta!  Takes 10 or 15 mins. BLUE CHEESE is the secret!

<question>



I'm looking for an old recipe for chicken hash?



I remember that you boil a whole chicken, strip the meat off the bone return to the pot, add potatoes,onions and salt and pepper. That's all I can remember! The old gentleman that  made this for me when I was young never gave me the recipe and he has been gone for many years,he always told me his mother made it for him. Can anyone help me find this recipe?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Just use a basic hash recipe like this, which works for any meat
To make the hash. Sweat the chopped shallots in a little of the olive oil until tender. Scoop the potato flesh from the skins of cooked baked potatoes and mix it with the cooked shallots and slow cooked chicken or duck leg meat and a knob of melted butter. Season with salt and freshly ground black pepper.
Divide the hash mix into four and press into buttered rectangular or round moulds, or simply shape into cakes. Fry in butter until golden brown before turning each and roasting in the oven for 8-10 minutes



</answer>

<question>



What can I add to a sugar cookie recipe to add flavor?



I want to make some cookies using cookie cutters, but the typical sugar cookie recipe is bland. Is there something to add for flavor?



</question>



<additional details>



Would I add the almond extract instead of the vanilla that the recipe calls for? O do I add both?



</additional details>



<answer from>



piong
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



just use one of them, go for the flavor you really want, both of them are really aromatics, their flavor profile might not complement each other. You may add a little  coffee as a secondary flavor and also try to substitute half of the sugar you use with brown sugar or if you could get "mascovado" (raw brown sugar), it has a more distinct  aroma than regular table brown sugar. Do not substitute entirely with brown sugar coz the cookie might get soft and chewy. Lastly, you may want to bake it on an oven that uses charcoal or fire wood to give it a smokey hint but i think this is a long shot in your area... maybe you can add a little smoke flavor to your batter...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks! I will definitely add more brown sugar.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Tomk
Member since: 26 June 2007
Total points: 11313 (Level 6)

<answer>

<question from>



K*G
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 212 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Your own recipe for creme brulee/cambridge burnt cream?



You own recipe that works everytime.



Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



UKTV Food
Member since: 07 August 2008



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



I love this recipe and it really does work everytime:



Burnt Cambridge Cream



Ingredients
685ml double cream, or equal amounts double and single cream
4 large egg yolks, beaten
60-90g caster sugar



Method
1. Heat the cream in a saucepan and boil for about 30 seconds before pouring immediately onto the egg yolks and whisk together.



2. Return the mixture to the pan and continue cooking without allowing it to boil. Stir the mixture continually until it thickens and coats the spoon, then pour into a shallow baking dish. Leave to cool completely and refrigerate overnight.



3. Two hours before the meal, sprinkle the chilled cream with an even layer of sugar and place it under a preheated grill on a maximum setting. The sugar will caramelise to a smooth brown crust. You may need to turn the dish in the grill to achieve an even colouring. It is important that this step is done very quickly in order to keep the custard cold and firm and the top crisp and brown.



4. Return to the fridge and chill before serving.



I bought a mini creme brulee torch from a hardware store and it works really well to get an even, golden top. Enjoy!



Julia



s



</answer>

<question>



Recipe help:- How can l make my Jacket potatoes more appetising ?



</question>



<answer from>



Choose ME
Member since: 14 April 2007
Total points: 2754 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



by cooking them and then dressing them up



</answer>



<answer from>



Rick W
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 1418 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Jacket Potatoes



Could there possibly be anyone in the wide world who doesn't drool at the thought of jacket potatoes with really crisp, crunchy skins and fluffy, floury insides with something lovely melted into them? I'm not speaking of the insipid microwave versions of convenience fame, but the hallowed, reverenced beauty of the real thing. Life is too short, and therefore we need to savour every moment by spoiling ourselves with what is best and not some pale imitation that fails to satisfy. If you ever feel like treating yourself and want something supremely soothing and comforting that costs almost nothing (forget chocolate bars and the like), just bake yourself the biggest potato you can lay your hands on (see the method below), then cut it in half and, as you do, listen carefully to the inviting crackle and crunch of the skin as the knife goes in. Next, with a fork, fluff the floury insides, then add a generous amount of butter and watch it melt and disappear into the clouds of fluffiness. Add rock salt and crushed black pepper, then eat and savour it alone in all its humble, simple glory. The secret of perfect jacket potatoes like the one described above is not to hurry them – give them up to 2 hours to get the really crunchy skin, learn to use the time when you're out, so they can be ready when you come home, or go and do something else and forget about them till they're ready. Below I have included the master recipe, and this is followed by some ideas for fillings and toppings.



Serves 2
Ingredients



2 large Desirée potatoes, 8-10 oz (225-275 g) each
a little olive oil
rock salt, crushed
a little butter
salt and freshly milled black pepper



Pre-heat the oven to gas mark 5, 375°F (190°C).



First you need to wash the potatoes and dry them very thoroughly with a cloth, then leave them aside to dry as much as possible. If you're using ready-washed potatoes you need not do this, as the high heat will purify them. Next, prick the skins a few times with a fork, then put a few drops of olive oil over each one and rub it all over the skin. After that, rub in some crushed salt – this will draw out the moisture from the skin and, together with the oil, provide more crunchiness.



Now place the potatoes straight on to the centre shelf of the oven and let them bake for 1¾-2 hours, or until the skins are really crisp.



When you are ready to serve, slit each potato in half lengthways and top with the butter and seasoning. Serve immediately because, after you remove jacket potatoes from the oven, they lose their crispness very quickly, so don't let them hang around.



This recipe is taken from Delia Smith’s Complete Cookery Course, Delia Smith’s Complete Illustrated Cookery Course and How to Cook Book One.



Source(s):



http://www.deliaonline.com/recipes/jacke...



</answer>



<answer from>



bouncer bobtail
Member since: 28 June 2007
Total points: 8551 (Level 5)



</answer from>

<answer>



Tasty roast potatoes recipe.



INGREDIENTS (Nutrition)
910 g red potatoes, cut into quarters



30 ml vegetable oil



6 g salt



1 g freshly ground black pepper



0.5 g dried rosemary, crushed



DIRECTIONS
Preheat oven to 450 degrees F (250 degrees C).



Place potatoes in a large roasting pan and toss with oil, salt, pepper, and rosemary until evenly coated. Spread out potatoes in a single layer.



Bake in preheated oven for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally. Serve immediately.



</answer>

<answer>



It tastes better fried for sure and is low fat, good for protein and a nice alternative for vegans and veggies to meat. It's better for women than men though as soya mimics a female hormone. That's why it helps women with menopause etc..



</answer>



<answer from>



sunny112...
Member since: 27 June 2007
Total points: 1429 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tofu is a very good source of cholesterol-free protein.  Very fresh tofu is nice raw, chilled, served with a sprinkling of yuzu zest, bonito flakes and a generous swirl of soy sauce.  It can also be added to hot miso soup (or other soups) towards the end of cooking time, just to heat through.  Or marinated and stir-fried with veg.
There is some controversy re soy's effect on hormones: it is sometimes recommended for perimenopause (reduces hot flushes), but too much may hinder some types of thyroid function and possibly male fertility.  Whole-food soy products such as tofu are less likely to cause such problems than isolates in pills (e.g. isoflavones).



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 07 February 2007
Total points: 787 (Level 2)

<question from>

<question>



What are some white wines that you'd recommend for cooking?  ?



I'm a newbie to cooking and found out that I love to cook!  However I'm ignorant when it comes to wines, and some of the recipes I want to try list white wine as an ingredient.  I don't know wines at all so I could use the help.



</question>



<answer from>



Skull Boy
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 6276 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Something really dry like a Sauvignon Blanc. There are a few really good New Zealand Sauvignon Blancs under $10 that are aged in steel drums rather oak barrels. They are less oakey which I personally prefer for cooking.



A cheap Chardonnay works well too. The Charles Shaw (also known as Two Buck Chuck) is a good cooking wine that's about $3 at Trader Joe's.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I learned a little more about wine through this answer.  Like Cabernet Sauvignon is a dry white wine and dry white wines should be used for cooking.  Also glad to know that (now three where I am) buck Chuck is just fine to use. Thank you much!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



chefgril...
Member since: 30 August 2006
Total points: 57406 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



OK, this is purely my opinion on cooking with wine.  Cheaper whites are just fine for cooking.  (But yes, not that stuff bottled as cooking wine.)  If I paid for a bottle of Markham sauvignon blanc, I'm not using 1 cup of it in the risotto!  I like getting those little bottles of wine, the 4 packs to use as my cooking wine.  It's about $5 for the 4 little bottles, and that way you don't waste the rest of an $8 bottle when you only need 1 cup or so.  Anyway, I recommend a sauvignon blanc, pinot grigio/gris.  I've been using Bella Sera.  They're lighter than chardonnays.  I won't use chardonnay since they started the barrel oaking 10+ years ago.  What used to be a crisp chardonnay turned into a very buttery wine that overwhelms a dish.



</answer>



<answer from>



SayWhat?
Member since: 11 June 2006
Total points: 10715 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The rule is to use wine you wouldn't mind drinking.  However, this does not mean you have to spend as much as you would on the wine you pour in glasses.  It basically means, use DRINKING wine, not the cooking wine they sell with vinegars.



The best white wine in most recipes is Barefoot Chardonnay or Yellow Tail Chardonnay.  Both are $5-$6 dollars a bottle at Walmart or the grocery store.



</answer>



<answer from>



Spin
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 1334 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Use a wine that you would like to drink.  If you like the taste of it by itself, you'll like it in your recipes too.



</answer>



<answer from>



Miami Lilly
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 24960 (Level 6)

Diet & Fitness

<question>



Any one no a recipe for blue frosting for a cup cakes?

<answer from>

<answer>

<answer>



BUTTERCREAM FROSTING



1 lb. confectioners' sugar
1/2 c. butter, softened
1 tsp. vanilla extract
3 tbsp. milk
Food coloring (optional)



In large bowl, beat together sugar, butter, vanilla and milk until smooth. If necessary add more milk until frosting is spreading consistency.



add a few drops of food coloring (blue for you). Mix everything well.



Add drops slowly - you can add, but you can't take out.



Enjoy!!



Source(s):



My kitchen  :-)



</answer>

<question>



Recipe help :- How do l Poach eggs ?



</question>



<answer from>



Thunderh...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 796 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Poached Eggs recipe



This recipe is also available as a step-by-step video guide
308 calories per portion



Serves: 1



Ingredients
1 Large Lion Quality egg
Water for boiling
Pinch of salt
Dash of vinegar
Warmed, buttered muffin or toast to serve (optional)



Method



Fill a large pan with 5cm (2") of water. Add a pinch of salt and a dash of vinegar to help set the egg. Bring the water to a gentle boil. Crack the egg onto a plate and then tip it into the water. Set a kitchen timer for one of the timings below:



3 minutes for a completely runny egg yolk



4 minutes for a slightly set yolk with a runny middle



5 minutes for a firm egg yolk



When the cooking time is complete, carefully remove the poached egg from the boiling water using a slotted spoon and place on kitchen paper to drain. Serve immediately on a warmed, buttered muffin or slice of buttered toast.



Micro tip



For extra speed use the microwave. Carefully crack the egg into a large teacup or ramekin dish filled with 1/2 tbsp of water. Use a cocktail stick to pierce the yolk and white in a couple of places and poach in the microwave on HIGH for 40 seconds (750 Watt oven)/60 seconds (650 Watt oven). Stand for 1 minute and serve. Turn your poached egg and muffin into Eggs Benedict with a layer of smoked ham topped with a ready-made or home-made Hollandaise sauce.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Great Answer TY



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Emma Lemma Ding Dong
Member since: 17 April 2007
Total points: 2944 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Poached Eggs
Always use the freshest eggs you can find for poaching: The thick albumen will hold its shape better around the yolk than older eggs. Add vinegar to the poaching water to help the eggs coagulate faster by preventing the whites from spreading out.



Instructions:
Bring a large, wide saucepan of water and 1 tablespoon of vinegar (any flavor) to a boil. Break one egg at a time into a small heatproof bowl, about the size of one egg. Reduce heat so that the water is just simmering. Slightly immerse the bowl in the water, and gently slide in the egg. After all eggs are added, cover pot, turn off heat, and let stand 2 to 3 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, remove eggs in the order they were added and set spoon briefly on a kitchen towel to drain. Trim ragged edges with a knife or scissors, if desired, and serve immediately.



Planning Ahead:
If cooking for a crowd, poached eggs can be made ahead of time: Chill in an ice-water bath, transfer to a covered container, and refrigerate for up to 24 hours. Reheat them by immersing in simmering water for 1 minute.



Source(s):



http://www.marthastewart.com/article/egg...



</answer>



<answer from>



Fallen Angel ღ
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 271 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Fill a saucepan with 3 inches of cold water, add a pinch of salt and bring to the boil.



For your first attempt at preparing poached eggs, you may want to carefully break each egg onto a small cup, plate or bowl before adding it to the water.



As the water reaches boiling point, reduce the heat and allow the water to simmer.



Once the eggs are in the water, do not move them around. Let the eggs cook for 2½ - 3½ minutes, allowing for the size of the egg and the preferred doneness of the egg yolks.



Remove each egg with a slotted spoon and drain for a few seconds on kitchen paper. Trim any stringy or dangling bits with a knife or scissors if you wish and serve immediately.



</answer>



<answer from>



caroline ♥
Member since: 21 December 2006
Total points: 32575 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Glasgow



</answer from>



<answer>



Fill a frying pan with boiling water, deep enough to cover an egg. While it is boiling briskly over a high gas flame, break as many eggs as you need into the water. The water will go off the boil, but keep an eye on it until it comes back to the boil. Once it is boiling again turn the heat off and let it sit. The eggs will continue to cook and you can take them out when they are cooked - about four minutes should be the maximum. You will end up with a runny yolk but a fully cooked but non-rubbery white. The yolk will be covered all over with a delicate white.



</answer>



<answer from>



SayWhat?

Drive by the chicken farm late at night.  Shine the henhouse with your million-candle-power spotlight.  Use your 22 mag to shoot the chickens off their roost and steal the eggs.  Don't let the gamewarden see you.



Seriously though, I have trouble boiling them directly in water like most people are suggesting.  I prefer to spray a little pan in a shallow cereal bowl (earthenware is best) and crack an egg or two in there, then put the bowl in a skillet of boiling water and cover a few minutes until the egg is at desired doneness, then scrap out of bowl onto plate for eating.

Eddie

</answer from>



<answer>



To all those people saying use really fresh eggs - Don't.  You shouldn't use any eggs less than a day old, as the whites of these eggs really spread themselves out during cooking.



The same goes for frying and boiling - the white of really fresh eggs spreads all over the pan, and when boiled the white sticks to the shell making them hard to eat.



Unless you have your own hens I wouldn't worry about this though!



</answer>



<answer from>

Source(s):

<answer from>



J
Member since: 17 May 2008
Total points: 6416 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



New York Cheesecake !!!
And this is a great recipe for it!!
You have to try it!!



15 graham crackers, crushed



2 tablespoons butter, melted



4 (8 ounce) packages cream cheese



1 1/2 cups white sugar



3/4 cup milk



4 eggs



1 cup sour cream



1 tablespoon vanilla extract



1/4 cup all-purpose flour



Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9 inch springform pan.



In a medium bowl, mix graham cracker crumbs with melted butter. Press onto bottom of springform pan.



In a large bowl, mix cream cheese with sugar until smooth. Blend in milk, and then mix in the eggs one at a time, mixing just enough to incorporate. Mix in sour cream, vanilla and flour until smooth. Pour filling into prepared crust.



Bake in preheated oven for 1 hour. Turn the oven off, and let cake cool in oven with the door closed for 5 to 6 hours; this prevents cracking. Chill in refrigerator until serving. Serves 12.
==============



</answer>

<question>



How many cups of water do i use per cup of rice that i want to make?



i want to make a half cup of rice



</question>



<answer from>



Toffy
Member since: 06 October 2007
Total points: 11758 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Most varieties of rice use the 1 to 2 ratio. 1 cup Rice to 2 cups Water. Some varieties use just a bit more water. If you have regular long grain white rice then it is the 1 to 2 ratio.



For the 1/2 cup rice, use 1 cup water and a dash of salt. It still takes about 20 minutes to cook covered.
Minute Rice is equal amounts of rice and water. We are thinking you are asking about regular long grain rice. Or the regular 20 min rice.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



yep, regular long grain jasmin rice. thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



hambone
Member since: 19 April 2006
Total points: 10836 (Level 6)



</answer from>

then use 1 cup of water.... 2 parts liquid to1 part rice.



Oh, you want to make only 1/2 cup of COOKED rice? Still, 2 parts water (1/3 cup) to 1 part rice (1/6 cup)



</answer>

<question>



2 questions about CAKE FROSTING?



First: I am looking for a good, FLUFFY, cake frosting recipe. I have found many, but none of them seem to look like what you would see in a store-bought cake !?!!? It even possible to make a nice frosting like that?



Second: I found this one recipe, will it make a fluffy frosting?, and is it possible to use splenda instead of the powdered sugar? They are both light.  http://www.cooks.com/rec/view/0,176,1301...



</question>

<answer from>



Colby

<answer>



You can try using Splenda, but I find it doesn't really taste the same as sugar. You can try doing half-sugar/half-Splenda if you really wanted to but you may as well go all out if you're making a cake.



</answer>



<answer from>



WeddingC...
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The thing with frosting recipes is - you never follow the recipe exactly, for example the milk is added as needed until you get the desired consistency.  The ingredients for this recipe look pretty good, and basic - what I would usually see for a chocolate frosting recipe.  Though I haven't tried this one myself.



For finding recipes, I really like the the website allrecipes.com  Other users can give reviews, post pictures of what they have made, rate the recipe, and give tips on how to improve it.



Here is a search for chocolate frosting:



http://allrecipes.com/Search/Recipes.asp...



You can put them in order by rating so you only see the good ones.  Read the reviews to see what others have said about how the recipes have come out, I'm sure you'll find one that suits your needs!



Edit:



Also, I would not substitute splenda.  Powdered sugar and splenda have very different textures, and it would certainly effect how the frosting comes out.  Though substituting a portion of the sugar with splenda, and mixing the two together well prior to including them in the recipe can have okay results.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



ED
Member since: 16 January 2008
Total points: 4668 (Level 4)

Stefanie

<answer>



I used to ice cakes, the frosting used was made with lard. I used several frosting recipes and haven't found one as good. I am happy with a simple ganache (equal part of baking chocolate and heavy whipping cream). Sometimes when using Splenda in a recipe that has to cook or bake it doesn't turn out, because the sugar alcohol evaporates during the baking process.



</answer>

<answer from>



shellks

<answer>



Give stuff away



Splenda is better calorie wise. But no matter, make a batch and give at least half of it away. Take it to work. Send it to work with someone else. Make friends with your neighbors. Who doesn't like someone that gives/brings them cookies or cake??



Put individual portions into baggies and freeze. Most baked stuff freezes very well.



Source(s):



I love to bake, but don't like sweets. I keep all my family and freinds in cookies and treats. It makes my teen sons crazy when I give it away. But if I left it here, they would eat most of it and let the rest go to waste, knowing they would have more in a day or two. I've got lots of happy neices and nephews...and neighbors!



</answer>

<answer from>



chicko_3
Member since: 09 February 2007

<answer>



Use self rising flour. Add water and stir until the flour mix is not too runny, thick but smooth. Pre heat your pan with a little dob of butter or margarine. Lace your pan with butter or margarine by wiping off the excess fat with paper towel. Then pour some mix on the pan with simmer heat. Turn your pancake when you see bubbles forming. Your pancake will be ready in a few seconds. Enjoy.

<answer from>



granny.r...
Member since: 23 November 2007
Total points: 13198 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



Packed lunch.
I liked the old fashioned meals my mom used to make for my lunch;
Here is a good one;
Bread Fritters;
Go to the bakery section of the store where you normally buy bread.
Ask the baker for an "unbaked" loaf of bread.
He must put exactly the same amount of dough he would have used to bake a bread with in to a plastic bag for you, and it would cost no more than a loaf of bread.



Take that home and in a pot warm some cooking oil to about half the depth of the pot. (Smaller pots take less oil than bigger ones do)...
The oil temperature should be medium hot. (About half the heat that the stove plate will go)



Now cut from the unbaked dough a slice about the size of your palm, and with a little water on your fingers (to prevent the dough from sticking to your hand), stretch out the dough in all directions until it is about the size of your whole hand including the fingers. That brings the cutting of dough to about twice the size it was when you cut it....



Now with care, drop the stretched out dough in to the hot oil.
It would rise almost instantly.
Fry it in the oil until it is golden brown all over, taking care to turn it over occasionally.
It would be puffy and crisp when done.



With a large ladle or sieve, scoop out the bread fritter and place on an absorbent kitchen towel to rid it of most of the oil still on it.
Repeat this process until all the dough is done.



These bread fritters are extremely filling, and can be cut open and filled with almost anything from grated cheese to minced meat to cold processed meat, syrup or jam.
Try it, you will probably have some left over for two or three days, which you can take to work if you like....
Bread fritters can be frozen and warmed up again if you have made too much, but the dough cannot, so rather make the whole lot and freeze what is left over for another day. If you decide to freeze them, do so without a filling. Fillings should always be made fresh.
Finger snack variety;



By making the bread dough cutting about half the size when cutting off the raw dough from the batch, you can make smaller sized bread fritters and fill them with fancy foods like tuna mince or savory beef mince for buffet snack parties



</answer>



<answer from>



Shell
Member since: 06 November 2007
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My little girl is in p1 and loves school dinners i also use to enjoy them!!!



</answer>

<question>



150 grams and 250 grams in baking powder?



Can you please tell me how much 150 grams and 250  grams are in baking soda. Thanks!!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



To change grams to ounces divide by 30  (30 grams = 1 ounce)
(actually 28.8 grams but unless you are doing scientific work 30 is close enough)
150 divided by 30 = 5 ounces  you can do the rest



</answer>

<answer from>



old know all
Member since: 13 April 2006
Total points: 55120 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Before you cook the spaghetti (or any pasta), add about 10ml (2 teaspoons) of olive oil to the boiling water.  It floats on the top and coats the pasta as you put it in.  If you're going to serve it with a sauce, when it's cooked drain off the water and add the sauce to the pasta in the pan.



</answer>



<answer from>



The Trickster
Member since: 12 September 2007
Total points: 549 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Whilst it is cooking add some olive oil to the pan this sits on top of the water and coats the spaghetti as you drain it.  It also enhances the flavour of the spaghetti.  That should solve your problem.  Also over cooking the spaghetti can cause this problem to be worse than if you under cook it.  Spaghetti when ready can be thrown at a wall and should stick initially then fall off after a short time.



Source(s):



Gordon Ramsey offered me a job.  Ex Chef!!!



</answer>

<answer from>



STEVE S
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 3184 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Add a tablespoonful of olive oil to the pan of boiling water before you put the spaghetti in. Use a large pan with plenty of water and a small handful of salt, bring the pan back to the boil quickly after adding the spaghetti. Stir as soon as the spaghetti begins to soften.



To completely prevent sticking, stir a little more oil into the spaghetti after draining. Oil infused with basil also adds to the flavour.



Be careful when serving, if you're not, the spaghetti can slide off the plate very easily.



</answer>

<answer>



oil in the water is a false statement however many short order cooks do it anyway....



the best way is once the pasta has hit the boiling water stirrup the pasta  for the first minute or so with out stopping and then continue to stir it well very often until the pasta is done...then run cold water over it until it's completely cooled...then lightly drizzle with olive oil...and toss...



reason when the dry pasta hits the water the first 5 to 45 seconds is when its going to stick because the starch becomes gluey at first that's what makes it stick..mainly



</answer>

<original file>1.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk20001.txt</current file name>




<category>



Food & Drink



Cooking & Recipes



</category>



<question from>



Carrot's
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 210 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What's the best, tastiest, pudding?



What is the best pudding?
There's a very special event coming up and my family has persuaded me to make the pudding. It shall be very interesting! I need advice on what to make and the recipe to make it. Any recipe's will be appreciated!
Thanks!



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks everyone! There's so many delicious pudding's here that I think I'm going to have to make more than one!



</additional details>



<answer from>



UKTV Food
Member since: 07 August 2008



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Being a boy, my favourite pudding has got to be a good old fashioned treacle sponge. The recipe below is really easy and will bring a tear of nostalgia to the eyes of your guests.



If the occasion calls for something a bit more decadent, you could try this recipe for Chocolate Truffle Pudding. http://uktv.co.uk/food/recipe/aid/513315



We have a top ten English pudding recipe page on our website, as well as 980 other puddings for you to look through. http://uktv.co.uk/food/homepage/sid/5896



Treacle Sponge Pudding



Serves: 4 Prep: 15 min, plus 5 mins chilling



Cook: 1 hr 30 min



Ingredients
2 tbsp golden syrup, plus extra for serving
115g plain flour, sifted
1 1/2 tsp Baking powder
2 large Eggs
115g brown sugar
75g margarine
25g unsalted Butter
1 tbsp Brandy
clotted cream or custard, for serving



Method 1. Generously butter a 900ml pudding basin. Place the buttered pudding basin into the fridge for 5 minutes to firm up the butter.



2. Once cooled, remove from fridge and add the golden syrup to the base of the basin.



3. In a large mixing bowl, place the flour, baking powder, eggs, brown sugar, margarine, unsalted butter and brandy and mix together thoroughly.



4. Spoon the flour mixture into the basin, over the golden syrup.



5. Take a large piece of tin foil, fold it in half and grease one side thoroughly.



6. Cover the pudding with the greased tin foil, pleating the foil a few times to allow room for the pudding's expansion.



7. Fasten the foil to the rim of the pudding basin with string.



8. Place the covered pudding basin in a large steamer.



9. Steam over a medium heat for 1 hour 30 minutes. Make sure that the steamer does not boil dry, topping up with boiling water as needed.



10. Once the pudding is risen and cooked, turn it out from the pudding basin. Serve with golden syrup and clotted cream or custard.



I hope you find the one you want,



Michael.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

archie
Member since: 10 March 2008
Total points: 1348 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bourbon Sauce for Bread Pudding and Bread Pudding Soufflé
Ingredients
3 large eggs



3 large egg yolks



1 cup sugar



1 teaspoon vanilla extract



1 tablespoon bourbon (optional)



Directions
1
In a medium bowl or the bowl of your electric mixer combine eggs, yolks and sugar, whisk to combine.
2
Place your mixing bowl over a pan of hot water over low heat and stir continuously until it reaches 165°F.
3
I like to start the water off at well below the boiling point and slowly raise the temperature until it's just shy of boiling.
4
Do not whisk this mixture too much at this stage or you will incorporate too much air and take too long to heat.
5
If water starts to boil or you see steam coming off your mixture remove from the heat for a few seconds and whisk.
6
Getting this mixture too hot will cause eggs to cook.
7
After desired temperature is reached, use the whip attachment for your electric mixer and beat on high speed until thick and cooled to just warm to the touch.
8
Beat in vanilla and optional bourbon, serve ASAP.
9
The mixture will keep in the fridge for a day or so before it starts to separate.
10
Variations: Use rum, flavored liqueur or various extracts in lieu of bourbon.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jay p
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 515 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try chocolate trifle and thanks for using 5 point to hear our opinions.



Ingredients



45 g brownie mix
9 g instant chocolate pudding mix
10 ml water
1/8 (14 ounce) can sweetened condensed milk
20 g frozen whipped topping, thawed
30 g frozen whipped topping, thawed
4 g chocolate candy



DIRECTIONS



Prepare brownie mix according to package directions and cool completely. Cut into 1 inch squares.



In a large bowl, combine pudding mix, water and sweetened condensed milk. Mix until smooth, then fold in 8 ounces whipped topping until no streaks remain.



In a trifle bowl or glass serving dish, place half of the brownies, half of the pudding mixture and half of the 12 ounce container of whipped topping. Repeat layers. Shave chocolate onto top layer for garnish. Refrigerate 8 hours before served.



</answer>



<answer from>



Flo
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 171 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Trifle is quite impressive and relatively easy to make although it can take a while...here is a recipe...enjoy!
Line a large bowl with slices of swiss roll. You could soak these in sherry if you like but I'm not into that. Use a tin of your favourite fruit or fresh, this is best. I usually like using raspberries, strawberries and blueberries.Spread fruit over sponge. Make up jelly (flavour to match fruit if possible, I like raspberry or strawberry), using drained juice of tinned if used. Let cool and pour over fruit and sponge. It tends to float a bit. Let set in fridge for about an hour.



Put a layer of cooled custard on top, I use ready made. Then top with whipped cream and decorate with whatever you fancy, choc drops, fruit, candy...be creative!!



Oh yea and if possible use a glass bowl so you can see all the layers!



</answer>

SPICY HOT CHILI



1 lb. ground beef
1/4 c. chopped onion
Chopped green pepper
1 (12 oz.) can Hunt's tomato sauce
1 (1 lb.) kidney beans
2 tsp. chili powder
3 tbsp. Durkee red hot cayenne pepper sauce
3 tbsp. Louisiana gold pepper sauce



Brown ground beef, onions and green pepper. Add tomato sauce, kidney beans and remaining ingredients. Cook 30 to 45 minutes in electric fry pan with cover off until thick.



</answer>

<answer>



How about chilli tiger prawns with salad?



Ingredients:
2 chillies
Some cooked tiger prawns
Bell peppers
Oliveoil
Chilli seeds
Salad
Plain vinaigrette
Tabasco
Chilli powder



Cut the bell peppers into strips and mix with the salad
Chop up the chillis into tiny little pieces, as small as you can get
Put the prawns in a bowl, mix with the little bits of chilli and some chilli seeds.
Mix the olive oil, a few teaspoons of vinaigrette, some drops of tabasco, some chilli powder. Mix
Mix the chilli oil/vinaigrette with the prawns
put on the salad
Use any of the leftover chilli oil/vinagrette on the rest of the salad.



</answer>

<answer>



Zebra Marshmallow Cups Recipe



White chocolate, dark chocolate, cookie crumbs, and marshmallows make a black and white layered zebra candy. What's not to love? No-bake zebra candy cups are easy to make and great for gifts.



* 12 ounces Hershey's Cookies & Cream Nuggets, unwrapped



* 2 cups (about) mini-marshmallows



* 2 Tbsp shortening



* 1 ounce paraffin



* 3 cups semi-sweet chocolate chips



* 1/2 cup finely crushed chocolate cookie wafers
Line mini-muffin tins with muffin papers.
In a double-boiler, melt butter and white chocolate Nuggets, stirring to avoid scorching, until combined. Remove from heat.
Spoon about 1/2 teaspoon of melted white chocolate into each mini-muffin cup. Press 3 miniature marshmallows into each cup.
Clean double-boiler and dry thoroughly. (One drop of water will make the chocolate seize.) Place shortening and paraffin in double-boiler and melt. Add chocolate chips 1 cup at a time to melt, stirring until all are melted and smooth. Remove top from double-boiler and place on a trivet or heat-proof pad. Mix in cookie crumbs. Spoon melted chocolate mixture into cups to cover marshmallows. When trays are full, tap gently on the counter to force chocolate down and around the marshmallows.
Refrigerate zebra candy cups at least 4 hours before serving. Keep leftovers refrigerated.
Yield: 4 dozen candy cups



Smashed Bugs Candy Recipe



They sort of look like smashed bugs, but they are really bites of pure heaven. These crunchy chocolate caramel candies are easy to create for parties, bake sales, gifts, and Halloween.



* 2 cups (about) square snack pretzels



* 1 package (12 ounces) Rollo® chocolate-covered caramel candies



* 8 (about) large marshmallows, each cut into 8 pieces



* 1 cup (about) pecan halves
Preheat oven to 300 F. Line baking sheets with Silpats or parchment paper.
Place pretzels in rows 1 inch apart on lined baking sheets. Top with chocolate caramel candies. Place marshmallow on top. Bake for 3 minutes only. Immediately place pecan half on top of each and gently press down so all layers stick together.
Let cool. (May refrigerate to set chocolate.)
Cover and store in a cool place or refrigerate. If you refrigerate, let the candies stand at least 15 minutes at room temperature to soften up a bit. Best served at room temperature.
Yield: about 56 candies



</answer>



<answer from>



Jessicα m-s
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 991 (Level 2)

<answer>



PEANUT BUTTER FUDGE OREO COOKIE PIE



1 Keebler ready-made Oreo pie crust
1 (4oz) box instant French vanilla pudding mix
1 cup cold milk
3-4 tablespoons creamy peanut butter (or more if you like)
1 jar chocolate fudge sauce (Smuckers or Dove)
1 regular container Cool Whip (thawed)



Have pie crust ready. Carefully spread/frost the bottom and sides of pie crust with fudge sauce (if really thick microwave for a few seconds). You won't need to use the whole jar.
In a bowl, blend instant pudding and 1 cup milk using a whisk.



Using an electric mixer, add the peanut butter (mixture will be thick). Spoon onto the fudge layered pie crust.



Top with Cool Whip. Garnish with any Oreo crumbs from the pie crust.



Refrigerate.



This is so quick and easy but everyone thinks it takes a long time because of the taste. Doesn't last long at events.



ENJOY!



</answer>



<answer from>



kiwi
Member since: 27 November 2006
Total points: 6363 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



dark chocolate creme brulee



Servings: Serves 8.



Ingredients
2 cups whipping cream
2 cups half and half
8 ounces semisweet chocolate, finely chopped
8 large egg yolks
1/3 cup plus 8 tablespoons sugar PreparationPreheat oven to 300°F. Bring cream and half and half to boil in heavy large saucepan. Reduce heat to low. Add chocolate and whisk until melted and smooth. Remove from heat. Whisk yolks and 1/3 cup sugar in large bowl to blend. Gradually whisk in hot chocolate mixture. Strain.
Divide custard among eight 3/4-cup custard cups. Place cups in large baking pan. Add enough hot water to pan to come halfway up sides of cups. Bake until custards are set, about 50 minutes. Remove from water; chill 2 hours. Cover and refrigerate overnight.



Preheat broiler. Sprinkle each custard with 1 tablespoon sugar. Broil until sugar turns golden, watching closely to avoid burning, about 3 minutes. Refrigerate until custards are set, 1 to 2 hours.



</answer>
