<answer>



It's like a whipped filling of chocolate and cream, in desserts like cakes and truffles.



</answer>



<answer from>



Val
Member since: 09 August 2006
Total points: 3766 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ganache is normally made by heating heavy cream, then pouring it over chopped, dark chocolate. The mixture is stirred or blended until smooth, and can be enhanced with liqueurs or extracts. Depending on the kind of chocolate used, cream should be adjusted to reach desired consistency.



Ganache can also be used in filled chocolates, chocolate truffles, and other desserts. The portions of chocolate to cream vary depending on the intended usage of the ganache. Typically, a ganache is equal parts chocolate and cream; this is used for filling cakes. For a chocolate truffle base, twice as much chocolate as cream is used. For making a glaze, one should use three times as much chocolate as cream. Ganache can also be allowed to cool and whipped to increased volume and then spread to cover a cake.



Ganache is said to originate from a culinary accident, whereby a chocolatier's apprentice spilled cream in the chocolate he was melting. The chef called the apprentice 'Ganache', a word meaning, figuratively, 'fool'. The result was delicious, and the name stuck.



</answer>



<answer from>



funkucla...
Member since: 18 November 2006
Total points: 2297 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its a mixture of cream and melted chocolate. mix it together so its ribbon stage and ur able to use it on top of cakes or as fillings or inside tart crusts.



Source(s):



Myself, i graduated culinary school le cordon blu 4 years ago.



</answer>



<answer from>



Been There~Done That!
Member since: 23 May 2006
Total points: 103540 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Family



</answer from>



<answer>



Ganache is a rich mixture of chocolate and cream which can be used as a frosting or filling. Depending on the intended use, different ratios of chocolate to cream are used, to create anything from a light glaze to a dense standalone truffle. Although ganache is remarkably rich and luxurious, it is extremely easy to make, and it is well worth adding to one's baking repertoire, in the opinion of this wiseGEEK writer.



The evidence suggests that ganache was developed in the mid-1800s, although both France and Switzerland claim the credit for the invention. In either case, ganache quickly spread into European dessert making. To make ganache, heavy cream is brought to the boiling point and then poured over chunks of chocolate. The mixture is stirred so that the chocolate melts, and the result is a dense chocolate cream. Adding butter or oil to the ganache will make it highly glossy, as is sometimes desirable for frosting. Liqueurs and other flavorings can be added as well, if desired.



If the cook uses one part cream to every three parts of chocolate, the result will be a chocolate glaze which can be used like a chocolate frosting. This glaze can be rather elegant, and is is especially popular for tortes and other rich chocolate dishes. As it cools, the ganache will become more stiff, but it can easily be reheated, if needed. The addition of small amounts of coffee or orange can also radically change the flavor profile, if desired.



Using one part cream to two parts of chocolate yields a very rich, dense chocolate filling which can be used in truffles and other candied desserts. This version of ganache can also be lightly rolled in cocoa powder and served plain, like a truffle. For a lighter filling, the ratio is one to one. This type of ganache is good for layering in cakes and similar desserts.



Different types of chocolate yield various styles of ganache, from bittersweet to white. As a general rule, it is a good idea to use high quality chocolate, since the ganache is so simple that cheap chocolate will mar the flavor. Especially when the ganache is being paired with a rich, luxurious cake, this cheapness can become glaringly obvious. If you are glazing a cake with ganache, try adding ornaments like marzipan flowers for extra elegance, or dust the cake in cocoa powder for more visual texture.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jessicα m-s
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 991 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<question>



How to make Spanish ham?



I had this ham from a Spanish restaurant the other day and it was great. I wanted to know if anyone knew how to make it.I was able to pick up on some ingredients like cinnamon, whole cloves, pineapple, sugar, does anyone know the full recipe?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



True Spanish ham is made by curing particular types of pig leg.  The type of pig determines the "grade" of ham.



Unless you're up getting a raw pig leg and curing it, this is not something to do at home.



</answer>

<original file>11251.html</original file>

<question from>



cityanco...
Member since: 31 March 2007
Total points: 164 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How should I be cooking these vegetables?



I had this couscous at a restaurant and it was really great and I'm trying to re-create it. I know how to easily make the couscous but what I'm concerned about is how I'm going to make the vegetables.
The vegetables she used were:
Potatoes
Zucchini
Carrots
Celery



I have all of them but they came out very nice and soft and I'm not sure how to do that.. should I boil them? I don't want them TOO soft.



And I feel like putting only vegetables on top of couscous would come out very plain, which spices should I add for more flavor?



</question>



<answer from>



PJ
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 18214 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, precook the veggies and pre spice them.  I don't know what spices were in the couscous you ate at the restaurant, I would use onions, garlic, salt and pepper and any other spice you like.  You could boil the veggies, but they would be better sauted in butter with the other seasonings, then added to the couscous.  Couscous only cooks for 5 minutes or so, you could cook the veggies to almost done, then add them to the couscous and cook the two together.  That will help flavor the couscous.  Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lana
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 2839 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



1st, make your couscous with chicken stock (or vegetable stock) instead of water.



Do you like curry?
I would curry them.



Get some RED CURRY PASTE in the store -- usually near the Thai foods.



_________________________________
Peel and dice the potatoes.  Put them in a pot of cold water and bring it to a boil.  Boil for 10 minutes then pour them into a strainer & let them dry off a little (maybe lay out on some paper towel).
Dice up your zucchini, carrots, celery, and some onion too.  I'd also use a little chopped garlic.



In a skillet, put about 3T canola oil and heat with 2 large spoonfuls of the red curry paste.  Stir and heat on medium then put in all of the veggies and potatoes.  Stir/toss to combine with the curry paste oil.  Cook on low/medium for about 10 mins to soften the veggies, stirring often.  Sprinkle with 1 T brown sugar and continue to stir.



Personally, I'd add in about 1/4 cup coconut milk to the veggies and stir.



Serve the veggies tossed with the couscous.



</answer>



<answer from>



kiwi
Member since: 27 November 2006
Total points: 6369 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can steam the veggies, then add them and spice with coriander, salt, pepper, curry, onion powder, cumin and nutmeg.



</answer>

1 pound sweet Italian sausage

<question>



Leg of lamb for a party?



I am looking for a method to cook a leg of lamb to medium and serve hot. Problem is that we are going to a game before people come to our house and eat. I would like to serve the leg of lamb medium and warm, but will be gone for 4 hours before we have to eat.



I was thinking caterers must be used to reheating the leg of lamb. What do they do? Can I precook the leg of lamp to rare and reheat it when we get back? How do I make sure that the meat is safe to eat and that it is medium and juicy - not being around for 4 hours?



</question>



<answer from>



Leafsfan...
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 10560 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If your oven has a timer, just set the oven to come on at a specified time.  Most modern stoves have this option.



Failing that...you could cook it at a very low temperature (200-250) for a long period of time, and then bump it up when you get in (depending on the internal temperature).



</answer>



<answer from>



thrombus...
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 248 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why don't you do spoon lamb and then you won't have to worry about keeping it medium.



http://www.recipezaar.com/281177



Mid rare lamb is nice, but it seems like a hassle with the time constraints.



</answer>

<answer from>



RSJ
Member since: 01 July 2007
Total points: 10561 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the best is apple pie with some vanilla ice cream.



This one has been around forever under so many different names- it's a classic and delicious



Orange Sunshine Cake



INGREDIENTS
1 (18.25 ounce) package yellow cake mix



4 eggs



2 (3.5 ounce) packages instant vanilla pudding mix



1/2 cup vegetable oil



2 teaspoons orange extract



1 (11 ounce) can mandarin orange segments undrained
1 (12 ounce) container frozen whipped topping, thawed



1 (8 ounce) can crushed pineapple, drained



DIRECTIONS
Combine cake mix, eggs, 1 package of pudding, vegetable oil, orange extract, and mandarin oranges and beat well for about 3 minutes.



Bake in 3 - 9 inch greased and floured round cake pans for 20-25 minutes in a pre-heated 350 degree oven.



To Make Frosting: Mix by hand pudding and pineapple into whipped topping.  Let frosting sit in frig for at least an hour.



- - - - - -



Easy and reduced-fat / calories



No-Bake Lemon Cheesecake
Light & Tasty



This dazzling dessert is a dieter's delight. A light and refreshing alternative to classic cheesecake, the slim sweet calls for gelatin and lower-fat cheeses. Eva Wright, who sent the recipe from Grant, Alabama, recommends, "Vary the gelatin and pie filling flavors to suit your family's taste."



Ingredients:



1 whole reduced-fat graham cracker, finely crushed, divided
1 package (.3 ounce) sugar-free lemon gelatin
2/3 cup boiling water
1 package (8 ounces) reduced-fat cream cheese, cubed
1 cup (8 ounces) 1% cottage cheese
2 cups reduced-fat whipped topping
1 cup reduced-sugar cherry pie filling



Directions:



Coat a 9-in. springform pan with cooking spray.  Sprinkle half of graham cracker crumbs on the bottom and 1 in. up the sides of pan; set aside.  Dissolve gelatin in boiling water; cool to room temperature.



In a blender, combine the gelatin mixture, cream cheese and cottage cheese; cover and process until smooth.  Transfer mixture to a bowl; fold in whipped topping.  Pour into prepared pan.



Sprinkle with remaining graham cracker crumbs. Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or until set. Carefully run a knife around edge of pan to loosen, then remove sides of pan. Garnish with pie filling. Yield: 8 servings.



- - - - - -



Simple and very yummy!



Ooey Gooey Cake



* 1 (18.25-ounce) box yellow cake mix
* 1 egg
* 1/2 cup (1 stick) butter, melted



Filling
* 1 (8-ounce) package cream cheese, softened
* 2 eggs
* 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
* 1 (16-ounce) box confectioners' sugar
* 1/2 cup (1 stick) butter, melted



Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Lightly grease a 13x9x2-inch baking pan.



In the bowl of an electric mixer, combine cake mix, egg, and butter and mix well. Pat into the bottom of prepared pan and set aside.



Still using an electric mixer, beat cream cheese until smooth; add eggs and vanilla. Dump in confectioners' sugar and beat well. Reduce speed of mixer and slowly pour in butter. Mix well.



Pour filling onto cake mixture and spread evenly. Bake for 40 to 50 minutes. Don't be afraid to make a judgment call on the cooking time, because oven temperatures can vary. You want the center to be a little gooey, so don't bake it past that point!



Remove from oven and allow to cool completely. Cut into squares.



Happy cooking!



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



RSJ

Total points: 10561 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The dry parsley is better than going without.  It's strange that parsley is in a marinade.  Parsley doesn't really impart a flavor to marinades-  the liquids and onions and garlic impart most of the flavor.



</answer>

<answer from>



Night S
Member since: 31 May 2007

<answer>



Definitely don't go without. Contrary to what one person said earlier dry parsley isn't as song as fresh chopped up parsley. With some herbs that is true that its stronger however that's not the case with parsley. I don't know how much your recipe calls for but I probably wouldn't do more than 1tsp of the dried parsley. I wouldn't have any worries about it not being fresh though because it will be plumped up by being in your marinade and having the soaking time.



</answer>



<answer from>



dee k

<answer>



Many people swear by fresh herbs & i am one of them,however cannot see why you should go without when you have the dry one handy,as already suggested dry herbs need to be used sparingly.
I love gardening & have some choice potted herbs,so nice to pick your own fresh herbs.I grow both the flat & curly leaf varieties .Flat is flavoursome & best for cooking,curly besides cooking makes a fancy garnish.



Source(s):



gow them mostly from seed,parsley is slow to germinate.

<original file>12191.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk22438.txt</current file name>




<category>



Food & Drink



Cooking & Recipes



</category>



<question from>



Nadia R
Member since: 24 August 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Recipe for Los Burritos bean & cheese burrito?



I used to go to Los Burritos in Los Angeles and they had the BEST bean and cheese burritos... I don't live there anymore! :-(



Does anyone know their recipe so I can make it at home?  Or does anyone know of a super-amazing bean and cheese burrito I can make at home?  I know it may sound silly, but I am seriously craving it.  Thanks!!!



</question>



<answer from>



Lana
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 2850 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Make your own!



Sweat some diced onion in a pan with a little canola oil, add in 1 can refried beans, 1 can whole pinto beans - rinsed and drained (if you can find them), 1 tsp. cumin, 1/2 tsp. salt, 2 T your fave salsa and a dash of hot sauce.  Stir and heat thoroughly on medium heat.  Mash up the whole beans a little with a fork, or omit them.



Put the bean mixture in a large flour tortilla with shredded mexican blend cheese.



Fold thoroughly like a burrito and stick in the microwave for about 45 seconds.



</answer>

Member since: 15 January 2008
Total points: 19146 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question from>



seerakin...
Member since: 20 February 2007
Total points: 196 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Diabetic Christmas cookies and/or cakes?



My boyfriend's mother is diabetic and his father is on a diet. Are there any cookie recipes or cake recipes I can use? I'm doing this as a Christmas present for them.



</question>



<answer from>



Susakins Makoozakins~
Member since: 11 November 2007
Total points: 42111 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Apple Raisin Cakes -- These look like fat pancakes. hehe



INGREDIENTS



2 eggs, beaten



1 cup applesauce



1 teaspoon ground cinnamon



2 teaspoons white sugar



1 cup all-purpose flour



1/2 cup whole wheat flour



2 teaspoons baking powder



2 teaspoons vanilla extract



1/2 cup raisins



DIRECTIONS
In a large mixing bowl, combine eggs, applesauce, cinnamon, sugar, flour, baking powder, vanilla, and raisins. Form small cakes out of the batter.



Heat a nonstick griddle over medium heat, fry the cakes until both sides are browned, about 5 to 7 minutes.



^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^...



Diabetic Oatmeal-Raisin Cookies --



Ingredients
1 cup self-rising flour



1/2 cup butter



2 tablespoons white Splenda granular



2 tablespoons milk



1 1/2 cups quick oats



1 egg



1/4 teaspoon cinnamon



1/3 cup splenda brown sugar substitute



1/2 teaspoon vanilla



1/2 cup dark raisin



Directions
1) Preheat the oven to 325 degrees.



2) Mix the flour with the cinnamon.



3) Cream the butter and both the sugars until fluffy. Add the egg, milk, and vanilla. Gradually add the flour mixture.



4) Stir in oats and raisins.



5) Drop by teaspoonfuls if small cookies are desired, tablespoons if larger cookies are desired onto parchment paper (this stuff is reusable - one sheet will do the whole batch).



6) Bake until golden brown, 10-12 minutes. Cool on wire racks.



^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^...



Diabetic Chewy Molasses Ginger Cookies Recipe --



nonstick cooking spray



1/3 cup margarine, softened (not spread or tub product)



1/3 cup Splenda brown sugar blend, packed



1 teaspoon baking soda



1 teaspoon ground ginger (or to taste)



3/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon (or to taste)



1/4 cup Egg Beaters egg substitute



1/4 cup dark molasses



1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour



1/2 cup whole wheat flour



1/4 cup Splenda granular



1 teaspoon ground cinnamon



Spray cookie sheet with nonstick spray; set aside.



In a large mixing bowl, beat the margarine with an electric mixer on medium to high speed for 30 seconds.



Add the brown sugar, baking soda, ginger, and 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon; beat until combined.



Beat in Eggbeaters and molasses.



Beat in as much of the all-purpose and whole wheat flour as you can with the mixer.



Stir in any remaining flour with a wooden spoon.



Cover and chill in the refrigerator for 1 hour.



Shape dough into 1-inch balls.



Combine the granulated Splenda and 1 teaspoon cinnamon.



Roll balls in Splenda-cinnamon mixture.



Place 2 inches apart on prepared cookie sheet.



Bake in a preheated 350F oven for 10 to 11 minutes or until set and tops are cracked.



Remove from cookie sheet.



Cool on a wire rack.



Makes about 4 dozen.



~~~Here is 21 more recipes that are all DIABETIC recipes. They are in order from 5 star rating to Not yet rated~~~~



http://www.recipezaar.com/recipes.php?q[...



(I'm looking too - my father is Diabetic)



Source(s):



HAPPY COOKING AND RECIPES!!!!



</answer>

David H
Member since: 09 August 2006
Total points: 51044 (Level 7)



Contributing In:

Ethnic Cuisine



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



You can make all your Xmas baking with "Splenda" both the white and brown for baking it cooks and measures like sugar, I use it and know one know the difference, I should mention I am a diabetic and was a professional chef for 20+ year internationally.



You can even make shortbread with it but use it with either cornstarch or rice flour to make the cookies, I also use unsalted butter, sugar is not the most critical issue with a diabetic, both carbs and fat are a no-no to when looking at a recipe for things.



</answer>

<answer from>



BizzyLiz...
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 605 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Layer the macaroni with sliced tomatoes. The top layer is tomatoes drizzled with olive oil.
Add chopped ham or bacon bits.
Add thyme and parsley to the cheese sauce.
Add a splash of Worcestershire sauce to the cheese.
Replace a quarter of the cheese with blue cheese.
Make sure the top goes really crispy and crunchy by putting it right at the top of the oven.
Use different shapes of pasta.
Add mustard powder to the cheese sauce.
Add a little horseradish to the cheese sauce.



Endless fun!



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 28 September 2007
Total points: 865 (Level 2)

Here's website with different mac&cheese's. From Reuben mac&cheese to quesdilla mac& cheese

<question>



Pie question how do I squeeze it in a cup?

I set the alarm for about 10:30 p.m. to put it in the refrigerator, however, I fell asleep and for some reason the alarm never went off.  I woke up at about 5:00 a.m. to put it in the refrigerator.



Since the recipe has the cream cheese, sour cream, eggs, etc., is it ok to eat and serve to others?  Or do you recommend tossing it?

<question from>

<question>



How can i bake a jacket potato that is fluffy inside?



A bit like fluffy mash potato in a jacket potato..



uk



</question>



<answer from>
Member since: 15 January 2008
Total points: 19168 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



steam it in microwave



</answer>



<answer from>



ezzy
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 216 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



microwave for 10 mins or more depending on size then wrap in tin foil and bake in the oven for a while.
then take out of tin foil and bake if you want crispy skin



</answer>



<answer from>



Marvinat...
Member since: 16 June 2006
Total points: 25882 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Poke holes in the potato with a fork, inserting it at least half way into the potato.



Wrap the potato in Plastic Wrap, making sure to seal all ends.



Microwave on high for 8 - 10 minutes.



The peal should slide off (but can be eaten too).



</answer>



<answer from>



steve j
Member since: 16 August 2007
Total points: 2170 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Make sure you use a russet potato which has a lower starch content and then blend in some milk and butter when it is done



</answer>

<question from>



oo0rache...
Member since: 08 May 2008
Total points: 348 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



I have this rump roast 4.5 pounds and needed to know what temp, how long, and how much water ?



i'm cooking it in the oven.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



roast at 400 degress for 30 min then lower to 350 and roast it for 20 min a pound



no water needed for roast beef - if making pot roast out of it
brwon meat in heavy duty pan, add veggies cover with water and season it
cook it for 3-4 hours to get tender meat



</answer>

leeplus3

<answer>



That's such a personal question.  I love peppers and eggs.  In fact I had it today.  I also love potatos and eggs and here's how you make them:



cut and deseed 1 whole (green/red/yellow - doesn't matter) pepper then julienne it.  Fry in oil till crisp cooked.  While frying mix 2 eggs w/ little milk (just like for scrambled eggs).  When peppers are done remove from oil and remove most of the oil from the pan, return pan to heat, return peppers to pan, add egg mixture on top and make like your making scrambled eggs.  Serve on crusty Italian bread and salt to taste (just a little).  Enjoy.



Potatos and eggs - same as above substituting the potato for the pepper.  I like this with a little ketchup and salt on it.  Enjoy!



</answer>



<answer from>



megtrose
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 458 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Chicken and Apple



Take any kind of GOOD quality bread. Preferably ciabatta, foccacia or other panini style. Sourdough also works.



Spread with regular mayonnaise, or look for a flavored one. One with a little pesto is delicious. You can also use a cranberry chutney for this.



Add sliced chicken, thinly sliced apple, and brie cheese. You can toast this or eat as it. It is my Favorite sandwhich.



Source(s):



16 Years in the kitchen



</answer>

<answer>



Chicken in Bernaise sauce. If it is just the two of you you could go with 2 or 3 chicken breast. Get two packages of Bernaise sauce and a package of sliced mushrooms. You will need a pretty big pan like a soup pan. First mix your packages of Bernaise by following the recipe on back of package and you will double it of course since you are using two packages. Bring to a boil and add almost whole package of fresh sliced mushrooms. Unless you don't like them then you could probably leave them out. Add your chicken and let cook until chicken is no longer pink. As for sides you could cook some fresh cut asparagus, or just go with some corn on the cob. And maybe some salad or whatever else you like.

<original file>13429.html</original file>

</category>



<question from>



Marie B
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Does anybody know of an easy recipie for an electric fan oven to make plain scones(ones without raisons etc)?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingriedients:



225g self-raising flour



40g butter



150ml milk



1.5 tbsp caster sugar



pinch of salt



Method:



Heat the over to gas mark 7, (220 C / 425 F).



Sift flour into a bowl and add the butter.



Rub the butter gently into the flour until it resembles bread crumbs.



Add the salt and sugar.



Slowly mix the milk in using a metal spoon to form a soft dough.



Knead the dough with your hands to bind it.



Roll out the dough so it's about 2cm thick.



Use a 4cm pastry cutter to cut the little scones out.



Keep reforming and cutting until all the dough has been used.



Place the scones, with a little dusting of flour on top, onto a greased baking sheet and put into the oven.



Remove the scones after 12-15 minutes and cool on a wire rack.



Enjoy with butter, cream and/or jam.



Or:



350g/12oz self-raising flour
1½ tsp baking powder
pinch of salt
40g/1½oz caster sugar
75g/3oz unsalted butter, slightly softened
1 tsp freshly grated lemon zest
175ml/6fl oz milk
flour, for dusting
or 1 small egg beaten with ½ tsp sugar, for brushing



Method:



1. Preheat the oven to 220C/425F/Gas 7.
2. Sift the flour, baking powder and salt into a bowl, then stir in the sugar. Add the butter and rub it in, giving a texture of fine breadcrumbs, then stir in the lemon zest. Gradually add the milk and mix to give a soft smooth dough, kneading lightly with floured hands. If the dough fells a little dry, add a drop more milk.
3. On a lightly floured surface, roll out the scone mixture to 2.5cm/1in thick. Using a 7.5cm/3in plain or fluted pasty cutter, press firmly through the dough, trying not to twist the cutter or you'll end up with a little flour for a matt finish, or brush wit the beaten egg and sugar fro a shiny glaze.
4. Bake in the oven for 12-15 minutes until golden and nicely risen. Once cooked, place on a wire rack to cool slightly. These scones are definitely best served still warm from the oven with lots of melting butter or strawberry jam and sticky clotted cream.



Tip
If you prefer plain scones, just leave out the lemon zest but do try it for a change as the lemon is really refreshing with the strawberry jam and cream.
For a fruit scone, add 75g/3oz sultanas to the mixture before adding milk. Orange zest or lemon.



Enjoy!! and good luck!! :)



Source(s):



http://www.bbc.co.uk/food/recipes/databa... and http://www.robertprice.co.uk/robblog/arc...



</answer>

<answer>



a beef or pork roast, on low setting, with a packet of lipton french onion soup mix, a couple dashes of worcheshershire sauce, pepper, herbs, potatos, carrots and onions. super simple, super delish.



You could also do short ribs, on low setting, with a cup of BBQ sauce and a dash of liquid smoke.



Another idea is chicken and rice. cook the chicken in the crock pot until almost done in some chicken broth, then add instant rice, a can of brocolli cheddar condensed soup, and some chopped frozen brocolli.  Make sure you remove enough of the broth so that the end result wont be too soupy.
When it is almost done, add shredded cheese.



</answer>

<answer>



If you want something a little different I've made a Thai stew. I've done it the oven and crock pot.



use mixed fresh veggies usually you can find premixed at the grocery store in a bag like:



broccoli
cauliflower
pea pods
carrots



1 package of sliced mushrooms
1 diced onion



1 can water chestnuts



then add 1 can coconut milk and 2 tablespoons red curry paste



I've also added potatoes before, and have made it with chicken or tofu



</answer>



<answer from>



cowgirl_...
Member since: 14 January 2008
Total points: 9677 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Crock Pot Chicken Salsa Curry



10 chicken thighs-bone in
1 jar of your fav salsa
1/2 onion chopped
1 tablespoon curry (or about 1/2 if you don't like a strong curry taste)
1/2 cup sour cream



Place the chicken in the crock pot. Mix the onion, curry and salsa. Pour over the chicken and cook on low for about 6-8 hours.



When the chicken is done take it out of the crock pot and put on a serving plate. Add the sour cream and mix well. Spoon the sauce over the chicken.



This would go well with rice or cous cous.
--------------



Mexi-rice:



Use rice that is still warm.



Heat a skillet or griddle pan to a med-low heat. Add the rice and your favorite salsa, some olives, corn and ground cumin. (A great salsa to use would be the kind in the plastic tubs in the produce section, I think it's labeled as "Fresh Salsa" but El Paso or whatever would work as well.)



Instead of pre-made salsa make your own using roma tomatoes chopped small, red onions, chopped cilantro, minced garlic, finely chopped jalapeño pepper, adding some lime juice, and garlic salt. Then toss this fresh salsa in with the rice and cumin, olives, and corn.



Serve hot and I like mine with just a sprinkle of melted cheese.....yumm!!!



You will most liekly have left overs so youcan cut the recipe in 1/2 or use the left overs in a chicken quesadilla with grilled onions, and bell peppers. Or mix it in with some left over rice, and also toss into a chicken tortilla soup.



</answer>



<answer from>



Proud Mommy
Member since: 27 April 2007
Total points: 6919 (Level 5)



</answer from>

http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Kathys-Roas...

Raspberry icing



2 cups powdered sugar
1 pinch of salt
1/4 cup fresh raspberries, crushed
2 teaspoons lemon juice



Mix together, add a little red food coloring to give it a nice color.

<question from>



Ramzi K
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do we manufacture Charcoal Briquettes?



How do we manufacture Charcoal Briquettes?
Ingredients?
detail of Process?
Presses needed?



Thanks a Million



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Its actually pressed wood remnants (mostly wood shavings and saw dust).



Today they use multiple ton hydraulic presses and the moisture in the wood and the pulp hold the briquette together.



Source(s):



Saw it on "How It's Made"



</answer>

<category>

<question>



Is it safe to cook scrambled eggs in the microwave?



</question>



<answer from>



Ask the Chef
Member since: 11 July 2006
Total points: 3667 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Research from a German scientist show that the electromagnetic field from microwave rays are not healthy.  As far as food safety you can cook an egg, but the long term effects by using a microwave along with all the other crap in our world (pollution ect.) can lead to illness later in life.



Source(s):



Cures they dont want you to know about.- Kevin Trudeau



</answer>



<answer from>



B0uncing...
Member since: 31 August 2006
Total points: 3647 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes you can, but doing scrambled eggs in the microwave requires split-second timing to get them right.  So always keep checking and stirring them.



</answer>



<answer from>



tracy
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 9239 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes.  Crack your egg into a glass bowl, add a little milk, salt and pepper, stir a little, then cook in microwave for about 30 seconds, check and stir, then cook for about another 15 - 20 seconds.



</answer>

<answer>



Wagon Wheel Beef Stew



Use vegetables on hand for this tasty slow-cooked beef stew. The condensed beef broth keeps it flavorful, and the wine adds a little zing. If you don't have the wine, more beef broth or water will work fine.



* 1 1/2 to 2 pounds stewing beef, cut in 1/2 to 1-inch cubes



* 2 to 3 medium potatoes, cubed



* 1 medium turnip, cubed



* 1 cup sliced carrots



* 1/2 cup chopped onions



* 1/4 to 1/2 cup sliced celery



* 1/2 to 1 cup sliced mushrooms



* 1/2 cup butter beans or lima beans



* 1 can (10 1/2 ounces) condensed beef broth



* 1/4 cup red wine



* 1/2 teaspoon salt



* 1/4 teaspoon pepper



* pinch thyme



* 3 tablespoons flour blended with 1/4 cup water



* 1/2 cups frozen mixed vegetables, corn, or peas, optional



In slow cooker, combine beef, potatoes, turnip, carrots, onions, celery, mushrooms, butter beans, beef broth, wine, salt, and pepper. Cover and cook on LOW for 9 to 12 hours, or on HIGH for 5 to 6 hours. Add thyme and frozen mixed vegetables, corn, or peas, thawed, if using. Pour liquids into a medium saucepan and simmer to reduce slightly. If desired, skim off excess fat. Add the flour and water mixture and simmer until thickened. Add back to vegetables and continue cooking on LOW until serving time.
Serves 6.



</answer>

<question from>



marie.le...

</question from>



<question>



What to do with leftover egg yolks?



I've got some friand pans and need some recipes to use up some of the egg yolks I am going to have left.



tia



</question>



<additional details>



I am making friands, which are a small cake, they use lots of egg whites but no yolks.  I am looking for recipes that use lots of yolks so I don't waste them.
Thank you to those who answered my question seriously.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Apples to Apples
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 14534 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



AIOLI MAYONNAISE
Makes: 1 cup
4  garlic cloves, peeled, chopped fine
2 egg yolks
1/8 teaspoon sea salt
1 cup virgin olive oil
1 teaspoon Dijon mustard
1/2 teaspoon cold water
1 teaspoon lemon juice



I N S T R U C T I O N S



Add the garlic and salt to the mortar bowl and grind slowly with the pestle, moving in one direction only.  You can do this first step in a food processor if you'd like, then transfer the mixture back to a medium sized bowl. Whisk in  the mustard first, then the egg yolks. At this point you can transfer the mixture back into the mortar or use the whisk in the bowl.



Now you will add in half of the oil.  This must be done very slowly or the oil will not emulsify and your sauce will not thicken.  Add the oil in a slow, fine stream while either whisking with a wire whisk or using your pestle.  Once the first half of the oil is incorporated, then add the water and the lemon juice, and mustard,



whisking or stirring constantly with the pestle. Then slowly add the rest of the oil.  The mixture will thicken as you continue to blend it. The mixture should be slightly thinner than commercial mayonnaise.  If it becomes too thick you can add a bit more warm water, one teaspoon at a time.



ZABAGLIONE RECIPE
8 large egg yolks
1 cup confectioners' (powdered) sugar
1/2 cup of dry Marsala (or Sherry)



I N S T R U C T I O N S



Place the egg yolks and the sugar in top of a double boiler and place on top of the bottom of the boiler. The water should be lightly boiling and the should not be touching the bottom of the top of the boiler. (You can also use a bowl over a large pot of boiling water. )



Use a wire whisk and whip the mixture until it is foamy.  Then add the Marsala and continue to cook the mixture until it has doubled in volume Use an instant-read thermometer to insure the mixture has reached 140°F.  Beat the mixture for additional minute or two.



Serve the zabaglione immediately.  This dish looks quite elegant served in long stemmed wine or parfait glasses.



FREEZE THEM!
Tips For Storing or Using Left Over Egg Yolks



Store Individually - Egg yolks need to be stabilized before freezing or the thawed product will be pasty and hard to mix. For best results store the yolks pre-measured according to future use. If the yolks will be used for sweet or dessert recipes, add 1 tablespoon of sugar or honey per pint of yolks.  If the yolks will be used for savory recipes add 1 teaspoon of salt per pint of yolks.  The stabilized yolks may be dropped,  one egg yolk in each section of a ice cube tray and frozen.



Remove the egg yolk cubes and store in a freezer style zip-lock bag.



Thawing Frozen Yolks - All the yolks to thaw in the refrigerator for about 8 to 10 hours.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you for the great ideas.  I love aioli and I didn't even know you could freeze egg yolks!



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Poach some salmon and make hollandaise sauce.



1/2 cup butter



3 large egg yolks



1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon of lemon juice



1/8 teaspoon salt



dash cayenne pepper or hot pepper sauce



2 tablespoons hot water



finely chopped fresh parsley, if desired



Heat butter in a heavy saucepan until hot and foamy, but not browned. In a small bowl, whisk or beat egg yolks with lemon juice, salt, and cayenne pepper or hot sauce. Gradually beat in butter, then water. Return mixture to saucepan and beat over very low heat until mixture is slightly thickened. Serve immediately or let stand over warm water for up to 30 minutes. If desired, sprinkle with chopped fresh parsley before serving.
Makes about 2/3 cup of hollandaise sauce.



</answer>



<answer from>



mamamia

<answer>



Egg Yolk Cookies



Ingredients
1 cup butter (or shortening for cookies that won't spread quite as much)



1 1/2 cups sugar



6 egg yolks (or 3 whole eggs)



2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour



1 teaspoon baking soda



1 teaspoon cream of tartar



1 teaspoon vanilla extract



1/2 teaspoon lemon extract



1/2 teaspoon orange extract



Directions
1Cream butter and sugar until fluffy.



2Separately, beat egg yolks and add extracts.



3Add beaten egg yolk mixture to creamed butter and sugar.



4Blend well.



5In a separate bowl, whisk together dry ingredients (flour, baking soda and cream of tartar).



6Add dry ingredients to creamed butter, sugar and egg mixture, mixing until well blended.



7Form into balls about the size of a walnut.



8Roll balls in sugar, place on greased cookie sheet or parchment lined cookie sheet, and slightly flatten.



9Bake at 350 degrees F for 8 to 10 minutes, depending on desired cookie



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Make homemade pasta.  2 cups of flour a tsp. of salt and a little water worked together with 4 egg yolks to form a dough.  Knead for 5 minutes on a floured surface.  Roll thin and cut in strips with a knife or pizza cutter and cook in boiling water until tender.

<question>



I want to make vegetable soup but I'm not  sure.......?



if I should make it with chicken/beef broth or tomato sauce. I also want to make it with green beans, potatoes, corn, maybe butter beans or kidney beans basically just garden veggies. So what do yall think, broth or sauce? Thanks



</question>



<additional details>



Oh I always put almost overwhelming amounts of seasonings! I'm from the south so thats how I was taught! I especially love garlic!



Oh yeah and should I use hamburger meat or stew meat or what? Thanks!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Confused
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hey, i'm a chef, so maybe i can help ya. Honestly, you could use both. I would use chicken broth and tomato sauce. Season your veggies when cooking them, add chicken or vegetable broth, then add a thick tomato sauce like a marinara slowly until you get the desired richness and consistancy. Always add a little at a time, and taste as you go. And simmer, not boil, for about an hour to let the flavors marry. Hope i helped!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



mykal2me
Member since: 07 February 2006
Total points: 194 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



.Hi I was a culinary student for 3 years at the Culinary School of Washington in DC. Even though I have not run any big expensive Restaurants I have cooked for a few wealth people and done a number of parties and I was also a banquet Chief at Dave and Busters restaurant. I would use Chicken stock if i used a meat stock but other wise I would make a veg. stock with some veggies that i love the most especially the mushrooms.  I would also try it both ways with the tomato sauce and with just including tomatoes in my veggies for the stew. As far as the beans I don't see a why you cant use the Green beans in the last fifteen minutes of cooking the stew so they don't get really discolored. I would cook my beans like kidney beans (In with turkey necks) separately so I can get them tender with out over cooking all of my other veggies. As far as my spices, would place them in a bag. Or Cheesecloth and tie them up with a string to the handle of the pot so that i can remove them at the end of the stew. That bag would have the Thyme, Basil, marjoram, garlic and whole cracked peppers in it. Salt it to taste and serve



Source(s):



Matha Stewarts cooking and, The cooking club of america



</answer>

<answer>



When I make vegetable soup I use stew meat.  I cook the meat first.  Then add a bag of mixed vegetables, onion, potatoes, beans, whatever sounds good that I have, and a couple of cans of stewed tomatoes.  Top it off with enough water for the consistence you want, remembering that it will cook down.



I suppose it depends on what you like in your soup.



It will be delicious however you make it.  Just add your own seasonings and simmer for the flavors to blend.
Enjoy!



</answer>

<question>



Do you have a diabetic recipe for chili?



</question>



<answer from>



fishinea...
Member since: 01 August 2006
Total points: 39666 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Chili
2 pounds stew beef, cubed into bite sized pieces



1 large sweet onion



2 jalapenos, seeded and minced



1/2 (4 fluid ounce) bottle mesquite flavored liquid smoke



2 heads garlic, minced



1 (14.5 ounce) can diced tomatoes with jalapenos



2 (15 ounce) cans chili flavored beans with jalapenos



1 (14.5 ounce) can red kidney beans



1 (14.5 ounce) can tomato sauce with garlic and onions



1/2 cup SPLENDA® Brown Sugar Blend



Hot pepper sauce, to taste



Combine beef, onions, jalapenos, liquid smoke and garlic in a slow cooker.  Cook on low for 6 hours. After 6 hours, add the tomatoes, chili beans, kidney beans, tomato sauce, SPLENDA® Brown Sugar Blend to the beef. Add hot pepper sauce if desired. Cook for an additional 2 hours.  Taste the chili after 2 hours to determine the need for additional SPLENDA®Brown Sugar Blend or hot pepper sauce.



Garnish with diced jalapenos, chopped and shredded onions, and cheese if desired.



nfd♥



</answer>



<answer from>



Ana P
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 209 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



5-Way Cincinnati Chili
(makes 8 servings)



1 1/2 pounds ground sirloin



2 medium onions, chopped



1 celery ribs, chopped



4 large cloves; garlic, minced



2 tablespoons good-quality chili powder



1 tablespoon paprika



1/2 teaspoon crushed dried basil



1/2 teaspoon crushed dried oregano



1/2 teaspoon crushed dried thyme



1 teaspoon ground cinnamon



1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper



1/2 teaspoon ground cumin



1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes



1/4 teaspoon ground allspice



salt (optional)



freshly ground pepper



2 14 1/2--ounce cans no-salt-added diced tomatoes with their juice



1 8-ounce can no-salt-added tomato sauce



1/2 to 1 cup water



12 ounces dried thin spaghetti



condiments



1 cup chopped onion



1/2 cup low fat shredded cheddar cheese



1 cup drained dark red kidney beans



In a large nonstick pot, brown ground sirloin, onion, celery, and garlic over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until beef is browned and vegetables are limp, about 10 minutes. Drain off and discard all fat.



Stir in chili powder, paprika, basil, oregano, thyme, cinnamon, cayenne pepper, ground cumin, red pepper flakes, and allspice.



Season with salt (if using) and pepper to taste.



Stir in tomatoes and tomato sauce. Add 1/2 cup water, adding additional water as needed to reach desired consistency. Partially cover and simmer for 30 minutes.



Transfer chili mixture to a freezer container and freeze until firm or cover and refrigerate overnight.



When ready to serve, defrost chili and reheat on the stove for at least 15 minutes while you cook the spaghetti, following package directions, to al dente. Drain the spaghetti and keep warm.



Place the chopped onion, shredded cheese, and kidney beans in small serving bowls.



To serve, divide the hot spaghetti between 8 shallow soup bowls. Ladle hot chili over each serving and pass the condiments separately to spoon onto each serving.



Per serving: 401 calories (22% calories from fat), 29 g protein, 10 g total fat (3.6 g saturated fat), 50 g carbohydrates, 6 g dietary fiber, 32 mg cholesterol, 376 mg sodium



Diabetic exchanges: 2 1/2 lean protein, 3 1/2 carbohydrate (2 1/2 bread/starch), 3 vegetable)



Source(s):



http://www.diabetic-recipes.com/recipes/...



</answer>



<answer from>



annie
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 630 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



3/4 lb. ground beef
1/4 c. chopped onion
1 c. cooked spaghetti; optional
1 qt. tomato juice
1/4 tsp. chili powder
1 c. kidney beans
Salt and pepper to taste



Brown beef and onion; drain. Add the rest of ingredients and simmer 20-30 minutes. This is a diabetic recipe. If cheese is used, count as a meat exchange.



</answer>

<question>



I want to make some wholegrain bread and I have some ripe bananas to use up - is it ok to put them in?



</question>



<answer from>

<answer from>



annie
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 630 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



QUICK WHOLE GRAIN BANANA BREAD



This recipe uses a lot of whole grains, but it will turn out excellently if you use all-purpose flour in place of any or all of the whole grains. Also, any of the whole grains are interchangeable with any of the other whole grains in the recipe.



1/2 c. butter
1 c. sugar
2 eggs, slightly beaten
1 c. mashed banana (3 med.)
1 c. flour
1/2 tsp. salt
1 tsp. soda
1/4 c. whole wheat flour
1/4 c. oat bran
1/4 c. wheat bran
1/4 c. wheat germ
1/3 c. hot water
1/2 c. chopped walnuts



Preheat oven to 325 degrees. Melt butter. Blend in sugar. Mix in beaten eggs and bananas, blending until smooth. Sift flour, salt and soda. Stir in whole wheat flour, brans and wheat germ. Add alternately with hot water. Stir in nuts. Bake in a loaf pan 1 hour and 10 minutes.



</answer>






<original file>3180.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk26063.txt</current file name>




<category>



Food & Drink

</category>



<question from>



Koter Boters luvs Duke and Koter
Member since: 25 May 2007
Total points: 4460 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



How do you make beef stew?



Every time I make it, It seems soupy not stewy.



</question>



<answer from>



Dune
Member since: 27 May 2007
Total points: 76420 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



Yahoo! Answers



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Stew.
Cut the beef into bite sized pieces, and trim away fat.
Brown the beef in a fry pan in a little oil, in batches and transfer to a heavy based pot. (preferably)
Fry off the onions and garlic and deglaze the fry pan with a little water.
Add the onions and garlic to the meat.
If the soup mix is powdered sprinkle over meat and onions and stir to combine.
Stir in more water until in covers the meat completely.



Add seasonings, S&P, Worcestershire sauce and bring to the boil.
Reduce and simmer for 45 minutes, on the lowest heat on an element.
Check water level and stir from time to time
Add carrots celery and chopped potatoes and crushed tomatoes and juice.
You may need to top up the level of water and stir to combine.
Bring to the boil and simmer gently for about 20-30 minutes, or until the potatoes and carrots are cooked.
Check seasonings once again, and if necessary thicken.



Serve.
(You could put everything into a casserole dish and cook in oven, but I prefer stove top)
I omit the potatoes so I can boil and mash, to mop up the gravy.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



chef_ren...
Member since: 13 January 2008
Total points: 5319 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I love Beef Stew, but my recipe is a family classic so I won't give it out, respect for my Mother, Grandmother and Great Grandmother, sorry. But, I can tell you some hints, flour your Beef roast before you sear it and add a little tomato paste about 2 hrs. into your cooking time. Obviously, the flour will create it's own thickening process and the tomato paste will also do this and bring all of your flavors together with that little added something to your Beef Stew. Cutting your additional veggies a little larger might also give you a stewy look as apposed to a soupy stew, because the longer cooking time of the Beef Stew will break down your celery, carrots and onions quicker if they are too small.  So, that's it, sorry I can't tell you the exact process, but if still need some more help, email me and I can give you some more hints.  Good luck and happy cooking, hope I've helped you out today.



</answer>



<answer from>



NannaKan...
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 795 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



In a large dutch oven (if you have one. use a skillet if you don't.) Rinse and then dredge the beef cubes in seasoned flour, shake off excess, brown on all sides in oil in skillet or dutch oven.



Place meat in bottom of dutch oven, or in a large pot with a lid. Add frozen stew veggies, or use fresh chopped celery,carrots, pearl onions, potatoes.



Add just enough liquid to cover. Bring to a boil, then simmer, covered, about 1 hour. (For the liquid, you can use beef broth, or water, but if you use water, you might wanna add a packet of lipton soup mix (maybe onion soup, or beefy mushroom, whatever you like.)



The flour from the beef cubes should thicken the "gravy" on it's own, along with the starch from the potatoes. Hope this helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



Wedge - The Envy of all Corellia
Member since: 10 July 2007
Total points: 42501 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



This is one of my favorite beef stew recipes:



OLD FASHIONED BEEF STEW



Ingredients
1/4 cup all-purpose flour



16 ounces beef stew meat, cut into 3/4-inch cubes



2 tablespoons cooking oil



2 tablespoons butter
1 medium onion, cut into thin wedges



2 15-ounce cans of seasoned diced tomatoes
6 beef bouillon cubes - I like to use Knorr



4 cups water
1 1/2 tablespoons Italian seasoning
1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes
1/4 teaspoon black pepper



3 cups cubed potato (about 3 medium)



1-1/2 cups frozen cut green beans



1 cup frozen whole kernel corn



1 cup sliced carrot (2 medium)



OR in place of the above frozen veggies and carrots, use 2 16-ounce bags of frozen mixed vegetables



Directions
Place flour in a plastic bag. Add meat cubes, a few at a time, shaking to coat. In a large saucepan or Dutch oven brown meat, left over flour and onions in hot oil and butter. Stir in diced tomatos plus 1/2 can of water from each can, water, bouillon cubes, Italian seasoning, red pepper flakes, pepper and potatoes. Bring to boiling; reduce heat. Simmer, covered, for 1 to 1 1/4 hours or until meat is nearly tender.



Stir in green beans, corn, and carrot or mixed vegetables. Return to boiling; reduce heat. Simmer, covered, about 30 minutes more or until meat and vegetables are tender.



Slow-cooker directions: Prepare and brown meat as above. In a 3 1/2- or 4-quart slow cooker layer meat, onion, potatoes, green beans, corn, and carrot. Decrease vegetable juice to 2 cups. Combine vegetable juice, water, Worcestershire sauce, bouillon granules, Italian seasoning and pepper. Pour over meat and vegetables in slow cooker. Cover and cook on low-heat setting for 10 to 12 hours or on high-heat setting for 5 to 6 hours or until meat and vegetables are tender.



I like to serve my stew with fresh hot biscuits or hot corn bread or crusty French bread.



WA



</answer>



<answer from>



busybake...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 167 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There so many ways to make beef stew. The basic method is below:



1) Purchase stew beef (or cut chuck or round steak into cubes)
2) I usually cut the purchased stew beef into smaller cubes for ease of eating
3) Heat a couple tablespoons of vegetable oil (your favorite) in a Dutch oven or deep saucepan
4) Brown the beef cubes on all sides until well caramelized
5) Add water or beef broth to the beef cubes
6) Add frozen stew vegetables to the mixture
7) Season with salt, pepper and other favorite spices such as garlic, bay leaves, etc.
8) Cover and let simmer for a couple hours until the beef is tender
9) Make dumplings and add to stew, if desired



Note: Can use fresh veggies such as potatoes, onions, carrots, celery instead of frozen stew veggies



busy baker
List owner:  CozyCookingNewsletter
To Subscribe:  CozyCookingNewsletter-subscribe@yahoogro...



</answer>

<question>



What's a good crab cake recipe?



</question>



<answer from>



annie
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 640 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



CRAB CAKES



1 lb. crabmeat
1 egg, beaten
1 1/2 tbsp. Old Bay seasoning
2 tbsp. Dijon mustard
2 tbsp. shallots
2 tbsp. chopped parsley
1 tbsp. lemon juice
2 tbsp. mayonnaise
Approx. 20 crushed saltine crackers
1 stick butter



LIME BEURRE BLANC:



6 tsp. white wine vinegar
2 tbsp. shallots
3 tbsp. fresh lime juice
1/2 c. heavy cream
1 stick unsalted butter, cut into sm. pieces



Put all ingredients in mixing bowl and mix thoroughly. Make sure there is enough saltines to give it body. Using hands, take out desired amount and shape into patties. Using a non-stick frying pan melt butter and saute crab cakes approximately 5 minutes on each side. Do not burn. Serve with any of the following sauces.
Lime Beurre Blanc, fresh lemon, lemon-dill sauce, mustard-caper, burnt butter.



For Sauce: Put vinegar, shallots and lime juice into saucepan. Over high heat reduce to approximately 2 tablespoons. Add cream and reduce for approximately 5 minutes. Remove from heat and whisk in the butter 1 piece at a time. Serve over crabcakes.



Serves 4-6.



</answer>

<answer from>



JulieT
Member since: 10 January 2008
Total points: 320 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients
Serves 4
5 saltine crackers, crushed to fine crumbs



1 pound lump crabmeat, picked over for cartilage



1 large egg



2 1/2 tablespoons Mayonnaise



2 teaspoons freshly squeezed lemon juice



1 1/2 teaspoons Worcestershire sauce



Dash hot sauce, such as Tabasco



Coarse salt and freshly ground pepper



3 tablespoons peanut oil, vegetable oil, canola oil, or even just Pam
Horseradish Tartar Sauce



Directions
In a large bowl, gently mix together cracker crumbs, crabmeat, egg, mayonnaise, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce, hot sauce, salt, and pepper. The mixture will be wet. Form about 1/4 of the crab mixture for each cake.



Heat oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium heat. Gently slide the cakes off a spatula into the oil. Saute until the crab cakes are golden brown and cooked through, about 5 minutes on each side. Remove from skillet, and drain on paper towels. Serve hot with tartar sauce.



Source(s):



Martha Stewart's website, and I've tried them, they're VERY good.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tacy
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 4502 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



This is FANTASTIC and YUM!!! Trust me!!



2 tablespoons olive oil



6 green onions, chopped



3/8 cup olive oil



1 (6 ounce) can canned crab meat, drained



1 egg



1 tablespoon mayonnaise



1 teaspoon dry mustard



8 ounces buttery round crackers, crushed



1/2 teaspoon ground cayenne pepper



1 teaspoon garlic powder



1/4 teaspoon Old Bay Seasoning TM



salt to taste



ground black pepper to taste



1 cup dry bread crumbs



Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a skillet over high heat. Saute green onions briefly until tender; cool slightly.



Combine crab meat, sauteed green onions, egg, mayonnaise, dry mustard, crushed crackers, cayenne pepper, garlic powder, Old Bay seasoning, salt and pepper. Form into 1/2 inch thick patties. Coat the patties with bread crumbs.



Heat 1/2 cup oil in a skillet over medium high heat. Cook cakes until golden brown on each side. Drain briefly on paper towels and serve hot. Serves 4.
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^



</answer>



<answer from>



Been There~Done That!
Member since: 23 May 2006

Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes

</answer from>



<answer>



CRAB CAKES



2 slices firm white sandwich bread
1/2 lb jumbo lump crabmeat, picked over
2 Tbsp mayonnaise
1/2 tsp Worcestershire sauce
1 large egg, beaten
2 Tbsp unsalted butter



Tear bread into small pieces into a bowl with crab. Add mayonnaise, Worcestershire sauce, 2 Tbsp egg (discard remainder), and a pinch of salt. Mix together gently but thoroughly, then form into 4 patties (about 3 inches in diameter).



Heat butter in a 12-inch heavy skillet over medium heat until foam subsides, then cook crab cakes, turning once, until golden brown, about 6 minutes total.



Serve with: french fries and/or baby greens tossed with lemon vinaigrette.



</answer>

<question>



Simple slow cooker pot roast recipe?



what kind of roast do i buy, how to prepare, etc.



</question>



<answer from>



annie
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 640 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



SLOW COOKER POT ROAST



1 rump or shoulder roast
2 cans cream of mushroom soup (use the garlic variety for one of the cans if possible)
1 can water
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 1/2 teaspoons salt
1/2 teaspoon pepper
1 teaspoon basil
1 teaspoon oregano
6 small, red or golden potatoes cut into quarters
½ onion diced (if you don't have onions, use 1 tsp onion powder)
3 cups chopped carrots
3 cups mushrooms, whole or chopped



Set slow cooker on low. Chop onions. Remove any larger pieces of fat from roast. Add roast, water, soup, herbs and spices, and onions to slow cooker and let simmer for 4-6 hours. After 3-5 hours, add the rest of the vegetables.
Let simmer for 1-2 hours and serve. A lot of this is by your preference; herbs and seasonings may be increased or decreased, if desired.



</answer>



<answer from>



tracy
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 9243 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't really have a "recipe", but this is how I do it.  I purchase a 3 - 4 pound chuck roast, bone in is good and adds more flavor.



Start by browning your roast in olive oil over medium high heat.  Once your roast is browned on both sides, transfer to the slow cooker.  Peel and quarter about 4 medium sized potatoes, peel and slice into large chunks about 6 - 7 carrots.  Open a bag of dry onion soup mix and sprinkle all over the top.  Add a few splashes of Worcestershire sauce, 4 cups of hot water, put the lid on and turn your slow cooker to low.  Let cook and simmer for 8 - 10 hours.



Remove your roast and vegetables, strain your liquid into a saucepan, heat over over medium high heat.  In a jar with a lid, place 3 heaping tablespoons of cornstarch and add 1/4 cup cold water.  Put lid on jar and shake well.  Pour this mixture into the pan with your roast liquid very slowly while stirring with a whisk.  Continue stirring and cooking until mixture get bubbly and thick.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tacy
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 4502 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



This is an AWESOME one!!! And very easy to make...



2 (10.75 ounce) cans condensed cream of mushroom soup



1 (1 ounce) package dry onion soup mix



1 1/4 cups water



5 1/2 pounds pot roast



Serves 12.



In a slow cooker, mix cream of mushroom soup, dry onion soup mix and water. Place pot roast in slow cooker and coat with soup mixture.



Cook on High setting for 3 to 4 hours, or on Low setting for 8 to 9 hours.



^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^



</answer>

<answer from>



weirdfis...
Member since: 25 January 2008

<answer>



It adds an interesting zip...probably especially good with chocolate. Also, the acid in the buttermilk probably means there is less baking soda in the recipe, which can reduce any bitter aftertaste.



Try it and see.

<answer from>



Guess Who
Member since: 13 June 2008
Total points: 1213 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients you need are:



2 sheep's hearts
basic herb stuffing
2 oz (50 g) soft lamb or mutton fat
butter for greasing
250 ml any strong stock
1 tbsp plain flour (All purpose)
salt and pepper



method
1. Prepare the hearts. Dry thoroughly and fill with the stuffing.



2. Skewer or sew together the thin flaps at the top to hold in the stuffing.



3. Heat the fat in a small baking tin and put in the hearts.



4. Baste well, and bake them in a moderate oven, 180°C, Gas 4, for 1 hour for sheep's hearts, 45 minutes for lamb's hearts.



5. Baste them several times during cooking.



6. When cooked, transfer them to a warmed serving dish, remove the skewers, if necessary, and keep hot under buttered greaseproof paper.



7. Drain most of the fat from the tin but keep any meat juices.



8. Blend a little stock into the flour to make a paste.



9. Mix the paste into the pan juices, then gradually stir in the remaining stock.



10. Heat to simmering point, stirring all the time, and simmer until thickened. Season well.



11. Pour a little of this gravy round the hearts and serve the rest in a warmed sauce boat.



Goodluck



</answer>

Total points: 139 (Level 1)

<question from>



Dark Angel
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 12819 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



How do i cook a pot roast in the oven'?



How do i cook it in the oven without  the seasoning bag for baking' and at what temperatures.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Start by browning your roast in olive oil over medium high heat. Once your roast is browned on both sides, transfer to roasting pan. Peel and quarter about 4 medium sized potatoes, peel and slice into large chunks about 6 - 7 carrots. Open a bag of dry onion soup mix and sprinkle all over the top. Add a few splashes of Worcestershire sauce, 2 1/2 cups of hot water, seal well with heavy duty aluminum foil.  Bake in 325 degree oven for 5 - 6 hours.



Remove your roast and vegetables, strain your liquid into a saucepan, heat over over medium high heat. In a jar with a lid, place 3 heaping tablespoons of cornstarch and add 1/4 cup cold water. Put lid on jar and shake well. Pour this mixture into the pan with your roast liquid very slowly while stirring with a whisk. Continue stirring and cooking until mixture get bubbly and thick.



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk26743.txt</current file name>

Food & Drink

<question from>



SARA J
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What meals can i do with chicken?



i need some meal ideas for chicken, i do a roast chicken dinner which th children loves bt what other meals can i do with it please help. my children are 19 months and 3 years old



</question>



<answer from>



sissy
Member since: 19 November 2006
Total points: 2376 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Chicken pot pie, chicken and dumplings



</answer>



<answer from>



annie
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 644 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



BISCUIT CRUST CHICKEN PIE



3-4 cups chicken broth
3 large potatoes, quartered
3 carrots, sliced
2 stalks celery. sliced
3 cups cooked chicken, cubed
1 3-4 lb chicken
1 sweet onion, chopped
1 tablespoon olive oil
3/4 stick sweet unsalted butter
1/3 cup flour
1/4 teaspoon thyme
1/4 teaspoon sage or bell seasoning
1/8 teaspoon nutmeg
1/4 cup minced fresh parsley leaves
5 cloves fresh garlic, chopped



BISCUIT DOUGH FOR THE CRUST:



1 1/3 cup flour
1 1/2 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon baking soda
1/3 cup buttermilk
1/2 teaspoon salt
5 tablespoon butter, sliced thin
1/3 cup sharp cheddar, grated
1 egg



In saucepan melt butter, add olive oil and chopped onion. Fry on high heat for 2-3 minutes. Add herbs, vegetables and garlic and fry 2 more minutes then remove from heat. Stir in flour and blend with fork. Return to heat and slowly add broth, mixing with wire whisk until smooth. Simmer on low heat until vegetables are nearly tender but not mushy.
For the crust, stir baking powder, soda and salt into flour and mix well. Cut cold butter (you can freeze it for best results) into flour mixture until only chunks the size of walnuts remain. Add cheese. (A nice addition is to add some chopped fresh rosemary to the crust but this is optional). Beat the egg with the buttermilk and stir into the dough. Gather the dough into a ball, place in the refrigerator in a plastic bag for 10-15 minutes to rest. This prevents gluten from developing.



It's important not to overwork the dough or you will cause it to become tough. Roll dough out on board to 1/2 inch thick. Cut out rounds of dough with a 2-3 inch biscuit cutter.



Put cooled chicken mixture in deep dish casserole. Place rounds of biscuit dough until chicken mixture is covered. Brush top with milk or cream.



Bake at 425 degrees F for approximately 20-25 minutes or until golden brown.



Optional: Use Pillsbury flaky biscuits (from a tube) as a substitute when in a hurry.



</answer>



<answer from>



mmm food
Member since: 09 March 2008
Total points: 984 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<answer>



I made a really good, quick and easy chicken casserole last night that gets rave reviews. You need...
a rotisserie chicken
a can of cream of chicken soup
a can of water chestnuts
a bag of celery
a sleeve of Ritz crackers
some slivered almonds
1/2 stick of butter
Preheat oven to 375. Cut up celery in small bites and cook with 1/4 stick of butter for 5-10 minutes. Pick apart chicken and put in bowl. Mix can of soup, water chestnuts, and the cooked celery in with the chicken. Transfer to baking dish (I use a 9" square glass dish). Melt the remaining butter in seperate bowl. Crush the sleeve of Ritz and add to melted butter. Stir up. Dump and spread Ritz over top of casserole. Sprinkle slivered almonds on top. Bake at 375 for 20 minutes and ENJOY!



</answer>

<answer>



My mum's chicken casserole was always the best ever!
Chicken pieces (thighs, drumsticks or portions) are good for this.
Seal them first in a frying pan, frying on both sides until browned slightly then put them in a casserole dish,



To the frying pan, (wok is ideal for this) add a little oil, a chopped onion, garlic if your kids like it and fry until softened, then add a whole teaspoon of paprika and one to two teaspoons of cornflour.



Add a pint of chicken stock and a tin of plum tomatoes.  Bring to the boil, then cover and leave to simmer for 20-30 minutes.



Finally, add a tin of cooked, drained red kidney beans, and pour the whole lot over the chicken you put in the casserole dish, then pop in the oven for an hour.
To serve, you can serve rice, or mashed potato, the latter is my favourite and it is so delicious it is beyond belief, but not expensive, and very tasty.
Enjoy!
P.s, can I come for a roast chicken dinner, I love them? lol.



</answer>

<answer>



My 18 month old, and 5 year old both love Garlic CHicken strips, and so do we, their good for the whole family! And they are sooo easy!



2 Lbs boneless skinless chicken breast cut into strips
1 1/2 sticks butter melted
2 stacks saltine crackers
1/2 C parm cheese
2 teaspoons garlic salt
3 Tablespoons dried parsley flakes



Preheat oven to 350. Cut breasts into strips. Dip strips into butter, then into breading. Place in pan, and bake 20-30 minutes. Do not over bake. serves 4-5!



When dipping the chicken in the breading, usually the chicken will absorb the garlic salt and parm cheese faster than the rest of the reading, so half way threw I always just add a little more of each to the breading so that they don't get to bland! I also take some of the leftover breading and sprinkle it on the chicken before I bake it, yummy!!



Source(s):



My moms cookbook!



</answer>

<answer>



Chicken and vegetable kebabs are great, especially if you marinate the chicken first.  I normally use a sweet chilli sauce for marinating, but might be a bit spicy for children - perhaps simply soy sauce or olive oil and herbs, or a honey & mustard marinade instead?



Then use whatever vegetables you have and/ or they like. Aubergine (egg plant), mini cherry tomatoes, olives (pitted), pepper and button mushrooms do well.  Sometimes I combine or substitute chicken with Halumi too.



Traditionally they're grilled on skewers but I find it too much work. So just cube everything then roast it all together on a tray for about 40 minutes with a bit of olive oil and herbs, then serve with pitta bread and a bit of salad if I've got some in.



Easy for the kids to eat with ther fingers too :-)



</answer>

<question>



What's the purpose of flouring chicken breasts before sauteeing?



So many recipes for boneless chicken breasts require flouring the chicken breasts before cooking.  Why is this? I'm not talking about deep-fried chicken with the skin on. What's the purpose of doing this?



</question>



<answer from>



sharrona
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 18035 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Usually to brown the flour if you will be using a sauce with the chicken
in the same pan. To remove the flour taste, and still will add some thickness to your sauce.



</answer>



<answer from>



Takenfor...
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 1405 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It makes the chicken crispier and if you are making a sauce to go over the chicken, it will thicken the sauce and make the sauce stick to the chicken better.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dark Angel
Member since: 09 January 2008

<answer>



To make and keep the juices in so it keeps the flaver so right.

<answer from>



avoiding the ironing
Member since: 21 March 2007

<answer>



Use Self Raising - or plain and add baking powder.



225g/ 8oz SR Flour
1/2 teaspn salt
Add extra baking powder if you want fluffier scones. About 2 teaspns will be ok without if you don;t have it, just be gentle.
40g/1 1/2oz  butter or marg
150ml 1/4pt milk



(for sweet scones use 25-50g/1-2 oz caster sugar - maybe 100g sultanas)
(Or 100g/4oz grated cheddar cheese for savoury scones)



Preheat oven 220c Gas 7



Sift flour, salt, baking powder ( and any sugar) into  bowl. Cut up butter into small cubes and "rub together" with your fingertips until it resembles fine "breadcrumbs"



Add any fruit or cheese.



Stir in the milk and mix with a (butter) knife until it forms a rough dough.



Turn onto floured surface and press or roll until 2cm thick.



Using a knife or shaped cutter form into the desired shape.



(Reform and re-use dough to make more scones)



Brush with milk. (sprinkle on a small amount of sugar if you are making sweet scones or some grated cheese if you are making the cheese scones)



Place on floured baking tray and bake for 10-12 mins.



</answer>



<answer from>



sakoo11
Member since: 05 July 2008
Total points: 418 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Scones are traditional cooked pastries that are simple and easy to make, and delicious to eat.you have to use self-raising flour.



[edit] Ingredients



* 200g (1 3/4 Cup) self raising flour



* 1/4 pint (1/2 cup) milk



* 50g (1/4 Cup) butter or margarine, chilled



* salt



* 50g (1/2 Cup) filling - any fruit, chocolate



* spices



* 1/4 cup sugar



[edit] Steps



1. Heat the oven to 220C/425F/Gas 7.



2. Lightly grease a baking sheet.



3. Mix together the flour and salt.



4. Rub in the butter.



5. Stir in the sugar.



6. Add the milk to get a soft dough.



7. Turn on to a floured work surface and knead very lightly. Pat out to a round 2cm/¾in thick.



8. Use a 5cm/2in cutter to stamp out rounds and place on a baking sheet.



9. Lightly knead together the rest of the dough and stamp out more scones to use it all up.



10. Brush the tops of the scones with a little milk. Bake for 12-15 minutes until well risen and golden.



11. Cool on a wire rack and serve with butter and good jam and maybe some clotted cream.



[edit] Tips



* The less you handle the mixture the better. Fast and light with the touch.



* Chill the butter well and cut into small pieces before rubbing in.



* Chocolate chip scones are very nice to take to school for break.



* When cutting the scones, don't twist the cutter or glass as it breaks up the scone so they won't rise as well.



* If your scones do not rise as high as you want, place them higher up in the oven.



* An alternative shape is: after you make the dough into a circle, run a knife through it like a cake so you have triangles.



</answer>
