<answer>



See link below for pizza dough.



The toppings you have suggested will probably burn so put the dough in the oven first until almost cooked then put the toppings on just to heat through.



Source(s):



http://www.deliaonline.com/recipes/basic...



</answer>



<answer from>



johnny c
Member since: 11 July 2006
Total points: 1522 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Easiest way is to get a packet of dough mix from a supermarket.



I make it as follows:
500g plain flour
7g fresh yeast (don't like the dried stuff myself but use as per instructions if you do)
equal amounts of milk and water
1 egg
1 tsp sugar
3 tbsp olive oil
½tsp salt.



Liven up the yeast in some water/milk/sugar for 5 mins until your wife complains about the yeasty smell.  Mix the mixture into the flour.  Add water in small amounts, mix in and when it forms a ball that isn't that sticky it's ready.  Add the salt, and knead it for 5 mins gently.  The harder you knead it the more bisuity the base will be, if you want a thin crust then work it hard.



Put it in a warm place for 45mins or so, until it has doubled in size.  You don't need to let it rise twice.  Then just roll it out and put your toppings on.



Now for the toppings.



Pizza without cheese isn't as nice as with, but I guess you have your reasons, presumably you're vegan or lactose intolerant.  Paint the rolled out disk with plenty of olive oil, and season well with seasalt and black pepper.



The tomato puree wouldn't burn, but will dry out.  You should use passata (sieved tomato) which tastes like puree but is a bit more watery.  You could also use chopped tomatoes or fresh and add the purée.



Add plenty of oregano and fresh basil, they will bring out the taste of the tomatoes and red pepper.



I often make pizza bianca (literally 'white pizza') with cheese, garlic, basil, pork sausage which I buy in Italy but with no tomatoes, it's very nice. Most people would baulk but in Italy it's a lot more common. I haven't seen cheeseless pizza there though.



Cook for 10 mins in a 200C oven.



Source(s):



Learnt to make pizza in Italy, regular pizza maker



</answer>



<answer from>



Gemma F
Member since: 30 April 2008
Total points: 13200 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



Despite your remarks, a pizza without cheese isn't a pizza - it's a FLAN, and you will have to cook the pastry first  because nothing else will hold the heat like cheese would whilst the pastry is cooking. With regards to the 'dough' you might just as well use shortcrust pastry - I mean, you're not making a pizza so why would you want pizza dough!



</answer>



<answer from>



tracy

<answer>



Pizza Dough



1 pkg yeast
1 cup warm water (105 - 115 degrees)
1 t. sugar
1 t. salt
2 T. olive oil
2 1/2 cups all purpose flour



Dissolve yeast in warm water about 5 minutes.  In large bowl, combine remaining ingredients, mix in yeast mixture.  Beat vigorously about 20 strokes.  Cover and let rest 5 minutes.  Punch down then pat evenly into 12" pizza pan.  Spread 1 cup of sauce over dough, top with desired toppings.  Bake at 375 degrees for about 20 minutes.



And, no, your toppings won't burn up, but if you want your toppings to be more firm, add them after your pizza pie has been cooking for 10 minutes.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



Reign in Blood.

Contributing In:



Other - Skin & Body



</answer from>



<answer>



Arh yeah, all those stupid answers that are like, "pizza without cheese is not a real pizza!" It's like... so?!?



3 1/2 cups of all-purpose flour
2 tablespoons of olive oil
2 teaspoons of honey
1 cup of warm water
1 teaspoon of salt
1 teaspoon of yeast



Put warm water into a bowl. Add salt and honey and mix with a spoon. Add yeast, mix and let it sit for about 10 minutes.



Gradually add flour and olive oil and start mixing.



When the mixture gets too heavy to mix, start kneading the dough with your hands.



Knead the dough until you have a smooth ball. If the dough cracks it is too dry. Add water bit by bit until if forms a nice coherent ball. If your dough feels more like batter, it is too wet and you need to add flour bit by bit. If you need to add water or flour, do it by small amounts.



Coat the dough with olive oil, place it in a large bowl and cover it with kitchen wrap or a grocery bag. Let the dough rise for about an hour at room temperature, then push it down again so it deflates. Let it sit for about another hour. If you want to use it the next day, put it in a refrigerator.



Put the dough on a lightly floured surface, put a bit of flour on top and make it into the shape of a pie by stretching it out from the center outwards. Use a rolling pin until the dough is about 1/4" thick. Punch some holes in the dough with a fork to let the air escape while the pizza is in the oven.



With the burning, yeah, just put your dough in the oven for a while, and then all the toppings you want. :) Simple and easy.



</answer>

<answer from>



kayamat_...
Member since: 21 November 2006
Total points: 726 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just bear in mind the following:-



Patrick Wall, chairman of the European Food Safety Authority, recently asked whether it is "morally or ethically correct" to feed grain to animals while people starve. Rearing animals for human consumption is a shocking waste of resources: 16lbs of grain are needed to produce just 1lb of animal flesh. The world's cattle alone consume the same amount of calories it would take to feed more 8.7 billion people – that’s more than the entire human population on Earth.



Some more statistics for you: ninety per cent of the agricultural land in the UK is used to raise livestock, but still we do not have enough grain and so we import 46 million tonnes annually from developing countries. These are countries which not only suffer environmental degradation as a result but, in many cases, cannot afford to feed their own people. Every day, 24,000 people die from hunger and hunger-related causes; 75 per cent of them children less than five years old. Meanwhile, millions of tonnes of grain are being siphoned off to feed animals destined for the already groaning dining tables of countries with the fattest populations in the world.



Factory farming puts a serious strain on our water supplies too. While millions face drought, much of the world's water supply is diverted to animal agriculture. A study this year by the Stockholm International Water Institute, the Food and Agriculture Organisation and the International Water Management Institute found it takes up to 4,000 litres of water to produce one kilogramme of wheat but up to 20,000 litres of water to produce one kilogramme of beef. A totally vegetarian diet requires 300 gallons of water per day, while a meat-eating diet requires more than 4,000 gallons of water per day.



Source(s):



http://style.uk.msn.com/wellbeing/health...



</answer>

Member since: 09 December 2007

<question from>



O
Member since: 07 December 2007
Total points: 2578 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Shouldn't the water in a crock pot be simmering.?



It's my first time!



I have some chicken legs in there.  On low for 8 hours.  They are completely covered by the water.  I guess it's like 1/3, or barely 1/2, full of water.  It's been 2 hours and the water isn't simmering.  The first 1/2 hour I did on high.  I do hear a little popping here and there, pretty rare.  The legs were kinda frozen.



</question>



<answer from>



terrified by spiders
Member since: 17 May 2006
Total points: 3334 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



My crock pot does not simmer. That's part of the plan, that the contents will slow cook at low temperatures.



</answer>



<answer from>



tracy
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 9255 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



</answer from>



<answer>



The liquids in my crockpot really don't start to simmer until after cooking for several hours, especially when on low.  And, yeah, I will occasionally hear the lid rattle while it's cooking.  Since your chicken was frozen, may take a little longer to heat up.



</answer>

<answer from>



smith226...
Member since: 24 March 2008
Total points: 5340 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Take any recipe that calls for ground beef, such as spaghetti or chili or whatever. Then, after you fry the hamburger, put it in a collander and rinse it with hot hot water. You can remove practically ALL of the fat from ground beef this way.



Of course, you'll lose some flavor, too. Let's face it, fat tastes good. So add extra spices.



</answer>



<answer from>



grendagi...
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 874 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would have to highly recommend the cook book "Fix it and forget it Lightly".  It is the best cookbook for low fat cooking in the crock pot.  We have used most of the recipes in that book over and over.  Very tasty and very easy.



Happy cooking!



</answer>

</category>



<question from>



CECELIA H
Member since: 09 December 2007
Total points: 209 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can anyone tell me where i can get the recipe for these i buy them at my bakery. there a bacon fried egg beans?



they are bacon fried egg and beans on pastry you can eat them cold or hot



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



this prolly isnt what you wanted but its something i have made. you can just add beans to it after draining them well.



2 sheets of pie dough
1 pound bacon crispy and crumbled
8 eggs whpped with a little milk
8 oz chedder cheese
pepper ( i just dash til i feel i have enuff)



mix ALL ingredients in a large bowl...



in a pie dish put one layer of the pie dough down...pour in egg/bacon/cheese mixture top __this is where you can add your well drained beans as well --with other pie dough and crimp down a little bit.



brush top just a little with butter



bake 40 minutes at 400degrees let sit for a minute or two before cutting....



can be served hot or cold.



</answer>

<answer>



I think Fajitas are really easy, all you need is Ole El Paso Fajita box (the original BBQ), Chicken breast (approx 3), peppers x 2, onion, (we add mushrooms as we like them), Guacamole dip, sour cream dip, grated cheddar.



It is so straight forward, heat the chicken in some oil, dice all the veg and add once the chicken is cooked through, heat together and sprinkle of the seasoning in the box.



Heat the tortillas either in the oven or in a microwave.



When you feel everything is cooked enough (i like my peppers to be warm but crunchy!) put the chicken mix on to plates, place the fajitas, dips and grated cheese in the middle of the table and enjoy.



Hope this helps



</answer>

Amy H

<answer>



No you do not need to be a domestic goddess, just cook a stir fry tonight all you need to do is boil some rice (use boil in the bag rice because it won't stick to the pan) and while that's cooking pan fry some pieces of chicken and cut up some vegetables (any you have in the house), make some chicken stock using some Knor stock powder because it's better that the stock cubes as it dissolves quicker. Heat up some olive oil* in a big wok (a large frying pan will do if you don't have one) then mix up the rice chicken and vegetables for about 2 minutes and keep stirring while it cooks it so that it does not stick to the pan and that's it.



Source(s):



*olive oil is the best type to use because it doesn't make your food greasy.



</answer>



<answer from>



Seafret1...
Member since: 30 April 2008
Total points: 1088 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Panic ye not!
One pot cooking can be your new friend!  Anyhoo, if your man is a good cook, let him do that, and you be in charge of another big household task.
However, chilli con carne, spaghetti bolognese, chicken casserole, they are all the sorts of things where you just put one ingredient in the pan, stir it round for a bit on medium heat, stick the next ingredient(s) in and keep going until you add the stock, then leave it for 20 minutes to half an hour (longer for the chicken casserole) stirring occasionally to avoid sticking.
If all else fails, pasta, cooked with a jar of home pride bake in sauce, with some cheese on the top looks pretty impressive and tastes lovely.
No one will ever know that it's not your own recipe, if you hide the jar, lol.



Simple dishes can be the novice cook's friend.



I think Lasagne is quite easy to make, you just layer the mince, and other ingredients in between sheets of pasta with the bechemel sauce, but other stuffs are easier.  Get yourself a cheats cook book, with easy to make stuff in it and give the cheaper stuff a whirl to build your confidence.



Home made pizza is really easy too, buy bases, add your favourite ingredients, then stick grated mozzarella on top then bake for the recommended time on the pizza base box.
Once you master the easier stuff, move on to something that's slightly more difficult, but as long as you alternate a lot of easy dishes, I am sure it will all be fine.  After all, souffle and creme brulee would be boring if it were served every day!



</answer>



<answer from>



sandyxrs...
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can make a stew lots of fresh ingreadants in a pan, can put wine or cider in to give extra taste, leave to simmer for couple of hours!



or you could make stir fry,
take 5 mushrooms, meat,onion,2 meduim tomatoes, 1 pepper,
chop them all up put into a wok or large pan, simmer for 25 mins, put teaspoon of pataks sauce in! then add 1-2 handfulls of rice! simmer for another 15 mins, then serve!



</answer>



<answer from>



Rose
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>



Easy Lasagna



8 ounces lasagna noodles



1 pound ground beef



1/2 cup chopped onion



1 jar spaghetti sauce, my fav, Hunts garlic & onion



1 teaspoon garlic powder



1/2 teaspoon salt



1 teaspoon dried leaf oregano, crumbled



1/2 teaspoon dried leaf basil, crumbled



1 1/2 cups ricotta cheese



2 cups shredded Monterey Jack cheese



3/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese



Cook lasagna noodles according to package directions; drain and set aside.



In a large skillet, brown beef, onion, and drain off grease. Stir in spaghetti sauce,



garlic powder, salt, oregano, and basil.
In a 2-quart buttered baking dish (about 11x7x2-inches), layer 1/3 of the lasagna noodles, 1/3 of the sauce and 1/3 of the ricotta cheese, Monterey Jack cheese and Parmesan cheese. Repeat layers twice.



Bake lasagna for 30 minutes, or until thoroughly heated and bubbly. Let stand 10 minutes before cutting and serving.



</answer>



<answer from>



thornyy_...
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 226 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



lasagna isnt that hard really....



what you neeed....



lasagna noodles (1 box)



ricotta cheese (2lbs should be more then nuff for two)



italian sausage if you like (1 pound or 4 to 5 links)



2 jars sauce of your choice



8 oz of mozzeralla



parmasian cheese(romono)
-------------------------
what to do.



preheat oven 350.



have all ingrediants ready on counter with you



get out a rectangle  cake size
pan (glass/metal it dont matter)



put a little sauce on bottom of pan



one layer of noodles....little sauce



layer of ricotta ( just plop it on the noodles to cover them up some) ...add a little more sauce over cheese



layer of nooodles....sauce..



layer of ricotta (same as above)



last layer of noodles add little extra sauce to the top.



( put just about 1/4 cup or less of water in the pan--pouring around the pan/noodles)



cover with foil and put in oven



in another pan put the sausage with a bit of the sauce (enuff to cover the links)



put sausage in oven uncovered



while that is cooking add rest of sauce to a sauce pot and simmer on stovetop low heat for about 10  minutes..add a lil season like garlic/ oregeno if you want.



bake both for about 45 minutes....



take the lasagna out and test the doneness of noodles lift foil carefully to watch steam...cut thru nooodle...should go thru nice and easy....



lasagna now being done leave it sit for about 5 minutes covered on stove top...then carefully remove the foil because of steam



top with the mozzerella and put back in oven just to melt the cheese if you want..or just top it and it will melt from the heat itself.



cut and serve with a sausage link...



(warm bread and buter go nice with this too if you want...or the cheaters garlic bread...make buttered toast add a little garlic salt)



there you have it...its not that hard..can have a lasagna meal in and hour.



( i used to cater and have used this method many times..and many other shortcuts for certain things)



i have loads of super easy recipies...



</answer>

<answer>



try this it might be easy
curried beef kabobs
2/3 cup olive or vegetable oil
1/2 cup beef broth
1/2 cup lemon juice
2 garlic cloves, minced
2 teaspoons curry powder
2 teaspoons salt
4 bay leaves
16 whole peppercorns
2 pounds beef tenderloin, cut into 1 1/4-inch cubes
2 large green bell peppers, cut into 1 1/2 inch pieces
3 medium tomatoes, cut into wedges
3 medium onions, cut into wedges



Nutrition InfoPer Serving



Calories: 529 kcal
Carbohydrates: 11 g
Dietary Fiber: 2 g
Fat: 44 g
Protein: 21 g
Sugars: 5 g



About: Nutrition Info



Powered by: ESHA Nutrient Database



2. Cooking Directions
In a large resealable plastic bag or shallow glass dish, combine the first eight ingredients; mix well. Remove 2/3 cup for basting; refrigerate. Add beef to remaining marinade; turn to coat. Cover and refrigerate for 8 hours or overnight. Drain and discard the marinade.
On metal or soaked bamboo skewers, alternate beef, green peppers, tomatoes and onions. Place on a greased rack in a broiler pan; broil 5 in. from the heat for 3 minutes on each side. Baste with reserved marinade. Continue broiling, turning and basting for 8-10 minutes or until meat reaches desired doneness (for medium rare, a meat thermometer should read 145 degrees F medium, 160 degrees F well-done, 170 degrees F).



</answer>

<question>



Making gravy



?



If I'm frying some steak in a frying pan, can I use the little amount of fat and oil left and make it into a gravy? or does it have to come from oven baked turkey?



</question>



<answer from>



Happy Cooker
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 17832 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



You can make gravy from any meat you fry.



</answer>



<answer from>



tracy
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 9255 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



</answer from>



<answer>



Sure you can -- sprinkle some flour into the fat, whisk well until incorporated. Keep adding bits of flour until all the fat is absorbed and let cook over medium heat about a minute.  Gradually add water and continue to whisk to avoid lumps.  Keep adding water, a little at a time, until your gravy is the consistency you like.  Add salt and pepper to taste.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ozmaniac
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 25620 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Sydney



Other - Australia



</answer from>



<answer>



Why would it have to come from oven baked turkey if it's for steak? If you have the juices and/or fat from anything, simply add some all purpose flour with a small amount of liquid (water, stock or whatever). Mix until a smooth cream, then add liquid a little at a time. Your gravy will taste of whatever you've cooked (as it should). Gravy browning essence or Parisian essence will give it a good color if it's a bit pale.



</answer>



<answer from>



Been There~Done That!
Member since: 23 May 2006
Total points: 103511 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Family



</answer from>



<answer>



Country Fried Steak Gravy



Make the gravy by adding the 2 tablespoons remaining flour to the pan drippings, scraping the bottom with a wooden spoon. Stir in the remaining 1/4 teaspoon pepper, and the salt. Reduce the heat to medium and cook, stirring frequently, until the flour is medium brown and the mixture is bubbly. Slowly add the whole milk and the Ac'cent, if using stirring constantly. Return the steaks to the skillet and bring to a boil over medium-high heat. Reduce the heat to low, and place the onions on top of the steaks. Cover the pan, and let simmer for 30 minutes.



Here are two basic ways of making gravy from roast drippings, one using corn starch, the other using flour. In each case, you start with the roast drippings. You may have much more drippings than you need for the amount of gravy you want to make. You can follow this guideline - for each cup of gravy you would like to make, start with a tablespoon of drippings. So, if you want to make 2 cups of gravy, drain all but 2 tablespoons of fat and drippings from the roasting pan (set aside for future use). These instructions will be for the end result of 2 cups of gravy, but you can easily divide or multiply to adjust for how much gravy you want to make.



Making Gravy with Corn Starch



Remove the roast from the pan. Place pan on stove on medium high heat. Pour off all but 2 Tbsp of the drippings in the pan.
Dissolve 2 Tbsp of corn starch in the minimum amount of water needed to make a thin paste - about 1/4 cup. Pour into pan with drippings and use a wire whisk or spatula (as pictured) to blend into the drippings
Stir with a wire whisk until the gravy begins to thicken. As it thickens, slowly add water, stock, milk, or cream, or some combination to the pan. Alternate stirring and adding liquid, maintaining the consistency you want, for several minutes (about 5). You will probably add about 2 cups of liquid all together. Taking into consideration the evaporation that is occurring while you are cooking, you will end up with about 2 cups of gravy. Season with salt



Making Gravy with Flour



Remove the roast from the pan. Place pan on stove on medium high heat. Pour off all but 2 Tbsp of the drippings in the pan.
Into the 2 tablespoons of drippings in the pan stir in 1 to 2 tablespoons of flour. Stir with a wire whisk until the flour has thickened and the gravy is smooth. Continue to cook slowly to brown the flour, and stir constantly.
Slowly add back some of the previously removed drippings (remove some of the fat beforehand if there is a lot of fat). In addition, add either water, milk, stock, or cream to the gravy, enough to make 2 cups. Season the gravy with salt and pepper and herbs.



</answer>



<answer from>



t1ggerb0...
Member since: 03 August 2008
Total points: 1093 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sure you can. While your steak is resting, make yourself some gravy.



Take your steak out and put it on a plate and cover lightly with aluminum foil to keep it warm.



Use the grease/drippings from the steak to make your gravy. Turn your heat up on your pan to about medium-medium high. You should have at least 1 tablespoon of drippings. If not, add yourself a little veggie oil to make a tablespoon. Then I add 1 tablespoon flour to the pan and mix thoroughly with the drippings. Constantly stirring I cook over the heat for a couple minutes. You'll notice a slight nutty aroma.



Reduce your heat. At this point I add some wine about 1/4 C (remove the pan from the heat before you do this) and mix thoroughly. I put the pan back on the heat then turn the heat back to med-high. Then I add either beef broth if I have some or just water while constantly stirring. The amount of water depends on the thickness you want your gravy. I stir and let it cook for a couple minutes, add some salt and pepper and enjoy.



Source(s):



Personal recipe



</answer>



<answer from>



mariesad...
Member since: 22 September 2006
Total points: 312 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



you don't have to fry to make good gravy...marinade you steak in olive oil and you favorite seasonings...cook in low to med heat with lid on to draw out that essence take lid off. Now once you have you steak temp to your liken take the steak out..mix flour and water in a bowl(more water than flour) bring the essence to a simmer pour the water and flour mix in and start stirring turn heat down

<answer from>



busybake...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually the best gravy for steaks (meaning top sirloin, porterhouse, etc.) is to deglaze the pan. Add a bit of red wine and bring to a boil while scraping up the brown bits on the bottom of the pan. You can add a bit of shallot or chopped onion, maybe a bit of garlic, plus salt and pepper while deglazing the pan. Makes a yummy pan sauce.



busybaker

</answer>

<answer>



Croque Monsieur - Basically a grilled ham & cheese sandwich



you will need:



Bread
Ham
Cheese
egg
butter
jam, syrup, powdered sugar



Make a ham & cheese sandwich (no mustard)
Dip the sandwich in a bowl with a beaten egg
Fry the sandwich in a pan with a little butter until browned and the cheese has melted.
Dust with powdered sugar and serve with jam or syrup.



----
Molten Chocolate Cupcakes



1 cup unsalted butter or unsalted margarine*



8 ounces semisweet chocolate chips, or bars, cut into bite-size chunks



5 large eggs



1 cup sugar



Pinch of salt



4 teaspoons flour (or matzo meal, ground in a blender to a fine powder)



8 extra-large paper muffin cups (or use regular paper muffin cups, which will make 12 cakes)



Garnish:



1 (6 ounce) container raspberries, barely moistened and rolled in about



1/2 cup sugar right before serving



Melt butter and chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl over a saucepan of simmering water; remove from heat. Beat eggs, sugar and salt with a hand mixer in a medium bowl until sugar dissolves. Beat egg mixture into chocolate until smooth. Beat in flour or matzo meal until just combined. (Batter can be made a day ahead; return to room temperature an hour or so before baking.)



Before serving dinner, adjust oven rack to middle position; heat oven to 450 degrees. Line a standard-size muffin tin (1/2 cup capacity) with 8 extra-large muffin papers (papers should extend above cups to facilitate removal). Spray muffin papers with vegetable cooking spray. Divide batter among muffin cups.



Bake until batter puffs but center is not set, 8 to 10 minutes. Carefully lift cakes from tin and set on a work surface. Pull papers away from cakes and transfer cakes to dessert plates.



Top each with sugared raspberries and serve immediately
---
Pasta alla carbonara



INGREDIENTS:
1 lb. spaghetti pasta
4 slices bacon
2 egg yolks
2 Tbsp. milk
2 cloves garlic, minced
1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese



PREPARATION:
Cook the bacon in a heavy skillet until crisp. Remove from pan and drain on paper towels. Set bacon aside.



Cook the pasta as directed on package. Meanwhile, combine the egg yolks, milk, and garlic in a medium bowl and beat until well blended.



When the pasta is cooked, drain and immediately return to the pot. Stir in the egg mixture and toss thoroughly until combined. Add the bacon and cheese and toss again to coat. Serve immediately.



OR



Ingredients
200g/8oz dried tagliatelle
2 rashers streaky bacon, cut into lardons
2 eggs, beaten
100ml/3½fl oz double cream
100g/½ tub cream cheese
25g/1oz fresh flat leaf parsley, chopped
freshly ground black pepper
Method
1. Half fill a large pan with water. Season with salt and bring to the boil.
2. Cook pasta as per packet instructions.
3. Heat a medium wok. Fry the bacon for 1-2 minutes, to seal.
4. Pour in the eggs and stir occasionally for 1 minute. (You do not want a consistency like scrambled eggs.)
5. Stir in the cream.
6. Stir the cream cheese.
7. Drain the pasta and gently mix it into the sauce.
8. To serve, season with lots of freshly ground black pepper and fold in the parsley.
NB. Soft fresh herbs should always be added to cooked dishes just before serving, to retain colour and flavour



or



4 egg yolks
1 egg white
parmesan cheese to taste



150ml double cream/heavy cream
3 rashers bacon diced
buffalo mozarella



mix the eggs and cream in a bowl with some parmesan cheese, season with plenty of pepper.



dice and fry off your bacon or you can use parma ham in a little oil and garlic



when your pasta is al dente add the sauce plus the bacon to the drained pasta and let the heat of the pasta cook the sauce through. tear buffalo mozarella over the top and season again if needed



</answer>

<answer>



We had Fiesta Tortellini (tortellini, steamed carrots, bell peppers, cocktail onions, sugar snap peas, scallions) with white cream sauce (like alfredo but without the cheese); apple & pear salad (different apples and pears peeled & cubed, with a little blue cheese dressing & walnuts on romaine); Double chocolate pudding for after.

<answer from>



Windir
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm going on the assumption you'll be eating, too:



Ingredients:
4-6 Lamb chops (I normally do 2 per person, but if they're small then one each should do)
2 TBS honey (any sort should do, as long as it's not set)
1 lemon, fresh
2-3 cloves of garlic
1-2 tsp rosemary (pref. fresh, but you can use dried)
1 medium onion (I use red onions, but it's just preference)
1-2 leeks
3 cups kale
A little cooking oil (I use peanut, but safflower or canola will work)
Extra virgin olive oil



1. Mince or crush the garlic, slice the onion and leeks. If you're using fresh rosemary, then chop it fine.



2. Mix the honey and about half the lemon's worth of juice together (about 3:1). Mix in the rosemary and about 1tsp of the garlic. (Adjust to taste, and add salt and pepper if reqd.)



3. Heat up a little cooking oil in a skillet to a high heat, meanwhile preheat a grill to low-medium heat



4. Sear the lamb in the skillet briefly - the outside should brown but not blacken



4. Coat one side of the lamb with a thin layer of the glaze, and carefully transfer it to the grill, glaze up. Then add the leek and onion to the skillet, and turn the heat down a little.



5. Sautée the leek and onion for about 7 minutes, turn the heat down a bit more, then add the kale, add a dash more cooking oil, and stir it around until all the kale looks very deep green. Cover the skillet with something. It should be just hot enough that it only just makes a very faint sizzling sound.



6. When the chops are done on one side, turn them over, glaze the other sides, and grill 'til nearly done.



7. Remove the cover on the skillet, make a little bed on each plate with the green, sprinkle the rest of the garlic over the top, squeeze some lemon juice on, and drizzle on a generous amount of the olive oil.



8. Transfer lamb chops to bed of green, serve, enjoy.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 14 December 2006
Total points: 6195 (Level 5)

<original file>6908.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk30204.txt</current file name>




<category>



Food & Drink



Cooking & Recipes



</category>



<question from>



Bubbles X
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 237 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Help with cooking meal for chef?



my bf is a chef and i am cooking a roast chicken with new potatoes and vegetables tonight. its just a small whole chicken for the two of us, frozen veg and potatoes.  how shall i cook it? do you put butter over the chicken to make i t crisp? i have olive oil, bisto , salt, pepper and garlic. nothing else. what shall i do with this? no fancy words plz basic bullet points. how long does chicken take



</question>



<answer from>



busybake...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 174 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Rinse the chicken both inside and out. Be sure to remove the giblets, heart and gizzard from inside the chicken. Pat dry with clean paper towels.



Rub olive oil on the skin. Season with garlic, salt and pepper. If you can find some rosemary, crush it between your fingers or in your palm, rub the seasonings on the outside of the chicken.



Place the chicken on a roasting rack and put it in a shallow pan or roasting pan. Roast until the chicken is crisp and golden. I think the internal temp should be 165 degrees F. Check a cookbook to be sure as my old memory is gettin' old! LOL!



To make some nifty potatoes:  Peel the potatoes and cut them into large chunks. Place in a 8 x 8 or 9 x 9-inch baking pan. Toss in a bit of olive oil (about a 1/4 cup) and season with garlic and onion powders, salt and pepper, plus a bit of paprika. Place in the oven about 30 to 40 minutes before the chicken roasting time is nearly ended. Roast until crisp and golden.



Remove the chicken to the cutting board and let rest for a few minutes. Carve and serve with the roasted potatoes.



busybaker
List owner: Cozy Cooking Newsletter
Subscribe: 	CozyCookingNewsletter-subscribe@yahoogr...



</answer>



<answer from>



Rosie R
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 1905 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can put butter on the skin to make the skin crispy add a little salt too. I'd say cook it for about 2 hours nice and slow. Gas Mark 4.  Keep basting it - the juices that come out of the chicken, spoon them back over the chicken to keep the meat moist. Do that every half an hour if you can.
cook the potatoes for about 20 mins or until you can get a knife cleanly through them. cook the veg separately till that is cooked - depends on what you have depends on how long it takes.

tayntedf...

<answer>



Ok try this out. I did once and it turned out amazing!



2 tablespoons of butter
2 tablespoons olive oil
salt
rosemary or thyme (this is optional so dont worry if you dont have it)
garlic



Preheat oven to 475 degrees F. Rinse the chicken well, and dry thoroughly with paper towels. Rub the inside cavity of the chicken with kosher salt. If you like rub the outside of the chicken with peeled, halved garlic cloves, and add whole unpeeled garlic cloves to the roasting pan. Crush the peppercorns with the flat of a heavy chef's knife, pounding with your hand, or with the bottom of a heavy pan. Rub the cracked peppercorns all over the outside of the chicken, along with more salt. If you're stuffing the chicken, stuff the cavity at this point. Otherwise, you may insert a few sprigs of fresh herbs into the cavity. For more even cooking and a neater appearance at presentation, truss the chicken: Tuck the wings in under themselves, and pass the middle of a 5-foot length of kitchen string under the tail, making a loose single knot across the drumsticks. Slip the string under the ends of the drumsticks, pulling them together tightly. Bring the ends of the string along the body of the chicken toward the neck end. Position the string so that it pulls tightly across the drumstick-thigh joint. Make a single knot at the neck opening. Bring the ends of the string back up toward the tail, along the first length of string. Tie a single knot catching the loose skin on either side of the open cavity (this helps keep the stuffing in). Pull the string over the drumsticks and tie a tight double knot, catching the tip of the breast. The chicken should be a neat, compact shape, and the cavity should be tightly closed.



Select a large cast-iron skillet, a heavy sauté pan, or any sturdy pan that's large enough to hold the bird and can go from stovetop to oven. Melt the butter in the pan, and add the olive oil, and heat. Put the chicken in the pan over medium heat and turn the chicken to coat it with the butter and oil mixture. Set the chicken on its side and put the pan on the middle rack of the 475°F oven and roast for 15 minutes. Turn the chicken to the other side and roast another 15 minutes. Lower the heat to 400°F, turn the chicken breast side up, and continue roasting for 25-30 minutes, basting with the pan juices every 5 minutes.



I used this reciep i found a couple months ago and the chicken was to die for. Heres the website if you want to check it out yourself.  Hope this helps some. If you don't like this one I have one other one that I made up.



Source(s):



http://www.gumbopages.com/food/roast-chi...



</answer>

A A

<question>



I need some good advice for cooking sausage!?



OK, so I tried making some sausage in a fry pan....just sprayed some Pam on it and put the sausages on. I had the heat on low-low/middle heat.  Seemed that the outsides started getting faster than the outside....blacker on the outside but the insides weren't exactly "cooked" color.



What color should I be looking for on the inside of the sausage? Grey or a bit red?  Thanks for any general tips



</question>



<answer from>



chef_ren...
Member since: 13 January 2008
Total points: 5319 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well, at least you tried and we've all done this before, so don't beat yourself up about it, at least you're not to prideful to ask for help.  I always do my sausage in a large, flat pan with a water bath to begin with, about 1/4 of the way up to your sausage links and drizzle some Olive Oil in the pan as well. Cook your sausage on Medium High heat and while the water evaporates out of the pan, this will cook the inside of your sausage. Then, once the water evaporates, the olive oil will take over and lightly brown the skin of your sausage and seal all those wonderful flavors inside!  When your sausage is done, you should see a uniform color upon cutting into it, a light grey color, no pink or red at all.  Please remember, that differently flavored sausages might be different in color on the outside, but the inside should be the same, basically. For an exact internal temperature, it should be 160 at least. Hope this helps you to enjoy your safely cooked sausage and this was a good question to ask!  Happy Cooking to you!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



awesome answer!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



COCO
Member since: 12 June 2006
Total points: 3587 (Level 4)



</answer from>

am_the_g...
Member since: 28 May 2006

<answer>



I generally make a bleeding heart cake for our annual pumpkin carving party  (Pumpkinfest). Sometimes the heart beats, sometimes it's anatomically correct, and so on and so forth. This year I decided to go the whole hog and make an entire thoracic cavity cake. The plan was for each organ to be made out of a



different kind of cake and to secrete a different color of fluid when it was cut into. Previous heart cakes have bled fresh, homemade raspberry sauce. This year I made raspberry, strawberry, kiwi, mango, and blueberry sauces. Sadly,



the organs didn't bleed as well as I had hoped when I cut the cake, as each organ was relatively small and couldn't hold much sauce. Also all the moving around after filling the organs made it hard to keep the sauce contained in the little cavities I hollowed out. The heart bled pretty well, but the other organ fluids weren't very dramatic. On the bright side, there were lots of leftover



sauces, which were all quite delicious. But I'm getting ahead of myself. My intended organ-cake-sauce combinations were as follows.



</answer>

<answer>



Make your own vanilla extract.



HOME-BREWED VANILLA EXTRACT



2 c. vodka
5 vanilla beans, cut into 1 inch pieces



Combine vodka and vanilla beans in a jar with a tight fitting lid. Cover the jar and let it stand 6 to 8 weeks. The vodka mixture will turn amber colored after a day or two.
After half the vanilla extract is used, add more vodka to cover the beans. The flavor in the beans is gone when the vodka no longer turns to a dark color. Yield: 2 cups.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



I don't know what Coronation chicken is but if it is a fairly bland recipe then there are lots of ways to recycle cooked chicken. Here's some ideas:



Barbecue chicken sandwiches. Add chicken to saucepan and moisten with favorite barbecue sauce. Heat until warm.



Creamed chicken:  Add a bit of thinned cream of mushroom soup (or any other favorite cream based soup) to a pan. Thin the soup with a bit of milk, cream or half and half. Add the chicken and heat through. For color add chopped pimientos or peas and carrots. Serve over toast points, biscuits or rice.



Chicken Pot Pie: Follow the creamed chicken recipe except add vegetables including potatoes. Turn out into a lined pastry pan. Top with the remaining pie crust. Vent and bake. You will need a double crust pie for this recipe.



Curried Chicken: Follow cream chicken recipe except add curry powder to taste. Serve with favorite curry condiments. Serve over rice.



busybaker
List owner: Cozy Cooking Newsletter
Subscribe: 	CozyCookingNewsletter-subscribe@yahoogr...



</answer>

<answer from>



Stephen L
Member since: 30 September 2006
Total points: 8207 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



CHICKEN & SWEET CORN SOUP



Serves 2



INGREDIENTS



1 egg



1 chicken breast (either fresh or leftover from a roast chicken)
1 tablespoon of sunflower oil (if you are using a fresh chicken breast)
200g (½ a 400g tin) of creamed sweet corn



1 chicken stock cube
500ml of water



Ground pepper to taste



METHOD



Break the egg into a bowl and pick out any bits of shell. Mix up the egg.



If you are using a fresh chicken breast, cut it into thin strips. Put the oil into a frying pan on a medium heat. Fry the chicken for about 5 minutes. Stir frequently to stop it sticking.



If you are using a leftover chicken breast, tear it into thin strips.



Put the chicken and sweet corn into a saucepan on a medium heat. Crumble the stock cube into the water and pour it into the pan. Mix thoroughly. Bring to the boil, then turn down the heat until it is just boiling (simmering). Continue to cook, stirring as the mixture boils, for about 10 to 15 minutes.



Slowly pour the egg into the soup, stirring gently all the time to form ‘strings' of cooked egg. If the soup reaches the desired consistency before you’ve added all of the egg, stop adding the egg.



Season with the pepper.



ADDITIONS & ALTERNATIVES



If you want a thick soup, add ½ a tablespoon of cornflour mixed with a little water towards the end of the cooking.



For Creamed Sweet Corn Soup, omit the chicken and substitute a vegetable stock cube for the chicken one.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jen M
Member since: 03 August 2008
Total points: 3673 (Level 4)



</answer from>

<question from>



rk =)
Member since: 12 March 2008
Total points: 2870 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Mathematics



</question from>



<question>



Do you know of a pumpkin pie recipe with white rice?



I know lots of people who make pumpkin pies with rice in them but how do I do it?



</question>



<answer from>



annie
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 662 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



PUMPKIN PIE FILLING



2 c. cooked rice
1/4 c. pitted dates
1 c. pureed yams or pumpkin
1 c. soft tofu
3 tbsp. honey



Blend half of mixture at a time until very smooth. Blend 1/4 cup unflavored gelatin, 3/4 cup pineapple juice, 1 teaspoon vanilla. Let stand 2-3 minutes, then add 1 cup boiling water to gelatin mixture, whiz briefly. Stir 2 mixtures together thoroughly. For pie, pour mix into 2 baked pie shells and refrigerate until set. For pudding pour in casserole and refrigerate.



</answer>



<answer from>



Haven_Su...
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 10979 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds like the recipes your refering to have Rice milk or powdered rice in the crust. If thats the case Heres one with rice in the crust and one with rice milk. And if thats not what your looking for ask for the recipe from one person who does use it in the recipe.



Rice based piecrust
Makes two 10-inch pie shells



2/3 cup rice flour



1/4 cup tapioca flour



3 tbsp potato starch



1 tsp xantham gum



1/4 tsp salt



1 tbsp sugar



1/4 tsp Gluten-free baking powder



3 tbsp cold dairy-free margerine (omit and double the shortening below if you can't find a suitable margerine)



3 tbsp cold vegetable shortening in small pieces



1



egg yolk



3 tsp cold water



1 tsp cider vinegar



Blend the dry ingredients.



Cut in margarine and shortening until mixture resembles a course meal. Add egg yolk, water, and vinegar.
Blend.



Wrap dough in plastic and press into a ball. Chill for 1 hour. 4. Between two sheets of plastic wrap, roll dough out into a 12-inch circle (about 1/4-inch thick). Remove top sheet of plastic wrap and flip pastry onto a 10-inch pie plate. Keeping the plastic wrap over the top of the crust, pat it into the pan, piecing together any parts that separate when the crust lands in the pan. Remove the second sheet of plastic wrap. Crimp edges.



Dairy Free Pumpkin Pie filling
Makes two nine inch pies



1 cup sugar (1-1/2 cup if using the rice-based crust)



1/4  cup  Brown Rice Cream hot cereal mix (or tapioca pudding mix (tapioca pearls work ok, too)). The rice cereal really helps the pie firm up.



1/4  cup  tapioca flour (or omit and double the rice cereal or tapioca mix above)



1  tsp.  Salt



1  tsp.  Ground cinnamon



1/4  tsp.  Ground cloves



1/4  tsp.  Ground ginger



4



large whole eggs



2



large egg whites



1  can  (29 oz.) Libby's “100% Pure Pumpkin”



3  cups  rice milk (soy is OK too if you like it).



Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Mix sugar, salt, cinnamon, clover, ginger, and tapioca into a small bowl.



Beat eggs in a large bowl (I use the main mixing bowl for my big mixer) and then add the canned pumpkin. Running the mixer, add the sugar/spice mix, lastly add the rice milk. Mix thoroughly.



Pour into the pie shells. Bake at 425 degrees for 15 minutes, turn down to 350 degrees (maybe open the oven door for a sec to let some heat out), turn the pies a bit if spots of the crust are burning, and bake for another 40 minutes.



Usually you test a pumpkin pie for "doneness" by sticking a knife in the center and it's done if nothing sticks when you pull it out. That doesn't work with this recipe since it isn't doesn't make a pie that solid (when hot out of the oven). So, I say the pies are done if he center is not completely liquid. If you care, the pies solidify nicely when refrigerated overnight. However, mine rarely survive long enough to even cool down ...



http://www.polyweb.com/danno/PumpkinPie/



Source(s):



http://www.recipezaar.com/147043



</answer>

<question>



What can I make with old cornbread?



Leftover cornbread.  Preferably something on the sweet side.



</question>



<answer from>



Lana
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 2828 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Sweet Cornbread and Blueberry Muffin Stuffin'



Goes GREAT with chicken breast or pork chops.



_______________



Crumble cornbread and 2-4 blueberry muffins into a large bowl  (the good blueberry muffins, from the bakery section)



Sweat/sautee 1/2 onion diced and 1 rib celery, diced in 2T butter and 1 T canola oil until soft.



To the cornbread/blueberry mixture add in 1 tsp. dried sage, 1/2 tsp. poultry seasoning, salt and pepper, and some dried herbs (whatever you have on hand --- basil, oregano, etc.)



Pour the butter/celery mixture over the bread and mix with 1 can warmed chicken stock.  Mush to combine.



Add in 1 egg and combine fully.



Bake for 30 mins (in a baking dish, covered) on 350.



</answer>

<answer>



Cornbread pudding
Dry Corn Bread for Bread Pudding
1 1/4 cups frozen corn kernels, thawed
1 cup chopped red bell pepper
2 cups coarsely grated Monterey Jack cheese (about 8 ounces)
3/4 cup thinly sliced scallion
4 large eggs
two 10-ounce cans mild enchilada sauce
1 1/4 cups vegetable or chicken broth PreparationCrumble corn bread into 1-inch pieces and transfer to a large baking pan. Dry corn bread, uncovered, at room temperature 12 hours. (Alternatively, dry corn bread in a 250°F oven 1 hour.)
Butter a 2-quart baking dish.
Pat dry corn kernels. In a bowl toss together corn bread, corn kernels, bell pepper, 1 cup Monterey Jack, scallion, and salt and pepper to taste and transfer to baking dish. In bowl whisk together eggs, enchilada sauce, and broth and pour over corn-bread mixture. Sprinkle remaining cup cheese evenly on top. Chill pudding, covered, at least 1 hour and up to 1 day. Preheat oven to 350°F. Bake pudding in middle of oven until bubbling, about 40 minutes.



Soup w/cornbread croutons
For soup



1 lb dried small white beans such as navy or Great Northern
1 lb smoked ham hocks
1/4 cup bacon drippings (from 1/2lb bacon) or olive oil
2 cups chopped onion
2 tablespoons minced garlic
1 lb tomatoes, peeled, seeded, and diced



4 fresh thyme sprigs
8 cups chicken broth
For corn bread croutons



3 tablespoons unsalted butter
1 garlic clove, minced
3 cups 3/4-inch cubes corn bread



1 lb arugula, coarse stems removed
Tabasco to taste



PreparationMake soup: Soak beans in cold water to cover overnight (8 hours). Drain and rinse well. Simmer ham hocks in 6 cups water in a 3-quart saucepan, partially covered, skimming foam as necessary, 1 hour. Reserve 4 cups cooking liquid and drain ham hocks.
Heat bacon drippings in an 8-quart heavy pot over moderate heat until hot but not smoking, then cook onion and garlic, stirring, until softened. Add tomatoes and thyme and cook, stirring, 1 minute. Add soaked beans, broth, ham hocks, and reserved cooking liquid and simmer, covered, stirring occasionally, until beans are tender, about 1 hour.



Make croutons while soup simmers: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Melt butter with garlic and toss together with corn bread cubes in a shallow baking pan. Toast in middle of oven until lightly browned and crisp on the outside, about 15 minutes.



Prepare soup for serving: Remove ham hocks and shred meat. Return meat to soup and stir in arugula. Simmer, uncovered, stirring occasionally, until greens are tender, 3 to 5 minutes. Season with salt, pepper, and Tabasco. Serve soup topped with croutons.



</answer>

<question>



Baking soda and Baking powder?



What is the difference between baking soda and baking powder?



</question>



<answer from>



FLGossip...
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 2497 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not sure but trust me when I tell you they can't be used interchangeably.  I accidentally used one instead of the other in a cookie recipe and it went horribly wrong, LOL



</answer>



<answer from>



noitall
Member since: 23 November 2006
Total points: 17815 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



baking powder makes something rise.  baking soda is bicarbonate of soda - it's needed to neutralize acid and is used for many, many things besides baking.  read the label and use the right ingredient.



</answer>



<answer from>



shedaisy...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can't remember exactly, but it has to do something with a chemical balance. Baking Soda is already well balanced, but when we add stuff like chocolate to a mixture, it throws the balance off, so we have to add baking powder. Check out the muffin episode of Good Eats.



</answer>



<answer from>



Xiao Xiong
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 1997 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Baking powder is self-rising. It actually has some baking soda in it, but it also has something acidic that will react with any liquid in your batter and cause bubbles that will make the cake (or whatever rise).



Baking soda requires something acidic to cause it to rise, so you'll often see baking soda used in recipes such as buttermilk biscuits or banana bread.



You can see the difference easily: put a little baking powder in some water and you'll see it fizz; baking soda will just sit there.



If you don't have baking powder and you want to make a recipe, simply use about a teaspoon of baking soda instead and add a couple teaspoons of white vinegar to the liquid.



Source(s):



my ginormous brain



</answer>



<answer from>



Irosha D
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 154 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



both are used commonly



</answer>



<answer from>



Chimes
Member since: 17 October 2006
Total points: 809 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



What Is the Difference Between Baking Soda & Baking Powder?



By Anne Marie Helmenstine, Ph.D., About.com
See More About:



* baking tips



* science faqs



* cooking ingredients



* food chemistry



Question: What Is the Difference Between Baking Soda & Baking Powder?



Answer: Both baking soda and baking powder are leavening agents, which means they are added to baked goods before cooking to produce carbon dioxide and cause them to 'rise'. Baking powder contains baking soda, but the two substances are used under different conditions.



Baking Soda



Baking soda is pure sodium bicarbonate. When baking soda is combined with moisture and an acidic ingredient (e.g., yogurt, chocolate, buttermilk, honey), the resulting chemical reaction produces bubbles of carbon dioxide that expand under oven temperatures, causing baked goods to rise. The reaction begins immediately upon mixing the ingredients, so you need to bake recipes which call for baking soda immediately, or else they will fall flat!



Baking Powder



Baking powder contains sodium bicarbonate, but it includes the acidifying agent already (cream of tartar), and also a drying agent (usually starch). Baking powder is available as single-acting baking powder and as double-acting baking powder. Single-acting powders are activated by moisture, so you must bake recipes which include this product immediately after mixing. Double-acting powders react in two phases and can stand for a while before baking. With double-acting powder, some gas is released at room temperature when the powder is added to dough, but the majority of the gas is released after the temperature of the dough increases in the oven.



How Are Recipes Determined?



Some recipes call for baking soda, while others call for baking powder. Which ingredient is used depends on the other ingredients in the recipe. The ultimate goal is to produce a tasty product with a pleasing texture. Baking soda is basic and will yield a bitter taste unless countered by the acidity of another ingredient, such as buttermilk. You'll find baking soda in cookie recipes. Baking powder contains both an acid and a base and has an overall neutral effect in terms of taste. Recipes that call for baking powder often call for other neutral-tasting ingredients, such as milk. Baking powder is a common ingredient in cakes and biscuits.



Substituting in Recipes



You can substitute baking powder in place of baking soda (you'll need more baking powder and it may affect the taste), but you can't use baking soda when a recipe calls for baking powder. Baking soda by itself lacks the acidity to make a cake rise. However, you can make your own baking powder if you have baking soda and cream of tartar. Simply mix two parts cream of tartar with one part baking soda.



Source(s):



http://chemistry.about.com/cs/foodchemis...



</answer>

<question>



Best way to make a chicken soup?



I am a novice in the kitchen so need some help. I have some chicken leftover from yesterday and some chicken stock and would like to make a lovely soup. I also have carrots, potatoes, french beans and onions. What is the best way to make it?



Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



charc720...
Member since: 14 February 2006
Total points: 29603 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



First heat your stock back up. You need to taste it. Use sea salt if possible, Add extra boullion cubes and water to make sure you have enough broth as you will need to reduce it for the maximum richer flavor, anyway simmer on high not (boiling). When it reduces down to a good half pot(enough for veggies to move around), add a spoon of sugar & taste to see if you need salt, add bay leaf, basil carrots, plenty of onions, beans & deboned chicken back to the pot, then potatoes. When it returns to a boil, reduce and simmer with a lid for 45 min or so, tasting every lil bit as potatoes absorb some salt and may require more. Tomatoes would be good, about 1/4 c of celery, green onion tops and 1/4 c chopped cilantro would be the ultimate. When it has cook and veggies are tender, add either wide egg noodles cook 5 min and remove from heat. Let set an hour if possible. If you add rice instead of the noodles it need to cook about 20 more minutes, then remove from heat and let set...Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Kiley K
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 763 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Reheat your chicken and broth, add carrots, 1 can kernal corn, cut onions, (I would leave the potato's out). Add egg noodles and put on med/high..just at boil, take off heat, and add a chicken boulian cube.



Serve with crackers. Yummy. You can even sprinkle a little parsley over top. hmmm. good stuff.



</answer>

<answer>



HOMEMADE CROCK POT CHICKEN SOUP



1 pkg. boneless, skinless chicken breasts
1 lg. can chicken broth



carrots and Potatoes



Beans
chopped onions
Seasonings according to taste (parsley flakes, garlic, salt, pepper, etc.)



in a large pan cook carrots, potatoes, onion add green beans with broth,  Boil until tender,add chicken from yesturday and simmer for 1 hour . u can also add to your soup  rice or noodles this would be  for thicker soup.  Or if you have a crock pot throw everything in the crockpot and cook for 6 hours (without the chicken since its already cooked)...Happy cooking

<question>



Franchises and recipe sharing?



When you open a food franchise, do they give the recipes to make the food? If so, how do they know you won't steal the recipes and create your own restaurant? Or do they pre-make for instance sauces and send them to each franchise?



</question>

<answer from>



barbigrl...

</answer from>



<answer>



Some places do the pre-making, some places send recipes but they make you sign a contract that you can never open up a restaurant of your own that has the same style food, or be a direct competitor. That's what happened with Outback Steakhouse and Boulder Creek. But Outback lost their case.



</answer>



<answer from>



busybake...
Member since: 29 September 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



Most franchises will "sell" their recipes to the franchise owner. That's part of the deal from what I understand. I've never had the money to own a franchise so I can't say yup that's true for sure.



Also, most commercial kitchens use prepared products to help complete meals. Good kitchens cook from scratch but most restaurants purchase soup bases, etc. to help with their cooking.

<answer from>



Lana
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 2830 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes

<answer>



Practice makes perfect.  Start out with easy to make recipes.  Don't look at them as chores, but as time away to spend with yourself.  Have fun, don't worry so much about getting the measuring just right.  As long as you aren't makin' a cake, measurements can usually be approximate.



Buy some common utensils like a good measuring cup, measuring spoons, and a can opener.



Get basics like:
Olive oil
Canned tomatoes
Tomato Sauce
Ground beef
Chicken Breasts
Pasta
Cheeses
Seasonings
Jar of chopped garlic
Sugar



Most men LOVE spaghetti, so you can't go wrong there.



______________________________



The pasta:  bring big pot of water to a boil and add in a dash of salt.
Put half the box of pasta into the water and stir it up a little and let it do its thing.
For about 10-12 mins then pour into a strainer.



Beef:  Put thawed beef into a pan with 2 T water on medium heat.  Break up the meat with a spoon and stir it around as it browns.  Let cook until you see little or no pink.



Add to the sauce.



Sauce:  Pour 1 jar pasta sauce, 1 can tomatoes, 1 spoon of chopped garlic, 1 tsp. sugar into a pot.  Stir and let heat on medium heat for about 10-15 mins.  Reduce heat if it starts to bubble too much.



Put sauce on pasta and serve.  Your guy will love it.



Better yet, get some store-bought garlic bread and salad stuff.  Even better!



Source(s):



I cook all of the time:



http://shylahsrecipes.blogspot.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



busybake...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 180 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Purchase a basic cookbook such as Betty Crocker. Start with simple recipes (roast chicken, oven fried chicken, sandwiches, casseroles) and work your way up the kitchen ladder.



Cooking is fun and easy, if you start out simple.



Also, try to plan something you can make ahead so you can concentrate on the final recipe.



Below is a sample easy menu:



Coleslaw (buy pre-shredded coleslaw mix to use in your recipe) and prepare. Chill until ready to serve.



Oven Fried Chicken. Prepare and bake the chicken.



Mashed Potatoes:  Peel, cook and mash potatoes while the chicken is cooking.



Remove chicken from oven and place on platter.
Add mashed potatoes to serving bowl.
Serve with chilled coleslaw.



There ya go!



busybaker
List owner: Cozy Cooking Newsletter
Subscribe: 	CozyCookingNewsletter-subscribe@yahoogr...



</answer>

emilymay...

<answer>



Here's an oven pancake recipe for you:



(6 servings)



INGREDIENTS



3 tablespoons white sugar



1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon



1/3 cup butter



4 eggs



1 cup milk



1 cup all-purpose flour



1 tablespoon confectioners' sugar



Add to Recipe Box



My folders:



DIRECTIONS
Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). In a small bowl, mix together white sugar and cinnamon; set aside.



Place butter in a 9 inch cake pan and heat in the oven until melted. In a blender or food processor, whip eggs and milk. Pour in flour and beat until well combined. Pour batter into hot pan. Sprinkle on sugar and cinnamon.



Bake in preheated oven for 20 to 25 minutes, or until puffed and golden. Dust with confectioners' sugar; serve warm.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Oven-Pancak...



</answer>



<answer from>



sherwin
Member since: 10 June 2007
Total points: 355 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



it wont be pancake anymore... it would be just a cake or bread.



pancake is called such because of its pan toasted exterior and soft fluffy inside.



if you baked it in the oven, its cake or bread.



if you cook pancake batter using a waffle maker, its a waffle... not a pancake anymore.



</answer>

busybake...

<answer>



No. It is not safe to eat. Botulism is found in canned foods so that shouldn't be a concern but you can get food poisoning from other sources including improperly stored food. Your stew would qualify for improper storage.



Check the USDA web site for more info.



busybaker
List owner:  Cozy Cooking Newsletter

</answer>

<question from>



Zachary's Mummy
Member since: 13 August 2007
Total points: 1237 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Can you put potato gnocchi in soup?



I bought some potato gnocchi for the first time and I was wondering what happens if you add them to a soup. I know you're actually supposed to serve them with sauce and whatnot, but what do you think? Will they break down if I put them in soup?



Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



chad c
Member since: 09 May 2007
Total points: 11772 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



they won't break down. you just have to make sure you don't let them sit in the hot broth for too long. they will be like dumplings, if they are overcooked they will be tough. the most appealing thing about gnocchi is the pillow like, soft texture of the pasta.



</answer>



<answer from>



WTF????
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 30054 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



they wont break down at all, but i would cook them seperately and then add them to your soup bowl instead of putting them in your soup as they will absorb too much liquid and get soggy and mushy.



</answer>



<answer from>



steve j
Member since: 16 August 2007
Total points: 2144 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Make the soup and don't add the gnocchi until you are serving it. Any pasta will break down if it's left in a hot broth long enough



</answer>

<question>



Banana bread recipe question?



I have been making banana bread from the same recipe for the last few months, it always comes out good, but my last 2 batches seem a little different then the previous times. It comes out much paler, and not as moist. Does anyone have any idea how it can come out differently if I didn't change anything that I did before? All the ingridents are the same brands as before to.
Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Dee Bee
Member since: 19 February 2008
Total points: 771 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I recently made the BEST banana bread ever. I found the recipe on Foodnetwork.com. It's by Chef Tyler Florence. It was so moist and delicious, even the very next day! It calls for pecans, but I didn't put them in. Even my fiance, who loves his mom's banana bread couldn't stop eating this one!



http://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/tyler...



Source(s):



foodnetwork.com



</answer>



<answer from>



PJ
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 18189 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It might be due to the ripeness of the bananas, or the humidity on the day you make the bread.  Riper bananas make a darker, moister bread than yellow/green bananas.



</answer>



<answer from>



neilysta...
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 315 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Welcome to the club! That has happened to me before...remember that products of same brand do sometimes have higher or lower qualities, the bananas may have been more ripe or less ripe each time, sugar could be slightly lighter or darker, the eggs could be the same in quantity but slightly larger or smaller each time. You also have to be careful not to over mix the batter and ensure the oven temperature is right and preheated before baking....As long as the consistency and taste is good I think you should be okay...



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



Suzanne

Total points: 351 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Do you want to fry.. or bake?



If frying:



There are special seasoning blends made for Seafood.. I would use that. For frying.. coat in egg, then flour (or fish fry), get your oil hot, but not too hot and fry for a few minutes on each side (until med. brown)



It doesn't take too long to fry.



Source(s):



good luck, hope it turns out great!

<answer from>



Irish Sean

<answer>

Put this fish in a glass baking dish and smother in marinate.



Cover with aluminum foil and broil for about 30 minutes.



Enjoy!

<answer from>



Jackie G
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 297 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just season with salt and pepper...dredge it in flour and fry in about 1/4 inch of oil.  Let it cook a few minutes on one side, then flip.  The key to keeping the crispy fried crust on is to make sure you wait until it's cooked good on the first side before you flip it.



Warning: it WILL stink up your house.  I don't cook fish much because of that.



</answer>



<answer from>



David S
Member since: 19 September 2006
Total points: 8602 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Law & Ethics



</answer from>



<answer>



If you like fish breaded and fried, I suggest that you head to the grocery store and pick up some fish fry coating. It will contain all seasonings needed to cook up crispy and tasty.



My mother taught me to break an egg and mix it with a little water. The egg helps the coating adhere to the fish. Dip the fish in the egg, and then into the coating. Use one hand for each part or you'll end up washing your hands over and over.



Cook the fish at medium to low heat in pre-heated olive oil. Yum.



</answer>



<answer from>



hairdressers's kid
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Frying fish (or any food) really isn't a healthy way to prepare a very healthy food.  Myrecipes.com has a lot of resources for someone just starting out.



An easy recipe for any white fish is to bake it with a little fresh lemon and herbs such as targon or rosemary.  Serve with wild rice and a side of veggies and you have a very clean meal.



Good luck!



Source(s):



http://www.myrecipes.com/recipes/



</answer>



<answer from>



jackdaws...
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 275 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



ANOTHER RECIPE....IN FRYING PAN..U CAN COOK W/ BONES EVEN. IT TASTES BETTER. PUT SOME VIRIN OIL/BUTTER FOR NON STICKING NEED. (OR BAKE AT 350 DEG. F. FOR 20 MINUTES FOR ONE OR TWO FILLETS.)
THEN WAIT UNTIL SLIGHTLY COOKED - MAYBEE 2 MINUTES.  THEN ADD TOMATO,ONION, OR UR CHOICE OF VEGGIE ON TOP..A LITTLE CILANTRO AND ALWAYS SOME GINGER ROOT (VERY SMALL AMOUNT-MABEE A FEW PIECES SMALL AS YOUR FINGERNAIL)
ADD SALT IF  U LIKE



</answer>



<answer from>



Haven_Su...
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 10998 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Easy home made fish fry- or go buy a fish fry coating and follow directions.



1 rinse and pat dry fish



2 season with a bit of salt and pepper" not much



3 Get out 3 shallow low lip plates or bowls- bowl 1- all purpose flour with salt, pepper, paprika and any other seasoning you like, bowl 2 egg wash 2 -3 eggs 2 tablespoons of water., Bowl 3- other bread coating or batter mix.



4 always when battering anything have a wet hand that will only touch wet ingredients and a dry hand that only touches dry. Now dip your fish in the flour mix first and shake off any excess. then in the egg, and finally in to the other coating. Shake off excess and place on a tray single layer.



5 heat up 2-3 tablespoons of canola oil in large skillet with lid at med high heat and a high edge. Get long handeled tongs, a brown paper bag for soaking up excess oil and With help if your unsure begin to fry your fish. To know if its done on one side, gently flip over and if its a like carmel color flip and finish cooking the other side. Remove from skillet place on brown grocery bag and continue. Serve with tarter sauce, lemon and you other dishes. Enjoy



Source(s):



http://www.recipezaar.com/24861- Quick and easy tartar sauce



</answer>



<answer from>



katjones...
Member since: 21 July 2006
Total points: 3383 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tilipia is a really nice mild white fish, so you can make it in a variety of ways.



You can season it with a spicy seasoning mix like Old Bay and a bit of olive oil and/or butter and slide it under the broiler for about 10 minutes per inch of thickness.



You can roll it in a mix of flour, cornmeal and grated parmesan cheese(about 1/2 c. flour for every c. of cornmeal and 1 tblsp. grated parmesan).  Season with salt, pepper and garlic powder.  Heat canola oil on the stove at medium heat until you can feel the heat when you put your hand about an inch from the pan, and then fry on both sides until golden.



You can slide it in a vegetable-based broth and seasonings and poach it.



By the way, if it is fresh or fresh/frozen, it should NEVER stink up the house.



</answer>

<answer>



EZ and fun.



Peanut Butter Cookies.



1 jar peanut butter / does not matter what kind



1 egg



1 cup sugar



Mix well, bake in preheated over for 10-15 mins at 300-325 degrees, depending on your oven check on them after 10 and see if they need longer.



The child can pour all the ingrediants together , you mix, and then you both dollap onto cookie sheet.  - that way you can save your milk to drink with the cookies.



</answer>



<answer from>



Heidi Ho
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 212 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<question>

<answer from>



Sougandh...
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



We cant do anything after preparation.



Before preparation, the brinjals should not be kept outside after cutting them. Keeping them in salt water till putting them in the cooking vessel avoids turning bitter.



This tip may be helpful next time.



Source(s):



experience.



</answer>

<question from>



Lana
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 2825 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</question from>



<question>



I am going to make butternut squash ravioli tonight and want to make a "brown butter" sauce.  How?



How do I make a brown butter and sage sauce?



Or a "buerre blanc" sauce.



Which would be better!



(People who make these sauces, only, please.  I can google all by myself, imagine that!  Looking for personal experience.)



</question>



<answer from>



Amber M
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 279 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Brown Butter Sauce
3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) butter
1 1/2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar
1 1/2 tablespoons chopped fresh thyme



For brown butter sauce:



Melt butter in heavy large skillet over medium heat. Cook until butter begins to brown, about 4 minutes. Remove from heat. Carefully mix in vinegar and thyme.



Meanwhile, working in batches, cook ravioli in large pot of boiling salted water until just tender, about 3 minutes. Using slotted spoon, carefully transfer ravioli to hot butter sauce; spoon sauce over to coat ravioli. Transfer to plates. Sprinkle with pecans, if desired; serve immediately.



</answer>



<answer from>



caroline ♥♥♥♥♥
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 43476 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



the recipe i use , its delicious



1/2 cup unsalted butter



3 tablespoons chopped fresh sage leaves (or 3/4 t. dried ground sage OR 3 t. dried crumbled sage)



1/4 teaspoon salt



1/8 teaspoon ground black pepper



3/4 cup freshly grated parmesan cheese



If possible, use fresh sage and freshly grated Parmesan to heighten the flavor of this dish. Makes a huge difference!



Heat butter over medium heat in a large skillet. Add sage and slowly cook butter until it begins to brown. (It's okay if the sage darkens and gets crunchy).



Remove from heat.add parmesan cheese, salt and pepper and toss.



</answer>
