<answer>



Your description is an oxy-moron;-{ pick one: good, healthy, easy.
To maximize your choices, use whole-grain pasta, boil 2 cups.
Make a white sauce, melt 2 tbsp butter or oil with 2 tbsp of flour.
Whisk over medium heat until smooth & golden yellow.
Add 2 cups of milk & whisk until smooth & thickened.
Add 1 cup of grated cheeses, cheddar, mozzarella, asiago, etc.
Stirring in a little at a time to melt but not curdle or get stringy.
Pour over pasta, mixing to coat thoroughly, then transfer to baking dish & bake in 400F oven until bubbly & golden on top.



</answer>



<answer from>



padget20...
Member since: 07 July 2006
Total points: 3307 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www.thesneakychef.com/free_recipe...



</answer>



<answer from>



Diamond Strength
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 5037 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



What You Need
1 cup elbow macaroni
1 cup milk
3 Tbsp. all-purpose flour
salt and pepper to taste
2 Tbsp. butter
1 cup shredded Cheddar cheese



What You Do
Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add pasta and cook for 8 to 10 minutes or until al dente; drain and reserve.
In a microwave-safe bowl, combine milk, flour and salt and pepper to taste; whisk or beat until smooth. Add butter and cheese; microwave on high for 5 minutes and whisk until smooth. Microwave for an additional 4 to 5 minutes and whisk or beat until smooth and no lumps remain.
Add cooked pasta to mixture; stir and serve.



</answer>

<question>



Have you a Recipe for Peach Crumble?



</question>



<answer from>



O
Member since: 16 July 2006
Total points: 2393 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients

6 cups peeled sliced ripe peaches 
1/4 cup packed brown sugar 
3 tablespoons flour 
1 teaspoon lemon juice 
1/2 teaspoon grated lemon, rind of 
1 teaspoon cinnamon



TOPPING

1 cup flour 
1 cup sugar 
1 teaspoon baking powder 
1/4 teaspoon salt 
1/4 teaspoon nutmeg 
1 egg, beaten 
1/2 cup butter, melted and cooled



Directions

1Heat oven to 375*. 
2Put peach slices in greased, shallow 11x7 baking dish. 
3Mix brown sugar, flour, lemon juice, peel, and cinnamon. 
4Sprinkle over the peaches. 
5Mix flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 
6Stir in egg until mixture is coarse crumbs. 
7Sprinkle over peaches. 
8Drizzle butter evenly over topping. 
9Bake for 38 minutes.



Voila!!!
Enjoy!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sunny Lass
Member since: 18 February 2007
Total points: 3716 (Level 4)

<answer from>



Rli R
Member since: 25 August 2007
Total points: 8153 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



You can make a wonderful fried rice!!  Make sure you start with your cooked rice cold.  Hopefully you also have a couple of eggs.  If you do, beat them, place in a hot skillet, sprinkle with the ground black pepper and cook as one big pancake.  Roll up and set aside.  Dice the chicken and saute in some oil (if raw) - very good using sesame oil.  Cook in the same pan you did the egg in - you don't have to clean it.  Set aside.  Dice the onions and saute until translucent.  Add the bell peppers, cut into small pieces and saute until tender. Add the rice to the pan, with the bell peppers, onions and the chicken, smashing the rice into them. Cook a bit until the rice is warm.



Add some soy sauce (hopefully you have it) and stir to coat all the rice with the soy sauce.  With the egg rolled up, cut it width-wise into strips and just before serving, stir it into the mixture.  The soy sauce is better if you mix a little water and sugar in with it before adding it to the mixture.  That will take away some of the bitterness of the soy sauce.



Enjoy!



</answer>



<answer from>



seamonster .
Member since: 16 April 2007
Total points: 728 (Level 2)

granny.r...
Member since: 23 November 2007

Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



NUTTY CABBAGE SLAW WITH PINEAPPLE

A delicately flavoured delicious crunchy texture



Ingredients

¼ (small) white cabbage, shredded
½ (small) red cabbage, shredded 
3 apples of choice cut into chunks juice of 2 lemons 
250 ml seedless raisins 
250 ml pineapple, cut into chunks 
30 ml roasted sesame seeds 
60 ml flaked almonds salt to taste



For dressing

80 ml olive or cooking oil 
30 ml white vinegar 
30 ml honey 
30 ml crushed garlic 
60 ml chopped parsley or coriander 
2 green chilies, finely chopped salt and pepper to taste

Method 
•	Place finely shredded cabbage into a large bowl. 
•	Toss apples with lemon juice. 
•	Add all salad ingredients together and keep aside. 
•	Mix all dressing ingredients together in a jar and shake well. 
•	Sprinkle over salad in bowl. 
•	Chill and serve as desired.



WATERCRESS STEW

1.8 kg cubed motton	50 ml oil
50 ml butter	4 large onions cut in portions
2 pinched garlic cloves	250 ml meat stock
250 ml white wine	8 baby potatoes
10 ml salt	Freshly ground black pepper
500g watercress	Saltwater
25 ml lemon juice
Wash watercress and place in salted water for about an hour
Heat butter and oil and brown mutton in that. Add onion and garlic and saute for a further 3 minutes.  Add meat stock and wine.  Bring to the boil.  Reduce heat and simmer for about 90 minutes.  Add baby potatoes, salt and pepper.  Add watercress, (Important that watercress has been washed and placed in salted water for an hour before cooking).  Simmer for another 30 minutes.  Add lemon juice just before serving. Serve hot on a bed of rice or on its own.

If after this you are still hungry, try these for sweets...

Koeksisters
The secret of the crisp syrupy outside of koeksisters is that they are taken straight from hot oil and dipped into ice-cold syrup. This seals the syrup outside and leaves the inside dryish in contrast. 
To make the syrup, mix a liter of sugar, 5 ml cream of tartar, 2.5 ml tartaric acid and 5 ml vanilla essence or grated orange rind or cinnamon, or 1.5 ml ginger with 500 ml of water. Bring mixture to the boil and allow it to simmer for about 10 minutes or until syrupy. Set syrup aside to cool. It is advisable to make the syrup first and leave it overnight in the fridge. 
To make the batter, sift 500 ml flour, 10 ml baking powder and 5 ml salt into a mixing bowl. Cut or rub 70 ml of margarine or butter into the dry ingredients. Beat an egg thoroughly and add it to 80 ml of milk. Add the egg and milk to the flour mixture, handling as little as possible. Put the dough in the fridge for at least one hour. Roll out the dough to a thickness of 4 mm. Cut into strips about 8 cm long and 2.5 cm wide. Cut each strip into three lengthwise, leaving one side uncut. Now plait the three pieces and press ends together firmly. 
Pre-heat a deep pan and remove syrup from the fridge. The hot fried koeksisters must be dropped into the cold syrup. The syrup will warm up about halfway through, so divide the syrup into two bowls. Deep-fry koeksisters until golden brown, drain for a few seconds on absorbent paper and dip into cold syrup.



</answer>

<answer>



tuna pasta that is cheap,  filling and tasty, get a tin of tuna (can be in brine or sunflower oil whatever your preference) cook the pasta, drain the tuna and put in bowl, to the tuna add either a finely chopped onion or some chives add some mayo and salad cream too suit your taste, mix it together, once pasta is cooked drain water and add the tuna mix making sure all pasta is covered, get a fresh lemon cut it in half and squeeze over pasta mix stir in. nice with a crusty roll.

You could also save up money and buy a wide mouth thermos jug.
How about stuffed tomato, hollowed out apple filled with cottage cheese or peanut butter, ants on a log, cold soup such as gazpacho, cold pizza, energy bars, or bring a shaker and some Carnation Instant breakfast and make a milkshake. How about making some Cornish Pasties? They are filling. You can make several at a time and freeze some before baking. You can thaw one during the day, bake the night before or that morning and plop into a sandwich bag or wrap in foil. They are just as good at room temp as they are when hot. Well, almost. You could make some Samosas. They are spicy East Indian fried pies. Great with chutney, hot or cold. I love them both ways. OR you could get an immersion heater and use it to heat some water to make soup or noodles or ??



Source(s):



Spent several years shifting for myself at lunchtime. We got a new principal who was determined to force everyone to eat the crappy cafeteria food. We got a small microwave and kept it in the trunk of my friend's car. Plugged it in in the gym during lunch. He almost caught us a couple of times and I overheard him say, "Did they get a new cook? Lunch actually smells GOOD today!" Imagine his shock and surprise when he actually tasted it, LOL. It was his first time. It wasn't the cafeteria he smelled, it was my reheated Portugese chicken. He fired the cook that day and things improved when he hired the kids who had just finished at the culinary institute. They wanted to build their resumes.

<question from>



Katherine E

</question from>



<question>



When making Lasagne/Lasagna.......?



Do you put a layer of meat first or a layer of pasta? I've seen both mentioned in different recipes but wondered what peoples personal preference was!



</question>



<answer from>



Goldengirl 2
Member since: 10 November 2007
Total points: 234 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



LASAGNE - MAKE SAUCE AS U WOULD FOR CHILI - IN LASAGNA DISH, SPOON A COVERING OF THE SAUCE, SO IT WILL NOT STICK TO THE DISH - LASAGNA IS PASTA THAT IS STICKY WHEN WET - SO THE TOMATO PASTE(CHILI) WILL PREVENT STICKING - THEN LAYER THE PASTA-LASAGNA - WITH THE SAUCE - WHEN IT REACHES DESIRED SIZE, USING THE PASTA AND SAUCE, COVER ENTIRE CONTENTS WITH GRATED CHEESE, AND BAKE UNTIL BUBBLY



Source(s):



MY EXPERIENCE OF 86 YEARS



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

<answer>



You should never put the pasta down first - are you sure you've seen that in a recipe? If you did that it would go hard and dry, it needs the moisture of the meat sauce or the bechamal on either side to work properly. Ignore anyone who is stupid enough to say pasta first, it will be horrible.

Does anyone know the recipe for making mousse using ideal milk and jelly. What size can do I use. Thank you. ?

</answer from>



<answer>



You just make up a fruit jelly according to the instructions then let it cool but before it sets you whisk in a can of evaporated milk. Then you let it set in the fridge.
Not sure if that is a large tin of milk or a small one but you could try the small one first to see how it works out. If it doesn't look fluffy enough then just whisk in a second small one. I suppose it depends how you like it.
Hope it works. It has been years since I made one of those and I might have to try it out myself now you have reminded me about it!!



</answer>

<question from>



scotty
Member since: 14 August 2007
Total points: 567 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Anybody got a recipe for a nice steak pie?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



STEAK PIE



Serves 2

INGREDIENTS

250g of beef
½ an onion
1 tablespoon of sunflower oil
½ a tablespoon of flour
150ml of beer
Ground pepper to taste
1 tablespoon of parsley
1 egg 
450g packet of frozen ready rolled pastry

DEFROSTING

Defrost the frozen pastry according to the instructions on the packet.



METHOD

Chop the beef into 2 cm (1 inch) pieces. Peel the onion, cut it in half, chop one half into tiny pieces and save the other half.



Put the oil in a saucepan on a moderate heat. Fry the beef and onion for about 5 minutes until the meat is brown with no pink bits. Stir frequently to stop it sticking. Add the flour and beer, and stir. Season with the pepper.



Bring to the boil, then turn down the heat until it is just boiling (simmering). Put the lid on and cook very gently for 2 hours. Check the liquid level from time to time and top it up if it starts to dry out.

Add the parsley. Mix and put into an ovenproof dish.



Break the egg into a bowl and pick out any bits of shell. Mix up the egg.

Unroll the pastry. Moisten the rim of the dish with some of the egg. Cut off a strip of pastry and place it around the moistened rim of the dish. Moisten the top of the strip of pastry with some more of the egg. Cover the dish with the pastry, pressing the edges down firmly. Trim the edges and make a hole in the centre. Brush the pastry with the remainder of the egg, so that it comes out of the oven shiny.



Cook in a preheated oven at 200°C, 400°F, gas mark 6 for 30 minutes.



ADDITIONS & ALTERATIONS

Use water instead of the beer. Add some button mushrooms at the same time as the parsley. Use mixed herbs instead of the parsley.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Fresh puff pastry
1lb stewing steak
4 beef links
mushrooms
chopped onion
2 oxo cubes
12oz. water
salt & pepper
mixed herbs.

Put everything in a pressure cooker for 15 mins. When cooked thicken gravy with cornflour then spoon into steak pie ashet.
Roll out puff pastry and cover stew.
Brush with beaten egg and make slits in pastry.
Bake at 210 degrees for 20 minutes.
Delicious!!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients:



* pasty for 1-crust pie (you can get frozen ones at the grocery)



* 1 cup sliced onion



* 2 tablespoons butter



* 1 pound round steak, cut in small cubes



* 1/4 cup flour



* 1 1/2 teaspoons salt



* 1/8 teaspoon black pepper



* 1/2 teaspoon paprika



* dash ginger



* dash allspice



* 2 1/2 cups boiling beef broth or bouillon



* 2 cups diced raw potatoes

Preparation:

Cook onions in butter until lightly browned; remove and set aside. Coat meat in flour mixed with salt, pepper, paprika, ginger and allspice. Brown in the hot butter. Add boiling beef broth, cover and simmer for about 1 hour, or until meat is tender. Add potatoes and cook for 10 minutes longer. Pour mixture into an 8-inch greased casserole; arrange onions on top. Cover with pie pastry; crimp edges and cut slits for steam. Bake at 400° for 30 to 40 minutes.

**You can also add chopped veggies (carrots, celery...etcetera) to the beef mixture before putting in oven, if desired.



</answer>

<question from>



tim
Member since: 28 August 2008

</question from>



<question>



Can you eat the swede raw??



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Why would you? Wouldnt all that hair and corpse paint get in the way?



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I suppose so, but they sound like that would be better cooked.
The rutabaga or swede or (yellow) turnip (Brassica napobrassica, or Brassica napus var. napobrassica) is a root vegetable that originated as a cross between the cabbage and the (white) turnip—see the turnip disambiguation page. Its leaves may also be eaten as a leaf vegetable.

"Rutabaga" (from dialectal Swedish rotabagge) is the American term, "swede" is the term used in England. Its common name in Sweden is "Kålrot" (Cabbage root). It is also known as the "Swedish turnip" or "yellow turnip". To the Scots, the Irish, and some of the Northern English it is called "turnip", or colloquially, especially in Scotland, "neep"—the vegetable known elsewhere as a turnip being called a "swede" or a "white turnip" in Scotland. In the US, rutabagas may also be called "yellow turnips." In Newfoundland, white turnips are relatively unknown, with rutabagas being known simply as turnips.

The vegetable is native to Sweden, and was introduced into Scotland. From there, it spread to the rest of Britain and to North America. In continental Europe, it acquired a bad reputation when it became a food of last resort during World War I. In the German Steckrübenwinter (swede winter) of 1916–17, large parts of the population were kept alive on a diet consisting of little else but swedes. After the war, most people were so tired of eating swedes that they have remained unpopular to this day and are rarely planted.

These days, swedes are mostly eaten as part of stews or casseroles, or are served mashed with carrots, or are baked in a pasty.

In Scotland, "neeps" are traditionally served mashed as part of the Burns supper and are hollowed out at Hallowe'en to make Jack-o'-lanterns.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

<question from>



sacha
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can you correct this cooking fault?



Im making Roast stuffed chicken. But the breast chicken is dry. What should I do?



</question>



<answer from>



Nicky
Member since: 17 February 2007
Total points: 10622 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If it's already cooked, not much to be done other than to make some gravy to go with it to add some moisture. Next time try covering the breast meat (after about 30 minutes when it's already browned) with some foil to reduce the amount of heat it receives. Then as it's nearing the time to be done remove it for the last 10 or so minutes to crisp up the skin again.



</answer>

<answer from>



Chef Mark
Member since: 08 November 2006
Total points: 3442 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't stuff your chicken.  In the words of Alton Brown from the show "Good Eats":



"Stuffing is evil."

The problem is that breast meat is dry to begin with because it's so low in fat.  Then, when you stuff a bird, by the time the center of the stuffing is cooked to the proper temperature, (165 degrees), the outer portions will be overcooked.  While the dark meat can tolerate this to some degree, the white meat cannot.

To improve a chicken's juiciness you can brine it.  That means soaking it in a salt-water solution which causes the meat to absorb some of the water.

http://www.foodforthoughtonline.net/
______________________________________...



</answer>



<answer from>



mamaflut...
Member since: 07 May 2007
Total points: 8788 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's a really good dip for chicken:
2 tablespoons low sodium soy sauce 
2 tablespoons lime juice 
1 1/2 teaspoons rice vinegar 
2 tablespoons brown sugar 
1 clove garlic, pressed 
1 teaspoon chili 
garlic paste 
Combine soy sauce, lime juice, vinegar, sugar, garlic and chili garlic paste in a small bowl. Per serving: 232 Calories; 8g Fat; 28g Protein; 10g Carbohydrate; trace Dietary Fiber; 68mg Cholesterol; 463mg Sodium. Exchanges: 0 Grain (Starch); 4 Lean Meat; 1/2 Vegetable; 0 Fruit; 1 1/2 Fat; 1/2 Other Carbohydrates.



</answer>

<answer from>



curious
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 571 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try marinading them over night in a mix of olive oil, rosemary. If you have pau pau leaves or flesh where you are, add that too. BBQ is best but as they will have soaked in the olive oil, you can hit them with a really hot pan, slightly oiled, flash fry and seal the tender juices inside. try not to keep these in the oven while you prepare the rest...serve them straight onto the plates!  Not Baaaahd!!



</answer>



<answer from>



TAL
Member since: 10 July 2007
Total points: 2169 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try planking them.  I took a grilling on a plank class this summer and lamb was one of the meats we cooked.  Marinade or season your lamb with whatever you like.  We used an orange juice, brown sugar, and blackened seasoning for our marinade. You can plank either on a gas grill or in the oven.  We used red cedar planks that had been soaked in water for 4 to 6 hours.  Both grill and oven were heated to 350 degrees.



Use indirect heat on the grill.  Take the wet planks and put in the oven or on the grill for 5 minutes allowing the plank to warp.  Then turn the plank over for another 3 minutes and the warping should pretty much even out.  At this point, put your lamb on the hot plank and close the oven or grill.  When using a plank, you do not turn the meat over.  It took between 15 to 20 minutes to cook on the gas grill and 20 to 25 minutes in the oven.  Start checking you lamb at about the 15 minute mark as each grill and oven are different in their regulation of temperature.  Also when using the grill, check periodically to make sure your plank has not caught fire.  If it has, use a spray bottle with water to extinguish the flames.

Anyway, the lamb turned out tender, juicy, and very tasty.



</answer>

<question from>



1985
Member since: 31 July 2006
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the purpose of butter in bread making?



I want to make a bread loaf, like a white farm loaf, but all recipes call for butter, eggs, or oil, what are the purpose of these ingredients in the bread making process?
is there any way i can make the bread without them?



</question>



<answer from>



Tyler L
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 2489 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



butter makes the bread moist, and makes it lighter and airier.  oil does the same thing.  eggs bond together all of the ingredients.  sorry, but all of these ingredients are necessary (except you can have butter without the oil, and the other way around)



</answer>



<answer from>



U.S.  AMERICAN
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 5995 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



when oil and butter are both included in a baking recipe, the butter is usually added for flavor and the oil for not sticking to the pan.  Your going to need to follow the recipe to the letter when baking.  Making sauces, gravies and casseroles, soups, you can make it up as you go along.  But baking is more of a science.  If you make that recipe without butter, you should increase the oil to make up the difference and sacrifice the taste and texture.  It wont be as good with out.



</answer>



<answer from>



The Fat Man
Member since: 02 July 2008
Total points: 1525 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

~The Fat Man



</answer>

<question from>



Chocolate O Latrell
Member since: 22 August 2008
Total points: 2946 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Why does temperature setting matter when something is in the oven?



I'm being ridiculous here, so don't take this serious. But I want to know why they tell me to set the temperature to 300degrees or something, but what does all that matter????..Why can't I just go to 10000 degrees to make the food cook quicker??..Why wait 2 hours instead of 2 minutes?

Do things become better cooked when given more time or something??



</question>



<answer from>



Natalia
Member since: 22 August 2008
Total points: 1020 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It matters because it helps cook the food you want to it's best taste.  Like meat, it's always good to either cook above 500degrees or broil it.  When you broil meet, you have to pay attention that the top of the oven doesn't burn the top of whatever you are cooking.  Pasta type recipes should be cooked between 300 to 400 degrees.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



The degrees here are in degrees Celsius and not Fahrenheit.lol..I have to convert.lol



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



fromtheg...
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 2532 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>

Source(s):



http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=slo...



</answer>



<answer from>



Tecoy M
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



it depends on what you are cookinh if its to high it will burn  etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



Scanner
Member since: 27 March 2008
Total points: 12443 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The answer is simple it is physics. The density and type of the food being cooked dictate the cooking (oven) temperature. To cook a pot pie for instance, if you put the pie at a very high temperature, not only does the top food burn but it ceases to conduct heat to the center to cook the rest. That's the full story.



</answer>



<answer from>



Craig B
Member since: 11 May 2006
Total points: 2163 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all depends on the thickness of the food, but you want to make sure the outside and the inside cook correctly relative to each other.  If you want the heat to permeate evenly, say for a cake or a thick roast, then your temperature should be lower.  If you want the outside to get crusty, but the inside to stay rare, say for a smaller roast or some veggies, then you crank it up.  It's all in the physics.



</answer>



<answer from>



cross-st...
Member since: 18 September 2007
Total points: 7234 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Cleaning & Laundry



</answer from>



<answer>



So, you wouldn't burn whatever you're cooking in the oven.  But if you
want to cook it faster, may I suggest that you use the microwave oven?



</answer>



<answer from>



Timbo
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



some things just require lower temps such as cookies, so they don't cook to fast and become burnt on the bottom, extra crispy on the outside and still dough in the center. basically anything you cook at a higher temp than it says is going to be raw in the center a look done on the outside.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=ApDF.6LsYhw0AMbhPbtSM3DfLRV4642.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk46313.txt</current file name>



<category>



Food & Drink



Cooking & Recipes



</category>



<question from>



Jamieee
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What does a deep fat fryer look like?



can you please be descriptive



</question>



<answer from>



R B
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 942 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A deep fat fryer can be a big, DEEP, heavy metal pot.  You put fat in it - preferably vegetable or corn oil, and peanut oil also works well because it doesn't burn at high temperatures.  Keep the oil deep enough to cover the food you will put in it.  This means it needs to be at least 1/3 full because when you add the food it sometimes bubbles up.  You heat this oil to 350 to 400 degrees F using a thermometer that is just for this.  Frying in small batches will insure that the temperature of the oil does not drop so much that the food absorbs a lot of oil and get soggy.

If you buy/use a deep fat fryer you will find that they have a thick wall - like the Fry Daddy, or an insulated wall which has an outside wall and an inside wall.  The inside will be metal and the outside can be painted or decorated.  Both have electric plugs.  The Fry Daddy comes with a metal slotted scooper and has a non-stick interior.  The deep fat fryer has a metal basket you put the food in and usually does not have a non-stick interior.  The Fry Daddy has no temperature control.  You just put the oil in, heat it up by plugging it in and when the oil is hot enough, you put the food in and watch it.  It is small-ish and cooks quickly.  The other deep fat fryer has a temperature gauge so if your recipe has a temp. to cook it at then you set it to that.  When I want to know if the oil is hot enough I drop one drop of water in the oil.  It spatters like crazy, and the oil is hot.  I could also use the thermometer, but when I can't find it, the water works okay.  The Fry Daddy uses less oil as it is smaller.  Using a large pot or an electric deep fat fryer uses about the same amount of oil.  Both come with lids for storage, but you don't use it to cook with.  I drain my oil out every time and store it in a container with a lid.  You can store it in the refrig to keep it longer.



Hope this was helpful.



Source(s):



www.ibiblio.org



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks for the  info



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Brian C
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 74 (Level 1)



</answer from>

</answer>

<answer from>



mad
Member since: 20 June 2006
Total points: 13732 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The easiest way is to buy a jar of your favourite cook in curry sauce, chop a piece of chicken breast into small pieces, fry them until they are white all over, then add the sauce, stirring, and bring to the boil. Cover the pan, lower the heat and allow to simmer for about 30 minutes - and there you are!



</answer>



<answer from>



Silly's-...
Member since: 04 March 2008
Total points: 4480 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I marinate the meat for a few hours or over night. and use lots of hot pepper.

Here is one of my favorit base recipes, I add what I have, omit what I don't have and adjust to my tastes, but its a good start to a great dish.  Remember all amounts are estimated, a great curry dish needs to be seasoned by taste, not with a teaspoon.

Hope you enjoy.



2 lbs. beef 
4 tablespoons cooking oil 
2 cloves garlic 
2 tablespoons finely chopped chives (green onions) 
1 tablespoon finely chopped fresh ginger root (optional) 
a few sprigs of fresh cilantro
a few sprigs of frsh thyme
2 cups water 
2 onions 
2 tablespoons curry powder 
1 teaspoon black pepper 
salt to taste 
Method:
Cut meat into small pieces. Chop fine onions, garlic, chive, ginger. Heat oil in pan, add curry powder and seasonings and cook for about 3 minutes. Add the meat, black pepper and brown in savoury fat. Add water to cover meat and cook until meat is tender. Cooking too rapidly will toughen meat and boil away curry sauce



</answer>



<answer from>



Ja Ma
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 522 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



saute chopped onions, garlic, and whole dried cayenne and add cubed meat with potatoes or veggies stirring until meat surface is dry and somewhat carmelize and the extracted water has been boiled off. add curry powder of your choice along with thai fish sauce (a substitute for salt) and sour unsweetened youghurt. stir and cover. simmer until meat and potatoes are tender enough to eat. serve on rice or flat unlevened bread with cold sauvignon blanc.



</answer>



<answer from>



Son Goku
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Okay, you've got many types of curry.



American, Indian, Thai (many of which come of India, Vietnam and Cambodia), Cambodia, Vietnamese, and Japanese.

Curry is a thick broth with a paste, normally spicy or added with a sweet flavor.I would write a whole synopsis for you, but why not watch this video instead? http://www.metacafe.com/watch/463224/cle... Part two is on there as well... Happy cooking!



Source(s):



http://www.metacafe.com/watch/463224/cle...



</answer>

<answer>



one is a traditional chicken curry and one is a japanese curry



Chicken Curry
it can be frozen and thawed the day of)

Serves (4-6)



INGREDIENTS
1/2 cup unbleached all purpose flour 
Salt & Pepper 
3 boneless whole chicken breast halved 
5 tablespoons unsalted butter 
1 medium onion 
2 cloves garlic 
2 red peppers seeded and diced 
3 tablespoons best quality curry powder 
1 can stewed tomatoes 
1 can cream of coconut 
a dash of Tabasco sauce 
a dash of Worcester sauce 
1/2 cup currants 
PREP WORK Gather up all the ingredients and preheat your oven to 350°F.

Finly chop the onion and mince the garlic cloves.

Seed and dice the red peppers.



HOW TO MAKE AT HOME
Season the flour with S&P and lightly coat chicken with mixture. Heat 3 Tbl. butter in a skillet over medium heat, add chicken and lightly brown on all sides. Remove chicken from the skillet and preheat oven to .



Add remaining 2 tablespoons butter to the skillet and melt over medium heat. Add onions, garlic, peppers and sauté, stirring frequently until the veggies are soft (5-7 minutes).



Stir in curry powder and cook 2 minutes longer.



Stir in tomatoes and cream of coconut, heat to simmering and season with Worcester sauce, Tabasco and S&P to taste. Stir in currants & remove from heat.



Arrange the sautéed chicken in a casserole and pour the curry sauce over the chicken bake covered until the chicken is tender, about 45 minutes. Serve over rice.



This Japanese vegetable curry recipe is a variation on basic Japanese curry recipe. Other vegetables and mushrooms can be added as you like. Using Japanese curry roux (curry sauce mix) makes it easy to cook Japanese-style curry at home. Various kinds of curry roux, such as S&B and House brand are available at supermarkets and Asian grocery stores. Serve curry with steamed rice.



Japanese Curry



Ingredients:
1 1/2 Tbsp. plus 1 Tbsp. olive oil
1 Japanese eggplant, trimmed and cut into 1/4 inch thick rounds (1 cup)
2 small yellow bell pepper, cored and cut into bite-size pieces (1 cup)
Salt and pepper to season
1 clove garlic, minced
1 small onion, sliced (1 cup)
1 medium carrot, peeled and cut into bite-size pieces (1 cup)
4 cups water
1 small package (125g) Japanese curry roux

Preparation:
Heat 1 1/2 Tbsp. of olive oil in medium skillet over medium heat. Saute eggplant and bell pepper for a few minutes, or until tender. Sprinkle with salt and pepper and set aside. Heat 1 Tbsp. of olive oil in large and deep pot over medium heat. Saute garlic and onion until onion is tender, about a few minutes. Add carrot and stir-fry with onion for a minute. Add water, stir well, and simmer on low heat for about 15 minutes, or until carrot is tender. Dissolve blocks of Japanese curry roux in the soup and stir lightly. Add fried eggplant and bell pepper in the curry and stop the heat. 
*Makes 6 servings



Source(s):



about.com
www.reluctantgourmet.com



</answer>

<answer>



Simple chicken curry recipe -



1lb fresh chicken, chopped into bite size pieces

Three tablespoons cooking oil or ghee

One large onion, finely sliced

Four cloves of garlic, finely chopped

Three red chillies, seeds removed and finely chopped

One inch of ginger, finely chopped

Three fresh tomatoes, finely chopped or one tin 400g chopped tomatoes

1tbs tomato puree

Handful fresh leaf coriander

1tsp cumin powder

1tsp coriander powder

1tsp turmeric

1tsp garam masalla

1tsp of your favourite curry powder

1tsp salt



Method



Fry the onions in the heated oil over a medium heat for 20-25 minutes, stirring occasionally.

Add the chillies, ginger and garlic and continue frying gently for five minutes.

Add the spices (except the fresh coriander)and salt and cook on the lowest heat for another five minutes.

Add the tomato puree and tomatoes and bring to a boil. Then reduce the heat and let it all bubble away for 10 minutes.

The curry sauce is now ready. Add the chicken and continue to cook for half and hour.

Ensure the chicken is thoroughly cooked through before serving.

Serve sprinkled with fresh coriander and accompanied by pilau rice.



</answer>



<answer from>



louise
Member since: 21 January 2008
Total points: 3210 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



creamy chicken curry

Ingredients
25g Plain flour
3 tsp Garam masala or mild curry powder
500g Chicken breasts, skinned and cut into strips
2 tbsp Vegetable oil
25g Butter
1 Onion, sliced
1 tsp Cumin seeds
1 tsp Fennel seeds
2 Bay leaves
400g tin Peeled tomatoes
2 Garlic cloves, crushed
1 tsp Turmeric
1 Green chilli, finely chopped
250g Natural yogurt
15g Fennel fronds or coriander leaves



Method
Mix together the flour and 2 tsp garam masala with some salt and pepper in a dish. Dredge the chicken in this mixture, shaking off any excess. 
Heat 1 tbsp oil and half the butter in a large frying pan and fry the chicken, in batches if necessary, for 2 minutes on each side. Remove from the pan and set aside. 
Heat the remaining oil and butter in a saucepan and sauté the onions over a gentle heat for 5 minutes, until soft. Add the cumin seeds, fennel seeds and bay leaves and cook for 1–2 minutes. Add the tomatoes, garlic, turmeric and remaining garam masala and cook for around 10 minutes until the mixture becomes thick. 
Add the chilli and chicken and simmer for 15 minutes until everything is cooked through. Serve with yogurt and fennel fronds or coriander leaves.



</answer>



<answer from>



Derek J
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)

<question>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



meatloaf



Takes 15 minutes to make, 1 hour 30-40 minutes in the oven, plus cooling



Vegetable oil, for greasing
700g minced beef or 500g minced beef and 200g minced pork
2 onions, finely chopped
2 garlic cloves, crushed
1 large carrot, grated
2 tsp dried thyme
1 egg, lightly beaten
250g fresh breadcrumbs
50ml milk
2 tbsp Worcestershire sauce
2 tsp Dijon mustard



1. Preheat the oven to 160°C/fan140°C/ gas 3. Grease a 1kg loaf tin. In a bowl, mix the mince, onions, garlic, carrot, thyme and egg. Meanwhile, in a separate bowl, mix the breadcrumbs with the milk, then add to the meat mixture. Stir in the Worcestershire sauce, mustard and season well.
2. Fill the loaf tin with the mixture. Cover with foil. Put in a deep roasting tin and pour in boiling water to come a third of the way up the loaf tin’s sides. Bake for 1 hour 30-40 minutes, until cooked through. Cool for 15 minutes in the tin, then remove, slice and serve with mashed potato, gravy and mixed vegetables.



</answer>

<question>



Are the ingridients in jerk chicken unhealthy?



</question>



<answer from>



UKTV Food
Member since: 07 August 2008



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Not at all (although it depends how much oil is used). In this recipe there's only 1 tablespoon of oil and the rest is simply chicken, spices and vegetables:

Ingredients
2 chickens

For the marinade:
1 tbsp allspice berries, freshly ground
3 Scotch bonnet peppers
2 bunches of Spring onions, chopped
2 Onions, chopped
2 garlic clove, chopped
2.5 cm fresh ginger root
1 bunch of Thyme, chopped
1 tbsp vegetable oil
1 tbsp water
1 tsp Sugar
1 tsp Salt
freshly ground black pepper

Method
1. Using a food processor or a pestle and mortar, blend or crush the allspice berries, Scotch bonnet peppers, spring onions, onion, garlic, ginger, thyme, oil, water, sugar, salt and freshly ground pepper into a paste.



2. Toss the chicken quarters thoroughly with the marinade. Cover and marinate overnight in the refrigerator.



3. Preheat the oven to 200°C/gas 6 or heat a barbecue to cooking point. If using the oven, preheat a griddle pan until hot. Brown the chicken quarters on the griddle pan, transfer to a roasting tin and roast for 30 minutes until cooked through. If using a barbecue, cook the chicken pieces on it for around 40 minutes, turning often and basting with the marinade.



Enjoy!

Julia



Source(s):



uktvfood.co.uk



</answer>

<answer>



Mop means to use a kitchen tool that looks like a mop and baste meat with it.  It is used primarily in southern BBQ cooking techniques.  Mix all the ingredients together.  Put in the baster and get a lot of the sauce on there.  Then place the baster on the meat and get it all over the meat, generously.



When President Johnson threw a barbecue he called upon is favorite Pitmaster Walter Jetton to cook up a meal that often feed hundreds of people. This meal would be cooked on an open air fire pit that measured about 40 square feet. Walter would cover every square inch of this surface in ribs, roasts and meats of every variety. To keep the meat moist he mopped it, with a real mop. Hence the barbecue term, “mop”.



Today you can buy a miniature tool that looks like a kitchen mop to mop your meat. The cotton fibers hold the thin mop sauce and make it easy to dash large amounts on at once. But a mop isn’t just another kind of barbecue sauce. It is a thin, watery solution that drips over meat adding moisture to combat the drying of an open fire. Think of it this way; a sauce is applied with a brush, like a paint brush.



A mop, sometimes called a sop, is applied with, well a mop. Sauces are thicker than mops. Mops should have a consistency close to water.



Source(s):



About.com: Barbecues & Grilling and myself



</answer>



<answer from>



Mintee
Member since: 01 June 2006
Total points: 28895 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Saudi Arabia

<question>



Do you think mini marshmallows would be good in Nestle Toll House cookies?

<answer>

<answer from>



rgs_help
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 1985 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I make a rocky road cookie that my neighbor goes absolutely nuts for whenever i make them.  i use small marshmallows (when i think mini, i am thinking the kind you put in hot cocoa) and i freeze them, and add them to the cookie dough as i am dropping the cookies. this way i have control over where the marshmallows are placed in the cookie, and i can keep them from being on the bottom of the cookie, which makes a melty mess.  and instead of using drop method, i just spoon out the dough, put my marshmallows in top, and fold the dough all around the marshmallows until they are completely covered.  this keeps the white color of the marshmallow visible after they are baked, and you don't have to struggle with getting the cookie off your cookie sheet because of the melted marshmallow.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mustang Nik~Mikey's KittyKat
Member since: 16 December 2007
Total points: 16662 (Level 6)

<question>



Easy first date receipes?



I am new to the whole cooking thing, and I have a first date coming up in which I have to cook dinner.  Can anyone give me a receipe or two that are easy enough for a beginner to handle without burning the house down?  Thanks so much to everyone for your help!!



</question>



<answer from>



LovinTh...
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 2284 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



pasta is perfect for beginners.



Go to the market and pick up some boneless skinless chicken breast, some alfredo sauce in the bottle (classico brand 4 cheese alfredo), some fettuccini noodles, some garlic, some fresh basil, parmesean cheese, butter, and broccoli crowns.

cook your pasta- about 10m
Slice your chicken breast into peices, season with S&P, brown in a pan with some oilive oil and minced garlic. Add in the alfredo sauce. Meanwhile, steam your broccoli crowns. The last 8mins of cooking your chicken & alfredo sauce slice your french bread and brush with melted garlic and butter, throw it in the oven on 375.

When you serve, put some fettuccini on the plate, top with chicken alfredo sauce, shaved parmesean cheese, and chiffanade some fresh basil, top with that. Put a slice of garlic bread on the side with steamed broccoli.

YUMMIE!

and pair it with a nice white, not red wine



</answer>

<answer>



Your question leads to many other questions.  What is it you are cooking? Are you useing a glass or dark non stick pan?  As a gerneral rule most things are baked at 350 to 375 .degrees.  Bake times vary on what you are baking and how dense it is.

When all else fails consult a relative or friend.

Happy baking. Trial and error are all part of the process and the way that you learn.

<answer>



when I went to university, my mother bought me 2 cookbooks.. I still have them now.. (30years of age now).. and they are just about falling apart..
Better Homes and Gardens cookbook (it has a checkerboard cover)
and
Betty Crockers cookbook

both are easy and simple to understand..
think of cooking as science class.. it tells you exactly what measures to use and how to mix it together and how long to cook..
just follow step by step the recipe.. you'll get used to it in no time..

but purchase a few simple items like a 1 cup pyrex glass measuring cup, some teaspoon, tablespoon measuring spoons,  2 or 3 good sauce pans with lids. something small/medium sized for reheating sauces, and a largerone that might hold a whole stew..
a good frying pan (stainless steel) with a lid... a metal spatula for flipping foods in pan, a huge spoon for stiring stuff in pan and moving around fried stuff.. and substituting for  a ladle.. some good knives.. a cutting board.. a strainer for draining pasta etc.. a cake pan( go with the rectangler 13x9x2 pan) cause you can roast in it, bake a cake in it, and make casseroles in it also.. a good size to use.. buy a huge roll of aluminum foil.. 
staples like all purpose flour, milk, eggs, cooking oil. salt, peppers, sugar. etc is always good...

goodluck and dont be scared..



</answer>



<answer from>



gregpaul...
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



ok, you can learn to cook anything in a cookbook or off the web. the main thing i have to say, as a former cook/perpetually hungover college student, is that if you light a bacon grease fire FOR GOD'S SAKE do NOT smother it with flour. it is not happy times.

<answer>



I think you should invest in a slow cooker. They are so good. They come with a little recipe booklet. You can honestly throw just about anything in there, turn it on, get home from work and eat straight away. If this isn't an option for you, then why not buy a kitchen starter kit. I bought one when I moved out of home and it did the trick for the forst couple of years. You can get them at k-mart for about $120. The one I got included 3 different sized saucepans, a skillet, a collinder, a chopping block, a knife block with about 6 different knives and a pair of utility scissors, wooden spoon, whisk, ladle, and a few containers with lids. 
Some things that should always be in your freezer/fridge/cupboard are: flour, rice, canned tomatoes, tomato paste, pasta, stock cubes, gravy, mince meat, butter, milk, eggs, frozen veggies, bread, olive oil
I would recommend just buying a food magazine from the supermarket. They have some really tasty and cheap meal ideas that would be perfect for you. Hope I helped

ps. If you are aussie, (lol, me too!) try recipes plus magazine or super food ideas. They are good ones :)

<answer>



First of all, congrats on the move!

A good place to start is by asking friends that cook how they make any particular dish that you like.



Basic seasonings to always keep on hand; salt, pepper, garlic salt, seasoned salt.  There are others depending upon what type of food you are wanting to eat, but those are pretty common.  I would recommend that you start looking at chicken recipes, because that's pretty cheap (at least if you're in the US).



Onions are good to have on hand, whatever your favorite vegetable is.

Some things that are super easy to make: cheese enchiladas, pasta salad, tacos, stuffed bell peppers, mashed potatoes, baked chicken,  oh and I did find a good recipe for steak http://www.ehow.com/how_2161674_cook-ste...



Hope that helps!  You'll be fine, I went through the same thing in college and now, I love to cook and people love my cooking.

<answer>

<answer>



Try this one...wont be like your Grans but still......Boil and mash potatoes not leaving them too wet.



Add a little grated ginger, about two spring onions,  2 pieces of grated garlic and a handful of  chopped coriander leaves a green deseeded chilli .  Salt and pepper.  Beat one egg into it and add some cheddar cheese.  Form into balls and shallow fry till golden brown.

Or you can add some wetted bread slices in the mixture and deep fry the mashed potatoe patties....delicious especially with coriander or mint chutney...or even tomato sauce.

<answer>



I like with grated potatoes better but my Granny never threw any good food out either.

No real recipe...you just mix a little egg and flour and some grated or chopped onions up and fry.

You can get a better "from scratch" result from grating big potatoes , carrots,a little celery,and onions and mix lightly together...so it looks kinda right then add about a 1/2 cup of flour with a sifter (S & P) and a couple eggs - well just enough to hold together. Depends on how many people....

My Gran was Swedish...we ate these cakes with sour cream and different fruits on the side...often spiced apples because we always had a lot of those.

<answer>



Maybe this is what you're talking about?!

1 medium onion, chopped 
2 tablespoons butter 
2 eggs 
1 1/2 cups mashed potatoes 
1/4 cup all-purpose flour 
1/4 teaspoon salt 
1/8 teaspoon pepper 
1 dash hot pepper sauce 
1 tablespoon water



In a skillet, saute onion in butter until tender. Remove from the heat. In a bowl, lightly beat one egg. Add the onion, potatoes, flour, salt, pepper and hot pepper sauce if desired. 
Shape into four to six patties; place on a greased baking sheet. Lightly beat remaining egg; stir in water. Brush over potato cakes. Bake at 375 degrees F for 20-25 minutes or until heated through. serves 2.
=========



</answer>



<answer from>



cailin
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 1449 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Take the left over potatoes and mash well. Pour in some hot melted butter and mix well. Slowly add in some sifted flour, for lightness, until the mixture is malleable without sticking all over your hands. It should be nice and smooth, a little like pastry. Add a little salt and some freshly ground black pepper. roll out with a lightly floured rolling pin and then cut into however many pieces you like. Heat a frying pan until hot, then add some butter to melt. Place the potato cakes in the pan and let brown on a medium heat. check when they are golden and turn them over to cook the other side. Serve on a hot plate, with lots of butter. Not good for the figure really but delicious.



Source(s):



Old school cookery class recipe



</answer>

louise

Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Irish potato cakes



Serves 2-4



Preparation time less than 30 mins

Cooking time 10 to 30 mins



Ingredients
250g/8oz potatoes
salt and black pepper, freshly ground
½ head fresh garden cabbage, finely chopped
90ml/6tbsp milk
50g/2oz bacon dripping or butter, plus extra for frying
125g/4oz wholemeal flour



Method
1. Boil the potatoes in salted water until cooked. Drain, mash and leave to cool.
2. Place the cabbage in boiling salted water and cook for a few minutes. Drain and leave to cool.
3. Place the milk in a saucepan, add the bacon dripping and bring to the boil. Add the cooked potato and cabbage and blend together while the mixture heats through. Fold in the flour until the mixture comes away from the side of the saucepan.
4. Turn the mixture on to a cold surface and shape into cakes of approximately 5cm/2in diameter and 1cm/½in thick.
5. Cook in a little bacon dripping until brown and serve immediately.



</answer>

<answer>



We try our hardest not to waste food.  Anything I make has to be able to be my husband's lunch the next day.  And whatever else I make should be able to be frozen and socked in the deep freezer.  Food prices rise, and our paychecks don't.  It's a good lesson for us now, we'll remember it even when times get better.

I am bad with veges, fruit and meat.  That is what most of our wastage is because I leave cooking dinner too late and so I go for the quickest things to cook and end up having to chuck out sprouting potatoes for example.

<answer>



We don't waste much if any.
Leftovers get turned into a new meal or ate as is.

<answer from>



Veronica Alicia
Member since: 06 May 2007
Total points: 35492 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Left overs (we rarely have any because I try not to overcook) always go into the fridge - meat, of course, will make a sandwich for lunch next day.
Veges usually go into a box, for the freezer, labelled "Soup veges".
When I have a box full (roast potatoes are a great addition for flavouring and thickening), I make a thick mixed vegetable soup, with the addition of a stock cube and sometimes a handful of barley, lentils, etc.  A teaspoon of curry powder makes a spicy change.  A tablespoon of tomato ketchup enrichens. 
Vegetable peelings, chicken bones when not used for stock, etc., go down the insinkerator.
I take little or no notice of "Best before dates" - never had them till a few years ago.  Us old uns were born with senses which kept us safe - a sense of smell, a sense of sight and a sense of taste; if it smells OK, if it looks OK, if it tastes OK - it's OK.
Only had food poisoning once in over 70 years and that was from mussels in a restaurant.



When you grew up with War time rationing, you learned not to be fussy.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



LOL . . . can't help you with the skinning/gutting.  But seriously, anything in the crockpot has got to be good.  Throw in a bunch of onions and garlic, add potatoes and carrots.  Pour some water over the works and let it cook all day.  You can use this same technique for rabbits, squirrels, possum, racoon, etc.  They're relatively small and won't do much damage to your car.  I'd stay away from skunk (obvious reasons) and unfortunately, though much tastier, deer will do a terrible number on your car.



Best wishes to you!  :D



</answer>

<answer>



The first things first road kill can be safe to eat but only if it is fresh. If you don't gut it right away the intestines will leak toxins into the meat and you could kill your family. If it is stiff it's too late. However if it is fresh kill the first thing you need to do is slice it from it's neck to its rectum and pull out the guts. Then take it home and skin it. If you don't want anyone to know debone (remove bruised meat) it and cook it like stir fry or boil some raw biscuits and make "chicken" and dumplings. Obviously a deer would be your best kill but not with a car. So I would seek out thinks like raccoon and squirrels. Now I have a question for you. Why do you have the internet if you can't buy Ramon Noodles.

<answer from>



H-man
Member since: 30 April 2007
Total points: 82575 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Yahoo! Answers



</answer from>



<answer>



According to one French cookbook, 'Les Cuisines Oubliees' by Annie and Jean-Claude Molinier, it was traditional, prior to cooking, to skin the badger and then suspend it in a fast-flowing river for 48 hours to "de-grease" it.



After that, you cut it into pieces, brown it in a frying pan with butter, flambée with armanac, pour over some sparkling wine and simmer for two hours. Then add a glass of pig's blood, two egg yolks, some ginger and creme fraiche and, voila...a meal fit for anyone other than a Gloucestershire peasant.



Henry Smith, though, favoured simpler recipes. He rated cured badger hams as "exceptionally good fare" and declared: "Badger pies are even better than pork pies, hot or cold." He also said that the animals were at their best in October or November as they were "fat and succulent by then". And he reminded wannabe chefs what good gravy could be obtained from the skinned feet and tail, thickened with a little flour.



Go for rabbits, ducks and other small animals,
Cattle deer pigs sheep and deer tend to make a mess of your car.



LoL



Source(s):



http://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/main.jh...



</answer>

<answer from>



JOSEPH G

</answer from>



<answer>



1 Preheat oven to 400°F. Cut open the pumpkin and use a strong metal spoon to scoop out the insides. Separate the seeds from the stringy core. Rinse the seeds.



2 In a small saucepan, add the seeds to water, about 2 cups of water to every half cup of seeds. Add a tablespoon of salt for every cup of water. Bring to a boil. Let simmer for 10 minutes. Remove from heat and drain.



3 Spread about a tablespoon of olive oil over the bottom of a roasting pan. Spread the seeds out over the roasting pan, all in one layer. Bake on the top rack for 20 minutes or until the seeds begin to brown. When browned to your satisfaction, remove from the oven and let the pan cool on a rack. Let the seeds cool all the way down before eating. Either crack to remove the inner seed (a lot of work and in my opinion, unnecessary) or eat whole.



</answer>



<answer from>



Susakins Makoozakins~
Member since: 11 November 2007

<answer>



Toasted Pumpkin Seeds Recipe



Ingredients
One medium sized pumpkin



Salt



Olive oil
Method
1 Preheat oven to 400°F. Cut open the pumpkin and use a strong metal spoon to scoop out the insides. Separate the seeds from the stringy core. Rinse the seeds.



2 In a small saucepan, add the seeds to water, about 2 cups of water to every half cup of seeds. Add a tablespoon of salt for every cup of water. Bring to a boil. Let simmer for 10 minutes. Remove from heat and drain.



3 Spread about a tablespoon of olive oil over the bottom of a roasting pan. Spread the seeds out over the roasting pan, all in one layer. Bake on the top rack for 20 minutes or until the seeds begin to brown. When browned to your satisfaction, remove from the oven and let the pan cool on a rack. Let the seeds cool all the way down before eating. Either crack to remove the inner seed (a lot of work and in my opinion, unnecessary) or eat whole.



</answer>



<answer from>



preacher...
Member since: 15 May 2006
Total points: 838 (Level 2)



</answer from>

Then bake them at 350 for approximately 15 minutes or until they start to turn golden brown.  Then just pop them in your mouth, outer shell and all and ENJOY!



</answer>

<answer from>



joeschlo...
Member since: 16 October 2006
Total points: 965 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



How to Cook Brown Rice
March 14th, 2007 by Steve Pavlina



Email this article to a friend Email this article to a friend



Many people have trouble cooking brown rice and having it turn out decently, since it can be more temperamental than white rice.  There are also many different ways to prepare it.



Here’s the most efficient way I found to cook brown rice on a stove.  It takes about 35 minutes from when you start to when you’re eating (which is pretty good for brown rice).  This method works for both short grain and long grain brown rice.  I prefer long grain.  I’ve eaten hundreds of batches of brown rice using this method over the past 10 years.



Here are the instructions:



1. Put brown rice and water together in a pot with a lid.  Use the ratio of 1.5 cups water to 1 cup rice.  I normally make 3c rice with 4.5c water for a single batch.



2. Set the heat to maximum, and bring the rice/water to a boil uncovered.  Then put the lid on the pot, and reduce the heat to low/simmer.  If your lid has a steam valve, keep it closed.  Let the rice simmer for 20 minutes.



3. Turn off the heat, and let the rice sit in the covered pot for another 10 minutes.  It’s OK if you let the rice sit longer than 10 minutes (20 or 30 minutes is fine too), but don’t let it go any less.  I prefer my rice to be slightly chewy, not mushy, so I usually remove the lid after 10 minutes.



4. Eat and enjoy.  Be careful when you remove the lid, since a lot of steam may escape when you do.



This works for white rice too.



After the rice is cooked, I normally scoop some into a bowl, and mix it with a little tamari and 1-2 tablespoons of sesame seeds.  The sesame seeds add a lot of flavor to the rice.  Sometimes I’ll eat it with steamed veggies and blackened tempeh, both of which can be prepared while the rice is cooking.



I put the leftover rice in a plastic container in the refrigerator, which keeps well for several days.  Since I don’t use a microwave, I usually just eat the leftovers cold.  But when I’m not in the mood for cold rice, here’s another tasty dish I make from the leftover rice:



1. In a small pot, add 1 teaspoon of oil, and heat it for about 1 minute on medium heat.  I prefer dark sesame oil because it adds a lot of flavor.  Canola oil works well too.



2. Add some chopped veggies to the pot, and sauté them in the oil for a few minutes.  My favorites are onions, green onions, and bell peppers (any color).



3. Once the veggies are cooked, scoop in some of the leftover brown rice.  I like to use 2 parts rice to 1 part veggies.  Mix it well with the veggies.



4. Reduce the heat slightly to medium-low, and cook the rice/veggies for 3-4 minutes until the rice is hot, stirring about once every minute.



5. Pour in a little tamari to taste, and mix it with the rice.  Cook for another minute to sear in the flavor.



6. Turn off the heat.  Mix in 1-2 tablespoons sesame seeds.



7. Eat and enjoy.



I hope you find these recipes helpful.  Brown rice became a staple of my diet after I studied macrobiotics during the mid-90s, and I eat it almost every week.  I find it a great food for endurance activities.



Source(s):



http://www.stevepavlina.com/blog/2007/03...



</answer>

<answer>



Put brown rice and water together in a pot with a lid.  Use the ratio of 1.5 cups water to 1 cup rice.  I normally make 3c rice with 4.5c water for a single batch.



Set the heat to maximum, and bring the rice/water to a boil uncovered.  Then put the lid on the pot, and reduce the heat to low/simmer.  If your lid has a steam valve, keep it closed.  Let the rice simmer for 20 minutes.



Turn off the heat, and let the rice sit in the covered pot for another 10 minutes.  It’s OK if you let the rice sit longer than 10 minutes (20 or 30 minutes is fine too), but don’t let it go any less.  I prefer my rice to be slightly chewy, not mushy, so I usually remove the lid after 10 minutes.



Eat and enjoy.  Be careful when you remove the lid, since a lot of steam may escape when you do.



</answer>



<answer from>



steve j
Member since: 16 August 2007
Total points: 3995 (Level 4)

<answer>



You probably had the heat too high. Bring the rice to a boil, cover and cook over low heat until it's nearly done. Turn off the heat and let it steam for about the last ten minutes of cooking. Also make sure you are using a heavy bottom sauce pan

<answer>

<question>



Has anyone got a recipe for American Muffins?



I've been out and bought a muffin baking tray, but in my English cookery books I can't find a recipe for them (admittedly I haven't got many cookery books)  I fancy doing either berry ones, or chocolate ones.



And some tips on ensuring they rise well would be a help.

<answer from>



cin2win
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 24714 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes

<answer>



CHOCOLATE MARBLE MUFFINS



2 cups self-rising flour
1 cup sugar
half bag of chocolate chips
half bag of white chocolate chips
3 teaspoons melted butter
1 cup milk
1 egg



Preheat oven to 350°F (180C) degrees.
Sift flour. Add sugar and chocolate chips (including white). Beat egg. Combine egg, milk and butter.



Stir until all mixed but if stirred too much it will not rise! Pour into muffin tray.



Bke for 15-20 mins. Delicious muffins that the kids will love



here are more



http://www.cooks.com/rec/search?q=chocol...



</answer>

<question>



What is the best frosting recipe for sugar cookies?



</question>



<answer from>



cin2win
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 24725 (Level 6)



Contributing In:

<answer>



BLUE RIBBON FROSTING: Mix 1 pound sifted powdered sugar with 1/2 cup butter and 1/2 cup white Crisco and 2 teaspoons pure vanilla. Gradually add 1/4 cup scant hot water. Frost cookies when cooled.



</answer>



<answer from>



I LOVE 2 COOK!!!
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 2436 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



BLUE RIBBON FROSTED SUGAR COOKIES



2 c. granulated sugar
1/2 c. white Crisco
1/2 c. real butter
3 lg. eggs
2 tsp. pure vanilla
1 c. sour cream
1 tsp. soda
1 tsp. baking powder
4 1/2 - 5 c. flour for drop, 6 c. flour for rolled out (flour amount depends on size of eggs)



Blend first 3 ingredients. Add next 3 and mix. Mix remaining dry ingredients with whip and add to mixture. Bake at 375 degrees until lightly browned.
BLUE RIBBON FROSTING: Mix 1 pound sifted powdered sugar with 1/2 cup butter and 1/2 cup white Crisco and 2 teaspoons pure vanilla. Gradually add 1/4 cup scant hot water. Frost cookies when cooled.



</answer>



<answer from>



Heidi
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have always just used powdered sugar mixed with water. It is really easy to work with.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jana B
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 510 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



BUTTER CREAM FROSTING:



1 lb. box confectioners' sugar
1/2 c. butter
1/8 tbsp. vanilla
3 to 4 tbsp. milk



Cream together butter, salt, 1/3 of the sugar in large bowl. Gradually add milk and remaining sugar.



FROSTED SUGAR COOKIES



2/3 c. shortening
3/4 c. sugar
1/2 tsp. butternut flavoring
1 egg
4 tsp. milk
2 c. flour



Cream shortening and sugar together. Beat until fluffy. Add egg, stir in milk. Blend flour. Divide in half; cover and refrigerate for at least 1 hour.
Roll out 1/8-inch thick; cut with cookie cutters. Bake 6-8 minutes (until slightly brown on edge) at 350 degrees. Frost immediately; remove from pan to cool.



ICING:



Pour 1/2-1 cup confectioners sugar, 1/4 teaspoon flavoring, drop or two of food coloring, and 1-2 tablespoons water in a bowl. Mix well with spoon.



</answer>

<question>



What are some quick  yummy snacks for kids (halloween themed would be a plus)?



Just looking for ideas and simple recipes

<answer from>



cin2win
Member since: 11 October 2007

<answer>



Orange Jack-o'-Lantern



What you need:



Orange
Yogurt
Green Jell-O
Raisins



Halloween Foam Sticker
Knife
Spoon



What you do:



Make green Jell-O and place in refrigerator. Draw jack-o'-lantern faces on oranges with a sharpie. (Or glue pieces of black electical tape on orange) Let your parent cut off top part of orange and scoop out pulp. Mix some of the orange pulp with a vanilla yogurt. Add some swirls (let Jell-O sit for 1 hour only) or pieces of green Jell-O and some raisins into the mix.



Pour into the oranges and place them in a muffin tin and chill in the freezer. (The muffin tin will keep the oranges steady while they chill)



This is a great healthy treat and children love it
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;



http://www.associatedcontent.com/article...



</answer>

<question>



Can someone provide me with a really nice easyish recipe 4 pumpkin pie?



</question>



<answer from>



Susakins Makoozakins~
Member since: 11 November 2007
Total points: 44763 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



Libby's® Famous Pumpkin -- Simple and Delish!!!



INGREDIENTS



1 (9 inch) unbaked deep dish pie crust



3/4 cup white sugar



1 teaspoon ground cinnamon



1/2 teaspoon salt



1/2 teaspoon ground ginger



1/4 teaspoon ground cloves



2 eggs



1 (15 ounce) can LIBBY'S® 100% Pure Pumpkin



1 (12 fluid ounce) can NESTLE® CARNATION® Evaporated Milk



DIRECTIONS
Preheat oven to 425 F.



Combine sugar, salt, cinnamon, ginger and cloves in small bowl. Beat eggs lightly in large bowl. Stir in pumpkin and sugar-spice mixture. Gradually stir in evaporated milk. Pour into pie shell.



Bake for 15 minutes. Reduce temperature to 350 F.; bake for 40 to 50 minutes or until knife inserted near center comes out clean. Cool on wire rack for 2 hours. Serve immediately or refrigerate. (Do not freeze as this will cause the crust to separate from the filling.)



Source(s):



HAPPY BAKING!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



mlz19408...
Member since: 30 October 2007
Total points: 19742 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can not think of a simpler recipe than the instruction on the can of pumpkin



</answer>



<answer from>



DeeDee
Member since: 10 July 2006
Total points: 8216 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



open the can, pour it into a frozen unbaked pie shell, and then bake and enjoy.



</answer>



<answer from>



I LOVE 2 COOK!!!
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 2436 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



EASY PUMPKIN PIE



1 (9 inch) unbaked pastry shell
1 (16 oz.) can pumpkin
1 (14 oz.) can Eagle Brand sweetened condensed milk
2 eggs
1 tsp. cinnamon
1/2 tsp. salt
1/2 tsp. ginger
1/2 tsp. nutmeg



Preheat oven to 425 degrees. Combine ingredients in large bowl, pour into shell, bake 15 minutes, reduce oven temperature to 350 degrees and continue baking 35-40 minutes until knife inserted in center comes out clean.



</answer>



<answer from>



cin2win
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 24725 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www.pumpkin-pie-recipe.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



Jana B
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 510 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Famous Pumpkin --



INGREDIENTS



1 (9 inch) unbaked deep dish pie crust



1/2 cup white sugar



1/2 cup brown sugar
1/2 teaspoon salt



2 teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice



2 eggs



1 (15 ounce) can LIBBY'S Pumpkin



1  can Evaporated Milk



DIRECTIONS
Preheat oven to 425 F.



Combine sugar, salt, and pumpkin pie spice in small bowl. Beat eggs lightly in large bowl. Stir in pumpkin and sugar-spice mixture. Gradually stir in evaporated milk. Pour into pie shell.



Bake for 15 minutes. Reduce temperature to 350 F.; bake for 40 to 50 minutes or until knife inserted near center comes out clean. Cool. Top with cool whip



</answer>

DEEPANDJ...

<question>



TODAYS RECIPE FROM ABC7 NEWS?

<question>



Help with my crock pot experiment .....?



I got the bright idea this morning to experiment with my crock pot . I put in  beef broth ,carrots, celery, onions, canned tomatoes, stew meat & potatoes. My question is what can i add to it to thicken the gravy? I plan on going home at lunch to check on it,,,,so  should i add flour ?? if so how much??



</question>



<answer from>



Baby girl Due 1/25/09

<answer>



get some liquid from the pot,,,, add flour to the mix then pour back in the crockpot,,,, do it like you are making a gravy



</answer>



<answer from>



David R
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 2879 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



You can dissolve a few Tbsp of flour or corn starch in 1/2 c of water to make a slurry and add that.  But, keep in mind that the sauce won't thicken until it reaches the boiling point.  Since a crockpot typically cooks at 250 F on low and 325 F on high, you shouldn't have any problem.  Don't forget to re-taste and re-season when it's done, if necessary.



Dave



</answer>



<answer from>



Xiomy
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 15512 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If it's too thin, simmer over medium-high heat, allowing liquid to reduce. If your gravy is still too thin, add a beurre manie: Make a paste of equal parts flour and softened unsalted butter, and add it a little at a time, whisking constantly, until the gravy thickens.



Source(s):



http://www.marthastewart.com/article/tip...



</answer>

<answer>



Corn starch is the way to go. Remove a cup of the cooking liquid, stir a tablespoon of corn starch into it and then pour it back into the crock pot and stir it through.

<answer from>



Recipe4L...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



"There are several methods of thickening the gravy, and my favorite involves making a roux (equal parts of flour and butter or oil).



You simply cook the flour and oil/butter in a heavy saucepan or skillet, stirring constantly, until the color desired. (If you want a blond gravy, such as for chicken, only cook until a blond color. If you want a dark, rich gravy for red meat, cook the roux until milk chocolate brown. Add some chopped onions, celery, bell peppers, garlic (any flavors you like), and cook the vegetables in the roux until they are soft.



Whisk in the stock, and bring gravy to a low simmer. Cook until thickened and the flavors have come together. Add any extras you may like, such as chopped green onions, fresh herbs, or other spices and seasonings. For every 2 cups of broth or stock, you will need about 2 tablespoons of flour to thicken. Of course, if you like a thinner gravy, simply use less.



An even simpler method involves using cornstarch. Simply mix a little cornstarch with just enough cold water to form a pourable "slurry," then add this slurry, little by little, to hot stock or broth. As the stock comes to the boil, the cornstarch will work to thicken the sauce. You can always add more slurry if your gravy isn't thick enough, but always wait until the sauce boils between additions, to make sure you really need more."



From Recipe4Living's Encyclopedia of Tips: http://www.recipe4living.com/Common/Arti...



Source(s):



http://www.recipe4living.com



</answer>

twilight...

<answer>



Just like the inside of spam; the processed pork product in a square blue tin.



No matter how you cook it or burn it or irradiate it, the outside may look different - but the inside will always look the same.  Unless you burn it to a cinder, then it will look like charcoal.



All processed & re-manufactured food products are like that.



If you want it to look like its rare or medium done, you will have to cook virgin meats in their raw form.



good luck babe!



</answer>
