<question>



Recipe for Pineapple Pie...?



I need a recipe for pineapple pie my gradnmother had the recipe and lost it she said it consisted of cruched pineapple, chunked pineapple and cool whip she wasn't sure of the other ingredients if anyone can help me please



</question>



<answer from>



David R
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 2879 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



LIGHT AS A CLOUD PINEAPPLE PIE



Ingredients:
1 tub (8-ounce size) Cool Whip Lite
1 cup miniature marshmallows
2 cups crushed pineapple in its own syrup
2 cups coconut
1 purchased graham cracker crust (9-inch size)
Turn this recipe into a puzzle! [click]



Directions:



Place all ingredients (except the crust) in a large bowl and mix thoroughly. Remove plastic lid from the crust. Pour the Cool Whip mixture into the crust and spread it out evenly.



Place the inverted lid on top of the pie and place in the freezer for three or four hours, until firm. Serve. Keep refrigerated.



This recipe from CDKitchen for Light As A Cloud Pie serves/makes 10



PINEAPPLE PIE III



INGREDIENTS



* 1 recipe pastry for a 9 inch double crust pie



* 3/4 cup white sugar



* 3 tablespoons cornstarch



* 1 (20 ounce) can crushed pineapple with juice



* 1 tablespoon lemon juice



* 2 tablespoons milk



* 1 tablespoon white sugar



* add to recipe box Add to Recipe Box



My folders:



* add to shopping list Add to Shopping List



* add a personal note Add a Personal Note



DIRECTIONS



1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).



2. In a medium saucepan combine sugar, cornstarch, pineapple with juice, and lemon juice. Cook over medium heat, stirring constantly until thickened, then allow to boil 1 minute.



3. Cool slightly and pour mixture into pastry-lined pie pan. Cover with top crust and seal. Make a few steam vents in crust, then brush with milk and sprinkle with sugar. Place in preheated oven and bake for 35 minutes. Serve chilled or at room temperature.



Hope this helps!



Dave



Source(s):



allrecipes.com



</answer>

CheddarC...
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 1285 (Level 3)

<answer>



Frozen Pineapple Pie



1 lemon



1 (14 ounce) can sweetened condensed milk



1 (20 ounce) can crushed pineapple with juice



1 (16 ounce) package frozen whipped topping, thawed



2 (9 inch) prepared graham cracker crusts



Mix condensed milk and non-dairy whipped topping together.



Add the juice of one lemon and the pineapple to this creamy blend.



Pour pineapple blend into 2 graham cracker crusts. Freeze overnight. Take pies out of freezer 30 to 45 minutes before serving.



</answer>

Turn this recipe into a puzzle! [click]



Directions:

Add vanilla extract and drained pineapple; blend. Pour into unbaked 9-inch pie shell and bake in preheated 350-degree oven for about 45 minutes. Let cool for a few minutes before cutting, or serve cold.

PINEAPPLE "COOL WHIP" PIE



1/4 c. lemon juice
1 can condensed milk (Eagle Brand)

2 (9") baked pie shells

starlina...
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 3369 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pineapple Pie V



INGREDIENTS (Nutrition)



* 1 cup white sugar



* 3 tablespoons all-purpose flour



* 1/2 teaspoon salt



* 2 egg yolks



* 1/4 cup water



* 1 (8 ounce) can crushed pineapple



* 1 tablespoon butter



* 3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice



* 1 tablespoon grated lemon zest



* 1 (9 inch) pie shell, baked



DIRECTIONS



1. In a medium bowl, mix together sugar, flour, salt and egg yolks.



2. Bring water and pineapple to a boil in a medium saucepan. Stir in sugar mixture and mix well. Cook over medium heat until thickened; stir constantly.



3. Stir in butter, lemon juice and lemon zest to saucepan. Then spoon entire mixture into pie shell. Cover and refrigerate pie until ready to be served.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Pineapple-P...



</answer>



<answer from>



Jana B
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 527 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



DAD'S PINEAPPLE PIE



1 20 oz can crushed pineapple (drained)
1 small box vanilla instant pudding mix
1 tsp. lemon juice
1 deep dish pie shell



Preheat oven to 350°F. Mix together pineapple, vanilla pudding mix, and lemon juice until smooth. Prick pie shell. Pour mixture into pie shell.
Bake at 350 for about 20 minutes or until crust is golden.



Cool completely before serving. Serve with a dollop of Cool Whip on top.



</answer>

<question>



Can you cook negative calorie foods and still get the same effect?



Just curious if the foods need to be raw or if they can be prepared. And if so.. what are the recommended methods of preparing them?



</question>



<answer from>



midnight...
Member since: 20 May 2008

<answer>

Hope this helped a little!



</answer>



<answer from>



MacXe
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 14589 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Software



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, I believe celery is probably the only negative calorie food.
It takes more energy to consume and digest raw celery than it actually gives.



I suppose some things can be made into neg calories, if you make them especially hard to chew and digest. I doubt they will actually taste nice though.



</answer>



<answer from>



Nicholas L.
Member since: 09 December 2005
Total points: 753 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The phrase "negative-calorie food" has been coined recently to refer to foods that use up more calories in digestion than they provide. All foods have calories, but some have very few. Carrots and celery certainly do have very few calories, as do lettuce, cucumbers, and other green vegetables. What these foods can help do is fill your stomach and relieve some hunger pangs while you are on a weight-loss diet.



I would not focus a lot of attention on whether foods are "negative-calorie foods," however. The point is that if you limit your intake only to these foods, you could become malnourished. You need to eat protein, carbohydrates, and fat to survive. Still, eating lots of raw vegetables can fill you up because they are relatively high in volume and fiber and low in calories. In summary, while they have a role to play in a weight-loss diet, they shouldn't be the central focus of such a diet.



Source(s):



http://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutri...



</answer>

<original file>587.html</original file>

<question from>



Rodney J
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



how do you make butter?



I would like to make better at home.



</question>



<answer from>



bob
Member since: 07 August 2007
Total points: 11697 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The 'ingredients' for butter are simply cream and possibly a little salt. I think you can make butter from goat's milk, but it takes a different method so I'm sticking to what I know. Making butter from cow's cream.



Unless you have your own cow or access to a dairy, you are not going to save any money by making your own butter. As with most commodity products in the supermarket, the retail price of butter is less than you can buy the raw materials for.



Having said that, sometimes you will find the supermarket has reduced it's cream as it approaches the end of it's shelf life. One Christmas Eve we found our supermarket had a load of cream reduced to 5p for a large tub.



I've never managed to freeze cream so making butter was the ideal way to take advantage of a bargain and store it for use in the future.



You need double cream or whipping cream to make butter, single cream is just too thin.



Butter Making - Equipment
You do not need much equipment to make butter at home, a bowl and large jar with a lid being the minimum. If you have a food processor or an electric whisk then the task will be much easier.



Butter Making - Method
Let the cream reach room temperature, around 20 C (68 F) is ideal – this is critical. Don't heat it but leave the pots out of the fridge for a good few hours to warm up. If you have a cold kitchen, put them into the living room to warm up.



Now we are ready to make butter.



With a jar you need to half fill the jar, put the lid on and shake it for anything between half an hour and an hour. This is hard work, especially for any quantity and I've not tried it myself.



With a food processor or an electric whisk, proceed as if you are making whipped cream. In the processor, use the plastic blades if you have them. I'm told the Kenwood 'K' beater is the best tool if you are lucky enough to have one.



It will go through the usual stage of starting to form firm peaks and then it becomes quite stiff. At this point you might like to reduce the speed of your whisk because when it goes it happens very fast.



All of a sudden the cream goes a bit yellow in colour and then little bits of butter appear and a thin liquid, the buttermilk. Just seconds later, the butter seems to clump and is separated from the buttermilk. If your whisk is on high speed you are now redecorating the kitchen, hence my suggesting you reduce speed to a minimum



Source(s):



http://www.allotment.org.uk/allotment_fo...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you Bob



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



carolath...
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 7606 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



First you get a cow.  Milk it every day at the same time.  They prefer before dawn.



Then you find a butter churn (check with your Amish friends to see if they have an extra one lying around).



Now, pour a bunch of fresh milk (real creamy) in the churn, and sit there all day pumping the handle up and down, up and down, up and down, up and down.  All day.  The chunky stuff at the bottom is butter.  Glom it out and mash it into butter molds (you do have your own butter molds, don't you?)  After it solidifies, you have your own butter!  Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Betty
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 5933 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Put a pint of heavy cream or whipping cream in the bowl of a stand mixer and beat with the whip attachment.  Beat it on medium speed way past the point of whipped cream (about 20 min).  Put the butter in cheese cloth or a clean, lint free towel and rinse under cold water.  Rinse and squeeze until the water runs clear.  Squeeze out all excess water and open the towel.  You'll have butter.  Pretty simple.



Source(s):



professional chef
I've made butter tons of times



</answer>



<answer from>



ja b
Member since: 06 December 2006
Total points: 532 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



just beat whipping cream with electric beaters until it's thick



</answer>

<question from>



the.mont...
Member since: 08 June 2008
Total points: 94 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the best product to freeze liquids in ? ?



I want to freeze items such as soup and chili's , maybe sauces . I have tried to use some cheap freezer bags and the soup had about 2 inches of water in it once thawed. Please give me brand names if items you have used with success in freezing liquids. Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



John N
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I use Aldi/Netto food bags never had a problem or tuperware like plastic containers



</answer>



<answer from>



twilight...
Member since: 18 July 2006
Total points: 10791 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Regardless of whether it is a cheap or expensive product, soups & stews (chili too) some of the water in it will settle & separate while it sits & begins to freeze. Especially if its a watery soup/stew. Now if you used a thickening ingredient, them less of the water content won't separate.



The Best product to use would be a Vacuum Sealer Freezer bags. The food won't suffer freezer burn as badly as most other foods left in the freezer over long.



good luck babe!



</answer>

<question>



What are some good things to stock my pantry with for the winter?



What kinds of foods & staples

<answer from>



Miami Lilly
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 24587 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Diet & Fitness



</answer from>



<answer>



I stock my pantry with containers of broth (beef and chicken) to make homemade soups, tomatoes and tomato sauce (for chili) and a variety of pastas (mac and cheese) and beans. You can make some excellent bean soups (I like white bean and bacon). It's always nice to have those on hand.



I also like keeping different condensed soups (cream of chicken, cream of mushroom, celery, french onion, etc.) and rice on hand for casseroles.



</answer>

<question from>



beth m
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How much rice do I start with to get 1 3/4 pounds cooked rice?



I have this recipe... sounds great... but the ingredient quantities are goofy.  I think it was probably a restaurant recipe that got cut down for home use, but they didn't consider that we don't measure like they do.



</question>



<answer from>



Haley
Member since: 16 August 2006
Total points: 737 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i dunno but be careful cause rice goes very far and expands so dont put to mch



</answer>



<answer from>



Natalie Y
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 200 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the type of rice you are using.



RICE



Add a tablespoon of oil to the water when cooking rice so the grains stay separate and don't stick together.



• 1 cup dry rice = approx. 7 oz. (wt.)
• 1 lb. dry rice = approx. 2 1/4 c. (vol.)
• 1 cup cooked rice = approx. 8 oz. (wt.)
• 1 lb. cooked rice = approx. 1 pt. (2 cups)



• 1 lb. dry rice yields about 6-7 cups cooked rice



Check their answer (complete answer) and see if you can figure from that.



Source(s):



http://au.answers.yahoo.com/question/ind...



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Easy recipe with chicken?



So, I have chicken breast, and I'm really craving it, what should I make with it? I'd prefer it to be easy and healthy. I don't want to do too much work.



</question>



<answer from>



Dragon Gurl
Member since: 11 November 2006
Total points: 999 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Chicken
Bake with orange juice, salt and pepper, garlic



Sides:



Couscous and broccoli/brussel sprouts



</answer>



<asker's comment>



This was REALLY good.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



tracy
Member since: 23 September 2007
Total points: 12385 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Take your pick:



Creamed Peas
½ bag frozen green peas
½ onion, diced
¼ cup heavy cream
2 tablespoons butter
salt and pepper
Cook peas in water to cover in saucepan until tender, about 5 minutes. Drain in collander. Melt butter in same saucepan and sautee onions over medium heat until transparent. Add peas, salt and pepper and heavy cream. Simmer over low heat for 5 minutes.



Easy Zucchini and Squash
2 - 3 zucchini, scrubbed and trimmed
2 - 3 squash, scrubbed and trimmed
olive oil
salt and pepper
Cut each zucchini and squash lengthwise. Drizzle olive oil on bottom of large platter, place vegetables cut side down in oil. Let marinate at least 20 minutes. Turn over and season with salt and pepper.



Heat large skillet over medium high heat, drizzle with olive oil. Placed vegetables in skillet. Cook about 5 minutes each side.



Can also be prepared on the grill -- even better!



Garlic Mashed Potatoes
Russett potatoes, with their low moisture and high starch content, are excellent potatoes for mashing. But other types of potatoes work well too, including Yukon gold potatoes and round white or round red potatoes.
3 pounds russet potatoes, peeled and cubed
6 cloves garlic
½ cup fat free milk
1 tablespoon butter
salt
white pepper
2 tablespoons fresh parsley, chopped
In a large stockpot, cover the potatoes with water. Salt well with about 1 T. salt. Bring to boil, reduce heat, cover and let simmer until potatoes are tender, about 15 minutes. Drain.



In small saucepan, cover the garlic with water. Bring to boil. Reduce heat and let simmer until tender, about 10 minutes. Drain.



In food processor blender, combine the garlic and milk. Puree until smooth. Add the pureed garlic and milk to the potatoes. Add butter and mash potatoes. Season with white pepper and additional salt if needed.



Garnish with chopped parsley and serve immediately.



German Style Green Beans
2 - 3 slices bacon, fried crisp
3 tablespoons onion, chopped
1 can green beans, drained
2 tablespoons vinegar
1 tablespoon sugar
Reserve bacon drippings in skillet. Sautee onion in drippings until transparent. Add beans, vinegar and sugar. Heat over medium heat stirring frequently for about 10 minutes. Crumble bacon over beans and toss before serving.



Glazed Carrots
2 cups baby carrots
4 tablespoons butter
¼ cup brown sugar
Cook carrots in water to cover until crisp tender -- about 10 minutes. Drain and return to pan. Add butter and sugar, stir well to coat. Cook over low heat about 5 minutes, stirring often.



Italian Vegetable Medley
1 bag frozen Italian vegetables, steamed
3 tablespoons olive oil
1 tablespoon balsamic vinegar
¼ cup Parmesan cheese, grated
salt and pepper
Toss all together while vegetables are still warm.



Quarter Baked Potatoes
3 - 4 potatoes, scrubbed well, quartered
½ cup olive oil
2 teaspoons parmesan cheese, grated
½ teaspoon garlic powder
½ teaspoon salt
¼ teaspoon pepper
Place unpeeled and quartered potatoes in large bowl. Toss with the olive oil. Place in 8 x 8 inch baking dish and sprinkle with remaining ingredients. Cover and bake 30 minutes at 375 degrees, remove cover and bake additional 15 minutes, or until potatoes are done and golden.



Rice Pilaf
1 tablespoon butter
2 tablespoons olive oil
1 onion, chopped
2 cups white rice
4 cups chicken broth
salt and pepper
Melt butter with oil in large saucepan over medium heat. Add onion and sautee until tender. Add rice and cook for 2 minutes. Pour in broth and seasoning, bring to a boil, stirring frequently. Cover, reduce to low heat, simmer for 20 minutes. Remove from heat and let sit for 5 minutes before serving.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rachel *
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 356 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



here's my four main things i do:



1)  squeeze some italian salad dressing into a tupperware container.  put the chicken in and shake it up so it's coated.  if you have time, let it sit like that in the fridge for a while.  cook it @ 350 for about 40 minutes.



2)  rub some BBQ sauce on it... cook for about 40 mins.



3)  melt some butter in the microwave, add some seasoning (whatever you like) to the butter and put it on the chicken and cook it.



4)  get frenchs friend onions, crunch 'em up, roll the chicken in ranch dressing, roll it in the crushed onions, and cook it for 40 mins.



</answer>

<answer from>



Amy♥ Akita Mom
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 2603 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Dogs



</answer from>



<answer>



Sausage Stew



In order to make this sausage stew, you'll need the following ingredients:



Ingredients:



1 lg. onion, diced



3 carrots, sliced



8 med. potatoes, diced



4 tbsp. paprika



1 lg. can tomato sauce



2 links Polish sausage, sliced



Saute diced onions until tender with the paprika. Then add carrots and cover with water and cook until partially tender. Add your potatoes and a little more water and cook until tender. Lastly, add sausage and tomato sauce and cook for about 1/2 hour on medium heat.



</answer>



<answer from>



quit it!
Member since: 17 May 2008
Total points: 5348 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Egg and Sausage Casserole



1 pound pork sausage



1 (8 ounce) package refrigerated crescent roll dough



8 eggs, beaten



2 cups shredded mozzarella cheese



2 cups shredded Cheddar cheese



1 teaspoon dried oregano



Place sausage in a large, deep skillet. Cook over medium-high heat until evenly brown. Drain, crumble, and set aside.



Preheat oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Lightly grease a 9x13 inch baking dish.



Line the bottom of the prepared baking dish with crescent roll dough, and sprinkle with crumbled sausage. In a large bowl, mix beaten eggs, mozzarella, and Cheddar. Season the mixture with oregano, and pour over the sausage and crescent rolls.



Bake 25 to 30 minutes in the preheated oven, or until a knife inserted in the center comes out clean. serves 12
///\\\



</answer>






<original file>332.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk82624.txt</current file name>




<category>



Food & Drink



Cooking & Recipes



</category>



<question from>



Emily J
Member since: 09 May 2007
Total points: 6688 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



I want to make enchilidas?



So, I was wondering if anybody had a really basic recipe for this? I really don't have much stuff when it comes to making them, I have some spices, chicken breast, some frozen peppers, lettuce, tortillas, carrots, and that is about it.



</question>



<answer from>



Trisha
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 296 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This is the best recipe :) Try it out:



*  2 tablespoons olive oil



* 1/4 cup diced onions



* 1 tablespoon chopped garlic



* 1 teaspoon cumin powder



* 1 tablespoon hot sauce



* 1 pound left over chicken breast



* 1/4 cup chopped cilantro



* Salt and pepper



* 8 (10-inch) flour tortillas



* 2 cups leftover dirty rice



* 1 cup grated cheddar, plus 1 cup for topping



* 1 cup tomato sauce



Directions



Heat skillet on medium flame, add oil and saute onions. Once the onions are sauteed, add the garlic, cumin powder, hot sauce and chicken. Saute until the chicken is heated, then add the chopped cilantro and season with salt and pepper.



Preheat oven to 350 degrees.



Lay out a tortilla, add a layer of dirty rice, chicken, and cheddar. Roll up the tortilla and place in a casserole dish. Repeat process with the remaining tortillas. Once all the tortillas are stuffed and in the casserole dish, pour the tomato sauce over the top, and sprinkle the rest of the cheddar cheese over the sauce. Bake casserole for 20 to 30 minutes until heated through and the cheddar should be melted



Source(s):



Good luck hun;) I love cooking



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>

Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 149 (Level 1)

I then put the rest of the green enchilada sauce on them and cover with cheese!!! Bake for 30-40 Minutes or until all cheese is melted!!!



Serve with spanish rice and refried beans!! YUM-O!!!

<question>



Cover for a skillet meal now?

<question>



What's your favorite soup/stew?



What's your favorite soup or stew that doesn't take more than an hour or so to make? Any ingredients except for fish or oysters.  Chowders are also a no-go.  Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Em M
Member since: 28 June 2008
Total points: 1623 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Chili, chicken noodle and chicken tortilla... I LOVE beef stew, but I don't know of any stew that can be done in less than an hour.



For the easiest chili, brown ground beef (or chunks of beef) in a little oil. Add broth and seasoning packet (I know, it's a big cheat, but it's SO easy... Buy it from Ralphs) and simmer for a while. Serve w/ cornbread, grated cheese and chopped onions.



</answer>

<question from>



Crystail...
Member since: 10 June 2008

Contributing In:



Women's Health



</question from>



<question>



I'm attempting to make a chicken pot pie - suggestions?



</question>



<additional details>



I have chicken, peas, carrots, potatoes and I'll be using canned bisquits as the topping.



Any ideas on the gravy inside, how to make it? Also, should I make this is a pie pain or a regular pan?



Thanks!!



Thanks to all who answered! Very helpful - now I just have to decide ;0)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Leann C
Member since: 28 February 2007
Total points: 3997 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yummm!  I make this pretty often. Ina Gaarten, The Barefoot Contessa has a good recipe.  Mostly, I just wing it.



Make the gravey from chicken stock or chicken broth.  Use a baking pan.  I don't know how big your dish is so it's hard to give you ratios for the gravy.



Try melting two tablespoons of butter, stirring in two tablespoons of flour and then adding 2 cups of chicken broth or stock.  Salt & pepper. Pour as much of this gravy mixture as you need into the chicken, veggie baking pan.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks - this is what I ended up using. This worked out really well and the kids even had seconds (amazing considering they're all under three and incredibly picky). Thank you again!!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Master of My Own Remote Control!
Member since: 10 January 2007
Total points: 1447 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



In a large baking dish, place chicken and vegetables in two layers, evenly cover with sauce, and top with chosen topping (I prefer my celery seed pie pastry)..



SAUCE:



1/2 stick margarine (I use butter)
1/3 cup flour
1 pint chicken broth
1 can Cream of Chicken Soup
1 cup milk



Melt margarine and stir in flour.  Whisk in chicken broth.  Cook until thickened.  Stir in soup and then milk.



TOPPING:



1 cup self-rising flour
1 stick margarine, melted
1 cup milk



Mix together ingredients and spoon or pour on top.  Bake at 375 for 30-45 minutes, until topping is golden brown.



Source(s):



Fellow chicken pot pie fan ;)



</answer>



<answer from>



chris w
Member since: 06 May 2007
Total points: 23358 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I usually use a pie crust for a chicken pot pot - but cream of chicken
soup is a really good gravy for this pie.



CHICKEN POT PIE



1 can veg-all mixed vegetables
1 can cream of potato soup
1 can cream chicken soup
1/2 cup milk
1 or 2 large chicken breast cut into chunks
salt and pepper to taste
2 9-inch deep dish unbaked pie crust



Saute chicken in 2 tablespoons olive oil for about 3 minute until light brown, add chicken to the first 4 ingredients.
Mix together and pour into pie crust. Put top crust on pie, cut 4 slits in the crust. Brush with beaten egg wash.



Bake on a cookie sheet at 375 degrees for 45 min



I also use fresh vegs instead of canned



</answer>



<answer from>



yowza
Member since: 24 April 2007
Total points: 46967 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Books & Authors



Decorating & Remodeling



Baby Names



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't use potatoes in mine, but boil your potatoes first before adding them to the stew.



4T butter
1/4 cup flour
2 3/4 cup chicken broth
1/2 cup heavy cream
2t fresh thyme
1/8t cayenne pepper



4t lemon juice



melt butter in a large skillet over medium heat. Add onion & celery & cook until soft (4 mins). stir in flour, cayenne & cook stirring constantly until mixture is light brown (6 mins). Slowly whisk in broth, cream, thyme & simmer until thickened (5 mins). Stir in veggies, chicken & lemon juice & simmer until heated through (2-3 mins). salt & pepper & serve w/biscuits.



</answer>

<original file>694.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk83025.txt</current file name>




<category>



Food & Drink



Cooking & Recipes



</category>



<question from>



Bob7k
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 1959 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Is it possible to make candy from just water, a torch or small fire, a tiny cup, and plain granulated sugar?



I put some granulated sugar in the cup, and put that over the flame, but it turned brown before the rest of the grains melted, and when it hardend, i poped it out of the tiny aluminum thin cup, and it tasted burnt. is it possible to make any candy from just those items? if not, what else would i need to make some basic candy?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is possible, but with candy you have to be very careful with what the temperature is, because if it is too hot, it can crystallize and burn, if it is too cool then it will take too long to harden, so you have to find a balance.  Try finding a candy thermometer if you can, they have different levels of heat you need to apply while making candy and the different levels will give you different types of candy from hard candy, to taffy, to gummy.  With what you have, water, sugar, and heat, you can make a simple syrup base and add the flavoring of your choice, but you have to watch the temperature or you won't get anywhere.



Source(s):



Life.



</answer>

<answer from>



D_@z
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 329 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



tiramisu



Ingredients (serves 8)



* 2 cups strong black coffee



* 1/2 cup marsala (see note)



* 3 eggs, separated



* 1/3 cup caster sugar



* 250g mascarpone



* 300ml thickened cream, lightly whipped



* 1 large packet of sponge fingers (savoiardi)



* cocoa, for dusting



Method



1. Pour coffee and marsala into a shallow dish. Set aside.



2. Beat egg yolks and sugar in a large bowl with electric beaters until pale and thick. Add the mascarpone and whipped cream, mixing gently until just combined.



3. Beat eggwhites in a medium bowl with electric beaters until soft peaks form. Using a large metal spoon, gently fold eggwhites into the mascarpone mixture.



4. Dip enough biscuits into the coffee mixture to cover the base of a 19cm square ceramic dish. Cover the biscuits with one-third of the mascarpone mixture. Repeat layers 2 times, ending with the cream. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours. Dust generously with cocoa and serve.



Black forest triffle
ingredients (serves 6)



* 200g (1 cup) pitted black cherries in light syrup



* 1 tbs white sugar



* 1 x 300ml ctn thickened cream



* 1 tbs icing sugar mixture



* 1 tsp vanilla essence



* 18 Arnott's Chocolate Ripple biscuits



* 2 x 30g Cadbury Flake bars, coarsely broken



Method



1. Place the cherries in syrup and sugar in a saucepan over low heat. Cook, stirring, for 2-3 minutes or until the sugar dissolves. Set aside for 10 minutes to cool. Strain the cherries into a bowl and reserve the syrup.



2. Use an electric beater to whisk together the cream, icing sugar and vanilla in a bowl until firm peaks form.



3. Divide the reserved syrup among 2 jugs. Cover one jug and place in fridge. Dip one-third of the biscuits into the other jug of syrup and divide among six 250ml (1-cup) capacity glasses. Spoon over one-third of the cream. Repeat with the remaining biscuits, syrup and cream. Place in the fridge for 1 hour or until the biscuits soften.



4. Spoon over the cherries and reserved syrup. Top with Flake to serve.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kateann L
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<question from>



Raven B

<question>



Help!!!!!!!!!!! does anybody know recipe for strawberry cake ?



</question>



<answer from>



ALISON H
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 1632 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://southernfood.about.com/cs/cakerec...



</answer>



<answer from>



R@@R
Member since: 03 July 2007
Total points: 478 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients:
1 package white cake mix
1 package (3 ounces) strawberry-flavored gelatin powder
1 cup vegetable oil
4 eggs, lightly beaten
1/4 cup water
3/4 cup mashed strawberries
.
Strawberry Icing
1/2 cup butter
1 pound confectioners' sugar
1/4 cup mashed strawberries
Preparation:
Combine cake mix and gelatin powder in a large bowl. Beat in oil, eggs, water, and strawberries. Pour into 2 9-inch round greased and floured cake pans. Bake in a 350 degree oven for 30 minutes, until a toothpick inserted in center comes out clean. Cool and frost with strawberry icing.
For icing, beat the butter and confectioners' sugar together until smooth. Add strawberries. Spread between cake layers, then frost top and sides.



</answer>



<answer from>



D_@z
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 329 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients (serves 8)



* 2 1/2 cups (375g) self-raising flour



* 3 tsp baking powder



* 8 eggs (59g each), at room temperature, 2 separated



* 375g unsalted butter, chopped, softened



* 375g caster sugar, plus 1/3 cup extra



* Finely grated rind and juice of 2 mandarins



* 4 x 250g punnets strawberries, hulled, sliced widthways



* 1/4 cup (60ml) Cointreau or other orange-flavoured liqueur



* 1 1/2 cups (240g) icing sugar, sifted



* 300g mascarpone



* Sugar flowers or edible flowers, to decorate



Method



1. Preheat oven to 170°C. Grease two 24cm cake tins and line bases with baking paper. Sift flour, baking powder and 1/2 tsp salt into a large bowl of an electric mixer. Add 6 eggs, butter, sugar, and mandarin rind and juice, and beat on low speed until ingredients are moistened. Scrape down sides of bowl and beat for 1 minute or until mixture is smooth and well combined. Divide mixture between tins. Smooth tops, then bake cakes for 30 minutes or until a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean. Stand cakes in tins for 8 minutes, then turn on to a wire rack to cool completely.



2. Combine strawberries, liqueur and 1/4 cup icing sugar in a bowl and set aside for 20 minutes. Using an electric mixer, whisk mascarpone, 2 tbs extra sugar and 2 egg yolks until very thick. In a clean bowl, whisk 2 eggwhites until soft peaks form. Gradually add remaining 2 tbs extra sugar and whisk until firm peaks form, then fold gently into mascarpone mixture.



3. Drain juices from strawberries and reserve. Place strawberries on one cake half and top with mascarpone mixture, spreading it 3cm from edge. Top with second cake. Add enough strawberry juices to remaining icing sugar to form a thick icing, then spread icing over top of cake, allowing it to drip down sides slightly. Stand until icing is set, then decorate with sugar or fresh flowers.



</answer>



<answer from>



Karyn
Member since: 09 November 2007
Total points: 2180 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This one is real good & easy.  It's called Delicious Strawberry Cake.



1 box yellow cake mix
1 cup Wesson oil
1 (3 oz.) box strawberry Jello
1 box thawed strawberries
2 tbls. flour
4 eggs
1 cup water



Combine with mixer to make into a 3 layer cake.  Bake @ 350 degrees for 30-35 minutes.  Cool & ice.  Seems like when I made this cake I put it in a long rectangular pan.



Icing



1 box powdered sugar
1 box thawed strawberries
1 stick butter, softened



Combine all & spread on cooled cake.



</answer>

<answer>



1 (18.25 ounce) package white cake mix



1 (3 ounce) package strawberry flavored gelatin



2/3 cup vegetable oil



4 eggs



3 tablespoons all-purpose flour



4 ounces frozen strawberries



1/2 cup buttermilk



Add to Recipe Box



My folders:



Add to Shopping List



Add a Personal Note



DIRECTIONS
Thaw and drain the frozen strawberries.



Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Lightly grease on 9x13 inch cake pan.



Combine the white cake mix, strawberry gelatin, oil, eggs, flour, thawed strawberries, and buttermilk and mix until just combined. Pour batter into prepared pan.



Bake at 350 degrees F (175 degrees C) for about 25 to 35 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.



</answer>



<answer from>



Been There~Done That!
Member since: 23 May 2006
Total points: 107548 (Level 7)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



Strawberry Cake



A strawberry cake recipe, made with a cake mix and strawberries.



* 1 package white cake mix



* 1 package (3 ounces) strawberry-flavored gelatin powder



* 1 cup vegetable oil



* 4 eggs, lightly beaten



* 1/4 cup water



* 3/4 cup mashed strawberries



* .



* Strawberry Icing



* 1/2 cup butter



* 1 pound confectioners' sugar



* 1/4 cup mashed strawberries



Combine cake mix and gelatin powder in a large bowl. Beat in oil, eggs, water, and strawberries. Pour into 2 9-inch round greased and floured cake pans. Bake in a 350 degree oven for 30 minutes, until a toothpick inserted in center comes out clean. Cool and frost with strawberry icing.



For icing, beat the butter and confectioners' sugar together until smooth. Add strawberries. Spread between cake layers, then frost top and sides.



</answer>



<answer from>



Janvie ♥
Member since: 21 August 2007
Total points: 9255 (Level 5)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



***** Yummy Strawberry Cake



500-800 g (1 lb - 1.75 lb) fresh strawberries, washed & hulled
1/4 cup powdered sugar
1 Tbs rum
---CAKE:---
4 eggs, at room temperature
2/3 cup caster sugar
1/3 cup cornstarch
1/3 cup plain flour
1/3 cup self-raising flour
---WHITE FILLING:---
3 egg white
100 g (3.5 oz) sugar
juice of 1 lemon
---YELLOW FILLING:---
3 egg yolks (very fresh)
100 g (3.5 oz) sugar
100 g (3.5 oz) butter or margarine
---CAKE: Beat whole eggs in a small bowl with electric mixer on a moderately high speed about 7 minutes.Add sugar, about 1 tablespoon at a time, beating after each addition until sugar is dissolved.Sift dry ingredients together over the egg mixture, use a spatula to lightly fold the flours through.Spread mixture evenly into pan, bake in 175 C (350 F) oven for 40 minutes.
---WHITE FILLING: Whip the egg whites till stiffened. Add sugar and lemon juice and beat some more. Divide filling in 2 parts.
----YELLOW FILLING: Beat together egg yolks, sugar and butter. Fold in ½ of the white filling.Combine strawberries with sugar and rum and arrange them on the baked and cooled cake. Spread with the yellow filling, then with the white filling.
******* Light-As-Air Strawberry Cake
--- The cake: 3 large eggs



4 ounces caster sugar
3 ounces flour



---The filling: 1 cup strawberries



3 fluid ounces whipping cream



Strawberry jam



Grease two eighteen-inch cake tins and dust with flour and caster sugar. Tap out any excess.Put the eggs and sugar in a deep bowl over a pan of hot water and whisk until light and creamy. No heat is needed if you use an electric whisk. The mixture should just hold the impression of the whisk for a few seconds.Remove from the heat, if using, and whisk until cool.Fold the flour in half at a time. Be gentle to leave all the air in the mixture that you can.Divide the mixture between the tins and cook for 20-25 minutes until top springs back when touched.Turn out and leave to cool on a wire rack.To build the finished cake first choose which cake is to be on the bottom and place it on a serving plate.Spread with a layer of strawberry jam. Add a layer of sliced strawberries. Add a layer of whipped cream.Choose which side of the remaining cake is to be on show, and spread the other side with jam. Place on top of the cream.Sprinkle the cake with icing sugar and serve.
******Heavenly Strawberry Cake
1 Angel Food cake
2 pts. frozen strawberries (in syrup)
1 (10 oz.) tub Cool Whip
Cut top of cake off. Lay aside. Dig out ditch in center of cake; set cake aside. Mix strawberries and Cool Whip. Fill ditch with strawberry mixture. Put top of cake back and with leftover strawberries put on top of cake. Refrigerate for 1 hour, then serve.
******Strawberry Punch Bowl Cake
http://southerncuisine.suite101.com/arti...
*****Coconut Strawberry Cake
http://www.cooksrecipes.com/cake/coconut...
*****Glazed strawberry cake
http://www.sofeminine.co.uk/w/recipe/r13...
*****Simple Summer Strawberry Delight Cake
1 box white or vanilla cake mix
1 qt. strawberries
1/2 c. sugar
1 container Cool Whip
Prepare cake mix as directed. Slice strawberries, sprinkle with sugar. Use a toothpick to make small holes in baked cake. Drain strawberry juice in cake holes. Apply Cool Whip to cake as icing. Decorate cake with sliced strawberries.
****CHOCOLATE BANANA STRAWBERRY CAKE
1 egg
1 1/2 tsp baking powder
1 cup meshed banana
1 1/2 cup all purpose flour
3/4 cup semi sweet chocolate chips
1/2 cup unsalted butter which is melted
1/4 tsp salt
2/3 cup white sugar
1/4 cup milk
In a large mixing bowl stir together all purpose flour, sugar, salt and baking powder.Take another bowl and mix together melted butter milk egg and meshed bananas.Now add the banana mixture into the flour mixture until thoroughly blended.Be careful not to overmix.Add the chocolate chips. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F to 175 degrees C.Grease and flour a 9x13 inch pan.Pour the batter into the pan and bake it for 32-35 minutes or until the toothpick inserted into it comes out clean.When the cake gets baked take out the pan from the oven and let it cool for 10-15 minutes.
This cake will have some melted chocolate but no crumbs.



ENJOY :-)



</answer>

<answer>



this recipe is taken from the BBC "big cook little cook" recipe archive, so it's easy for kids to make. I made it once and it's absolutely gorgeous! Alternatively, you can make small individual pies if you get small pastry moulds. Serve warm with ice cream, kids will love it.



PUMPKIN PIE



Ingredients:



ready-made pastry case



1/4 chopped pumpkin into 2 cm squares



1 tablespoon treacle



50g soft brown sugar
a small pot of double-cream



2 eggs



Method:



Ask a grown-up to preheat the oven to 180 Celsius. 360 F/ gas mark 4. Place a baking tray inside to warm it.



Ask a grown-up to boil the pumpkin in a saucepan for about 5 minutes until soft.



Drain and mash up the pumpkin in a bowl with a potato masher.



Crack two eggs into another bowl and whisk until frothy.



Ask a grown-up to heat the treacle, sugar and cream in a saucepan. Simmer for about 2 minutes and mix with a spoon.



Pour the cream mixture into the whisked eggs and whisk again. Add the pumpkin and stir together well. Transfer the whole mixture to a jug.



Pour the mixture into the pastry case and put in to the oven for 35 - 45 minutes.



Ask a grown-up to take it out of the oven and allow to cool.



</answer>



<answer from>



D_@z
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 329 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



pumpkin has a soft taste, but if you baked or steam it, the smell is so good, delicious
I think pumpkin pie and pumpkin cake, is so delicious
I'm going to try give you some recipe



PUMPKIN PIE
Ingredients (serves 6)



* 2 cups pumpkin puree (steam 500g peeled pumpkin until soft, then puree)



* 3 eggs



* 1 1/2 cups thickened cream, plus extra to serve



* 185g brown sugar



* 1 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon



* 1 tsp ground ginger



* 1/2 tsp nutmeg



* 1/4 tsp ground cloves



* 1/4 tsp allspice



* Maple syrup, to serve



* Icing sugar, to dust



*



Pastry



* 250g plain flour



* 110g pure icing sugar, sifted



* 110g unsalted butter, chilled, cubed



* 1 egg



Method



1. To make the pastry, place the flour and icing sugar in a food processor and pulse for a few seconds. Add butter and process until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs. Add the egg and process until the mixture forms a ball. Cover in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 30 minutes.



2. Once chilled, roll pastry out on a lightly floured workbench and use to line a lightly greased 23cm fluted loose-bottomed tart pan. Refrigerate for 30 minutes to chill.



3. Preheat oven to 180°C. Line the pan with baking paper, fill with rice and blind-bake for 10 minutes. Increase oven temperature to 220°C. Place pumpkin puree, eggs, cream, sugar and spices in a processor and whiz until smooth. Pour into the tart shell, then bake for 10 minutes. Reduce oven temperature to 150°C and bake for a further 30-40 minutes. Cool, then serve with the extra cream, a drizzle of maple syrup and dusting of icing sugar.



PUMPKIN CAKE
Ingredients (serves 8)



* 600g piece peeled, seeded butternut or Queensland blue pumpkin



* 2 1/2 cups (550g) caster sugar



* Juice of 1 lemon



* 250g unsalted butter, chopped, softened



* 3 eggs, separated



* 1/2 cup (50g) walnuts, finely chopped, plus 12 walnut halves, to decorate



* Finely grated rind of 2 oranges



* 2 cups (300g) self-raising flour



Method



1. Preheat oven to 180°C. Cut a 100g piece from pumpkin and set aside. Cut remaining pumpkin into 3cm chunks. Wrap chunks in foil and place on an oven tray, then bake for 45 minutes or until tender. Remove from foil and cool. Mash cooled pumpkin then measure 1 cup puree. Using a vegetable peeler, peel reserved pumpkin into thin, wide strips.



2. Place 1 cup sugar and 1/2 cup water in a saucepan and stir over medium heat until sugar dissolves. Add pumpkin strips and cook for 20 minutes or until pumpkin is translucent and syrup is thick. Using a slotted spoon, transfer pumpkin to a piece of baking paper to dry. When dry, place in a bowl and scatter with 1/2 cup sugar. Stir lemon juice into syrup and set aside.



3. Grease a 24cm non-stick, fluted (bundt tin) cake tin. Using an electric mixer, beat butter and remaining 1 cup sugar until light and fluffy. Gradually add egg yolks and beat until combined. Add 1 cup pumpkin puree, walnuts and rind then beat until incorporated. Sift flour and 1/2 tsp salt over then gently stir in. In a clean bowl, using an electric mixer, whisk eggwhites until soft peaks form then gently fold into pumpkin mixture. Spoon into prepared tin and bake for 45 minutes or until a skewer inserted into the centre comes out clean. Stand for 10 minutes then turn on to a wire rack over a tray.



4. Using a pastry brush, brush warm syrup over warm cake then top with walnut halves and candied pumpkin. Serve warm or at room temperature.



</answer>



<answer from>



cin2win
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 24800 (Level 6)

Cooking & Recipes

<answer>



do pumpkin bread you could even just turn these into pumpkin muffins and let them decorate their own one



Ingredients:



1 1/2 cups flour



1/2 teaspoon salt



1 teaspoon baking soda



1 cup sugar



1 cup pumpkin puree



1/2 cup vegetable oil



2 eggs (beaten)



1/4 cup milk



1 teaspoon cinnamon



1/4 teaspoon allspice



1 cup chopped walnuts (optional)



--------------------------------------...



Directions:



In a large bowl combine flour, salt, sugar and baking soda.



In a separate bowl, combine pumpkin puree, oil, eggs, milk and spices.



Add pumpkin mixture to flour mixture until just combined.  Do not over mix.



Fold in walnuts (if using).



Transfer mixture to a lightly greased loaf pan.



Bake in a preheated oven at 350F for approximately 45 to 55 minutes or until golden and baked through.



Cool for 5 minutes in pan before removing to wire rack to cool completely.



</answer>

<question>



Why is rice bad for you?



why is rice bad for you when you have heart problems



</question>



<answer from>



epic_lay...
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 7626 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



too  much rice is bad for you.



try eating brown rice which retains most of the nutrients.  white rice is usually stripped of the more valuable nutrients.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I needed to know how eating rice affects
people with heart problems



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Eric S
Member since: 31 August 2007
Total points: 6606 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've never hear of it being actually bad, but it's starchy and can lead to obesity if your diet doesn't include other things like vegetables. Other problem with rice is that most people eat it with huge amounts of butter, cheese, or cream sauces.



</answer>

<question>



Recipe's for a first timer?



My boyfriend and I are getting an apartment together real soon. We're both 18, and I don't know too much about cooking. I DO know how to make spaghetti, hamburger helper, hamburgers, chili, you know, the easy stuff.



So what I'm asking is, if anyone knows any great recipes that they're willing to spare, I would love to have them. Anything is acceptable. Desserts, dinners, breakfast, and lunch.



It will be greatly appreciated!



</question>



<answer from>



Jason H
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 462 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



www.foodtv.com



</answer>



<answer from>



golfgirl...
Member since: 20 May 2008
Total points: 4248 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



***Kielbasa, Pasta & Cheddar Casserole***



1 pound rigatoni



2 tablespoons olive oil



1 large onion, sliced



1/4 cup all-purpose flour



1 quart milk



3 cups shredded extra-sharp cheddar cheese



1 teaspoon hot-pepper sauce



1 teaspoon salt



1 package fully cooked kielbasa (14 ounces), sliced into 1/4-inch-thick coins



3 Fuji apples, cored and cut into 1/2-inch cubes



2 scallions, thinly sliced



Directions
1. Heat oven to 350 degrees F. Coat a 10-cup baking dish with nonstick cooking spray.



2. In large deep pot of lightly salted boiling water, cook rigatoni until al dente, firm but tender, following package directions. Drain.



3. Meanwhile, in large, heavy-bottomed saucepan, heat oil over medium-high heat. Add onion; cook until softened, 5 to 7 minutes. Stir in flour; cook 1 minute. Gradually whisk in milk. Bring to boiling, stirring continuously; boil until thickened, about 1 minute. Remove from heat.



4. Set aside 1 cup cheese for topping the casserole. Whisk remaining 2 cups cheese, hot-pepper sauce and salt into milk mixture.



5. In pasta pot, combine rigatoni, cheese sauce, kielbasa and apples. Spoon into prepared baking dish, mounding slightly. Cover.



6. Bake in 350 degree oven, covered, for 30 minutes. Uncover and stir. Sprinkle with remaining 1 cup cheese and the scallions. Bake until cheese is melted, about 10 minutes. Let stand 10 minutes before serving. Makes 8 servings.



****Reuben Casserole****



Directions
1. Place contents of 20-ounce bag fully-cooked hash brown potatoes in greased 13 x 9 x 2-inch baking dish. Season with 1/4 teaspoon salt and 1/8 teaspoon pepper. Bake in 450 degree F oven 15 minutes. Slice 2-pound fully-cooked corned beef 1/4 inch thick; place slices, overlapping, on top of potatoes. Spread 1/4 cup bottled Russian dressing over meat. Spoon drained 16-ounce can sauerkraut over top. Cover with 8 slices (about 6 ounces) Swiss cheese. Bake in 450 degree F oven for 15 minutes. Serve with Russian dressing on the side. Makes 8 servings.



</answer>

<answer>



here is a very easy one
1lb pasta (elbow or rotini)
1lb hamburger or ground turkey
1jar of salsa
1regular size tub of light sour cream



1 can of whole kernel corn



cook hamburger or ground turkey fully
cook elbow or rotini pasta (something in that area of pasta will do fine. no long spaghetti like pasta though)
mix all ingredients together. it makes a creamy southwest pasta that will be great for leftovers too. Can feed 4-6 people. Takes about 30 min.

<answer>



A great breakfast...



Homemade Sauage and Cheese Muffin
1 package of Bob Evan's sandwich sized sausage patties
1 package of English muffins
slices of American cheese



Brown patties on grill, or in skillet as you would a hamburger.  When brown, fold in corners of a slice of cheese and top each patty.  Serve on slightly toasted (only to warm and soften) English muffin



Serve with or without eggs, hash rounds, and my favorite is mandarin oranges!



Source(s):



Living on the back side of a McDonald's, I decided that I could feed my whole family on what it would cost for one breakfast meal if I fired up my grill first thing in the morning. I could use the smell from McDonald's as a motivator!



</answer>

Jeg44

<answer>



As others have said allrecipes is a really good site.  My suggestion is to invest in a crock pot.  There are many really easy meals you can make and you do not have to worry about watching it all day.  There are also allot of casseroles that are quick and easy.  I am noting tater tot casserole.



Tater Tot Casserole
1 pound of hamburger cooked
1 bag of frozen mixed veggies (or whatever veggies you like)
1 can cream of chicken soup
1 8oz bag of cheddar cheese
1 bag of tater tots



Put a small amount of soup on the bottom of the casserole dish.  Layer the hamburger, mixed veggies, cream of chicken, tater tots.  Top with cheese and cook for 20 to 30 minutes, or until bubbly at 350 degrees.  You can cook this 15 minutes first and then put the cheese on top for the balance of cooking time.  The tater tots will crisp better that way.



</answer>



<answer from>



I LOVE 2 COOK!!!
Member since: 23 September 2008

<answer from>



Mark B
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi,



one of the best ways that I learned to cook is just to take things and experiment a little. It will mean the odd disaster - but for the sake of coming up with a few of your own dishes and getting to know what flavours and ingredients work with each other, it's well worth just giving it a go and trusting your own taste buds!



A few of my favourites though to start you off...



Breakfast: Drop Scones
200g/8 oz self raising flour
5g/1 oz caster sugar
1 egg
250ml/1⁄2 pint of milk
Pinch of salt



* Put the dry ingredients into a bowl and stir together.



* Make a well in the centre and drop in the egg and milk.



* Whisk everything together thoroughly. The batter should be a creamy consistency. Add a little more milk, if necessary.



* Pre-heat & lightly butter a heavy frying pan.



* Drop the batter in spoonfuls into the frying pan and cook about 2-3 minutes, until bubbles rise to the surface of the drop scones.



* Flip the drop scones over with a palette knife and let the other sides cook for a further 2 or 3 minutes - actually you will get to know when it's ready to flip them over, and then begin ignoring the timings!



* When the drop scones are cooked, place on  a clean tea towel on a cake cooling rack, and cover with another clean tea towel. The moisture and heat of the drop scones will be retained this way and they will stay soft. - I never usually bother with this alst bit, but rather I make a few at a time, then serve them up - it's quite a social thing at breakfast or any time of day. Put butter, golden syrup, bananas, etc on the table for people to choose as toppings. It's also nice to place thinnish slices of banana in the frying pan (one for each drop scone), then spoon the mixture over the top.



Lunch: Bread and dips
another good social style of lunching,



get some good quality extra virgin olive oil and balsamic vinigar. fill a small pot to about half full with oil, then pour vinigar in - the vinigar will fall to the base, making a nice dip. You can also get some humous and guacamole. Get a selection of different breads, and some olives - put in the middle of a table and share with friends, or just the two of you.
Okay, so it's not really cooking (unless you want to try making some breads!), but it is a good lunch, it is good for you, and it's great if you want to entertain for friends.



3 Courses for dinner:



Starter: Parsnip and apple soup (this is a lot nicer than it might sound!)



1 medium onion
2 medium parsnips
1 medium cooking apple
1 pint vegetable stock (a stock cube is fine)
1 tsp mixed herbs (optional)
1 pint milk



* Chop onions parsnips and apple and sauté in oil for a few minutes.
* Add stock. Bring to the boil and simmer for approximately 30 minutes
* Allow to cool slightly, then liquidise. Add the milk during this.



Serve this with fresh bread rolls - there are some great packet mixes around that make the job a lot easier!



Main: (this is for one person, obviously, so just adjust according to how many people you dare to cook for!)
Get a really sharp knife and cut into the fattest part of a chicken breast - try to make a decent size insision into the meat without going through it (it doesn't matter if this doesnt quite work every time!). Into that, stuff with chilli cheese - there are a few varieties out there - if you buy from the deli counter, they will usually let you try a little bit of the ones you are interested in before you commit to buying any.



Once done, wrap the chicken breast in a single layer of streaky bacon -  you may need three or four strips to cover completely.



Now you can do one of two things, either whack straight into a hot oven (about 200C - fan assisted), for 25 minutes, or pan fry for a bit first to give it some good colour, then transfer to the oven for about 20 mins.



Do remember to wash your hands after touching raw chicken and baconbefore touching anything else - I usually make sure I have the ingredients all ready next to me on a plate).



Serve with whatever takes your fancy - mash potato, stemed peas and carrots works really well.



Dessert: "Lemon Crunch"
blitz up 300g ginger nut biscuits.
Gently melt a large knob of butter in a pan
add gingernut biscuits into this and stir together.
press this mixture into a medium flan dish or spring-form cake mould. - Don't press it too firmly though, or it will be a pig to cut later!



While this is coolling down a bit, get the zest from two lemons, then juice them. Add this into a bowl along with a tin of condensed milk and a small tub of double cream. Whisk it all together for a minute or so, then pour over the biscuit base.



Crumble up a flake bar, or grate some chocolate ofer the top, then put in the fridge to set.



It's really easy to make - try substituting a bit of the lemon zest/juice for lime, or orange. It looks good, and is delish!



</answer>

<answer>



MullaKinVowles Soup



Ingredients:



2 cups chicken broth



2 cups milk



3 1/2 tablespoons all-purpose flour



1/2 cup skinless, boneless chicken breast halves - chopped



1 teaspoon curry powder



2 cups cooked white rice (could use the basmati rice instead)
1 stalk celery, finely chopped



1 small onion, finely chopped



1/2 cup cooked chopped broccoli (optional)



1/2 cup cooked cauliflower (optional)



1/2 cup cooked, sliced mushrooms



3/4 cup shredded Cheddar cheese



Directions:
In a large saucepan, heat chicken broth.



Place milk in a jar with lid, and add flour; shake until well blended. Add milk/flour mixture to chicken broth; stir until boiling. Stir in curry powder, and reduce heat to medium low.



Place chopped chicken breast, onion, and celery into skillet. Cook at medium heat until chicken is cooked and vegetables are soft; add to soup. Stir rice and optional vegetables into the soup. Simmer for 30 minutes, stirring.



Stir in grated cheese before serving.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/MullaKinVow...



</answer>



<answer from>



Branalis...
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 4122 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



___
1.
Gently sweat/sautee diced onion in a little oil, clean and dice leek, add to sautee pan and continue to cook over LOW heat, add in slices of carrots, and the chopped mushrooms.  Add those ingredients to chicken stock and some salt, pepper, & garlic if you have some.  Bring to a boil then reduce to low and simmer.



Prepare the chicken breasts -- if they are not breaded, you can sautee in olive oil and dice & throw into your soup.



Or you can sautee and have them as a dish with your soup.



_____________
2.
Sautee mushrooms and onions with oil, salt, pepper, and a dash of sugar.
Make rice.
Grill or sautee chicken breasts and serve mushrooms/onions over the chicken with rice on side.



With side of steamed broccoli.



_____
3.
Make rice and add lots & lots of cheese, a bit of milk, and steamed broccoli to it.
Put grilled or sauteed chicken breast on top and bake in a baking dish for 35 mins on 375, covered.



</answer>

<answer>



Pumpkin Soup
2 pounds pumpkin, peeled
2 onions, chopped
6 cups stock
1 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon pepper
1 tablespoon flour
1/4 cup cold water
1 cup light cream
Chopped parsley



Cut pumpkin into 1/2-inch cubes, removing seeds and fiber. Place in a saucepan with the onions, stock and seasoning. Cook over low heat until pumpkin is soft, about 1 hour.



Purée pumpkin in blender. Return to saucepan.



Combine flour and water and stir until smooth. Add to the soup, stirring constantly, until it begins to boil. Add cream. Mix well. Remove from heat.



Garnish with chopped parsley to serve.



Source(s):



http://www.gourmet-living.com/recipes.ht...



</answer>

<answer>



Try this recipe. The edges remain soft. This is our favorite recipe.



Truck-Stop Buttermilk Pancakes



Prep Time: 10 Minutes
Cook Time: 5 Minutes 	Ready In: 15 Minutes
Yields: 12 servings
"A yummy breakfast treat, and very easy to make!! Serve with bacon or sausage, and some fried eggs, wonderful!!! Batter will keep in fridge for a couple of days if you can't make all at once, or you can freeze and make at a later date."
INGREDIENTS:
5 eggs
1 1/2 cups milk
6 tablespoons butter, melted
5 cups buttermilk
5 cups all-purpose flour



5 teaspoons baking powder
5 teaspoons baking soda
1 pinch salt (optional)
5 tablespoons sugar
DIRECTIONS:
1. 	In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs, milk, butter and buttermilk. Combine the flour, baking powder, baking soda and sugar; stir into the wet ingredients just until blended. Adjust the thickness of the batter to your liking by adding more flour or buttermilk if necessary.
2. 	Heat a large skillet over medium heat, and coat with cooking spray. Pour 1/4 cupfuls of batter onto the skillet, and cook until bubbles appear on the surface. Flip with a spatula, and cook until browned on the other side. Continue with remaining batter.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Truck-Stop-...



</answer>

<answer from>



Sugar Pie
Member since: 18 March 2006
Total points: 69942 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



This joker will convince even avowed fruit cake haters that they like fruit cake!



Creole Christmas Fruit Cake w/ Whisky Sauce



For the Simple Syrup:
1 cup granulated sugar
1 cup water



1 1/2 tablespoons lemon zest, cut in strips



2 tablespoons lemon juice



For the Cake:



1/2 pound mixed dried fruits, such as blueberries, cranberries, cherries, raisins, and chopped apricots



1/2 pound, (2 sticks) unsalted butter, at room temperature



1 cup plus 2 tablespoons granulated sugar



2 ounces almond paste



4 large eggs



1/2 cup Grand Marnier, or other orange-flavored liqueur



2 cups bleached all-purpose flour



1 teaspoon baking powder



1/8 teaspoon salt



1/8 teaspoon ground cinnamon



Pinch freshly grated nutmeg



1/2 cup slivered almonds, toasted



1/2 cup pecan pieces



1/2 cup walnut pieces



1/4 cup bourbon



Make a simple-syrup by combining the sugar and water in a medium-size heavy-bottomed saucepan over medium-high heat. Add the lemon zest and juice and bring to a boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Boil for 2 minutes and remove from the heat.



Combine the dried fruits in a large mixing bowl. Pour the simple-syrup over them, toss to coat and let steep for 5 minutes. Strain and reserve the syrup.



Cream the butter, sugar and almond paste together in the bowl of an electric mixer fitted with a paddle at low speed, occasionally scraping down the sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula. Beat until the mixture is fluffy and smooth, about 2 minutes. Add the eggs 1 at a time, mixing in between each addition on low speed and scraping down the sides of the bowl as necessary. Add 1/4 cup of the Grand Marnier and mix to incorporate.



Combine the flour, baking powder, salt, cinnamon and nutmeg in a medium-size mixing bowl and blend well. Add this mixture 1/2 cup at a time to the butter mixture with the mixer on low speed, each time mixing until smooth, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as necessary. The batter will be thick.



Add the warm fruit and all of the nuts a little at a time, mixing well. Scrape down the sides of the bowl and the paddle.



Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F.



Lightly grease a bundt pan with butter or non-stick baking spray. Pour the batter into the pan and bake until golden brown and the top springs back when touched, about 45 to 50 minutes (turning the pan to ensure even browning after 30 minutes.)



Cool the cake for 20 minutes in the pan, then remove and continue to cool upside-down on wire racks.



Make tiny holes with a toothpick randomly on the rounded end of the cake. Combine the remaining simple syrup with the remaining 1/4 cup of Grand Marnier and the bourbon. Wrap the cake in a layer of cheesecloth and pour 1/4 cup of the syrup over the top of each cake. Store in a plastic zip bag for 3 or 4 days until the cake is slightly stale. Sprinkle syrup over cakes once every 2 to 3 days until all of the syrup is used. Let the cakes age for up to 3 weeks before eating.



For the Whiskey Sauce:



3 cups heavy cream



1/2 cup bourbon



1/2 cup granulated sugar



1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons cornstarch



Combine 2 3/4 cups of the cream with the bourbon and sugar in a medium-size nonstick saucepan over medium-heat. Stir to dissolve the sugar.



In a small bowl, dissolve the cornstarch in the remaining 1/4 cup cream. Add this to the cream-and-bourbon mixture and simmer stirring often, until the mixture thickens, 4 to 5 minutes. Remove from the heat and serve warm with the fruitcake.



The sauce may be stored, after it has cooled, in an airtight container for 24 hours. When ready to serve, warm over low heat.



--Emeril Lagasse, 2003



</answer>



<answer from>



Dune
Member since: 27 May 2007
Total points: 79026 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Cake:- Fruit
225 Gram Sugar (8 oz)
225 ml Milk (8 fl oz)
175 Gram Butter (6 oz)
225 Gram Dried fruit, your choice (8 oz)
400 Gram Self raising flour (14 oz)



Method



Put the first 4 ingredients in a pan, bring to the boil and mix together, let the mixture cool slightly then add flour and mix thoroughly.
Grease and line a 900g (2 lb) loaf tin, pour in mixture and bake for 1 hour at 160 °C / 325 °F / Gas 3. Leave to cool, remove from tin and slice.



</answer>

<answer from>



bonnie
Member since: 08 August 2006
Total points: 646 (Level 2)

<answer>



Here's one for you.



Black eyed Peas and Greens soup



•1 tablespoon vegetable oil
•1 cup diced onion
•1 cup diced celery
•1/2 cup diced sweet bell pepper, red or green
•4 to 6 ounces diced ham
•4 cloves garlic, minced
•4 cups chicken broth
•3 cups cooked black-eyed peas or 2 cans (15 to 16 ounces each) drained and rinsed
•1 1/2 cups frozen chopped turnip greens or spinach, thawed
•2 cans (14.5 ounces each) tomatoes, diced, with juice
•1/2 teaspoon Creole seasoning
•1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
•1/4 teaspoon dried oregano
•salt, to taste



Preparation:
Stovetop:
In a large Dutch oven or large saucepan over medium heat, saute the onion and celery in vegetable oil until tender. Add the ham, bell pepper, and garlic and saute, stirring, for 2 to 3 minutes longer.



To the ham and vegetable mixture add chicken broth, black-eyed peas, greens, tomatoes, Creole seasoning, pepper, and oregano. Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 45 minutes to 1 hour. Taste and add salt, as needed.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rick W
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 952 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Black-eyed peas with sausage and barbecue sauce, and more black-eyed pea recipes below.
Ingredients:



* 1 pound dried black-eyed peas



* 1 pound link sausage, or your favorite



* 1 small onion, chopped



* 3 tablespoons brown sugar



* 1 tablespoon prepared mustard



* 1 teaspoon salt



* 1 cup prepared barbecue sauce



Preparation:
Rinse, prepare, soak, and cook peas in about 3 cups water, following directions on the package. Drain and reserve half of the cooking liquid. In a skillet over medium heat, brown sausage and onions; drain off excess fat. Place peas in a 3-quart casserole; add sausage and onions. Stir in reserved liquid, brown sugar, mustard, salt, and barbecue sauce. Bake at 300° for 1 to 1 1/2 hours.
http://southernfood.about.com/od/blackey...



Ham and Black-Eyed Pea Soup with Collard Greens



Gourmet |  December 1998



*



recipe



*



reviews (37)



*



my notes



This recipe can be prepared in 45 minutes or less.



Although we call for canned black-eyed peas, you can use frozen peas or cook up a batch of dried ones.



Yield: Makes about 4 cups, serving 2 as a main course.



subscribe to Gourmet
Ingredients



* 1 medium onion



* 1 garlic clove



* a 4-ounce piece cooked ham



* 2 tablespoons olive oil



* 1/2 pound collard greens



* 1 cup chicken broth (8 fluid ounces)



* 3 cups water



* a 16-ounce can black-eyed peas (about 1 1/2 cups)



* 1 teaspoon cider vinegar



Preparation



Chop onion and garlic and cut ham into 1/4-inch dice. In a 3-quart saucepan cook onion, garlic, and ham in oil over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until onion is pale golden.



While onion mixture is cooking, discard stems and center ribs from collards and finely chop leaves. Add collards, broth, and water to onion mixture and simmer until collards are tender, about 20 minutes.



Rinse and drain black-eyed peas. In a bowl mash half of peas with a fork. Stir mashed and whole peas into soup and simmer 5 minutes. Season soup with salt and pepper and stir in vinegar.



http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/v...



Black-Eyed Pea Soup
From all-creatures.org
Vegan - Vegetarian Recipe Book



How Mary and Frank and Friends Eat
"We are dedicated to cruelty free living through a vegetarian - vegan lifestyle."
"Let no animal die that we may live!"



| Home Page | Recipes Table of Contents |



Soup - Black-Eyed Pea
This recipe is being prepared in a 6-1/2 quart slow cooker, if you have a smaller pot, cut the recipe in half.



Ingredients



2 lbs. Black-eyed Peas, dried
3 cups Onions, diced
1 - 6-oz. can Tomato Paste
4 Bay Leaves
Cayenne Pepper or Hot Sauce, to taste (optional)
(To enlarge the photo of the black-eyed pea soup, click on the photo or link)



Preparation



This black-eyed pea soup is best prepared the evening before you want to serve it.



Turn on the slow cooker (Crock-Pot) to "high."



Boil 12 cups of water and carefully pour into the cooker pot. Cover with the lid.



While the water is boiling, wash the dried black-eyed peas in a strainer and remove any extraneous matter.  It is best to do this in quantities of no more than one cup at a time.  Add the black-eyed peas to the pot, and cover again.



Add the bay leaves.



Before going to bed, turn the slow cooker down to "low."



In the morning, mix the black-eyed pea soup, add the tomato paste, and mix again.  If the soup is too thick, boil one more cup of water, add it to the pot, and mix.  Repeat as necessary.



Wash, peel, and dice the onions, and add to the the cooker pot. (We precook the onions in our microwave oven.)  Add cayenne pepper or hot sauce (optional, adjust to taste).  Cover the pot.



If you are planning to eat the black-eyed pea soup at noon, we suggest turning the heat back up to "high."  Mix the soup every hour.



If you are going to be away during the day, and are planning to eat the black-eyed pea soup in the evening, leave the pot setting on "low."



Serve and enjoy with a large tossed salad.



http://www.all-creatures.org/recipes/sou...



</answer>



<answer from>



Karen B
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 1933 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



My husband likes this.



Black Eye Pea Soup Recipe



Serves/Makes:



6
Ingredients:
8 ounces black eye peas
6 cups water
1 large onion, finely chopped
4 carrots, thinly sliced
2 tablespoons fresh garden herbs, finely chopped (dill and parsley)
4 large clove elephant garlic, crushed
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
2 teaspoons salt
3 teaspoons coarsely ground black pepper
natural Balkan or Greek yogurt to serve
Turn this recipe into a puzzle! [click]



Directions:



Bring water to a boil in a deep pan. Add peas, onion, carrots, garden herbs, elephant garlic, cayenne pepper, salt and black pepper. Boil rapidly for 15 minutes until frothy. Remove froth with a spoon and discard.



Reduce heat and simmer for 2 hours until smooth. Put in blender for a smoother soup. Serve red hot with a dollop of yogurt and pita bread.



This recipe from CDKitchen for Black Eye Pea Soup serves/makes 6



Source(s):



http://www.cdkitchen.com/recipes/recs/20...



</answer>

<question>



I want to make my baked ziti cheesy,smooth and stringy. which cheese should i use to do this?



</question>



<answer from>



Jypcee 5000
Member since: 02 May 2007
Total points: 10583 (Level 6)

</answer>



<answer from>



mark
Member since: 26 December 2006
Total points: 35904 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Gotta use Mozzarella as the main cheese
