The combination of mozzarella and Ricotta gets you that stringy and smooth combo.



</answer>



<answer from>



Paula M
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 711 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I use provolone, mozzarella and parmesan. Here's the recipe I use:



Baked Ziti



Ingredients:
1 (16 ounce) package dry ziti pasta



1 pound lean ground beef (I use pork sausage instead)
1 onion, chopped



2 (28 ounce) jars spaghetti sauce



6 ounces sliced provolone cheese



6 ounces sliced mozzarella cheese



1 1/2 cups sour cream



1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese



1/4 cup chopped fresh basil



Directions:
Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add pasta and cook for 8 to 10 minutes or until al dente; drain.



In a large skillet, brown beef over medium heat. Add onions; saute until tender. Drain off fat and add spaghetti sauce; simmer for about 15 minutes.



Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).



In a lightly greased 2 quart baking dish, place about half of the pasta; top with a layer of provolone and mozzarella cheese slices. Spread on a layer of half the spaghetti sauce mixture and sour cream.



Cover with remaining pasta, cheese and sauce; sprinkle a layer of Parmesan cheese and fresh basil.



Bake in preheated oven for about 30 minutes or until cheese and sauce are bubbly; serve.



Source(s):



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Baked-Ziti-...



</answer>

Total points: 4122 (Level 4)

<answer>

If you have parmesan, add a little parm too, for added salty flavor.

<question>



What can i do with the goop from inside my pumpkin (ideally savoury recipes please...)?



</question>



<answer from>



jlovett7...
Member since: 11 April 2006
Total points: 2113 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pumpkin pie is always an option. My favorite is making roasted pumpkin seeds. You just have to separate the seeds from the "goop" and bake them on a sheet tray. Then toss them with some salt and enjoy.



</answer>



<answer from>



cruizers...
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 706 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



When I was a child my Great Aunt used to put the pumpkin seeds in the oven to dry or roast.  Once done (usually 15-20mins) she would place them into a paper bag, put a little butter, sugar, and Cinnamon in with them and then shook them up!  I think she put them back into the oven for 5-10 more mins.  They're actually really good! Try it you might like too.



</answer>

<question>



Spaghetti sauce question?



ok. I've never really made spaghetti before. There is a boxed kind that I have had before. But anyhow, I want to buy a jar of spaghetti sauce, do I need to refrigerate it after opening?? How long can I keep it for? I'm looking to keep it for a good while. I've seen some spaghetti sauce mixes. Do they last longer than the sauce in a jar?? Would it be better to buy it instead?? Thanks in advance for any decent answers.



</question>



<answer from>



mark
Member since: 26 December 2006
Total points: 35904 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you do buy a jar, you will probably use most of it over 1 lb of spaghetti.



Toss some of it in with the cooked spaghetti (to prevent sticking) and serve some on the side to accomodate individual preferences for amount of sauce.



Refrigerate left over sauce but use it fairly quickly (a few days)



Never heard of a spaghetti sauce mix.



There are a million sauce recipes, but the ingredients are simple.



Garlic or Onion, Basil, some use oregano,



Some use celery and carrot finely chopped (with the onion).



And tomatoes of course.



Make it yourself



</answer>



<answer from>



dadnbob
Member since: 25 March 2006
Total points: 1183 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it goes in the fridge after opening.  As far as taste I think the jar tastes better than the mix.  Even when I just the jar stuff I always add extra stuff according to our tastes.  I wouldn't keep it much more than a week.



</answer>



<answer from>



Vecta
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 114 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, you will need to refrigerate the spaghetti sauce after you open it. It is good to keep anything that comes in a can or jar refrigerated after you open it, especially if you are unsure.



Keep the top on tightly, and it should be good for a while. I've been going though a jar of sauce for about a week now and it is still good.



A mix would keep longer if it is a powdered mix of some kind. Foods without water in them generally keep longer.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 274 (Level 2)

<answer>



If I don't have time to make a homemade sauce, then I always buy the jarred variety. They taste good. You can always add more ingredients (extra garlic, mushrooms, herbs, etc.) to the sauce to suit your tastes.



The storage directions are listed on the jar. You always have to store it in the refrigerator. It only lasts a few days though. Eventually, it will begin to grow mold.



</answer>

<answer>



I prefer the jar kind, but I always add alittle bit of brown sugar, some garlic & onion that I sautee in olive oil ....
I usually use the whole jar when I make spaghetti, and then I just refridgerate my leftovers.  You can keep the sauce in the jar in the fridge, but I wouldn't leave it there for more than a week once the top has been opened.

<answer>



Yes refrigerate it after opening, it keeps for several days.  What i do is make a big pot of sauce then freeze it in a ziplock bag and wrap it in tinfoil for future use, it can save 4-6 months in the freezer.  There are many good jarred sauces out there, one of my favorites is Newman's sauces, they are affordable, tasty, and the money goes to charity!

Layla

</answer from>



<answer>



Refridgerate open sauce jars after opening. They should stay good for at least 1 to 2 weeks. Any longer than that, pour the sauce into an ice tray and you can just pop out the number of "sauce cubes" you need and thaw them! Or you can just freeze the sauce in a plastic baggie or tupperware and thaw as needed.
The boxed kind are not good at all.



</answer>

<answer>



I usually make my own, but if I use the jarred kind, I add some dry red wine.  Also, Ragu and Prego don't have the authentic Italian taste....too sweet!  Newman's is good, as well as Bertoli and Classico in the mid-price range.  I find that the more you pay, the better it is.  You really do get what you pay for in this case.
As with anything in a jar, you DO have to refrigerate the leftovers, and use within a week, but simmer it all with the wine, then re-jar it.
The powdered stuff???  Yuck!

<answer>



The jar spaghetti sauce does have to be refrigerated after opening, but I don't keep mine longer than 2 weeks.



If I have the time I make my sauce using the spaghetti sauce mix. I use buffalo beef (very lean) onions, fresh mushrooms, sweet Italian sausage, 2 can of stewed tomatoes, 1/2 cup of red wine, spaghetti sauce mix, 1 can tomato paste, 1 cup of water, 1 tsp oregano & simmer. You can also freeze the sauce but I haven't kept it longer than a month.  Enjoy!

</answer from>



<answer>



An easy way to double or triple a recipe is to use the same measurement they use two or three times.  Instead of saying 3/4 X3 = 2 1/4



just do 3/4 three times.  Get it?  one 3/4 two 3/4 three 3/4.



</answer>

<question from>



Samantha
Member since: 24 July 2007
Total points: 727 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Pumpkin pie from scratch.......?



Im making a pie from scratch but I want to use pumpkin pie spice instead of all spice, cloves, ginger, etc. Does anyone know of a good recipe or where I can find one online. Or even better how much pumpkin pie spice I should use instead of everything else?



</question>



<additional details>



I have the sweet pumpkin. Ive never made it before, I figured I might as well try it out before the holidays.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Karen B
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 1952 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Pumpkin Pie Spice
Use 2-3 tsp. per 9" pumpkin pie. I hope this helps.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanx. The pie is great!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Joanne A. W
Member since: 15 July 2007
Total points: 47185 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



From:
http://www.ochef.com/810.htm



"Pumpkin pie spice is a blend of "warm" spices, generally including some or all of the following: cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, clove, allspice, mace. There are indeed a lot of pie recipes out there that call for pumpkin pie spice, but there are probably as many where the recipe writer specifies a particular mix of individual spices.  There are a variety of pumpkin pie spice blends on the market at various prices in various quantities. You can also easily make your own. — and quite possibly without having to run out to the store. Here are a few options:



Mix 1/4 cup of cinnamon with 4 tsp of ground ginger and 2 tsp of nutmeg



Mix 1/4 cup cinnamon with 1 Tbsp each of ground ginger, nutmeg, and ground cloves



Mix 1/4 cup cinnamon with 2 Tbsp of ground ginger and 1 Tbsp each of nutmeg and ground cloves



Mix 2 Tbsp each of cinnamon and ground ginger with 1 Tbsp ground nutmeg and 1 tsp ground allspice."



</answer>



<answer from>



sissy
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 3380 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



For 1 pie you'd need 2 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice. Remember if you are really going from scratch meaning baking your own pumpkin then you need a sugar pumpkin which is different from your jack ' lantern pumpkin. But if you're using canned then 2 tasp. of your spice will work.



</answer>

<question>



What will make a banana ripen quickly and what will make a banana ripen slowly?



what can i do to make a banana ripen more quickly or more slowly.



</question>



<answer from>



domquin
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 2147 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



More quickly by wrapping it in newspaper.
More slowly by keeping in a dark and cool area.



But don't expect miracles



</answer>



<answer from>



Princess
Member since: 04 May 2006
Total points: 370 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



What might make a banana ripen quickly is if you leave it in the Sunlight, ( I tried this, and it worked ). And what will make a banana ripen slowly is if you leave it in the shade or in the refrigerator.



</answer>



<answer from>



bunny
Member since: 09 December 2007
Total points: 4422 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



HI and if you want to ripen it quickly-put it in the fridge. For a slower way to ripen - put it in a sunny place. Hope that this works for you! It does for me! Happy Halloween!



Source(s):



used to work in a produce section.



</answer>



<answer from>



Alex
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bunny, for someone who worked in the produce section, you should know that putting it in the fridge does NOT make a banana ripen quicker.  It will SLOW the ripening process, although it will make the skin turn black (but fruit will still be fine to eat).



Putting a banana in a brown paper bag is the best way to speed ripening.  Ethelyn is produced by the banana in the ripening process, and the bag traps it in when it is released which, in turn, makes ripening even quicker.



</answer>



<answer from>



Shantal
Member since: 26 September 2007
Total points: 177 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



To ripen slower leave it on the counter, or in the sun. If you want a banana to ripen quickly put it in the fridge.



Source(s):



my brain



</answer>

<answer from>

<answer>



Best way to learn to cook is to go to the bookstore first!



Get a cookbook: Better Homes and Gardens, Betty Crocker, Fanny Farmer. My absolute favorite is the BH&G. Yes, they are quite expensive, but think instead of the investment you are making.



I have had my BH&G for nearly 50 years! I didn't need a learn to cook book when I got it, but it does have all the "how-to's" in it at the front of each section. It is a life time investment in Happy Cookery!! You won't really need any other cookbooks ever, but it does lead to collecting as many as possible to get all the variations on the theme you wish for later.



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



Paula M
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 721 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Self-rising flour can be created by combining 1½ teaspoons of baking powder with a ½ teaspoon of salt and 1 cup of all-purpose flour. This substitute equals one cup of self-rising flour.



Source(s):



http://www.recipetips.com/kitchen-tips/t...



</answer>



<answer from>



danrelv
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 132 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah, you'll be fine.  My old dear always used to use baking powder instead of self raising flour and it works just fine.  Chuck about a teaspoon in there....but, if it doesn't work, I am not to blame!  Happy baking!



</answer>



<answer from>



Karen B
Member since: 16 August 2008
Total points: 1952 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Flours~



US & UK all purpose and plain flour can be interchanged without any adjustments.  US cake flour is lighter however, and can be substituted with 1 cup minus 3 Tbsp. of all purpose/plain flour, and add 3 Tbsp. of cornstarch or potato flour to make the full cup.  Self rising flour can be made by substituting 1 cup of all purpose/plain flour minus 2 tsp., and add 1 1/2 tsp. baking powder and 1/2 tsp. salt to make the full cup.



Source(s):



http://www.realfood4realpeople.com/conve...



</answer>



<answer from>



CaveGal
Member since: 15 January 2008
Total points: 948 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



One cup self-rising flour equals:
1 cup all-purpose flour, plus
1 1/4 teaspoons baking powder, plus
1/8 teaspoons salt.



</answer>



<answer from>



idkkklol
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 295 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just use a few tbp (depending on how much flour you have) of Bicarbonate Of Soda, and it should rise :))



</answer>



<answer from>



stilldev...
Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 1543 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is the basic recipe for self-rsing flour.



4 c. flour
2 T. baking powder
2 tsp. salt



Mix together, and use in your favorite recipes calling for self-rising flour!



Source(s):



http://www.ehow.com/how_4532408_own-self...



</answer>



<answer from>



sue
Member since: 03 August 2007
Total points: 38424 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



1 cup regular flour and 1 teaspoon baking powder will sub for the 1 cup self rising.



I never buy the self rising because that means I have to have another canister for it! Some things do not require rising agents.



</answer>

<original file>15697.html</original file>

<category>

</category>



<question from>



Adriana marie
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 1338 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Is there any way i can quickly defrost cookie dough?



i have store bought sugar cookie dough and homemade chocolate chip cookie dough that are both frozen solid,how can i quickly defrost these?



is it of to put them in the microwave on defrost?



</question>



<answer from>



pilotjea...
Member since: 16 August 2006
Total points: 515 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



dont put it in the microwave but take the dough put it in a tightly sealed plastic bag and run it under warm water for about 10 -15 minutes that will not totally un thaw it but at least get it so that you can cut it...there is no need to have it totally unfrozen before you bake it! Good Luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Scared Stupid
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 282 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would not microwave it, it might get too gooey or something,
Fill the sink up with cool to warm water and let them soak.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cyd
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 2011 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wouldn't recommend putting it in the microwave because it will start to cook in places. If it's that kind that is tube shaped leave it on the counter for about 10 min. then run a sharp knife under hot water and you should be able to cut through them quite easily.



</answer>



<answer from>



sue
Member since: 03 August 2007
Total points: 38432 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



yeah!! defrost them on soften butter setting. About power level 3 for 15 seconds at a time.



Cookie dough slices best if it is still icy cold. Sharp butcher knife or boning knife works best.



Defrost only enough to be able to get the knife through the dough, lay on the cookie sheets and allow to finish defrosting. about 5 minutes to baking tops!!



</answer>



<answer from>



livelaug...
Member since: 24 March 2008
Total points: 409 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



the warm water tips are truly the best ideas. Microwaving will  partially cook the dough and you would not be pleased with the results. My 7 yr old experimented with this microwave idea and it was a mess.



</answer>

http://www.halloweenforum.com/party-idea...



KNORR SPINACH DIP



PREP TIME: 10 Minute(s)
CHILL TIME: 2 Hour(s)



INGREDIENTS
1 package (10 oz.) baby spinach, chopped or 1 package (10 oz.) frozen chopped spinach, thawed and squeezed dry
1 container (16 oz.) sour cream
1 cup Hellmann's® or Best Foods® Real Mayonnaise
1 package Knorr® Vegetable recipe mix
1 can (8 oz.) water chestnuts, drained and chopped (optional)
3 green onions, chopped (optional)



PREPARATION
Everyone loves our dip! Here's how we make it:



Combine all ingredients and chill about 2 hours. Serve with your favorite dippers to your favorite people.
A new serving idea: Hollow out cucumber slices and cherry tomatoes. Fill vegetables with Knorr Spinach Dip and garnish with a sprig of dill.
MAKES 4 cups dip



Definitely go for the water chestnuts, they add a nice crunch. You can also use Pumperknickel bread and make a cauldron. Turn it upside down to hollow out, the flat bottom gives a nice edge. Place it on a fire of big pretzel logs with red/orange/yellow bell pepper flames.



http://www.notecook.com/Appetizers/Dips/...



Happy Happy Halloween Pumpkin Dip



Great for decorative gifts or for a festive party during the holidays. Serve with fruit slices or sweetbreads.



Ingredients
2 cups canned pumpkin
2 tablespoon crystallized ginger
2 (8oz) package cream cheese (room temperature)
2 teaspoon pumpkin spice(pie spice)
2 teaspoon vanilla
1/2 cup brown sugar
Method
In a mixing bowl beat cream cheese until smooth



Beat in pumpkin mix, sugar, spice, vanilla, and ginger
Cover and refrigerate for up to one week



http://allrecipes.com/Recipe/Halloween-B...



Halloween Brain Dip



Cauliflower is hollowed out and filled with avocado dip to make a realistic brain that you will enjoy serving to guests! Perfect for Halloween parties.



INGREDIENTS (Nutrition)
2 avocados



1/2 cup prepared salsa



1 head cauliflower



6 thin slices red and blue fruit leather



DIRECTIONS
Slice the avocados in half. Remove the seeds and set aside. Scoop the avocado out of the skin into a bowl. Mash with a fork or whisk and stir in the salsa. Set aside. Slice off one side of each pit to make it flat and expose the cores of the pits. They will look like eyes.



Remove all of the leaves from the cauliflower and remove the stem, leaving a nice hollow area with the outer part of the head intact. Use toothpicks to hold it together if it starts to fall apart.



Place the cauliflower into a small bowl, so that the hollow is facing upwards and most of the cauliflower is up out of the bowl. The bowl is just for stability. Fill with the avocado dip and arrange the pits as eyes. Decorate the white ''brain'' by weaving thin strands of red and blue fruit leather between the florets to make veins and arteries. I wrap the bowl with cheesecloth and decorate with red food coloring to make it even more horrific!



</answer>

preheat oven 350.

<question>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have this casserole that I make for my nieces and they love it.



You cook 2 cups of chicken (or you can buy one already cooked like I do, lol) and shred it.



You chop 1/2 cup of onion and 1/4 cup of both green and red bell pepper



Mix the chicken, onion, and peppers with 1 can of cream of chicken soup and 1/2 cup of mayonnaise and 1 cup of monteray jack/ cheddar cheese shredded.



Cook 12 oz. of egg noodles until done (al dente) then mix the noodles with the rest of the mixture and bake in a preheated 350 degree oven for 30 minutes.  After the 30 minutes, place another cup of the cheese mixture on top and bake again for 10 minutes or until the cheese is melted.  It's quite good and I hope you find it delicious as much as my nieces do, lol.



</answer>

7. CATALINA CHICKEN:



From DontH8Me
http://www.city-data.com/forum/recipes/2...



"Catalina Chicken from the thighs and legs - separate them and skin them before baking to keep the fat down, if you prefer. The recipe I use is typically for a whole chicken, so I would substitute 4 - 5 legs and thighs in this case.



Take the cleaned pieces and put them in a rectangular glass baking dish. Mix one small or 1/2 large bottle of Catalina Island French salad dressing with one envelope of Lipton's French Onion Soup Mix. At this stage, depending on your preference, you could add to the pan of chicken any of the following: Onions, 1 inch dice, red/green/yellow bell pepper, 1 inch dice, and/or pineapple tidbits. Pour the sauce mix over the whole thing and swirl it around to coat all the pieces. Cover with foil to keep moist.



Bake in a 375 degree oven until the chicken juices run clear. You will want to make a batch of fluffy rice or mashed potatoes to soak up the delicious sauce from the chicken bake. My family loves this recipe and it takes less than 5 minutes to prep."



8. Magic Seven-Layer Bars recipe from:
http://www.bigoven.com/108338-Magic-Seve...



Magic Seven-Layer Bars Ingredients
1/2 c Butter  1 c Butterscotch chips



1 1/2 c Graham cracker crumbs  1 c Walnuts, chopped



6 oz Semi-sweet chocolate chips,  1 c Sweetened condensed milk



1 c Coconut, shredded



Instructions for Magic Seven-Layer Bars
Melt butter in a 9 x 13 inch pan. Sprinkle crumbs over butter and add remaining ingredients in layers as given. Bake at 350 F for about 30 minutes. Makes about 40 bars Note: If you prefer a thicker bar, use a 9 x 9 inch pan. Bake 10 minutes longer.

<answer>



Chicken Fried Steak.  It makes a great Sunday Dinner or an everyday sandwich.  So cheap and easy to make.  Here is how I do it.



Buy some cubed steaks.  Season some all purpose flour with salt, pepper, garlic salt and Lowry's season salt.  Dredge meat in flour then drop them in a small amount of vegetable oil.  Cook till golden brown on both sides.  Heat on a Electric Stove should be just slightly past medium.  Cook like a piece of chicken then serve with mashed potatoes, gravy and your favorite vegetable.  If your from the south, serve with Sweet tea and some rolls.



</answer>

<question>



Simple Greece foods??????



We are reading the sisterhood of the traveling pants for my book club, so we wanted to make some food for us to try.... U know how that one girl who goes to Greece? so we want to make Greece food, but we have no Idea what to make... any help? Something simple, thanks!



oh yeah is Greece and Greek the same place??



</question>



<answer from>



nIέL...
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 408 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



try this:
1 (16 ounce) package elbow macaroni



1 pound ground beef



1 large onion, chopped



1 garlic clove, minced



1 (8 ounce) can tomato sauce



1/2 cup water



1 teaspoon salt



1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon



1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg



1/4 teaspoon pepper



1 egg, lightly beaten



1/2 cup grated Parmesan cheese



SAUCE:



1 cup butter



1/4 cup all-purpose flour



1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon



3 cups milk



2 eggs, lightly beaten



1/3 cup grated Parmesan cheese



DIRECTIONS
Cook macaroni according to package directions. In a large skillet, cook beef, onion and garlic over medium heat until meat is no longer pink; drain. Stir in the tomato sauce, water and seasonings. Cover and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally. Drain macaroni.



In a large bowl, combine the macaroni, egg and Parmesan cheese; set aside. For sauce, in a large saucepan, melt butter; stir in flour and cinnamon until smooth. Gradually add milk. Bring to a boil over medium heat; cook and stir for 2 minutes or until slightly thickened. Remove from the heat. Stir a small amount to hot mixture into eggs; return all to pan, stirring constantly. Stir in cheese.



In a greased 3-qt. baking dish, spread half of the macaroni mixture. Top with beef mixture and remaining macaroni mixture. Pour sauce over the top. Bake, uncovered, at 350 degrees F for 45-50 minutes or until bubbly and heated through. Let stand for 5 minutes before serving.



---or---



Outstanding Greek Salad Dressing



1 clove garlic, coarsely chopped



1 tablespoon red wine vinegar



1/4 teaspoon salt



1/4 teaspoon black pepper, freshly ground



1 pinch cayenne



1/4 cup olive oil



2 anchovy fillets, chopped or 1 teaspoon anchovy paste, chopped



To make dressing, place the garlic, vinegar, salt, black pepper and cayenne in a blender or food processor fitted with a metal blade. Whirl until blended.



Continuing to whirl, gradually add the oil, drop by drop at first, then in a thinly steady stream.



The dressing will thicken.



Continuing to whirl, add the anchovies or anchovy paste. Taste and add more salt, if needed.



The dressing can be used right away or covered and left at room temperature. If making the dressing more than 1 day ahead, cover and refrigerate.



HOPE I HELPED!!



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

Sugar Pie
Member since: 18 March 2006
Total points: 69962 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes

<answer>



Greek Baked Stuffed Shrimp



1 lb. extra-large shrimp (16-22 count), washed, deveined and butterflied with tails on
1 roll Ritz crackers, finely crushed
1/4 cup dried parsley flakes
2 Tbsp. grated Parmesan cheese
1/2 cup butter
2 tsp. minced garlic
1/4 lb. scallops, finely chopped
2 Tbsp. fresh-squeezed lemon juice
Paprika



1. Preheat oven to 425ºF. Place each shrimp on a cookie sheet or broiler pan that has been lined with foil.



2. Place roll of Ritz crackers in a plastic zipper bag. Using a rolling pin, finely crush crackers. Add parsley flakes and Parmesan cheese and mix well. Set aside.



3. In a medium-size pan, melt butter. Add minced garlic and chopped scallops. Cook for 1 minute. Add lemon juice and simmer for a couple of minutes. Remove pan from stove.



4. Add dry ingredients from zipper bag and stir until well blended. Mixture should be moist enough to mold when pinched. Top each shrimp with a mound of about 1 tablespoon of stuffing. Sprinkle paprika over each shrimp to give color.



5. Place foil loosely over shrimp and bake 10 -12 minutes until shrimp begin to turn pink in color. Remove foil and bake another 5 - 8 minutes.



6. Arrange on a platter decorated with fresh greenery and place sliced lemons around the dish. Can be served with rice pilaf or oven potatoes, a vegetable and a Caesar or Greek salad.



Serves 4-6.



--The Advocate, July 31, 2008
--------------------------



Greek Orzo Salad with Feta Cheese
(*orzo is rice-shaped pasta)



½ (1 lb) box Orzo, boiled to al dente and drained
1 4 oz. package feta
1 large tomato, diced
1 bunch parsley, chopped (about 1/2 cup) or chopped Watercress
Juice from 1 lemon
1 Tbsp garlic, chopped
1/4 cup olive oil
2 Tbsp White Balsamic Vinegar (optional)
1 can cannellini beans or chick peas, drained and rinsed (optional)



Chill cooked orzo by running it under cool water for a few minutes. Drain well and toss with 2 T olive oil. Toss with diced tomatoes, chopped parsley or watercress, a small amount of the feta, juice of lemon, oil, garlic and the vinegar. Add in beans or peas if desired.  Let chill in the fridge for 1 hour.  Top with more feta before serving.
------------------------



Greek Roasted Potatoes with Garlic, Lemon and Oregano



1 (5-lb.) bag of potatoes, rinsed, peeled and cut into wedges (any type potato works fine)
1/2 cup olive oil
1 (14-oz.) can chicken broth
Juice of 2 lemons (about 1/3 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice)
4-5 cloves garlic, sliced into slivers
1/2 stick butter, cut into small pieces
Dried oregano
Salt and black pepper
Garlic powder
Paprika
Parsley flakes



1. Preheat oven to 425ºF. Spray a 9” x 13”or larger baking dish or pan with nonstick vegetable spray. Place potatoes in pan and toss with olive oil to coat.



2. Add chicken broth. Pour lemon juice evenly over potatoes. Place the slivers of fresh garlic and butter pieces on the potatoes. Sprinkle generously in the order given with dried oregano, salt, black pepper, garlic powder, paprika and parsley flakes.



3. Cover pan with aluminum foil. Oven-roast the potatoes for about 1 hour. Remove foil and gently toss potatoes with a spatula. Test potatoes by piercing them with a fork. Continue to bake until the potatoes are tender, about 15 minutes longer. The potatoes can also be placed under the broiler for 2 to 3 minutes for a golden brown color. Serve at once.



Serves 6-8.



--The Advocate, July 31, 2008



</answer>



<answer from>



scienceq...
Member since: 11 April 2006
Total points: 309 (Level 2)

<answer>



"Greek" is used to describe things/people/cuisine from the nation of Greece. The simplest Greek dish I can think of is tzatziki sauce with toasted pita bread. The tzatziki is plain yogurt, diced cucumbers, a little diced onion, lemon juice, dill, and salt. Should be cool, tangy, and smooth.



</answer>

<answer>



A good and easy food, which can easily either last you a few days or serve many is this:



boil up some pasta



strain off the water, put pasta back in the pan



add soup to the pan - plus any other herbs, etc you may want to add, maybe some of the mushrooms, etc you think may go with it. Heat it through thoroughly, stirring frequently.



If you have cheese, you could then put it all into an oven proof bowl, cover with cheese and whack under the grill for a few minutes to brown the cheese.



Plate up! (or bowl!)



Enjoy.



</answer>

kimmelhe...

<answer>



You could do this recipe - it's actually one of my very favorites and in regular rotation on my menu!!



Pasta With sausage and broccoli



SERVES 6



* 1 lb hot Italian sausage



* 1/2 cup olive oil



* 4 garlic cloves, minced



* 1/2 teaspoon salt



* 1 (16 ounce) package farfalle pasta



* 1 (16 ounce) package frozen broccoli



* 1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese



1. Over medium heat, brown sausage, breaking up with back of spoon as you cook. Drain and set aside.



2. To same pan add olive oil and garlic, saute until light golden.



3. Bring large pot of water to the boil, add salt and pasta and cook for 8-10 minutes or until al dente. 3 minutes before the end of the cooking time, add broccoli; drain pasta and broccoli.



4. In large serving plate, toss together sausage, olive oil with garlic, pasta and broccoli. Add parmesan cheese and toss again lightly before serving.



Enjoy!



</answer>

<answer>



2 cups baby carrots
1 tablespoon toasted sesame seeds
Pinch of dried thyme
Pinch of kosher salt



Toss carrots with sesame seeds, thyme and kosher salt in a small bowl.



1/2 cup low-fat cottage cheese
1/4 teaspoon spice blend, such as Jane’s Krazy Mixed-Up Salt
1/2 cucumber, cut into spears



Sprinkle cottage cheese with spice blend. Dip cucumbers into the cottage cheese.



</answer>

<question>



How to make fried apples?



</question>



<additional details>



If i don't have Nutmeg will it make a BIG difference in the flavor??



</additional details>



<answer from>



Jana B
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 504 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



here is two of my favorites



CRACKER BARRELL FRIED APPLES



1/4 lb. butter
1/2 c. sugar
8 Golden Delicious apples, cut up, unpeeled



Add all ingredients into a covered frying pan. Cook for about 15 minutes or until soft. Add cinnamon and nutmeg to taste. Serve warm. Good over ice cream.



FRIED APPLES



2 eggs
1/2 c. sugar
1 tsp. grated lemon rind
1 1/2 c. flour
1/4 tsp. salt
1/2 tsp. cinnamon
1/4 tsp. nutmeg
1 c. milk
4 apples, peeled and sliced about 1/2 inch thick
Powdered sugar



Beat eggs; add sugar, rind, flour, salt, cinnamon, nutmeg, and milk. Beat until smooth. Cover and let stand 1 hour. Dip apples in batter and deep fry until brown. Sprinkle with powdered sugar.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ira R
Member since: 17 March 2008
Total points: 699 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



slice the apples and peel them. sprinke them with cinnamon, roll them in floure and then sprinkle them with cinnamon again. pour some oil into the skillete and fry until golden brown. let them sit for between 5 and 10 min and then serve.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



step1
Wash the apples, and then peel the skin.
Step2
Slice the peeled apples, and then discard the cores.
Step3
Coat a saucepan with either butter or a healthy cooking spray. Add the sliced apples and sauté over medium heat.
Step4
Add cinnamon as desired.
Step5
Sauté the apples just until tender. Serve warm.



</answer>



<answer from>



C P
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 669 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a similar recipe to my Grandma's.  They are not deep fried in oil but pan fried.  She used Granny Smith if served as side dish for dinner and a sweeter apple (Golden Delicious) for breakfast.



Ingredients:
8 medium Granny Smith apples, chopped
1/4 cup butter
1/2 cup brown sugar
1/2 teaspoon cinnamon
1/8 teaspoon nutmeg
Preparation:
Melt butter in a heavy skillet over medium-low heat. Add apples, brown sugar, cinnamon and nutmeg. Sauté 15 to 20 minutes, or until apples are tender. Serve as a side dish for pork or with breakfast. Serves 6.



</answer>



<answer from>



jenn3516...
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 219 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



APPLES - VIRGINIA FRIED



Wash and core 6 apples and slice 1/4 inch thick.
Put 1/4 cup Mazola cooking oil in frying pan and heat. Add apples and brown lightly. Sprinkle with 1/2 cup granulated or light brown sugar. Cover and cook slowly until apples are tender. Remove cover to let apples brown and cook off excess juice.



A tart apple is best -- such as Rome Beauty, Winesap, Granny Smith.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jeanne
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 1170 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The way I fry apples is to cut the apples in half, remove the core & seeds then slice it (thick or thin - it's up to you.)  Melt some butter in your frying pan (approx. 1 tbsp. per 2 apples) add your apples slices & some brown sugar & nutmeg (optional) and cook until apple slices are tender.  I prefer Granny Smith apples, but any type will do.  Just remember that if the apples are tart you might want to add a bit more sugar if you want them sweeter.  That's a matter of taste.



Hope this helps!  Enjoy!



</answer>

<answer>



Fried Apple Rings --



"Four ingredients and a skillet are all that you'll need for these delightful apple rings that Mary Jane Ruther cooks in her Trenton, New Jersey kitchen. Serve them as a sweet side dish alongside pork...or for dessert."



INGREDIENTS



1 tablespoon butter



1 tablespoon sugar



1 1/2 teaspoons lemon juice



1 medium tart apple, cored



DIRECTIONS
In a skillet, melt butter over medium heat. Stir in sugar and lemon juice. Cut the apple into four rings; add to skillet. Reduce heat. Cover and simmer for 10-15 minutes or until apple rings are tender, turning frequently. Serve warm.



Source(s):



HAPPY COOKING!!!



</answer>

<answer>



Pumpkin Crumb Cake



1 (18.25 ounce) package yellow cake mix



1 egg, beaten



1/2 cup butter, melted



1 (15 ounce) can pumpkin puree



3 eggs, beaten



1/2 cup white sugar



1/4 cup packed brown sugar



1 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon



1/2 cup white sugar



3 tablespoons butter, softened



1/2 cup chopped nuts (optional)



Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Spray or grease one 9x13 inch pan.



Reserve 1 cup cake mix. In a large bowl, combine the remaining dry cake mix with 1 egg and 1/2 cup melted butter. Mix well, and then pat into prepared pan.



In a large bowl, mix together the pumpkin, 3 eggs, 1/2 cup white sugar, brown sugar, and cinnamon. Pour over crust.



In a small bowl, combine reserved 1 cup cake mix, 1/2 cup sugar, and 3 tablespoons softened butter. Crumble over pumpkin filling. Sprinkle nuts evenly over the top, if desired.



Bake in preheated oven for 40 to 45 minutes.



</answer>



<answer from>



saratha m
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 1140 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients



* for crust-



* yellow cake mix (18 1/4 oz box) prefer Duncan Hines



* 1 stick of melted butter (8 tbsp)



* 1 egg



* for cake-



* cream cheese (8oz package) softened



* can of pumkin (15 oz)



* 3 eggs



* 2 tsp vanilla



* 1 stick melted butter



* powdered sugar (16 oz box)



* 2 tsp cinnamon



* 2 tsp nutmeg



Directions



1. preheat oven to 350 degrees F



2. for crust- in large mixing bowl add cake mix,



3. 1 stick melted butter, and 1 egg



4. beat with mixer until moist (will be clumpy)



5. grease13x9 baking dish (or pan)



6. finger crust onto bottom of dish



7. now for the gooey part



8. in same mixing bowl you used , you don't need to wash it



9. add softend cream cheese



10. powdered sugar



11. 3 eggs beat on med-hi slowly adding 1 stick of melted butter



12. add vanilla



13. add pumpkin



14. mix together



15. add cinnamon and nutmeg



16. pour onto crust and bake approx. 45 min



17. crust will bown and pumpkin will firm around the outside



18. don't insert toothpick, it's not gonna come out clean, even when it's done



19. remember it's a gooey cake, I forgot that the second time I made it and I overcooked a bit, it was still good but not so much a gooey cake



20. enjoy!!



</answer>



<answer from>



cin2win
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 24712 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Ingredients
Cake:
1 (18 1/4-ounce) package yellow cake mix



1 egg



8 tablespoons butter, melted



Filling:
1 (8-ounce) package cream cheese, softened



1 (15-ounce) can pumpkin



3 eggs



1 teaspoon vanilla



8 tablespoons butter, melted



1 (16-ounce) box powdered sugar



1 teaspoon cinnamon



1 teaspoon nutmeg



Directions
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.



Combine the cake mix, egg, and butter and mix well with an electric mixer. Pat the mixture into the bottom of a lightly greased 13 by 9-inch baking pan.



To make the filling: In a large bowl, beat the cream cheese and pumpkin until smooth. Add the eggs, vanilla, and butter, and beat together. Next, add the powdered sugar, cinnamon, nutmeg, and mix well. Spread pumpkin mixture over cake batter and bake for 40 to 50 minutes. Make sure not to overbake as the center should be a little gooey.



Serve with fresh whipped cream.



Variations: For a Pineapple Gooey Cake: Instead of the pumpkin, add a drained 20-ounce can of crushed pineapple to the cream cheese filling. Proceed as directed above.



For a Banana Gooey Cake: Prepare cream cheese filling as directed, beating in 2 ripe bananas instead of the pumpkin. Proceed as directed above.



For a Peanut Butter Gooey Cake: Use a chocolate cake mix. Add 1 cup creamy peanut butter to the cream cheese filling instead of the pumpkin. Proceed as directed above



</answer>

<question from>



jj

</question from>



<question>



Does anyone know a recipe for a traditional british hotpot?



</question>



<additional details>



thank you jonno will give it a try with out the jalepenos me thinks as have 2 kids and they would not appreciate lol yum.



</additional details>



<answer from>



JOHNO
Member since: 31 March 2008
Total points: 661 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Lancashire Hot Pot



SERVES 8 (change servings and units)



Ingredients



8 lamb chops, about 2 . 5 cm thick
4 lambs kidneys, cut into quarters, cores removed
1/4 cup plain flour
50 g butter
4 potatoes, thinly sliced
2 large onions, sliced
1 large carrot, chopped
1 3/4 cups beef stock or vegetable stock
2 teaspoons chopped fresh thyme
1 bay leaf
30 g butter, melted
1 large jalapeno pepper, seeded and finely chopped (optional)



Directions



1 Preheat the oven to 315f degrees.
2 Brush a 4 litre overproof casserole with melted butter or oil.
3 Trim the meat of excess fat and sinew.
4 Coat the chops and kidneys with seasoned flour shaking off and reserving any excess.
5 Heat the butter in a large frying pan and brown the chops quickly on both sides.
6 Remove the chops from the pan and set aside, then cook the kidneys until browned.
7 Layer half the potato slices into the base of the casserole, then top with the chops and the kidneys.
8 Add the onion,pepper, if using and carrot to the frying pan and cook until the carrot begins to brown.
9 Layer on top of the chops and kidneys.
10 Sprinkle the reserved flour over the base of the pan and cook, stirring, until dark brown.
11 Gradually pour in the stock and bring to the boil, stirring.
12 Season well with salt and cracked black pepper, and add the thyme and bay leaf.
13 Reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes, then pour the mixture into the casserole.
14 Layer the remaining potato over the top, covering the meat and veggies.
15 Cover and cook in the oven for 1 1/4 hours.
16 Remove the lid, brush the potato with butter and cook for a further 30 minutes, or until the potato is brown.



I know this seems long winded but you will end up with an awesome and very traditional Lancashire Hot Pot



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

Twig Step

<answer>



For your traditional british recipes you can't beat good old delia:



http://www.deliaonline.com/recipes/tradi...



This recipe uses lamb kidneys and lamb best end and neck, however when I make it I just use whichever cut of lamb I can find (normally leg) and leave the kidneys out.  Also I like to add carrots to the cassserole below the potatoes.  Tried & tested - this recipe makes a nice juicy hotpot.



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



Does Avesil Work? It Looks Very Fishy To Me?



</question>



<answer from>



Janie S
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Despite these facts, there is no doubt that Avesil contains some good ingredients: Super Citrimax, Chromium, Green Tea extract and caffeine. These ingredients work together to increase the fat burning effect in the body, releasing stored fat, boosting energy and decreasing the appetite. The website provides the results of clinical trials performed on the ingredients and showed that Avesil is three times more effective in weight loss than by just diet and exercise alone (although the manufacturers do recommend a healthy, active lifestyle).
While Avesil does appear to be a promising product, it is too soon to say how successful it actually proves to be and, not knowing the exact amounts of the ingredients in the formula, makes it hard to judge adequately. It is hard to evaluate if there is enough of any of the ingredients to be effective as a weight loss supplement. The secrecy surrounding the ingredients is not an indication of the ability of this product to deliver the desired results but is a cause for concern. Finally, it is likely that the price will be off-putting at a cost of $89.95 per month. The consumer can take advantage of a free trial offer but should be aware that if not cancelled promptly, they may be signed up for the auto-ship program which can itself be hard to cancel.



If you do shop for a weight loss product in a health store, pharmacy or on the Internet, you'll often find hundreds of different brands containing a confusing array of ingredients. You may be tempted to experiment with different diet aids until you find one that works. But this approach may be expensive. Jennifer Berniello, a respected nutritional writer from Health News Minute did a fantastic review on diet pills and their actual effectiveness in a recent feature, the results are quite surprising.



Click on link to read her review:
http://healthnewsminute.com/weightlosspr...



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

<answer from>



amanda g
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 6635 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I love to buy a big cheaper cut of meat and make soup or stews with it. you can use any roast and just chunk it up and brown it then let it cool and put it in freezer bags in soup pot sized portions. I also make a lot of soups with beans or barley to stretch out the meat to save money.



If I am making a cream soup I will use non-dairy powdered coffee creamer to thicken the soup.



A big pot of pasta sauce with just a little meat and a lot of veg added will go quite far and freezes well for a quick meal later.



Source(s):



family of 5 on a budget



</answer>



<answer from>



Recipe4L...

You can always buy a lot meat (i.e. ground beef, steak, chicken, pork) and freeze it to cook later.

and more...

<answer>

1 pd hamburger
1 onion cut up
1 green pepper cut up
1 large can of tomato sauce
velvetta cheese or any cheese you like



cook mac
cook hamburger , onion, green pepper ,,salt and pepper



drain hamburger mixture
add to cooked mac
add tomato sauce
in casserole dish layer ,,,then add cheese to cover layer,,,repeat until top layer is cheese



bake 375 for approx 45 minutes or until the desired browness on top



serve with a french bread and salad

<question>



I tasted asparagus for the first time last week. ?



I really liked it and I was wondering if I got some from the supermarket how to prepare it at home? Where is the best place to get it? I had it at Papadeux so it was seasoned very well, I want it to taste that way. It was so good!!!



</question>



<additional details>



ur right tfoley50 I had it with salmon and it was good!!!!!



</additional details>



<answer from>



rockon
Member since: 30 June 2006
Total points: 1201 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



you can grill it over an open flame or put saute it in a pan. toss it the asparagus in olive oil, salt, pepper, and garlic powder. fresh minced garlic would be better. then just throw it on the grill/pan with butter and cook until tender.



oh yeah, dont over cook it until it they are limp, you still want a little bit of a snap



Source(s):



I have been a restaurant cook for 7 years and thats usually how it is prepared.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Master of My Own Remote Control!
Member since: 10 January 2007
Total points: 1690 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Roasting it in the oven is my favorite, as well as grilled.  For roasting, lightly coat with good olive oil (a Misto is perfect to apply if you have one), and put in a 425 degree oven for about 15-25 minutes (don't over bake ~ crunch is good).  I sometimes also like to add quartered zucchini, thickly sliced red onions, bell peppers, whole cherry tomatoes, a few sprigs of your favorite herb (Rosemary loves everything in my house!), and garlic.  Make sure to turn about every 5 minutes after the first 10 minutes of baking time, and watch carefully towards the end.



If just doing asparagus, I also love it topped with provolone/parmesan cheese browned under the broiler after it has been roasted (make sure to cover the entire spear with cheese so they do not burn).



On the grill, coat it lightly with olive oil as above, and make sure to keep turning every minute or so (depending upon how hot your grill is).  When I do a veggie mix, as above, I skewer them, and just pay attention that they do not burn.



Source(s):



Veggie lover ;)



</answer>



<answer from>



hardyone...
Member since: 18 August 2007
Total points: 383 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi,
when you are buying asparagus make sure you buy the skinny female asparagus. The fat (male) asparagus is not as tasty as the skinny asparagus.  To cook it you just need to steam it.  Place asparagus in a bowl or pot placed over a pot with water in it.  You should steam it for 3 - 4 minutes only. You want it firm not limp.  If you over steam it, it will be yucky. You can add garlic and salt to the water, so that the steam flavours the asparagus.  Also you can cover it with garlic butter, or regular butter and sliced almonds. YUMMMMM



</answer>



<answer from>



tfoley50...
Member since: 01 September 2006
Total points: 59100 (Level 7)

<answer>



Well to start off Good for you now you are showing better taste in Food and Two Asparagus would go great with Salmon, Grilled Chicken or Grilled Steak over Risotto and you'll have a Dinner that better then any 5 Star Restaurant can dish out, I'm proud of you show some Class while Cooking, Now find a Day to cook Risotto with Chicken or Salmon or Steak and Asparagus has  better Meaning.



I'll give you the recipe so you can cook something Good for yourself



Risotto Recipe



1 Cup of Arborio Rice
2 TBSP of Butter
1/2 Chopped Onion
1 TSP Salt
1/2 of Distilled White Vinegar
1 Finely Chopped Garlic
3 Cups of Chicken Broth
2/3 Cup of Parmesan Cheese
1 TBSP of Black Pepper



In Heavy Saucepan Saute Rice in 1 TBSP of Butter, Add Onion, Garlic, Salt, Saute Until Tender, add 1 Cup of Vinegar, saute until Absorb, 1 Cup of Stir Consistently, as the Liquid Cooks down, add the 2 cups of Remaining Broth, until the Mixture is Creamy, Put in the Cheese, Pepper and Remaining Butter stir in and Enjoy.



</answer>

<question>



How do you fry sausages?



Do you use oil, or something else?
How long will it take?
How hot should the pan be?



Thanks... I am just starting out cooking and I don't want to undercook them and risk food poisoning!



</question>



<answer from>



brettc27...
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)

normal cooking oil



at least 6 mins

<answer>



Heat some oil in to a frying pan.  Leave it for 10 minutes - then place you hand into the oil to see if it is warm.



If so, throw in the sausages.



</answer>



<answer from>



chad c
Member since: 09 May 2007

<answer>



it depends on what type of sausage you're talking about. some sausages are already cooked. i prefer to poach my brats in beer and spices first then finish on the grill. breakfast sausages have enough fat in them already, so you don't need to add any oil to the pan. just cook them over medium heat.



</answer>



<answer from>



MacXe
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 14593 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Software



</answer from>



<answer>



Use vegetable oil (or any oil you want)



Pan fry or deep fry? If it's pan fried, it'll take 8 minutes. If you deep fry, it'll probably take a few minutes lesser. The instructions are probably written on the packaging.



How hot? I'd say turn the heat up 3/4's of the way (medium tto high heat). You don't want to burn the outside. Cook it slowly until the center of sausage turns brown (no pink bits).



</answer>



<answer from>



John N
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Little olive oil/vegetable oil in a frying pan on a low heat.  Put in the sausages and cover with a lid.  You must turn frequently to avoid burning, replacing the lid each time (allows the sausages to cook in the middle and keep the hot oil in the pan and not all over the cooker!).  Total cooking time around 15-20 mins.



</answer>

I don't use oil, but I use a non-stick (teflon) pan.

<answer from>



beth m
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I usually put a very small amount of oil (1 tsp) in the frying pan.  This will help the sausages to not stick at the beginning of cooking.  Sausages are typically fatty, so they will release some grease as they cook.  They burner should be set at medium or medium low... if the pan's too hot, the outsides of the sausages will burn before the middles are cooked.  Cooking time depends on the type of sausage... are these small breakfast sausages or big italian sausages, for example.  Breakfast sausages - about 10 minutes, but cut one open and check.  Italian sausage - at least 20 minutes, again cut one open and check.  Hope this helps!  Cooking is fun!



</answer>



<answer from>



David R
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 2790 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



Other - Food & Drink



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the kind of sausage you're cooking.  If you're doing breakfast links (brown and serve), you don't need oil and only a few minutes in a medium heat pan to warm them through.



If you're cooking raw breakfast links (like Jimmy Dean), I use 1 tsp of olive oil and cook over medium heat for about 8 minutes or so, until the center of the sausage is no longer pink.



If you're taking about sausages like bratwurst (raw), I thaw them (if they're frozen), then simmer them in water or stock for about 8-9 minutes.  Then, remove from the liquid and grill for a few minutes to impart nice-looking grill marks on them.  If pan frying, use medium heat and cook (after simmering) until they get a good color on the casing.



If you're cooking pre-cooked sausage, like kielbasa, sometimes I cook it whole, other times I slice before cooking.  Again, I use 1 tsp of olive oil and cook over medium heat until the sausage gets a nice "crust" around the sliced edges.



Hope this helps.



Dave



</answer>



<answer from>



dragon_r...

Total points: 147 (Level 1)

<answer>



For the pre-cooked ones, I like to cook mine in a little bit of water over medium heat (about a cup of water in a standard frying pan).  The water keeps them moist while the middle warms up, and by the time the water cooks out, the sausages or brats are ready to brown on the outside.  I brown them and serve them up.  Yummy :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 288 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Put a small amount of oil into the pan (around 1-2 teaspoons) as the sausages will give out some fat. Heat the pan, until the oil runs easily around it and keep it onto a medium heat



2. How long you fry them for depends on their size, but typically around 20 minutes, turn 3 or 4 times



You'll find more information on cooking techniques etc. at this site



http://www.sausagelinks.co.uk/recipe_coo...



Personally, I prefer to cook them in the oven



1. Heat oven to Gas 6, 200C



2. Put the sausages onto a baking tray or rack in a roasting tin



3. Cook for 15 minutes, then turn



4. Cook for a further 15 minutes



</answer>



<answer from>



charliea...
Member since: 19 February 2006
Total points: 15686 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I never add oil when cooking sausage since they have enough of their own.  to make sure they are cooked



ht rough, I put the sausage in a pan with about1/2 inch of water in the bottom.  Place the cover on, and cook on high boil for 5 minutes.  Then remove the cover, let the water evaporate, and brown the sausage in the pan with the burner still on high.  The result will be well cooked, juicy, and browned sausage



Source(s):



through



</answer>



<answer from>



Beautiful -
Member since: 17 December 2005
Total points: 14023 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can cook them in many ways



and all the cooking instructions are on the sausage



because of the amount of fat content in a sausage, i tend not to use oil
i put the sausages into a cold pan and leave it to heat up on the low heat (if you fry without oil and heat the pan up first, it will stick and burn too easily)
once the pan starts to heat you will notice it getting more oily.. this is the fat in the sausage burning out
once the pan starts to get more oily .. you can then turn up the heat, cover with a lid



you keep turning the sausage so that each side turns browns



you can prick holes into the sausage so that you are certain it cooks inn the inside



the best way to cook is by oven or grill
when grilling you need to be constantly checking it because it will burn
you place your sauages on to an oven pan and put it under a low heat grill with no oil .. you continue to turn until all sides are brown



when ovening you cook it for 20+min's .. and when its down , it does look uncooked



</answer>

<question from>



daisy
Member since: 01 October 2007
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do I make a packet...?



of tasteless corn chips tortilla a bit more tasteful. i tried adding onion salt but it keeps falling off. Any idea on how to make it stick to the chips?



</question>



<answer from>



Delia .
Member since: 01 January 2007
Total points: 716 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Flavor salts or herbs need something to stick to.  You need to lightly spray on a liquid and then toss chips with the salt/herb mix while the chips are still moist.  Pop into a pre-heated 300 degree oven for 10 min. to crisp dry before serving or storing.



Spray suggestions are:



spray butter (refrigerator section of your market);



spray baking oil, some are flavored or olive oil based (in the baking section or near the oils in your market);
lo cal spray salad dressing -- comes in different flavors -- you might not need the flavor salts or herbs with these



OR Make Nachos!



spread chips on a baking sheet, top with olives, cheese, salsa, or whatever you like; bake till cheese melts; then put a dab of sour cream and/or guacamole on top.  You can mound the chips or spread them out so most get some of the salsa and cheese.



</answer>



<answer from>



JackHole...
Member since: 04 May 2008
Total points: 6149 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Homework Help



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



Get something to dip the chips in.



IE&gt;  salsa or spinach dip



</answer>

<question>



Is there a difference between jello and gelatin?



are they made the same way?



</question>



<answer from>



lolomgwt...
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 218 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



mamachan
Member since: 31 October 2008

</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



shells
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 250 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe they are the same thing.  Jello is more of a brand name, gelatin is usually what is written on the packaging of the generic stuff.  Just like Band-Aids and bandages.



</answer>



<answer from>



CONFIDAN...
Member since: 16 June 2006

</answer>



<answer from>



RoxiesMo...

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



FRESA
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 445 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



jello is a brand; well gelatin is any brand. i think they have the same ingredients, but you may prepare one a little different than the other.



</answer>



<answer from>



Yogesh G
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 3524 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Gelatin is made by boiling bones connective tissue skin and hooves. Then it is filtered processed and dried to make Gelatin.



Jello is made in a similar fashion. After the liquid is filtered, food flavors, sugar and anti-caking chemicals are added. The liquid is dehydrated forming crystals. Jello also is the brand name.



In a way Jello is a flavored sweetened Gelatin with starches and anti-caking agents.



</answer>



<answer from>



Horseback Barbie
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 535 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Jello is flavored gelatin. If you just buy gelatin it will be unflavored...it is used to "set" things.



Jello is a trademark, it is made with gelatin and flavoring.



</answer>

<question from>



Ryn
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 345 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



I need help making cocktail smokies using a crock pot?



I have bbq sauce, the smokies, and a crock pot.  I have never used the crock pot before so I was wondering how to make the smokies. Thank you. :)



</question>



<additional details>



So far everything ya'll are saying sounds good.  Um I'm not making too much, really just enough for me and my boyfriend.  I don't have jelly on hand and don't have time to stop at the grocery store today.  Oh and does anyone know how long it takes for these to heat up, I mean can I leave them on the warm setting for like 2 hours???  Thanks.  Happy Halloween!



</additional details>



<answer from>



rowlfe
Member since: 30 July 2006
Total points: 27676 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



OK, the little smokies are already cooked, so all you are doing is making the sauce. I use some canned spaghetti sauce and add some mushrooms and BBQ sauce and A-1 steak sauce and some crushed garlic and heat until it perks, gets bubbles, which means the sauce is cooked. Then, simply turn the crock pot down to the lowest setting to keep things warm for serving. I LOVE sticking little smokies with a toothpick...



</answer>



<answer from>



Master of My Own Remote Control!
Member since: 10 January 2007
Total points: 1694 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



Main thing to remember is that you should fill your crock at least half full to achieve proper cooking (read the instruction manual if you have it).



I make these for Superbowl, but my recipe is one bottle of Chili Sauce, half jar of grape jelly (I know, sounds strange!), and weenies.  I cook mine on low for about 1-1/2 hours to 2 hours, stirring about every 15 minutes after the first 30 minutes of cooking time.  If your crock has a "warm" setting, that is what I would put it on after they are perfect in temperature.  But again, it depends upon how large your crock is, and how large of a batch you are making.



If you can post more info, I would be happy to help with more exact times.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mickey
Member since: 13 April 2007
Total points: 696 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<question>



Help my mushrooms,asap?



Sorry about the title, that stupid 20 character minumum thing.Anyway I bought some mushrooms last week and used a few.I saved a few for this week and I was going to use them today.They look a little wrinkly though.Are they ok to eat?Should I be concerned at all?I really hope they are ok to eat I really wanted to eat them.Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



marlie girl 13
Member since: 23 August 2008
Total points: 275 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



they should be fine try smelling them if they smell funky then dont eat them did you put them in fridge as soon as you where done with them or no cuz if you left them out for over 1 hour stay safe and dont eat them but if you think they are fine go ahead and eat them did you properly seal the package or did you leave them unsealed you should be able to tell by what i said



</answer>



<asker's comment>



i used them and i feel fine i just cut off any part that looked really brown and i think its ok



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Vbonics
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 6972 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah they're probably fine.  Mushrooms contain a lot of water so having them sitting in your fridge probably took some of the moisture out...hence the wrinkly appearance.



</answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



not so--Unfaithful Chica!
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 3698 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



cover your cake in white icing then out on some slighty watery icing ((more watery than normal)) and pour it in a line down the cake, with a toohpick, zig-zag it back & forwardss to get the cool effect

<question>



What should I do if I don't have a non stick baking sheet?



I'm baking something in the oven and I dont have a non stick sheet. I don't want what Im baking to stick. What can I use.



</question>



<answer from>



daisy
Member since: 01 October 2007
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can use baking paper. Its like wax paper so food doesn't stick when you bake it.



</answer>



<answer from>



nadia g
Member since: 18 August 2007
Total points: 1883 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just make sure you oil the tray very well.  Apart from that, I don't think there are many other options.  Enjoy whatever you're baking:)



</answer>



<answer from>



Charlie F
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 496 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



just get some kitchen roll, dab some butter on it and wipe the dish with it, this stops is from sticking :)
x



</answer>



<answer from>



Delia .
Member since: 01 January 2007
Total points: 718 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ok Methods
1.  Baking spray - like Pam -- in the market in baking section (flour,sugar,spices)
2.  Waxed Paper - old method, not always the best
3.  Parchment paper, oiled or wiped with Crisco shortening



Best Methods
4.  *Reynolds Release Aluminum Foil -- Works very well for me -- use the correct side up, it is marked.
5.  Silicone baking mat like Sil-Pat -- washable, reusable, larger ones can be cut to size. Fairly expensive, but good for a long, long time.



Source(s):



Long time cooking...



</answer>



<answer from>



JackHole...
Member since: 04 May 2008
Total points: 6149 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Homework Help



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



Oil, margarine, butter, or a spray release (Pam).



</answer>



<answer from>



marvelgi...
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can buy those silicon baking sheet anywhere, but since you dont have one you can just spray cooking spray on the baking tin. Greasing the tin with butter helps too. Or just put the thing you wanna bake on a aluminum foil (if you have)



</answer>



<answer from>



happy_fa...
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 710 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



grease the pan with butter



</answer>



<answer from>



ckngbbbl...
Member since: 12 December 2007
Total points: 11498 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



people been baking for longer than there are non stick sheets.  Not everything you bake needs to be on a greased pan.  what does your recipe reccomend?  For a cake or pan bars, I would grease the sheet pan and then flour it generously.  For cookies that need a greased sheet, grease it.  If they don't need a greased cookie sheet, don't grease it.



</answer>



<answer from>



celzhang
Member since: 24 February 2008
Total points: 443 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Fi Be
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 376 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Use baking paper (also called baking parchment) to line the dish.
Or get butter on a kitchen towel and rub it into the sides, bottom and corners of the dish then sprinkle flour on it (put in about a tablespoon of flour and roll right round the dish then throw out the excess).



</answer>

<question>



Do bread bins make bread last longer and keep the bread fresh?



Always wondered if bread bins would help make your bread last young? and what is he best way to keep bread fresh for longer?



</question>



<answer from>



Fi Be
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 386 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bread bins keep bread fresher than exposed completely but the best way to keep bread is to freeze it and take it out the freezer a few hours before you need it.



</answer>



<answer from>



M H
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 110 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



the best way to have good fresh bread is to buy smaller loaves more often and give any old bread to the birds.



</answer>

<question>



What is your favorite chocolate recipe?



I mean something chocolate related eg. chocolate cake, chocolate truffles etc.



</question>



<additional details>



Dongdolin - I meant I wanted the RECIPE for it so that I can try it.



</additional details>



<answer from>



dongdoli...
Member since: 02 July 2008
Total points: 982 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Chocolate torte. Deliciously chocolaty. I highly recommend it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cazz ;)
Member since: 31 December 2007
Total points: 3305 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Malteser Cake
To make it you will need:
100g margarine



6 tbsps syrup



250g cooking chocolate



200g crushed digestive biscuits



200g crushed malteasers
Melt margarine and syrup and chocolate over heat. When it's all melted, take off the heat and add crushed biscuits and "Malteasers", mix really well. Spread into a lined greased swiss roll tin. Chill in the fridge then cut up into small squares. Keep refridgerated.



This can also be frozen.



</answer>



<answer from>



Master of My Own Remote Control!
Member since: 10 January 2007
Total points: 1698 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Cooking & Recipes



</answer from>



<answer>



I am a total scratch cook, but also do not fancy sweets (chilehead!).  Therefore, when I needed a sweet treat for a party, I called my sister for a recipe, and this is what I made.  It was the bomb, super easy, and I have made it several times since with rave reviews.



KAHLUA CAKE



Cake:



1 package yellow cake mix
1 package (4 cups) chocolate instant pudding mix (unprepared)
1 cup vegetable oil
4 eggs
1/2 cup Kahlua
1/2 cup water
1-1/2 cups chocolate chips



Mix all ingredients and pour into a bundt pan.  Bake at 325 for 45-55 minutes.



Icing:



1 cup powdered sugar
1-3 tablespoons Kahlua



Mix with a little water if you want to go easier on the Kahlua (not in my house!), and drizzle on cooled cake.  You want a thick consistency.



YUMMMMMY!!!



Source(s):



My Beautiful Sister ;)



</answer>



<answer from>



Fi Be
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 386 (Level 2)



</answer from>

</answer>

mel p

<question from>



juRiE .
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Basic terms in baking.. ?



helo, does anyone knows what are the meaning of these terms used in baking.
-roll-up
-toss
-ferment
-punch
-rest
-proof
-grease-line-grease
-flour



thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



ALISON H
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 1592 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Roll up - roll up pastry
Toss - toss a pancake
Ferment - yeast rising in bread or in wine
Punch - fruit cocktail
Rest - let pastry rest before rolling out
Prove - let bread rise
Grease line - grease the grease proof paper when lining a cake tin
Flour - dredge the pastry with flour



</answer>



<answer from>



Nane
Member since: 13 February 2007
Total points: 1484 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



These terms are as the answerer above described but I believe they are all being used together to describe the yeast bread making process(es) so i think "roll up" is being used to describe a form of bread roll, and "punch" is being used to describe the way a the  first rising of a dough creates a lot of air and some of it has to be knocked out of it by lightly punching it out.



Source(s):



http://artisanbreads.net/



</answer>

<question from>



Mac S
Member since: 29 December 2007
Total points: 5564 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



Why are bagels never sliced all the way through?



</question>



<answer from>



ALISON H
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 1624 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



So that they remain fresh. If they were cut all the way through they would go stale more quickly.



</answer>



<answer from>



Eric S
Member since: 31 August 2007
Total points: 6606 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You mean the ones in packages? It's to keep the halves together so they're easier to pack. Same thing with hamburger buns.



</answer>



<answer from>



Brenda A
Member since: 12 December 2006
Total points: 622 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a packaging thing. If they were sliced through, it would be harder to keep them neat and tidy. There would be 1/2 bagels falling all over the place. I used to work for a bagel shop, and our machine still left a little slice still attached for that very reason.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cheesema...
Member since: 01 March 2006
Total points: 6092 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



my bagels are never cut i buy mine from a bakery so i know they are fresh buy a name brand and who knows how long ago them were made



</answer>

<question from>



Dercio J
Member since: 24 July 2006
Total points: 89 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is credit crunch?



</question>



<answer from>



SLOANEY BABYY
